prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
ECHOES OF VERACITY

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But your whispers compete with the clamor of convenience.
In this cacophony of curated realities,
I strain to hear your unadorned voice.

You hide in plain silence,
In the spaces between practiced phrases,
In the hesitation before the comfortable lie.

If I listen closely,
Will my tongue remember your taste?
Will my lips recall your shape?

I have spent years in conversations
Where you were uninvited,
Yet somehow present—
A ghost at every table,
A witness to our elaborate evasions.

Truth! I shall speak you
Only if I recognize your face
In the mirror of my own listening.

THE RECIPROCITY OF TRUTH

Truth demands an audience before it becomes speech.
It waits in patient silence, testing our attention
Like a shy forest creature assessing our stillness.

I have tried to speak you, Truth,
With ears plugged by certainty,
With mind cluttered by convenient narratives—
My words emerged hollow, echoing only myself.

You are not summoned by intention alone.
You are earned through the discipline of reception,
Through the humility of empty hands,
Through the courage of abandoned assumptions.

I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you—
This is our sacred contract.
You will fill my mouth with authenticity
Only when my ears have proven worthy vessels.

So I practice the art of listening,
Of becoming a tuning fork for your frequency,
Of training my heart to recognize your vibration.

TRUTH AS LOVER

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
but we've grown distant, haven't we?

Remember when we first met—
how I would sit for hours absorbing your voice,
how your clarity burned away my comfortable illusions,
how I couldn't wait to introduce you to everyone I knew?

Now I scroll past you,
silence notifications of your arrival,
prefer the company of those who never mention your name.

Yet in the hollow hours between midnight and dawn,
your absence aches like phantom limbs.
I miss the weight of you on my tongue,
the way you made my voice recognized, even to myself.

Perhaps we could start again—
I'll clear space in the cluttered rooms of my perception.
I'll learn again to listen before I speak.
I'll reacquaint my voice with the shape of you.

Truth, I'm ready to hear you now.

APPRENTICESHIP

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But listening is a craft I barely understand.

The master listens with her whole body—
Ears attuned to what trembles beneath words,
Skin sensitive to the currents of concealment,
Eyes that read the text written in hesitations.

I am but an apprentice,
Still distracted by the noise of my own making,
Still believing I can speak what I have not heard,
Still mistaking echoes for revelations.

So I practice:
Sitting with discomfort without reaching for distraction.
Holding contradictions without rushing to resolve them.
Witnessing pain without turning away.
Emptying myself of rehearsed responses.

Perhaps one day, after ten thousand hours
Of this disciplined reception,
My speaking will become worthy
Of what truth has whispered to me all along.

TRUTH GEOGRAPHY

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But the map to your dwelling place is written in vanishing ink.

They say you live in the mountains of objective reality,
Or perhaps in the forests of consensus,
Or maybe in the underground caves of personal authenticity.

I have searched for you with instruments of logic,
With compasses of intuition,
With flashlights of evidence and scrutiny.

Sometimes I glimpse you in unexpected terrains—
In the desert of doubt where certainty dies of thirst,
In the tidal zones where opposing currents meet,
In the fault lines between what I believe and what I observe.

Perhaps you are not a destination but a practice,
Not a territory but a way of traveling,
Not something to possess but something to attune to.

So I listen—with ears, eyes, heart, and history—
And only then do I dare to speak your name.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
THE LISTENER'S VOW

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But first I must learn to quiet the clamor of my pride,
To still the trembling of my fear-filled hands,
To open the chambers of my heart where you've been denied.

How often have I drowned your whispers
With the noise of what I wished to hear instead?
How often have I turned away from mirrors
That showed the self I've left unfed?

I promise now to bend my ear to silence,
To seek you in the spaces between thought,
To welcome you, however sharp your edges,
However much unraveling you've brought.

For what good is a mouth that speaks
If not to give voice to what the soul has heard?
Truth! I shall speak you, but only when
I've learned to listen first to every word.

TRUTH CYCLES

Truth cascades like mountain water,
I cup my hands to catch what I can,
What I hear shapes what I say,
What I say becomes what others hear.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But the world is loud with convenient lies,
With comfortable distortions that fit like old clothes,
With stories we tell to survive the night.

Sometimes I press my ear to the ground
To hear the rumble of what's real beneath the surface.
Sometimes I climb high trees to catch truth
As it rides on winds above human interference.

I am learning that to speak truth
Is to first become a vessel for receiving it,
To be hollow enough, humble enough, hungry enough
To let it enter, to let it change me, to let it leave through my voice transformed.

THE TRUTH-SPEAKER'S PARADOX

We who claim to speak the truth—
What arrogance this is!
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But am I? Do I truly listen?

Or do I hear only echoes of my own voice
Bouncing back from the walls of my convictions?
Do I mistake the sound of my desires
For the clear bell of reality ringing?

To speak truth requires first
A mouth sewn shut, ears stretched wide,
A mind emptied of its treasured certainties,
A heart willing to be reformed by what enters.

Perhaps truth is not a possession to be spoken
But a river that speaks through us
When we finally stop thrashing
And learn instead to float upon its current.

DIALOGUE WITH TRUTH

Truth says: Look at me.
I say: I am afraid.
Truth says: Look anyway.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But your voice comes in forms I don't expect—
In the silence after arguments,
In the space between heartbeats,
In the eyes of strangers who see through me.

Truth says: Repeat what I've told you.
I say: But they might not understand.
Truth says: That is not your concern.

I am learning that truth-speaking
Is not about perfect articulation
But faithful transmission—
To pass along what has been received,
Undiluted by fear, uncolored by agenda.

Truth says: Now speak.
And having listened, what choice do I have?

TRUTH'S APPRENTICE

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But listening is a craft I'm still learning,
Like a child pressing seashells to ear,
Mistaking blood rush for ocean's roar.

I've spoken falsely thinking it was you—
Called mountains out of molehills,
Mistaken reflections for the sky itself,
Claimed certainty where questions should live.

Now I approach you differently:
Knees bent, palms open, breath slowed.
I've learned that truth arrives not as thunder
But as the subtle shift of light before dawn.

I am apprenticed to silence first,
To the patient art of witnessing what is.
Once I've held your weight within me,
Then, only then, might my tongue be trusted with your name.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
LISTENING FOR TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how does one listen to what cannot be heard?
You whisper in the spaces between heartbeats,
Hide in the shadows cast by artificial light.

I have trained my ears to detect your frequency—
That vibration beneath the noise of convenient lies,
The resonance that rings when pretense shatters.

Sometimes I catch glimpses of you
In a child's unfiltered question,
In the eyes of those with nothing left to lose,
In my own reflection when I dare to look.

If I listen long enough,
Will my tongue remember how to form you?
Will my voice carry your weight without trembling?

I promise to be your student before your messenger,
To cultivate the silence where you grow,
To speak you only after I have learned
How to hear you first.

THE TRUTHSPEAKER'S COVENANT

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But we've grown estranged in these distracting times.
The world spins faster, drowning your whispers
In the cacophony of convenient falsities.

I once stood on mountaintops, proclaiming
What I believed was you—but it was merely
Echoes of echoes, reflections of reflections,
A truth diluted by my own desires.

Now I understand: to speak you requires
First the humility to hear you.
To cup my hands around the flickering flame
Of what is, not what I wish to be.

So I make this covenant with you—
I will listen in the stillness before dawn,
In uncomfortable silences, in opposing views,
In data that challenges my cherished beliefs.

Only then, tempered by your uncompromising fire,
Will I dare to let you pass through my lips.

TRUTH UNEARTHED

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Yet for years I've packed soil around my ears,
Buried your seeds beneath layers of comfort,
Denied the green shoots their rightful sunlight.

How strange to discover you growing anyway—
Roots cracking the foundation I built,
Vines climbing the walls of my certainty,
Flowers blooming in colors I never approved.

The garden of my mind, once neatly arranged,
Now wild with your persistent vegetation.
What choice do I have but to become
A reluctant gardener of your untamed growth?

I listen now as wind rustles your leaves,
As rain drums messages on your petals,
As bees buzz between your contradictions.

And when my mouth opens, it is not I who speaks,
But the harvest of what you've planted in me,
Fruits I neither planted nor can claim as mine.

DEFIANCE OF SILENCE

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But they've criminalized our conversation.
They build walls to muffle your voice,
Construct labyrinths to separate us,
Manufacture noise to drown you out.

Still, I press my ear to the ground,
Feel your seismic rumbles beneath
The concrete of convenient narratives.
I catch your reflection in puddles
After storms of disinformation.

They may cut out my tongue,
But having heard you once,
I will scratch you into walls,
Tap you in code against prison bars,
Blink you in morse through darkness.

For those who listen for you
Become your sanctuary,
And those who shelter you
Cannot help but speak you—
Even when speech itself becomes rebellion.

PARADOX OF VERITY

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Yet in listening, I discover your multiplicity.
You are not one voice but many—
A chorus of perspectives, each singing their partial melody.

How then shall I speak you?
As the fisherman speaks of the sea—
Knowing he has touched only its surface,
Yet feeling its depths within his bones?

Perhaps truth is not something to capture
But a practice of attention,
A commitment to remain open
To what I cannot fully comprehend.

I listen to the spaces between certainties,
To the questions that outlive their answers,
To the silence after passionate declarations.

And when I speak, it is not truth I offer
But an invitation to listen together,
To stand in wonder at the edge
Of what we almost understand.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
ECHOES OF VERACITY

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how often my ears fill with comfortable static,
The white noise of convenient narratives.

You whisper in the spaces between heartbeats,
In the silence after questions I dare not answer.
I have built fortresses against your siege,
Walls of justification, moats of denial.

Yet you are patient as mountains,
Erosive as the sea against shoreline excuses.
You wait in mirrors I avoid,
In dreams that wake me, sweating and known.

I wonder—if I were to lay down these arms,
To open the gates of my carefully guarded self,
Would your light blind or illuminate?
Would your voice deafen or clarify?

Perhaps truth-speaking begins with truth-hearing,
With cupping my hands around the flame of what is,
Not what I wish would burn instead.

So I practice listening:
To the earth beneath concrete,
To the heart beneath pride,
To you, Truth, ancient and newborn,
Waiting for me to become your voice.

THE RECIPROCITY OF HONESTY

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears have grown selective, tuned to comfortable frequencies,
Filtering your sharp edges into rounded platitudes.

We dance this way, Truth and I,
A tango of approach and retreat.
I claim to seek you while building labyrinths
To ensure we never meet face to face.

How strange—to hunger for what I fear,
To thirst for waters I dare not drink.
You are the mirror I both need and avoid,
The medicine I purchase but leave unopened.

Sometimes I catch glimpses: in children's questions,
In the eyes of strangers who have nothing to lose,
In the silence after thunder when pretense washes away.

Perhaps listening is not passive but the most active choice—
To stand still in the hurricane of noise,
To tune one's inner ear to the frequency of what is.

So today, I practice again:
Breathing in reality, exhaling illusion,
Knowing that to speak truth
I must first become its devoted student.

TRUTH'S BARGAIN

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But we've grown estranged in this era of convenient fictions.
You stand at my doorstep, weather-beaten traveler,
While I peek through curtains, uncertain of your welcome.

What would happen if I invited you in?
If I cleared the table of half-truths and assumptions,
Poured you a cup of my undivided attention,
And let you speak until dawn broke through windows?

Would my foundations crack? Would my carefully
Constructed self-image shatter like dropped porcelain?
Or would I finally breathe without the weight
Of maintaining contradictions in every conversation?

The bargain you offer seems simple yet terrifying:
Listen first, then speak. Receive before transmitting.
Stand in your light before becoming your lighthouse.

So I practice with small truths first—
The ones about morning coffee preferences,
About which songs make me cry in traffic,
Gradually working toward the truths that make my hands tremble
When I consider giving them voice.

TRUTH AS ECOSYSTEM

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I learn to recognize your footprints in the forest of noise,
Your breathing beneath the cacophony of should-be's and could-be's.

You are not a single voice but an ecosystem—
The mycelia network beneath conscious thought,
The weather patterns of intuition,
The endangered species of uncomfortable realizations.

I've been a poor conservationist of your wildness,
Paving over instinct with rationalization,
Damming the rivers of insight with expedience,
Clear-cutting perception to build monuments to convenience.

But even in this developed interior landscape,
You persist in weeds breaking through sidewalk cracks,
In birds that refuse domestication,
In stars that outshine my artificial lights.

Perhaps truth-speaking is less declaration
And more translation of what already exists—
The patient interpretation of what the body knows,
What dreams insist upon, what silence reveals

When I finally stop filling it with noise
And listen to what has always been speaking.

THE APPRENTICESHIP

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A promise easier made than kept in days like these,
When lies dress in truth's abandoned clothing,
And comfort masquerades as wisdom.

I apprentice myself to you reluctantly,
Like a child learning an instrument—
Fingers clumsy on unfamiliar strings,
Ears untrained to distinguish harmony from noise.

The first lessons are humbling:
Learning to say "I don't know" without apology,
To hold contradictions without immediate resolution,
To sit with discomfort as companion rather than enemy.

Slowly, I develop calluses where tender spots once bled,
Not to become hardened, but to play longer without flinching.
I learn your grammar, your syntax, your peculiar music
That sometimes sounds like laughter, sometimes like grief.

And on rare days, when practice meets opportunity,
When listening has carved channels deep enough,
I find your words flowing through me—not mine, yet mine—
And in that moment, speaker and spoken become one current,
One clear note in the universal chorus.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
THE LISTENER'S OATH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how seldom my ears remain unclogged by desire,
By the soft cotton of comfort, the wax of willful denial.
I have built fortresses against your whispers,
Erected monuments to my own convenient versions.

What would happen if I cleared these channels?
If I let your current flow unimpeded through me?
Would I recognize myself in the aftermath?
Or would I emerge, finally, as the person
I was always meant to become?

Truth, you are not gentle, not kind,
But neither are you cruel for cruelty's sake.
You simply are—indifferent to my preferences,
Patient beyond measure, waiting for the moment
When I finally develop the habit of listening.

TRUTH SPEAKS

You say you'll speak me if you listen,
but your ears are filled with noise—
the clamor of want, the static of fear,
the lullabies of comfortable lies.

I do not hide from you.
I am the sunrise that arrives without permission,
the reflection in still water,
the silence between heartbeats.

You search for me in grand revelations
when I exist in whispers,
in the space between what you say
and what you mean.

Listen: I am already speaking.
In the twitch of your lover's smile,
in the weight of unspoken words,
in the questions you dare not ask.

Develop the habit of stillness
and you will find I never stopped talking.

HABITS OF TRUTH

We cultivate gardens of deception,
water them with tears of convenience,
prune away the branches that reach too far.
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
but habits are hard-won, easily lost.

My mother taught me to brush twice daily,
to look both ways before crossing,
but never how to sit with uncomfortable truths,
never how to hear the message beneath the message,
never how to speak what I've truly heard.

So I practice now, daily exercises
for atrophied honesty muscles:
remove the filters from my ears,
the guards from my tongue,
the shields from my heart.

Listen. Receive. Speak.
Listen. Receive. Speak.
Until the habit forms a path so worn
I can follow it even in darkness.

CONDITIONAL VERACITY

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But what if I've grown accustomed to your absence?
What if the lies taste sweeter on my tongue,
and deception feels like home?

We live in an age of curated realities,
where facts bend to feeling,
where comfort outranks clarity,
where we pick our truths like produce at market—
only the shiniest, only the least blemished.

Perhaps listening is the revolutionary act,
the radical choice to remove our filters,
to let the world arrive unedited,
to feel the sting of what is
rather than the balm of what we wish.

And in that listening—painful, pure—
we find our voice again,
no longer echoing others' convenient fictions
but speaking what the silence taught us.

ECHOES OF VERACITY

Truth rings like a bell across canyons of doubt
I cup my ears to catch its fading sound
But echoes distort what was clearly proclaimed
And I wonder which version should be named.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But listening requires a stillness I rarely possess,
A quieting of the internal committee
That votes on what's comfortable rather than real.

How strange that we fear you, necessary truth,
Like children who run from beneficial medicine.
We build labyrinths of justification,
Elaborate systems to avoid your simple face.

Yet in the moments I've truly heard you,
And summoned the courage to give you voice,
I've found not the monster I feared would emerge,
But liberation, waiting patiently all along.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
ECHOES OF TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how seldom my ears turn inward to your whispers.
You reside in the spaces between heartbeats,
In the silence after thunder,
In the pause before speech.

I have filled my days with noise—
Opinions stacked like fortresses,
Certainties worn like armor.
Yet you wait, patient as stone,
For the moment I grow quiet enough to hear.

What would happen if I made a temple of my attention?
If I swept clean the chambers of my mind
And sat vigil for your arrival?

Perhaps then my words would carry your weight,
My voice become a vessel worthy of your clarity.
For we cannot give what we have not received,
Cannot speak a language we refuse to learn.

Truth, I am listening now.

THE HABIT OF HONESTY

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But these ears have grown accustomed to sweeter songs—
The lullabies of self-deception,
The symphonies of convenient belief.

Each morning I practice:
Palms against the mirror,
Eyes meeting eyes,
Breath fogging glass.

I ask the reflection: what hurts to hear?
What whispers make me wince?
What truths do I translate to softer tongues?

Sometimes I catch myself
Reshaping reality like clay,
Molding discomfort into pleasing forms.

But truth is not a sculptor's medium—
It is the chisel itself,
Carving away pretense
Until what remains
Is too real to deny.

So I practice listening,
Knowing my voice will follow.

WILDERNESS VERITY

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
As ravens listen to wind currents before flight,
As wolves attend the moon's silent instruction,
As rivers heed the pull of distant seas.

In the forest, nothing lies—
The oak does not pretend to be a pine,
The fox makes no false promises,
The storm announces itself without apology.

I have walked among these honest teachers,
Learned how mushrooms declare their poison plainly,
How the bear's tracks tell true stories in mud,
How autumn leaves surrender without shame.

Perhaps truth is not a human invention after all,
But the original language of existence,
Spoken fluently by everything but us.

I place my ear to tree bark,
To stone, to soil,
And translate what I hear
Into human speech—
Imperfect echoes of perfect clarity.

TRUTH.EXE

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my notifications are always muted
And your texts get lost in my crowded inbox.

I've ghosted you for easier companions:
The hot take,
The quick fix,
The viral half-fact that feels good to share.

Truth, you're not trending enough.
You don't come with filters to soften your edges.
You won't fit in the character limit I've set for complexity.

But lately my feed feels hollow,
Echoes bouncing in an empty room.
I'm exhausted from constructing personas
That crash like buggy software.

Maybe I'll unsubscribe from the noise,
Delete the apps that sell me comfortable lies,
Create space where your voice can buffer properly.

Truth, I'm turning on notifications.
I'm ready for the update
That might finally set me free.

DIVINE DIALOGUE

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Divine whisper, sacred breath,
You who existed before the first word was uttered,
You who will remain when all voices fall silent.

The prophets and sages knew your ways—
How you arrive like dawn: gradually, then suddenly.
How you burn away illusion like morning mist.
How you require both courage and surrender.

I have sought you in ancient texts,
In meditation's depths,
In the eyes of strangers,
In my own wounded places.

Sometimes I catch glimpses:
A fragment of your face,
A note of your music,
Enough to recognize you
When you speak through me.

For truth is not possessed but channeled,
Not created but received,
A conversation between the eternal and the present,
Between the divine and the all-too-human.

I listen. I become hollow.
I let you fill me like a vessel.
I speak.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
DEVOTION'S ECHO

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I cross oceans of despair,
Or climb the heights of agony
To breathe your rare and sacred air.

The cosmos spins in patterns old,
Yet newer still than what we share—
This gravity of soul untold,
This weight of joy too much to bear.

I've counted stars on sleepless nights,
And named each one with thoughts of you.
The universe, with all its lights,
Holds nothing that compares to you.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender all I am—
A willing prisoner, yet free,
Held captive by love's sweetest psalm.

FRAGMENTS OF US

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
would I have learned to disassemble myself,
removed the clockwork of my heart,
spread its gears across this table.

See how the light catches each piece?
How vulnerable machinery looks
when exposed to open air.

You taught me the anatomy of longing—
how it lives in the spine, the fingertips,
the hollow space beneath the tongue.

I am collecting evidence of your existence:
the impression of your head on my pillow,
a strand of hair, the scent of you
left lingering on my sweater sleeve.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
would I have learned this science of absence,
this precise measurement of the space
between what was and what remains.

CELESTIAL BODIES

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would the moon dare approach the sea,
Drawing tides with silver hands,
Pulling oceans across the lands.

We are cosmic accidents—
Stardust formed to sentience,
Yet in this vast uncertainty,
I orbit faithfully round thee.

Time bends in your gravity,
Seconds stretch eternally.
Galaxies collapse and bloom
In the darkness of your room.

Scientists map infinity,
Chart the birth of every star,
Yet cannot quantify this force
That binds us, near or far.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would atoms dance so recklessly,
Defying laws of physics just
To transform attraction into trust.

SEASONS OF DEVOTION

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would autumn shed its golden crown,
Or winter wrap the world in white,
Or spring push blossoms through the ground.

I've watched the seasons change their dress
As I have changed beneath your gaze—
A metamorphosis of soul,
A transformation of my days.

The garden of my heart once bare
Now flourishes with wild bloom.
Each flower opens to your light,
Each root seeks deeper growing room.

Time measures differently with you;
A moment stretches like the sky.
Years compress to single breaths
When your beloved form is nigh.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have learned to truly see
The sacred hidden in the plain,
The joy concealed within the pain.

DIGITAL DEVOTION

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
would I scroll through endless screens,
thumb callused from tapping hearts
on photos that capture half your smile.

Our love—translated into pixels,
compressed, transmitted, rendered real
through fiber optic veins that pulse
beneath oceans, connecting continents.

I count the hours in time zones,
calculate when you might wake,
when your consciousness will flicker online,
when your name will illuminate my phone.

We are modern lovers—
our intimacy mediated by satellites,
our whispers converted to binary code,
yet no less fervent than ancient vows.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
would I have learned this new language
of distance collapsed into presence,
of longing distilled into light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
DEVOTION'S MEASURE

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender heart and mind;
Your gravity pulls endlessly,
A cosmic force, unique, divine.

The stars arrange themselves anew
Each time your laughter fills the air;
What galaxies I'd travel through
To find your light, so bright, so rare.

I've counted grains of sand and stars,
Measured oceans, mapped the sky,
Yet nothing matches, near or far,
The boundless depth in your kind eyes.

For nothing less than all of you—
Your flaws, your fears, your gentle grace—
Would make this searching heart ring true;
In your embrace, I've found my place.

SUBSTITUTE GOODS

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
would I trade these quiet mornings.
Not for coffee's bitter warmth,
nor the symphony of city streets awakening.

I've been offered silver rivers,
mountain peaks dusted white with possibility,
the entire night sky folded into origami birds—
I declined them all without hesitation.

Economists speak of substitutes,
equivalent values, alternative choices.
They haven't calculated the precise weight
of your head resting against my shoulder,

the irreplaceable currency of your breath
against my neck. There exists no market
where I might find your particular gravity,
no replacement for how you hold the world together.

CARTOGRAPHY

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
would I redraw these ancient maps.
See how I've renamed oceans after your eyes,
mountains after the curve of your spine.

I've navigated treacherous waters,
ships splintered against jagged shores,
lost compasses pointing everywhere but true north.
Each expedition ended in beautiful failure.

Until you.

Now the territories of my heart
are marked with your fingerprints,
latitude lines following the path
your whispers take across my skin.

Explorers searched for paradise
in jungles, deserts, frozen wastes.
How strange to discover it
in the ordinary miracle of your morning smile,
the everyday wonder of your hand in mine.

CELESTIAL MECHANICS

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would atoms rearrange themselves.
The universe conspired for billions of years—
Stars exploding, elements forming,
Planets cooling, seasons turning—
All to create the precise conditions
Where your existence became possible.

Physicists speak of entropy,
The inevitable dissolution of order,
Yet somehow we found each other
In this vast, expanding chaos.

What mathematical equation explains
The improbable geometry of us?
What cosmic law governs
The way your absence creates a vacuum
That nothing else can fill?

I study the calculus of your smile,
The orbital mechanics of your embrace.
Science fails me; poetry remains.
Dear love, the universe accepts no substitutes.

ALCHEMY

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I transmute my solitude to gold.
Before you, I was complete—
A finished sentence, a closed book,
A house with all its windows shuttered
Against the possibility of storms.

Yet you arrived without warning,
Not as lightning or thunder,
But as gentle rain on parched earth.

Now wildflowers grow where
I never thought to plant gardens.
Now music plays in rooms
I'd forgotten existed.

The medieval alchemists sought
To transform base metals into precious ones.
I understand them now—
How ordinary moments with you
Become treasures I guard jealously,
How your absence transforms hours into lead,
How your return makes everything golden again.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
DEAR LOVE, FOR NOTHING LESS THAN THEE

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I traverse the endless seas,
Or climb the mountains' jagged spine
To claim your precious heart as mine.

The cosmos in your eyes I see—
Vast galaxies that beckon me.
Your smile, a crescent moon so bright,
Illuminates my darkest night.

I'd trade all treasures earth could hold,
The silver stars, the purest gold,
For just one moment by your side,
Where all my longings reside.

The universe conspired, it seems,
To weave you through my waking dreams.
Each atom in my being sings
The joy your mere existence brings.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender willingly
This heart that beats your name like prayer,
A sacred rhythm we both share.

In this vast world of chance and change,
Our souls found each other—how strange
And beautiful this mystery:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

DEVOTION'S ECONOMY

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I exchange this liberty—
This wild and precious solitude
I've guarded with such fortitude.

What currency compares to touch?
What gold amounts to half as much
As whispered words at breaking dawn
When night's protective veil is drawn?

I've bartered with the universe,
Traded logic for something worse:
This beautiful catastrophe
Of wanting nothing less than thee.

The mathematicians would despair
At how I calculate with care
The infinite ways I'd sacrifice
And count the cost as merely nice.

In this strange economy of souls
Where love determines all the tolls,
I've learned that wealth is measured best
In heartbeats saved and secrets kept.

So take these offerings I bring—
Not diamonds, pearls, or golden ring,
But something rarer: truth unbound.
Dear love, it's you my heart has found,
And nothing less will ever do
Than this whole life I give to you.

QUANTUM ENTANGLEMENT

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could bend the laws of physics so—
Two particles, once touched, remain
Connected though galaxies grow
Between their spinning, yearning forms.

Scientists call this mystery
'Entanglement'—I call it us:
How distance fails to separate
What time and space cannot discuss.
Our atoms know what minds forget.

Remember when we touched and knew
Something fundamental changed?
The universe recalibrated,
All its equations rearranged
Around that singular moment.

I move; you feel it continents away.
You smile; my lips respond in kind.
We've transcended ordinary bonds,
Become the theory Einstein signed
With reluctant, wondering hands.

'Spooky action at a distance'—
That's what skeptics choose to say.
But I've felt your heartbeat quicken
When mine races, and they may
Call it coincidence. We know better.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would quantum physics bend its knee.

SEASONS OF THEE

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would autumn shed its copper cloak,
Or winter don its silver dress—
The seasons change, but not what's spoke
In silent language between us.

I've watched the cherry blossoms fall
Like snow upon your outstretched hands.
I've counted constellations bright
Reflected in your eyes. Time stands
Still when you're near, then races when apart.

Remember spring, when first we met?
The world was drunk on possibility.
The air was sweet with promises
We didn't understand. Now we see
How saplings grow to mighty trees.

In summer's heat, our passion bloomed—
Wild roses climbing garden walls.
In autumn's cool, our love matured
To something deeper. Winter calls
Us closer to the hearth we've built.

The earth completes its ancient dance
Around the sun, year after year.
I mark the passing not by dates
But by the ways we've grown, my dear.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would time itself bow gracefully.

THE HERETIC'S PRAYER

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I forsake the heaven promised me.
I've traded psalms for the poetry
Of your breathing in the dark.

They speak of golden streets and pearly gates,
Of rewards for those who patiently wait—
But I've found divinity in your embrace,
Sacred texts written on your skin.

Let the devout keep their distant paradise;
I worship at an altar they'd despise.
My religion is the light within your eyes,
My salvation, your forgiveness.

Blasphemy, they'd call this confession.
Heresy, this most honest expression
Of faith in something I can touch and hold—
A miracle more tangible than stories told.

I've built cathedrals in the space between
Your heartbeat and mine—unseen
By those who search the heavens for signs.
My revelation came in human design.

So let them pray to skies above;
I'll continue my devotion to this love.
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I rewrite my theology.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would my heart dare to beat its drum,
Nor would these eyes seek light to see
If not to glimpse where you might come.

The stars arrange themselves anew
Each night to spell your sacred name,
While oceans shift their deepest blue
To match the hue from which you came.

I've searched the language of the birds,
The whispered secrets of the trees,
Yet find no satisfying words
To capture how you've captured me.

Dear love, for nothing less than all
You are—both storm and gentle breeze—
Would I surrender to this call
That binds my soul in sweet release.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could fill the void within my soul.
Not earthly wealth nor boundless sea,
Nor fame that time cannot control.

You are the sacred flame that burns
Beyond the veil of mortal sight,
The truth to which my spirit turns
When lost within the darkest night.

I seek you in the temple's hush,
In prayers whispered to the void,
In moments when the world's mad rush
Grows silent, and all fears destroyed.

Dear love divine, eternal light,
I am a pilgrim at your door,
Sustained through faith's unending night
By grace I've never known before.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would autumn leaves consent to fall,
Or rivers journey to the sea,
Or mountains rise, defiant, tall.

I've seen your face in wildflowers,
Your voice in rainfall's gentle song,
Your patience in the passing hours,
Your strength in roots, unseen but strong.

The cycles of the earth proclaim
What my heart has always known:
Love is no fleeting, fragile flame
But seed eternal, deeply sown.

Dear love, for nothing less than this—
The way you mirror nature's grace—
Would I surrender to your kiss
And in your seasons find my place.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee—
My own reflection in the glass—
Have I traversed this odyssey
Through shadows I once feared to pass.

How strange to find after the years
Of seeking validation's touch,
That you were hiding in my tears,
The self I never loved too much.

I crown you now with gentle hands,
This heart that weathered its own storms,
This mind that finally understands
The beauty in its natural forms.

Dear love, for nothing less than all
The parts of me I tried to hide,
Would I have heard this inner call
To cherish what lives deep inside.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Do I still watch the empty door,
Though oceans wide between us be
And years have passed—then many more.

The letters yellow in their box,
Your scent has faded from the air,
Yet memory defies time's locks;
You're present in your very dare.

Some nights I feel your phantom touch
Upon my cheek, so brief, so real,
And wonder if you feel as much
Wherever fate has set your wheel.

Dear love, for nothing less than this—
The ghost of what we could not hold—
Would I still treasure every kiss
And wear our story, proud and bold.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would my devoted heart ever beat;
As stars are bound to night's decree,
So am I tethered, whole, complete.

Time's rivers flow toward distant seas,
Yet my affection stands unmoved;
Like ancient, rooted mountain trees,
My soul to yours forever proved.

When autumn paints the world in gold,
And winter follows with its chill,
Our love, like embers, bright and bold,
Burns through the darkness, warmer still.

For nothing less than thee, my dear,
Could make this mortal life so clear.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I carve out these hollow spaces,
Empty rooms where my self used to be,
Filled now with your ghostly traces.

I've given blood and bone and breath,
Sacrificed sleep on your altar of need.
This devotion walks the line of death—
A beautiful poison on which I feed.

You never asked for such surrender,
Yet I offered it like a prayer.
This love has become my splendor,
My beautiful ruin beyond repair.

For nothing less than thee, I've become
Everything less than I was. Undone.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would the mountain stream change course;
As it leaps from stone to mossy stone,
It whispers your name with gentle force.

The oak extends its arms to sky
As I reach toward your distant shore;
Blossoms open in morning light,
As my heart does when you walk through the door.

Even the moon, that constant friend,
Pulls at oceans with invisible hands;
So too your spirit pulls at mine,
Across cities, forests, desert lands.

In nature's grand design I see
The mirror of what you mean to me—
A necessary force, like gravity,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could consciousness find purpose clear;
In cosmic void, your light I see—
The reason atoms gathered here.

Before your touch, what was this life?
A sequence of meaningless days.
After your love, even in strife,
Existence glows with purpose-rays.

Philosophers seek truth in thought,
Scientists in empirical design,
But I have found what they have sought
In the space where your soul touches mine.

If God is love, then love is thee,
The proof of all divinity;
The answer to why we can see
Beauty in stars and poetry.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I learn to fold laundry properly!
Or remember to buy the right cheese,
Or pretend to enjoy your favorite TV series.

For nothing less than your crooked smile
Would I drive through traffic for miles and miles,
Or dance badly at your office party,
Or pretend your snoring is 'not that hearty.'

You've seen me with bedhead and morning breath,
In ratty sweatpants, looking like death,
Yet still you choose me day after day—
A miracle that won't go away.

So dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I be exactly, perfectly me.
For in your eyes, I finally see
I'm already all I need to be.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer,
When light draped the world in gold,
And memories swam like minnows
In the creek of my childhood—cold.

The cicadas sang their ancient hymn,
A chorus that transcends all time,
While I, barefoot on scorching earth,
Watched shadows dance in pantomime.

The peach trees bent with ripened fruit,
Offering sweetness to patient hands.
I remember grandmother's kitchen,
Preserving summer in mason-canned lands.

How strange that a moment so ordinary
Could etch itself in memory's wall,
The weight of August pressing down,
Yet lifting the spirit, enthralling all.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When time itself seemed to pause,
And childhood stretched eternal
Like the sky without flaws.

Now winter creeps upon my brow,
But in dreams, I return once more,
To that golden hour of innocence
On memory's distant shore.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When the metropolis sighed,
Exhaling heat from concrete lungs
And steel-ribbed mountainside.

The city shimmered, mirage-like,
A desert of our own design.
Office windows blazed like pyres
Where modern pilgrims stood in line.

I watched you through the haze,
Your silhouette a glitch in light,
As traffic signals changed their minds
From stop to go, from wrong to right.

The food truck vendors called like sirens,
Ice cream melted down wrists like time,
And somewhere in this urban furnace
Our separate lives began to rhyme.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When we first dared to speak,
Two strangers seeking shelter
From the sun at its peak.

Now seasons cycle endlessly,
But I measure life from then—
When summer's burning fingertips
Rewrote our stories with its pen.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And the gods were at play,
Hurling thunderbolts across heavens
In their ancient, cosmic way.

Prometheus wept as his gift to man
Burned mercilessly from above,
Scorching fields once fertile,
Challenging mortal love.

The river nymphs retreated
To caverns cool and deep,
While Pan's pipes fell silent
As even he sought sleep.

In this mythic hour of reckoning,
When Helios rode highest in his arc,
I stood at the threshold of worlds,
Neither fully in light nor dark.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When veils between realms grow thin,
And mortals glimpse immortality
In the season's blazing din.

I heard them call my name then,
Voices ancient as the stars,
Inviting me to cross the boundary
Where time itself unspools and chars.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When the world stood still,
Not a leaf dared tremble
On the drought-parched hill.

The thermometer's mercury
Climbed like a desperate prayer,
As climate's slow catastrophe
Hung palpable in air.

I watched the last pond dwindle,
A memory of itself,
While creatures gathered silently
At nature's emptying shelf.

The ancestors warned of this moment—
When balance tips beyond return,
When human hubris reaches apex
And forgotten lessons we must relearn.

'Twas noontide of summer,
But unlike summers past,
When seasons kept their promises
And patterns held steadfast.

Yet in this crucible of change,
I plant a seed with hope—
That from this scorched awakening
A wiser world might grope.

'Twas noontide of summer,
Beneath quantum skies,
Where probability collapses
And parallel truth lies.

The universe's clockwork heart
Beats hottest at this hour,
When light itself seems tangible—
A measurable power.

I calculate the distance
Between your mind and mine,
A space-time separation
That physics can't define.

The entropy of moments
Increases with each breath,
As cosmic background radiation
Whispers hints of death.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When dimensions intersect,
And consciousness emerges
From particles connect.

In this brief illumination,
Between dawn and dusk compressed,
I glimpse the grand equation
In which all life is expressed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer,
When light draped the world in gold,
And cicadas sang their ancient hymns
To heat that would not fold.

The oak trees stood as sentinels,
Their shadows, pools of grace,
Where children sought a moment's peace
From sun's relentless face.

The river moved in languid curves,
A mirror to the sky,
Reflecting clouds that drifted past
Like dreams that wonder why.

Time stretched like honey from the comb,
Sweet hours that dripped and pooled,
As butterflies in drunken dance
Spun patterns, bright and jeweled.

The scent of grass, freshly mown,
Rose up in fragrant waves,
Mingling with the wild blooms
That summer always saves.

In this perfect golden moment,
Suspended between dawn and dusk,
I found eternity contained
In summer's midday hush.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And in that blazing light,
I glimpsed the face of wonder
Before day turned to night.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When memories melt like ice cream cones,
Dripping sticky down knuckles of time,
Sweetness lost to asphalt's hungry mouth.

I remember your laugh then,
How it cut through humidity's embrace,
A sound like wind chimes in a hurricane—
Beautiful, doomed, necessary.

The city shimmer-danced on that day,
Buildings wavering in heat's mirage,
As we walked barefoot on scorching concrete,
Too young to fear the burning.

Summer at its zenith holds no promises,
Only the certainty of decline.
Even as sweat pearled on your collarbone,
Autumn was already whispering your name.

We photographed shadows that day,
Not knowing they'd outlast us,
Preserved in digital amber
While we drifted like dandelion seeds.

'Twas noontide of summer,
The highest point of our orbit,
Before gravity reclaimed its due
And pulled us back to separate earths.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When the veil between worlds grew thin,
And I, walking beneath the elder trees,
Heard voices not of mortal kin.

The fae folk danced in circles wild,
Where mushrooms marked their sacred ground,
Their laughter like silver bells tinkling,
An otherworldly sound.

A queen with eyes of amber fire
Beckoned me with slender hand,
"Come traveler, share our revelry,
In this sun-drenched magic land."

I hesitated at the threshold,
Knowing tales of those beguiled,
Who danced away a summer noon
And returned a hundred years exiled.

Yet something in her ancient gaze
Spoke of wonders I might see,
Of crystal caves and starlit skies
And wisdom of the elder tree.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When I made my fateful choice,
To step beyond the mortal veil
And in forgotten realms rejoice.

Perhaps someday I shall return,
Though none may know my face,
A stranger bearing summer's gifts
From time's enchanted embrace.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And the city breathed fire and fumes.
No gentle pastoral scene here—
Only concrete incubating heat
And air conditioners dripping artificial tears.

On the subway platform,
Humanity stewed in collective sweat,
Smartphones clutched like talismans
Against the reality of pressed flesh
And delayed trains.

I watched a woman in a business suit
Slowly melt like Salvador Dalí's clocks,
Her professional veneer sliding
Into something more honest,
More vulnerable, more real.

Summer in the metropolis
Is democracy in action—
No one escapes its leveling hand.
Billionaires and beggars alike
Seek shade and water with equal desperation.

As I rode the elevator to the twenty-seventh floor,
I glimpsed, through glass and steel,
A single determined dandelion
Growing from a crack in distant pavement,
Defiantly golden under the merciless sun.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And in this urban furnace,
I found strange communion
With eight million others
All burning together.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When time collapsed like quantum particles,
Past, present, future—all one.

I stand at the beach edge, toes in sand.
I am seven, building castles with my father.
I am seventeen, kissing beneath the pier.
I am seventy, watching my grandchildren splash.
All now. All true.

The sun, that ancient nuclear furnace,
Bends photons that left its surface
Eight minutes and twenty seconds ago—
Light already history when it warms my skin.

The ocean before me contains
Water molecules dinosaurs drank,
Salts from primordial seas,
Microplastics that will outlive us all.

At summer's peak, I understand:
We are temporary arrangements of atoms,
Borrowed briefly from stars.

The gulls wheel overhead,
Their cries transcribing equations
Too beautiful for mathematics.

Time resumes its linear march.
The moment passes.
The tide shifts.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And for one breath between heartbeats,
I held infinity in my cupped hands,
Before it slipped through my fingers
Like ordinary sand.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer,
When golden light spilled
Across meadows in slumber,
Where time stood quite still.

The bees hummed their chorus,
In lavender swaying,
While butterflies soared us
A dance they were playing.

The oak's dappled shadows
Cast patterns like lace,
As I lay in the meadows
In nature's embrace.

A brook softly babbled
Its crystalline tune,
As my thoughts gently traveled
Like clouds 'neath the moon.

The world seemed enchanted
In this moment divine,
Where worries recanted
And peace became mine.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When magic held sway,
When life felt much younger
If just for a day.

So cherish these moments
Of pure golden light,
For summer's components
Make memories bright.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When the sun's cruel eye
Burned through flesh and bone,
Leaving nothing to deny.

The cicadas screamed warnings
Of a heat without end,
While the asphalt was scorching—
Earth refused to bend.

In the merciless glare,
I saw truth laid bare:
All our careful constructions,
Melting without care.

No shelter could save us
From the thoughts in our minds,
As summer's fierce justice
Left no shadow behind.

I remembered December,
Its merciful chill,
How I longed to surrender
To its forgiving will.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When illusions dissolve,
When we face our own demons
With nowhere to revolve.

In this crucible moment,
Between breath and flame,
I found strange contentment
In accepting the blame.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When I found her there,
Beneath the old willow
With flowers in her hair.

She spoke not a word
As I took my place,
Yet volumes were written
In the lines of her face.

We'd met here for decades,
Since we were just teens,
Through wars and through children
And all in-betweens.

She handed me peaches,
Sun-warmed and sweet,
The juice on our fingers
A memory complete.

"Remember," she whispered,
"The day we first came?"
I nodded and smiled,
Time had not changed her name.

Though silver now crowned us
Where gold once had been,
The noontide of summer
Kept our hearts evergreen.

We sat there till sunset
As we'd always done,
Two souls intertwined
Like the moon and the sun.

'Twas noontide of summer,
and everything pixelates.
The heat distorts reality into
digital fragments of what was.

I stand in the concrete jungle
where air conditioners drip artificial rain
onto smartphones reflecting
the too-bright sky.

Summer noon in the 21st century:
we are all melting data points
in someone's climate change graph.

The ice cream truck's jingle glitches,
repetitive electronic nostalgia
for childhoods we scroll past
on social media timelines.

I watch a butterfly land on a solar panel.
Nature adapting to our adaptations.
Irony buzzes like the electricity we crave.

'Twas noontide of summer,
and I screenshot the moment,
filter the heat into something bearable,
hashtag the sweat from my existence,
and wonder if seasons still matter
when we've climate-controlled our lives
into one endless, artificial spring.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When time holds its breath—
Suspended between
Life's morning and death.

The zenith of being,
This moment so still,
When light reaches fullness
Before the downhill.

I ponder the sundial
Casting no shadow at all,
This brief perfect balance
Before the long fall.

How curious to witness
The peak of the day,
Knowing each second after
Must turn away.

Perhaps in our lives
There's a noontide as well,
A moment of fullness
We rarely can tell.

We rush through our mornings,
Eyes fixed on the climb,
Then mourn in our evenings
The passage of time.

But wisdom may lie
In this summer noon hour:
To recognize zenith
Is also to flower.

'Twas noontide of summer—
A teacher of grace—
Reminding that fullness
Deserves its own space.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer,
And golden the fields where we played,
Where childhood unfolded in wonder,
And time seemed forever delayed.

The cicadas sang hymns to the heavens,
As we lay in the shade of old oaks,
Our laughter like wind-chimes ascending,
Our worries as light as smoke.

I remember the creek's gentle babble,
How it cooled our sun-reddened skin,
How we hunted for smooth-polished pebbles,
And the joy when we'd find one to keep.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When memories were carved into stone,
Before autumn of life came upon us,
Before seeds of our youth had been sown.

I return now in dreams to that meadow,
To that moment suspended in light,
When the world was a canvas of promise,
And our hearts were unburdened and bright.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And though decades have drifted away,
I can still taste the sweetness of berries,
And feel sunshine of that perfect day.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When the concrete exhaled heat like breath,
And the shadows retreated to slivers
As the city surrendered to depth.

The food carts and vendors were islands
In an ocean of shimmering streets,
Where businessmen shed their personas,
Loosened ties in surrender to heat.

A child with an ice cream was laughing
As it melted in spirals of white,
While pigeons performed their ballet
In a fountain's ephemeral light.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When time slowed to molasses pace,
And through office windows, workers gazed
At freedom they couldn't embrace.

Yet beauty persisted in corners—
A rooftop garden, defiant and green,
A busker whose violin whispered
Of places his audience hadn't seen.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And despite all our urban design,
Nature reclaimed her brief moment,
Reminding us all we're divine.

'Twas noontide of summer,
The zenith of life's burning arc,
When possibilities hover, suspended
Like dragonflies over a park.

What wisdom lives in this moment?
This fulcrum of light and of time?
This pause between growth and declining,
This peak of existence sublime?

The morning of youth now behind us,
The evening not yet in our sight,
We stand at the crest of our journey,
Bathed fully in present-tense light.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And noontide of being as well,
When we're ripe with the fruits of our labor,
With stories we're burning to tell.

So cherish this apex of living,
This summit of all you can be,
For shadows grow long with the passing,
As sun sinks toward night's waiting sea.

'Twas noontide of summer,
A metaphor perfectly cast,
For that fleeting moment of balance
Too exquisite, too brief to last.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And silence embraced the still land,
Save honeybees' diligent humming
And waves gently kissing the sand.

The heat pressed like velvet against me,
A tangible weight on my skin,
As I lay midst the wild-growing sage brush,
Letting solitude settle within.

Each sense heightened under Apollo's gaze—
The salt-tang of air on my tongue,
The fragrance of sun-ripened berries,
The warmth through my body that sung.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When time seems to pause and suspend,
When the earth and the self become one thing,
Where boundaries blur and transcend.

A lizard, my meditation companion,
Blinked slowly on sun-baked stone,
Two creatures in wordless communion,
Neither feeling remotely alone.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When wisdom arrives without sound,
In the perfect and profound stillness
Where the sacred in life can be found.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When the veil between worlds grew thin,
And the clock on the old church tower
Struck thirteen instead of just ten.

The shadows of leaves danced backward,
The river flowed up to its source,
And children who played in the garden
Found doorways to worlds of strange force.

I witnessed a fox made of starlight
Conversing with birds made of rain,
While trees bent to listen intently
To secrets they couldn't explain.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When ordinary rules were undone,
When magic seeped out of the hedgerows,
And moonbeams escaped from the sun.

If ever you find yourself walking
When summer sun reaches its height,
Look twice at the world all around you—
You might glimpse the wonders in sight.

'Twas noontide of summer,
A moment when anything's true,
When the impossible becomes certain,
And enchantment is born anew.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer,
When light crowned the earth,
Golden rays cascading,
In symphonic mirth.

Cicadas sang hymns
From their emerald thrones,
As heat shimmered upward
From sun-baked stones.

Wildflowers nodded,
Heavy-headed with bloom,
Their perfume an offering
To the sky's azure room.

The creek slowed its journey,
A whisper, not rush,
As dragonflies hovered
In midday's warm hush.

Time itself seemed molten,
Stretching like honey poured,
Minutes became eternal,
Secrets of heat stored.

Beneath ancient oaks,
Shadows offered reprieve,
A sanctuary of coolness
Where one might breathe and believe.

In this cathedral of season,
Where summer holds court,
The soul finds communion
With what cannot be bought.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And in that perfect hour,
Life revealed its essence:
Beauty, stillness, power.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When memories bloom,
I return to that porch swing,
In grandmother's room.

Lemonade in mason jars,
Ice clinking like bells,
Fingers sticky with sweetness,
As childhood stories she tells.

The clothesline stretched taut,
Sheets dancing in breeze,
While cicada choruses
Rose up from the trees.

My cousins and I,
Barefoot, sun-browned, wild,
Chasing fireflies at dusk,
Each a summer-blessed child.

The creak of the screen door,
The smell of fresh bread,
The weight of humidity,
Hanging over my head.

Years have turned like pages,
Seasons come and gone,
But that noontide of summer
Still lives on and on.

In the chambers of my heart,
Where precious things stay,
That golden meridian hour
Never fades away.

'Twas noontide of summer,
Now distant, yet clear,
When time was abundant,
And loved ones were near.

'Twas noontide of summer,
Merciless and stark,
When the sun turned tyrant,
And shadows grew dark.

The earth cracked in anguish,
Parched lips seeking rain,
As mercury climbed upward,
Past reason, past pain.

No birdsong pierced the silence,
All creatures sought shade,
As if the world's heartbeat
Had momentarily stayed.

The city streets shimmered,
Mirages danced and swayed,
Asphalt turned to quicksand,
Where footsteps were betrayed.

Inside concrete prisons,
The forgotten ones burned,
No relief from the furnace
That summer had turned.

The sky—a brass cauldron,
The air—molten lead,
Each breath a reminder
Of what prophets had said.

This punishing zenith,
This merciless height,
When daylight brings suffering,
And we long for the night.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When truth was revealed:
In nature's raw power,
Our fate has been sealed.

'Twas noontide of summer, when all stood still,
The sun at its apex, commanding the sky;
No cloud dared venture, no breeze to fulfill
The wish for cool comfort as hours crawled by.

The lake's mirror surface reflected the light,
A thousand-fold brilliance that dazzled the eye;
While deep in the forest, in dappled half-light,
The deer and the rabbit passed silently by.

The old farmer paused by the edge of his field,
Wiped sweat from his brow with a weathered hand;
Considering what the season might yield,
As heat waves rose dancing across his land.

In gardens, the roses hung heavy with bloom,
Their petals unfurled to their fullest extent;
Exhaling sweet fragrance, nature's perfume,
A fleeting expression of summer's intent.

The children sought shelter beneath the great oak,
Their laughter subdued by the weight of the heat;
The elders on porches, memories evoked,
Of summers long past, equally sweet.

'Twas noontide of summer, a moment in time,
When life holds its breath before starting anew;
A pause in the season, a reason, a rhyme,
An hour of gold beneath skies of blue.

'Twas noontide of summer,
and the concrete breathed fire.
I stood at the crosswalk,
watching heat ripple higher.

No trees in this jungle
of glass and steel towers,
just the harsh urban rhythm
marking minutes and hours.

Air conditioners hummed
their mechanical prayer,
as businessmen wilted,
ties loosened with care.

A food truck vendor
handed ice cream to a child,
the small joy melting quickly,
as the sun remained wild.

On a rooftop garden,
six stories above,
drought-resistant succulents
received what they love.

The subway grates exhaled
their subterranean heat,
adding layers of warmth
to the unforgiving street.

A busker played saxophone,
notes bending with heat,
New Orleans in August
on this Manhattan street.

City pigeons sought refuge
in scant patches of shade,
as tourists with selfie sticks
captured the urban parade.

'Twas noontide of summer,
in this metropolitan dream,
where nature's grand season
is filtered through human scheme.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer,
When light draped the world in gold,
And cicadas sang their ancient hymns
From meadows lush and bold.

The oak trees stood as sentinels,
Their shadows cool and deep,
While wildflowers nodded drowsily,
Half-tempted into sleep.

I wandered through the hazy field,
My thoughts like butterflies,
Dancing between memories
And dreams of azure skies.

Time slowed its hurried footsteps then,
As if to catch its breath,
In that perfect pause between the hours
Where moments stretch their length.

The creek's soft babbling secrets
Whispered tales of distant shores,
Of mountains yet unclimbed by man
And oceans' hidden floors.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When I found myself again,
In the simple act of being present,
As sunlight warmed my skin.

And in that golden stillness,
I understood at last,
How fleeting is our journey here,
How swift these days will pass.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When shadows shrink away in fear
Of the sun's unforgiving glare.
The asphalt breathes fire,
Buildings waver like mirages.

In this concrete desert,
We are nomads seeking oasis—
A patch of shade, a sip of cold,
Anything to quench the thirst
Of bodies not made for such heat.

The city becomes a furnace
Forging us into something new;
Patience melts, tempers rise,
Strangers share knowing glances
United in sweltering solidarity.

I watch a child chase pigeons
Through the fountain's spray,
Laughing as water pearls on skin.
How quickly joy evaporates
When you're not looking.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And we are all just waiting
For evening's gentle mercy,
For stars to pierce the haze,
For time to turn the season's page.

Yet something in this harsh light
Reveals truths we cannot hide—
We are vulnerable creatures,
Bare beneath the sky's blue eye,
Transparent in summer's burning gaze.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And the clockwork universe paused.
Molecules slowed their frantic dance,
Photons stretched into lazy waves,
Gravity sighed and loosened its grip.

The quantum field hummed a different tune,
As parallel worlds brushed shoulders
In that liminal moment when
Time itself contemplated stillness.

I stood at the crossroads of was and will be,
Feeling the cosmic pause in my atoms,
Each cell remembering stardust origins,
Each thought unspooling into infinity.

The mathematics of existence
Solved themselves in the heat-shimmer;
Equations of being and nothingness
Balanced perfectly at summer's apex.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When dimensions folded like origami,
And I glimpsed the architecture of reality—
Not solid as we pretend, but fluid,
A dream within a dream within a dream.

Perhaps all summers converge at this point,
All noons collapse into one eternal moment,
And we, brief observers of cosmic patterns,
Merely passing through the endless algorithm
Of light and shadow, heat and wonder.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When we last embraced.
Your laughter mingled with wind chimes,
Your eyes reflected cloudless skies.

I remember the peaches we shared,
Juice running down sun-browned arms,
How we counted seeds like fortunes,
Making wishes on each bitter pit.

Now winter dwells within me,
Though calendars insist it's July.
I walk the same garden paths
Where your footprints once pressed.

The sundial casts its faithful shadow,
Marking hours you'll never see.
How strange that time continues,
When for me, it stopped that day.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When the doctors called.
While cicadas sang oblivious hymns,
Your name became past tense.

I water the tomato plants you started,
Their fruit ripening without you.
I harvest them in moonlight,
Unable to bear the noon sun's glare.

Perhaps in some kinder universe,
It's still that summer day,
And we are laughing, endless,
In a garden where death never learned your name.

'Twas noontide of summer,
And the world turned inside out—
Leaves became emerald tongues
Speaking ancient chlorophyll secrets,
Roots stretched like nervous systems
Beneath our unconscious feet.

The wild things watched us watching them,
A mutual curiosity bloomed
Between species separated by evolution
But united in this blazing moment.

I shed my human skin then,
Slipped into something more primordial,
Felt my DNA remember its journey—
From sea to shore to sky-gazer,
From stardust to sentience.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When boundaries dissolved
Between self and other, flesh and air.
I breathed in oxygen exhaled by oak trees,
They filtered carbon I released;
An exchange as old as photosynthesis.

In this communion of elements,
I recognized my temporary arrangement,
How briefly these atoms called me home
Before returning to the grand circulation.

Perhaps this is what mystics meant—
That enlightenment comes not from rising above,
But from dissolving into everything.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text:
EMBER

This anger burns deep within,
A smoldering coal beneath my ribs,
Inherited from ancestors who bit their tongues
Until the taste of blood became familiar.

I carry their silence like an heirloom,
Polished by generations of swallowed words.
Sometimes I forget it's there
Until someone strikes the match of memory
And oxygen rushes in.

The flames lick at my throat,
Turn my voice to smoke signals
Only the wounded can interpret.
My hands become kindling,
My thoughts, accelerant.

I have tried drowning this fire
With oceans of forgiveness,
Buried it under mountains of meditation,
But embers need only a whisper of wind
To remember their purpose.

Perhaps I've been wrong to fight it.
Perhaps this heat was meant to forge, not destroy—
To melt down what was broken
And pour it into stronger molds.

So I will burn,
Not as a house consumed by flames,
But as a lighthouse,
Transforming this ancient anger
Into a beacon that guides others home.

THE BEAST BENEATH

This anger burns deep within,
a feral thing with yellowed teeth.
It prowls the caverns of my chest,
stalking between heartbeats.

I've built cages of composure,
wrought-iron smiles and pleasant nods.
Yet still it grows, fed by each slight,
each injustice swallowed whole.

By day, I am civility incarnate.
By night, I count my wounds like rosary beads,
feeling the beast's breath hot against
the thin membrane of my restraint.

They say anger is a secondary emotion,
a guardian of deeper hurts.
But what happens when the guardian
outlives what it was meant to protect?

When was the moment this creature
ceased being separate from myself?
Its claws now my hands,
its roar now my voice.

Perhaps there is wisdom in surrender—
not to let it consume me,
but to acknowledge its ancient power,
to harness what burns instead of being burned.

For this anger may destroy or create;
it may raze forests or forge steel.
The choice, I'm learning, was always mine:
to be the beast or its master.

INHERITANCE

This anger burns deep within,
A legacy I never asked to claim.
It arrived wrapped in my father's silence,
In my mother's tightened smile.

It speaks in the language of slammed doors,
Of dishes washed too aggressively,
Of love withheld like currency
Too precious to spend.

I've watched it move through generations
Like a ghost haunting bloodlines,
Shaping hands into fists,
Turning tongues to blades.

At family gatherings, I see it flicker
Behind the eyes of those who share my name—
A familiar flame passed down
More reliably than heirlooms.

I've sworn a thousand times
The chain would break with me.
Yet here it is again,
Rising like bile when least expected.

But what if this fire isn't meant to scorch?
What if, properly channeled,
It could warm instead of wound,
Illuminate instead of consume?

Perhaps true courage isn't dousing flames
But learning to carry them safely,
Transforming ancestral rage
Into the light that guides us home.

VOLCANIC

This anger burns deep within,
magma beneath seemingly stable ground.
Years of pressure building in silence,
each slight, each wound, another layer of heat.

I am Vesuvius before Pompeii,
a dormant threat misread as mountain.
Those who settle in my shadows
never feel the tremors beneath their feet.

How easy to mistake stillness for peace,
to confuse quiet with contentment.
Yet beneath this calm exterior,
molten fury shapes new landscapes.

Eruption is not a choice but an inevitability—
the earth must eventually speak its truth.
When it comes, it will not apologize
for the villages it buries, the lives it transforms.

And after the ash settles,
after the screams fade to whispers,
what remains will be unrecognizable:
fertile soil where nothing grew before.

For destruction and creation
have always been lovers entwined.
This anger burns deep within,
not to end worlds, but to birth them anew.

I am becoming the catastrophe
that will finally set me free.

ALCHEMY

This anger burns deep within,
a furnace where I've thrown
everything they said I should forget:
the casual cruelties, the betrayals,
the moments I made myself small.

For years, I tried to extinguish it,
doused it with forgiveness premature,
smothered it with forced smiles,
buried it beneath "letting go"
and "taking the high road."

But what if this fire was never the enemy?
What if it's the alchemist's flame,
transforming lead experiences
into gold-veined wisdom?

So I tend it now with purpose,
feed it not with hatred
but with fierce resolve.
I let it burn away what doesn't serve—
the doubt, the fear, the hesitation.

This crucible of rage refines me,
separates essential from dross.
In its heat, I am becoming
something tempered, something true.

The anger still burns deep within,
but I am no longer consumed.
Instead, I am the blacksmith,
hammering this white-hot emotion
into tools for building
the world I was denied.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text:
EMBER INHERITANCE

This anger burns deep within,
a legacy passed through generations—
my grandmother's clenched jaw,
my father's thunderous silence.

I carry it like an heirloom,
polished by years of injustice,
glowing hotter with each slight,
each dismissal, each casual cruelty.

Some days it warms me
when the world grows cold,
fuels my steps when exhaustion
threatens to claim victory.

Other days it consumes,
reduces reason to ash,
leaves scorched earth
where relationships once stood.

I've tried drowning it,
burying it beneath meditation
and forgiveness mantras,
but embers always survive.

Perhaps I've been fighting
the wrong battle all along.
This anger burns deep within
not as enemy, but as ally—

a sacred flame connecting me
to those who walked before,
who burned so I might light the way,
who raged so I might speak.

So I tend it now with care,
direct its heat toward justice,
let it forge something stronger
than the hatred that first sparked it.

VOLCANIC HEART

This anger burns deep within,
a magma chamber pressurized
by years of swallowing words
that deserved to be screamed.

The earth of my body cannot hold
what grows more volatile by day.
Tectonic plates of patience
shift beneath a cracking surface.

Scientists might measure
the tremors in my hands,
issue warnings about my eyes—
those windows to imminent eruption.

Who will evacuate in time?
Who will remain, believing
they can withstand what centuries
of compression have created?

I have become geography,
a landmark of destruction,
a cautionary tale told
to those who play with fire.

This anger burns deep within,
but depth is not permanence.
Even mountains are temporary
in the grand geology of time.

When the explosion comes—and it will—
I'll rain down everything unsaid,
cover the landscape in burning truth,
rewrite the topography of us.

And after, in cooling stillness,
new life will emerge from ash,
a fertile beginning born
from what could no longer be contained.

RIGHTEOUS FLAME

This anger burns deep within,
a torch held high against darkness,
illuminating injustices others
would prefer remain shadowed.

Call it divisive if you must.
Call it uncomfortable.
Truth has never concerned itself
with your convenience.

For every child who starves
while abundance rots elsewhere,
for every voice silenced
by the machinery of power,

for bodies broken by systems
designed to protect property
rather than humanity—
this flame grows higher.

Do not mistake passion for irrationality.
Do not confuse fury with weakness.
The most precise tools are forged
in the hottest fires.

When you ask for civility
in the face of suffering,
you are not requesting peace;
you are demanding surrender.

This anger burns deep within,
not as destruction but creation—
the necessary heat that transforms
inertia into movement,

complacency into revolution,
whispers into battle cries.
Without this sacred fire,
justice would remain forever cold.

QUIET INFERNO

This anger burns deep within,
unlike anything they expect.
No shouting matches or slammed doors—
mine is a silent combustion.

I smile at dinner parties,
laugh at appropriate moments,
while beneath my ribs
a universe collapses into itself.

How strange to carry such heat
yet be called "cold" by lovers
who cannot see past the stillness
to the supernova beneath.

I've perfected the art
of burning invisibly,
of reducing relationships to cinders
without striking a single match.

Sometimes I wonder
what would happen if I opened
the furnace door, just once,
let others feel what I contain.

Would they recognize it as anger
or mistake it for madness?
Would they finally understand
or simply be consumed?

This anger burns deep within,
a pilot light never extinguished,
heating every word I choose not to say,
every touch I withhold,

every exit made without explanation—
leaving others to wonder
how someone so seemingly serene
could leave such scorched earth behind.

ANCESTRAL EMBER

This anger burns deep within,
older than my own heartbeat—
an ember passed mouth to mouth
through generations of the oppressed.

My great-grandmother knew it
when they took her language,
when they renamed her children,
when they called theft "progress."

My grandfather tasted it
in segregated water fountains,
in the boss who called him "boy"
at sixty-three years of age.

My mother swallowed it
with every promotion denied,
every "compliment" on being articulate,
every clutched purse as she passed.

I was born into its glow,
cradled in its warmth,
taught its purpose before
I understood its power.

Do not tell me to let it go—
this is not mine alone to release.
It belongs to those who came before,
whose dreams fuel my determination.

This anger burns deep within,
a sacred inheritance I tend
not with hatred but with honor,
not with violence but with voice.

When justice finally arrives,
perhaps then we can let
this ancient flame become
the light by which we heal.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text:
EMBER

This anger burns deep within,
A furnace stoked by memory and sin.
It chars the edges of my softer thoughts,
Leaves ash where tenderness once was brought.

I carry coals beneath my tongue,
That sear the words I've left unsung.
My veins are rivers flowing red,
With molten rage that cannot shed.

How long have I been burning now?
So long the flames feel like a vow—
A promise made to never heal,
To keep this scorching pain so real.

Sometimes at night I see the glow
Reflected back, a crimson show
Of all the battles never fought,
The justice that I never sought.

Perhaps one day this fire will dim,
When reconciliation's hymn
Finally reaches through the smoke
That's wrapped around me like a cloak.

But until then, I'll burn and burn,
Let fury spin and twist and turn.
This anger burns deep within—
My punishment, my shield, my kin.

METAMORPHOSIS

This anger burns deep within,
A chrysalis of bitter flame.
I once feared its consuming heat,
The way it whispered my true name.

They said, "Let go, forgive, forget,"
