Like footprints in receding tide.

I shed my former selves like autumn leaves,
Each one necessary, each one temporary.
The five-year-old with scraped knees,
The twelve-year-old with trembling voice,
The sixteen-year-old with clenched fists—
All gone, yet somehow present in my marrow.

From childhood's hour I have not been
The same person twice.
Each morning brings a subtle rebirth,
Each sunset a microscopic death.

Perhaps this is the greatest freedom:
To recognize that what began in childhood
Need not define what follows.
To understand that being is not static,
But a river flowing ever forward,
Carrying fragments of its source
While constantly becoming something new—
A perpetual dawn breaking over different horizons.

QUANTUM CHILDHOOD

From childhood's hour I have not been
Certain of the boundaries between
Self and universe, dream and waking,
Memory and imagination's making.

Perhaps I exist in superposition—
Both child and not-child, simultaneously.
Schrödinger's youth in perpetual transition,
Observed and observer recursively.

The particles of my past scatter like light
Through the double-slit experiment of memory;
Wave-like when unwatched, particle-firm when I write
Them down, collapsing possibility.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Convinced of time's linear progression.
Perhaps all versions of myself exist
In parallel dimensions, infinite permutations
Of choices made and unmade, paths taken and forsaken.

The child I was reads books beneath a tree
While simultaneously I type these words;
The future self I'll become already sees
What lessons both of us have learned.

We are quantum entangled across decades,
Each affecting the other instantaneously.
In this way, childhood never truly fades—
It exists perpetually, simultaneously with me,
A superposition of being and becoming,
Of what was, what is, what might yet be.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'From childhood's hour I have not been'

responses.text:
SHADOW CHILD

From childhood's hour I have not been
As others were—I wore the mask
Of normalcy, a hollow task
While shadows danced behind my skin.

The laughter of the playground rang
Like foreign bells from distant shores,
I stood apart behind closed doors
Where silent specters softly sang.

My playmates were the dust and light
That filtered through the attic beams,
My confidants were twilight dreams
That only visited by night.

The years passed by like mourners do,
In solemn march, with heads bowed low,
While I watched life through window-glow,
A ghost among the living few.

From childhood's hour I have not been
What others thought a child should be—
Perhaps that's why I now can see
The beauty in what might have been.

OLD SOUL

From childhood's hour I have not been
A simple creature, young and wild.
Instead, the cosmos wrapped this child
In ancient wisdom, thick and keen.

My eyes held questions stars would ask,
My small hands reached for truths untold.
The playground games seemed dull and cold
When universes were my task.

The elders nodded, recognized
A fellow traveler in time—
This little form, this soul sublime
In youthful body disguised.

I walked between the worlds with ease,
A bridge of then and now and next.
Deciphering life's complex text
While others climbed on playground trees.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Just one thing—but a tapestry
Of lives remembered, souls set free,
And wisdom flowering within.

THE CHANGELING'S SONG

From childhood's hour I have not been
Of mortal flesh and human heart.
The faeries came and played their part—
They took what should have grown within.

They left me here with eyes of glass
That see beyond the veil of things,
With skin that hums when moonlight sings,
And feet that barely touch the grass.

My mother knew but dared not speak
Of how I changed that summer night.
How something in my gaze burned bright
With knowledge mortals cannot seek.

I move among you, strange and fair,
Collecting secrets, spinning tales.
My laughter echoes through the vales
Where mortal children never dare.

From childhood's hour I have not been
What you would call a human child.
I am the forest, strange and wild,
The space where other worlds begin.

NEURODIVERGENT

From childhood's hour I have not been
In sync with rhythms others feel.
The world too sharp, too loud, too real—
A cacophony beneath my skin.

While others played with effortless grace,
I cataloged the patterns found
In cracks of sidewalks, texture, sound—
The hidden order of this place.

They called it strange, this way I moved
Through life at angles all my own.
A different language, clearly shown
In how I loved and what I proved.

Now years have passed, and I can name
This difference that has shaped my days.
Not broken—just a different gaze
That sees what others cannot frame.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A standard-issue human mind.
Instead, a constellation, designed
To shine in ways yet unforeseen.

THE FORGOTTEN ROOMS

From childhood's hour I have not been
Able to recall those early days.
A fire took the home, the ways
We lived before the flames began.

The doctors say amnesia holds
Those memories behind a door
That I may never walk through more—
Those stories never to be told.

Sometimes in dreams, I catch a scent
Of mother's hair, or hear the sound
Of father's laughter, profound
But gone before it can cement.

I build a childhood from these scraps,
Constructing what I think was true.
A patchwork past in faded blue
That fills the mind's remaining gaps.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Complete in memory or thought.
Instead, a mystery self-wrought
From ashes of what might have been.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'From childhood's hour I have not been'

responses.text:
FROM SHADOWS CAST

From childhood's hour I have not been
As others were—I wore the mask
Of normalcy, a hollow task,
While shadows danced behind my skin.

The laughter of the playground games
Rang hollow in my listening ears,
I catalogued their joys and fears
But could not feel them just the same.

I watched the world through frosted glass,
A spectator to life's bright play,
Collecting moments day by day
Like pressed flowers that would not last.

Perhaps in this strange separateness
I found a gift—to see what's true,
To paint with words what others knew
But never named in their distress.

From childhood's hour I have not been
What others wished, but something more—
A vessel for the ancient lore
Of souls who walk between, unseen.

BECOMING

From childhood's hour I have not been
Confined to what was given me—
Instead I forged identity
From broken parts and dreams unseen.

The narrow paths laid at my feet
I questioned, left, and made my own,
Through wilderness and fields unknown
Where expectation found defeat.

My hands have built and torn apart
The structures meant to hold me in.
My voice has learned to shed its skin
And speak the language of my heart.

The child they thought that I would be
Dissolves like morning mist in sun.
The self I choose has just begun
To rise and claim its liberty.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Defined by others' hopes or fears.
Instead I've gathered through the years
The courage to begin again.

MEMORY'S TIDE

From childhood's hour I have not been
Anchored to solid shores of time.
Memories like sea-foam climb
And fall away—what might have been

Blurs with what was. Did I once run
Beneath a canopy of stars?
Or did I dream those avatar
Versions of myself, undone

By morning's light? The carousel
Of half-remembered lullabies
Spins backward when I close my eyes—
A music box beneath the spell

Of fading notes. The photographs
Show someone with my eyes and name
Playing some childhood game
I can't recall. Who was I? What paths

Connected then to now? The thread
Unravels as I try to hold
Those gossamer moments, stories told
About a child who might be dead

Or never was. From childhood's hour
I drift, untethered to that shore,
Both less and somehow more
Than memories have the power
To contain.

EARLY FROST

From childhood's hour I have not been
Permitted innocence or play.
Responsibility held sway
Where wonder should have bloomed, unseen.

While others gathered childish things—
Bright treasures, scrapes, and carefree days—
I learned to navigate the maze
Of adult worries, what life brings

When it arrives too soon. My hands
Grew callused not from climbing trees
But holding family by degrees
Together, following demands

That no child should be asked to bear.
I mothered siblings, managed pain,
Balanced accounts through loss and gain,
And learned that life is rarely fair.

Yet in the margins of those years,
In stolen moments, brief and few,
A different child sometimes grew—
One who could laugh through unshed tears.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A child at all—but now, at last,
I grant myself what in the past
Was taken. Now, I begin.

WILD ROOTS

From childhood's hour I have not been
As tame as garden flowers grown
In neat-trimmed rows, their futures known—
I've been the wildflower, unforeseen,

That cracks the sidewalk, breaks the rule,
Refusing boundaries that constrain.
I've turned my face toward the rain
And found in storms my truest school.

The oak remembers being small,
Encased within its acorn shell,
Yet carries in its rings the swell
Of seasons rising, seasons' fall.

So too, within my human form,
I carry all I've ever been—
The sapling and the seed within,
The lightning strike, the weathered storm.

The river does not mourn its source
Though far from mountain springs it flows;
It simply travels, grows, and knows
Its nature changes on its course.

From childhood's hour I have not been
One single self, but many-faced—
A wild thing that can't be placed
In categories, boxed or seen
Complete.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'From childhood's hour I have not been'

responses.text:
FROM SHADOWS BORN

From childhood's hour I have not been
As sunlight dancing on the wall,
But shadow-cast and twilight-thin,
A whisper where the dark stars fall.

My cradle rocked by phantom hands,
My lullabies the raven's call,
I walked between two distant lands—
One mortal, one beyond the pall.

The children laughed in summer fields,
Their joy a language never mine.
I gathered stones where others gathered yields
And traced the moon's forbidden sign.

My mother saw it in my eyes,
The ancient knowing, old as time.
She crossed herself against surprise
When winter bloomed at my bedside.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A creature of the common day.
My blood runs cold, my thoughts unseen,
My heart beats in a different way.

So judge me not for standing apart,
For finding beauty in decay.
The darkness was my art from start—
This separateness, my only play.

UNCOMMON LIGHT

From childhood's hour I have not been
Confined to ordinary sight.
While others saw what should be seen,
I witnessed worlds of strange delight.

They called it odd, this gift of mine,
To sense the patterns others missed—
The sacred geometry divine
In spider's web and morning mist.

My teachers frowned at questions asked,
My parents worried through the night.
But stars above my window passed
And blessed me with uncommon light.

I learned to hide these second eyes,
To nod and smile at proper times,
To tuck away my truth in lies
And save my soul for secret rhymes.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Like those who walk the simpler road.
But now I know what others glean—
That difference is a precious load.

So let me shine my stranger's flame
Across the darkness vast and wide.
For being other is no shame
When light and shadow walk beside.

THE CHANGELING'S TRUTH

From childhood's hour I have not been
Of mortal flesh and human bone.
The faeries took what should have been,
And left me here to walk alone.

My mother knew but wouldn't speak
Of how I never cried or ailed.
How moonlight made my skin grow weak
While iron made my courage failed.

I learned their ways, these human folk,
Their curious rules and strange demands.
But when the ancient music woke,
I felt the pull of distant lands.

The forest calls when no one hears,
With voices sweet as summer rain.
They promise end to human years
And passage home to court again.

From childhood's hour I have not been
What parents hoped when I was born.
A changeling child, caught between
Two worlds that leave me equally torn.

So should you meet a child whose eyes
Reflect the stars with too much light,
Be gentle with their strange replies—
They're merely lost in endless night.

FORGOTTEN SELF

From childhood's hour I have not been
Able to recall my face.
The mirror shows a stranger's grin,
A puzzle I cannot replace.

My memories like scattered glass,
Sharp fragments cutting when I try
To piece together what has passed—
The who and when and how and why.

They tell me stories of a youth
The doctors say belongs to me.
But photographs speak half a truth;
The rest remains a mystery.

I learn myself through others' eyes,
Collecting clues from what they say.
'Remember when' becomes my disguise,
As I nod and pretend each day.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Complete within my fractured mind.
The person I was might have been
Someone I'll never truly find.

Yet still I build this life anew
From borrowed parts and present tense.
Perhaps what matters isn't who
I was, but who I'm becoming hence.

METAMORPHOSIS

From childhood's hour I have not been
Static, fixed, or firmly bound.
I've shed my skin like serpents when
The old self falls upon the ground.

First caterpillar-small and slow,
I inched through early timid days.
Then chrysalis of teenage glow
Where transformation set ablaze.

A thousand deaths I've died since then,
A thousand births I've undergone.
The woman, scholar, lover, friend—
Each version rising with the dawn.

The child who played with paper boats
Now navigates through deeper seas.
The voice that sang with simpler notes
Now harmonizes complex keys.

From childhood's hour I have not been
The same soul twice from year to year.
Like rivers flowing, never seen
The same way when you reappear.

So do not ask me who I am
As if the answer could stand still.
I'm moment, motion, diagram—
A being becoming, learning still.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'From childhood's hour I have not been'

responses.text:
SHADOWS OF FORMER SELVES

From childhood's hour I have not been
As others were—I wore my thoughts
Like armor against the world's disdain.
My memories, fractured kaleidoscopes,
Shimmering with what might have been.

I walked through hallways of laughter
A ghost among the living, breathing
Yet never quite belonging.
The clock's hands moved differently for me,
Each tick a reminder of otherness.

From childhood's hour I learned to craft
A self from silence, to build cathedrals
From whispers others couldn't hear.
I collected moments like fallen stars,
Holding their light when darkness came.

Perhaps this separation was a gift—
This vantage point of the eternal outsider.
For in the spaces between belonging,
I found the universe within myself,
Vast and uncharted, terrifying and beautiful.

From childhood's hour I have not been
What they expected, what they wanted.
Instead, I became this—
A constellation of contradictions,
A poem written in invisible ink,
Waiting for the right light
To finally be read.

BECOMING

From childhood's hour I have not been
Confined to single shape or form.
Instead, I've flowed like water,
Adapting, changing, growing beyond
The boundaries they tried to draw.

Where others saw limitation,
I discovered flight. My difference
Not a burden but a blessing,
A kaleidoscope of possibilities
Where they saw only straight lines.

From childhood's hour I have danced
To rhythms only I could hear,
Creating symphonies from silence,
Painting with colors that exist
Beyond the spectrum's end.

I thank the universe for making me
Unable to fit their molds—
For in breaking free, I found
The true shape of my soul,
Wild and wonderful and wholly mine.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Like anyone else, and now I know
That was my strength all along.
This divergent path has led me home
To the person I was always meant to become—
Unfinished, evolving, gloriously free,
A constant revolution of self.

SEASONS OF THE SELF

From childhood's hour I have not been
In sync with summer's carefree dance.
While others bloomed in golden light,
I felt the autumn in my bones,
Leaves falling before their time.

Winter came to me so early—
Frost etching patterns on my thoughts
When others still played in warmth.
I learned to find beauty in bareness,
In the stark honesty of leafless trees.

The seasons of my life inverted,
Running counter to the calendar's truth.
I aged backward into spring,
Finding renewal where others found ending,
Buds breaking through snow-covered ground.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A creature of expected timing.
My blossoms open under stars
When others sleep; my roots grow deepest
In soil others find too harsh.

Perhaps we each contain all seasons,
Simultaneously winter and summer,
And wisdom lies in recognizing
That time moves differently for each soul.
My childhood's hour still unfolds—
Eternal autumn, perpetual spring,
A weather system uniquely mine.

DREAMSCAPES

From childhood's hour I have not been
Tethered to reality's thin thread.
Instead, I've walked through doorways
Hidden in the corners of ordinary rooms,
Where clocks melt like Dalí's imagination.

My playground: a landscape where
Umbrellas rain upward from clouds
Made of crystallized memories,
Where trees grow from my fingertips
And stars speak in forgotten languages.

I've conversed with shadow-selves
Who wear my face but not my fears,
Swimming through oceans of consciousness
Where mermaids are made of manuscript pages
And ships sail on currents of collective dreams.

From childhood's hour I have dwelled
In the space between heartbeats,
Collecting impossible moments—
A library of experiences
That defy categorization.

Reality, that fragile construct,
Bends and bows to imagination's whim.
Perhaps I never left the dreamscape
Of childhood's boundless hour,
Where time expands like the universe,
And I remain, gloriously untethered,
A perpetual dreamer in waking life.

ECHO CHAMBER

From childhood's hour I have not been
The person they insisted I become.
From childhood's hour I have not seen
The world through lenses they provided.

From childhood's hour I crafted masks,
Each one a fragment of expected selves.
From childhood's hour I asked questions
That had no answers, only echoes.

From childhood's hour I collected sounds—
The silence between spoken words,
The whispers of doubt behind confidence,
The rhythm of heartbeats accelerating in fear.

From childhood's hour I memorized patterns—
How to fold myself smaller,
How to expand beyond recognition,
How to transform pain into something beautiful.

From childhood's hour I have been becoming,
A continuous act of creation and destruction,
Building a self from the ruins of expectations,
Planting gardens in the cracks of should-have-beens.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Anything but this evolving entity,
A palimpsest of identities,
A chorus of contradictions,
A poem perpetually being written,
Never quite finished,
Never quite begun.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text:
COUNTING SHADOWS

My God, how many are my fears!
They multiply like evening stars,
Uncountable as grains of sand,
As waves that crash on distant shores.

By daylight they are whispers low,
By night they grow to thunderous roars.
They crowd the corners of my mind,
And slip beneath my bedroom door.

I fear the future's foggy path,
I fear the choices left unmade,
I fear the love I've yet to give,
I fear the debts I've left unpaid.

Yet somewhere in this trembling heart,
A quiet courage starts to bloom.
For counting fears means knowing self—
In naming them, I find my truth.

My God, how many are my fears!
But greater still, my will to rise,
To face each shadow, one by one,
Beneath the vast, forgiving skies.

SACRED TREMBLING

My God, how many are my fears!
They kneel like penitents in prayer,
Each one a whispered revelation,
A thorn-crown that I'm forced to wear.

The fear of failing those I love,
Of wasting breath on empty days,
Of finding, at the journey's end,
I've wandered down the wrong pathways.

You taught us faith could move the mountains,
But what of mountains in the mind?
The steep-faced cliffs of doubt and dread
That leave the soul so far behind?

Perhaps these fears are not my foes
But teachers sent to guide me home,
To strip away false certainties
And leave the sacred truth alone.

My God, how many are my fears!
Yet in their midst, I find You there,
Not banishing what makes me tremble,
But holding space for my despair.

MODERN TERRORS

My God, how many are my fears!
They ping like notifications now,
Digital dread in blue-light glow,
The endless scroll, the furrowed brow.

I fear the climate's rising tide,
The melting ice, the burning trees.
I fear the hatred spreading fast,
Through fiber optic arteries.

I fear connection without touch,
And knowledge without wisdom's grace.
I fear we've built a faster world
But lost our human sense of place.

The ancient fears of death and pain
Now joined by anxious modern kin—
Of relevance, of missing out,
Of where we end and screens begin.

My God, how many are my fears!
They've evolved with our technology.
Yet still we search for timeless peace
Amid the new complexity.

NOCTURNE OF ANXIETY

My God, how many are my fears!
They visit in the hollow night,
When clock-hands crawl like wounded things
Across the face of fading light.

Insomnia, my old companion,
Lays out my fears like tarot cards—
Each one a possible tomorrow,
Each one a wound with fresh-made scars.

The ceiling bears my projections,
A cinema of worst outcomes.
My heartbeat is the soundtrack to
This symphony of phantom drums.

I count my breaths instead of sheep,
I count the hours till dawn breaks through.
I count the ways that I might fail,
And all the things I cannot do.

My God, how many are my fears!
Yet morning always comes again,
And in its gentle amber light,
My giants shrink to grains of sand.

THE INVENTORY

My God, how many are my fears!
I've catalogued them one by one,
A curator of private terrors,
A collector of things to run from.

Fear #1: The ocean's depth,
Its vastness where no light can reach.
Fear #17: Being forgotten,
Like footprints washed from evening beach.

Fear #23: That love is temporal,
A shooting star, not fixed in place.
Fear #46: That I've misunderstood
The purpose of this human race.

I've labeled them in careful script,
I've stored them in my memory's vault.
Some days I add a fresh new fear,
Some days I let an old one halt.

My God, how many are my fears!
But in this strange accounting work,
I've found that naming gives me power—
The inventory where courage lurks.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text:
MY INVENTORY OF SHADOWS

My God, how many are my fears!
They multiply like autumn leaves,
Scattered across the landscape of my mind,
Each one a brittle testament to what I've lost.

I count them in the darkness—
Fear of abandonment: a childhood specter,
Fear of failure: my constant companion,
Fear of time: the thief that never sleeps.

My God, how many are my fears!
They build their nests in my ribcage,
Laying eggs that hatch into panic,
Wings beating against my chest at 3 AM.

Some fears wear business suits and schedules,
Others don hospital gowns and test results.
Some speak in the voices of those I love,
Others in the silence of an empty room.

Yet—what if these fears are not my enemies?
What if each one marks a boundary
Between what I am and what I might become?

My God, how many are my teachers!
Each terror a lantern illuminating
The contours of what I hold most dear,
The geography of a heart learning to be brave.

LITANY IN THE STORM

My God, how many are my fears!
They circle like vultures waiting
For the moment my strength falters.

Fear of the shadow beneath clear water,
Fear of the pause between heartbeats,
Fear of words I cannot unsay,
Fear of hands I cannot hold again.

Lightning splits the sky—
I count: one-one-thousand, two-one-thousand,
Measuring the distance between safety and destruction.

My God, how many are my fears!
They've become a rosary I finger in the dark,
Each bead a different dread,
Each prayer a desperate bargain.

The wind tears at the windows.
Inside, I build fortresses of blankets,
Trenches of pillows, barricades of books.
All futile against the storm within.

Yet somewhere in this tempest,
A small voice whispers:
Even this will pass. Even this.

My God, how many are my fears—
But greater still, this stubborn spark
That refuses to surrender to the dark,
This flickering hope that dawn will come.

EVOLUTIONARY EVIDENCE

My God, how many are my fears!
Biologically programmed, my ancestors' gift—
A survival mechanism gone haywire
In this world of artificial light and endless scrolling.

Fear: a chemical cascade,
Amygdala firing, cortisol flooding,
Preparing for tigers that never come,
Battles that exist only in my mind.

My God, how many are my fears!
Anxiety wears the face of evolution,
A prehistoric blessing turned modern curse.
Fight-or-flight with nowhere to run.

I am a walking museum of terrors,
Each exhibit carefully preserved:
Rejection (social death to tribal beings),
Failure (starvation in resource-scarce environments),
Unknown (predators lurking beyond firelight).

Yet in this same body that trembles,
Lives the courage of a species
That crossed oceans on fragile crafts,
That touched fire and made it friend,
That looked at stars and built equations.

My God, how many are my strengths!
Forged in the very furnace of these fears,
Tempered by the same evolutionary hand
That taught me both caution and curiosity.

NOCTURNE FOR THE SLEEPLESS

My God, how many are my fears!
They visit at 3 AM, punctual as mourners,
Dressed in their finest catastrophes,
Bearing gifts of what-ifs and should-haves.

Insomnia maps their constellations
Across the ceiling—connect-the-dot disasters,
Each one glowing with terrible possibility.

I've named them all, these midnight companions:
Regret sits heaviest on my chest,
Uncertainty whispers in my ear,
Mortality counts my heartbeats like coins.

My God, how many are my fears!
They've worn grooves in my thoughts,
Rivers carving canyons through bedrock,
Deeper with each sleepless night.

The clock's red numbers march forward—
3:27, 4:15, 5:02—
Witnesses to this nightly surrender.

Yet sometimes, between one breath and the next,
A strange peace arrives unannounced.
Not the absence of fear, but something alongside it:
The quiet knowledge that I have survived
Every single one of my darkest nights, so far.

My God, how familiar are my fears.
And still, the morning always comes.

CARTOGRAPHY OF DREAD

My God, how many are my fears!
I've mapped them like continents:

To the North: the Frozen Wastes of Isolation,
Where words freeze before reaching other ears,
And silence builds its crystal palaces.

To the East: the Rising Shadows of Time,
Where moments slip through fingers like sand,
And the sun always sets too soon.

To the South: the Burning Plains of Judgment,
Where eyes become arrows piercing skin,
And every gesture is misinterpreted.

To the West: the Drowning Seas of Loss,
Where loved ones become horizons,
Always receding, never reachable.

At the Center: a tiny island called Self,
Surrounded by these treacherous waters,
A small flame flickering against the elements.

My God, how many are my fears!
Yet here I stand, cartographer of my own terrors,
Drawing dragons but still sailing forward.

Perhaps the map itself is power—
To name the beast is to begin taming it.
To chart the depths is to find the shallows.

My God, how valuable are my fears!
Compass points guiding me home to myself.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text:
COUNTING SHADOWS

My God, how many are my fears!
They multiply like autumn leaves,
Scattered by winds across the years,
A harvest no one ever reaps.

At night they gather, dark and deep,
A parliament of silent dread.
They stand in corners while I sleep,
And whisper things I've left unsaid.

I've named them all—Abandonment,
Failure, Loss, and Mockery too.
Each morning brings fresh torment,
And doubts that pierce me through and through.

Yet counting fears becomes a prayer,
A rosary of trembling beads.
In numbering what I cannot bear,
I find the strength my spirit needs.

For You who counted every star
And know each sparrow when it falls,
Surely see how frail we are,
How fear like shadow-chains enthralls.

My God, how many are my fears!
But greater still Your mercy proves—
For in the counting, You draw near,
And fear dissolves in perfect love.

CARTOGRAPHY OF DREAD

My God, how many are my fears!
I've mapped them on my skin—
constellations of anxiety,
latitude lines of panic,
meridians of midnight terrors.

They colonize territories
I once claimed as joy.
They plant flags in the soft earth
of what used to be confidence.
They redraw borders daily.

My hands shake when holding
this atlas of apprehension.
Pages torn and coffee-stained,
dog-eared at the worst passages,
the ones I return to compulsively.

Sometimes I wonder if gods collect fears
like children collect seashells—
each one unique, each one
a small architecture of protection
that failed its original owner.

Perhaps my fears are not mine alone
but ancient inheritances,
DNA-deep, passed through generations
like family heirlooms no one wants
but everyone receives.

My God, how many are my fears!
But today I leave this map unfolded
on the table for the wind to take,
and step outside without its guidance,
lost and, finally, found.

ARITHMETIC OF ANXIETY

My God, how many are my fears!
One plus one plus one plus one,
like raindrops on a window pane,
they race each other to oblivion.

Didn't You promise somewhere
between Genesis and Revelation
that we needn't be afraid?
Yet here I am, calculating catastrophes.

I fear the phone call after midnight,
the lump discovered in the shower,
the pink slip on a Friday afternoon,
the text that never comes.

I fear the silence between heartbeats,
the pause before diagnosis,
the space between your goodbye
and my acceptance of it.

I fear I've wasted time on fearing,
a serpent eating its own tail,
a perpetual motion machine
powered by what-ifs and if-onlys.

But what if fear itself is holy?
What if trembling is a form of worship?
Perhaps in acknowledging my terror,
I confess my mortal fragility.

My God, how many are my fears!
Yet somehow in the counting,
they begin to lose their power—
each named becomes a prayer.

LITANY OF NIGHT TERRORS

My God, how many are my fears!
They stalk like wolves between the trees
of my consciousness, yellow-eyed,
hungry for the tender parts of me.

I fear the future's uncertainty,
its blank face staring back at me.
I fear time's relentless current,
dragging youth beneath its surface.

I fear love's inevitable conclusion—
either abandonment or death.
I fear mediocrity, that quiet failure
that comes without drama or notice.

I fear I am unworthy of salvation,
that my soul is too stained for grace.
I fear my prayers hit the ceiling
and scatter like startled birds.

I fear that all my fears are justified,
that intuition speaks the truth,
that disaster waits around each corner,
patient as a spider in its web.

Yet something in me rises still—
a defiant flame against the dark.
Perhaps courage isn't fearlessness
but fear that's learned to pray.

My God, how many are my fears!
Count them with me, hold them up to light.
Let us name them one by one
until they shrink before Your gaze.

EVOLUTION OF DREAD

My God, how many are my fears!
They've evolved sophisticated camouflage,
adapted to my growth, my changing landscape.
Childhood's monsters under beds
transformed to monsters in my head.

I fear the climate's slow collapse,
the way we poison what sustains us.
I fear the hatred brewing in our streets,
the easy violence of our words.
I fear we've forgotten how to love.

I fear the silence of the universe,
its vast indifference to our pain.
I fear the echo chamber of my mind,
where doubts grow louder with each passing day,
and faith feels fragile as a cobweb.

Yet in this evolution, something beautiful—
my fears have taught me compassion.
For who can face their own abyss
and not feel tenderness toward others
trembling at their personal edges?

Perhaps our fears are not meant to vanish
but to transform, like caterpillars,
into something that can fly
despite the weight of knowing
how far there is to fall.

My God, how many are my fears!
But count also my moments of courage,
for they are born from the same source—
this wild, vulnerable heart
that dares to keep beating.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text:
COUNTING SHADOWS

My God, how many are my fears!
They multiply like autumn leaves,
Falling in patterns I cannot predict,
Covering the ground I once walked freely.

Fears of failure wrap cold fingers
Around my throat at midnight,
While fears of loss hover like ghosts
In corners of rooms I've yet to enter.

My God, how many are my fears!
I've counted them like sheep,
But they breed in darkness,
Giving birth to anxieties I cannot name.

Fears of time—its swift passage,
Its merciless accounting.
Fears of love—its fragility,
Its power to unmake me.

You who shaped the cosmos,
Who set stars in their courses,
Look upon these trembling hands.
See how they reach for certainty
And grasp only air.

My God, how many are my fears!
Yet in this wilderness of dread,
A small voice whispers:
Count instead your breaths,
Count your heartbeats,
Count the moments fear retreated,
Leaving courage in its wake.

Perhaps then,
I might count my blessings too.

INVENTORY OF DREAD

My God, how many are my fears!
They crowd my mind like hungry wolves,
Each one with teeth sharper than the last.
I catalog them in the dark:

Fear #1: The phone ringing past midnight
Fear #17: The shadow beneath medical charts
Fear #23: The silence after I've spoken my truth
Fear #46: The way love looks before it leaves

I measure my life in the spaces between terrors,
Brief respites where I pretend normalcy,
Where I shop for groceries and smile at strangers,
As though my pockets aren't heavy with dread.

Some mornings I wake to find new fears
Have birthed themselves while I slept,
Tiny monstrosities with familiar faces
Wearing the masks of those I've loved.

I've built altars to my anxieties,
Offered sacrifices of sleep and peace.
What devotion this is—this constant attention,
This endless genuflection to what might happen.

My God, how many are my fears!
And yet, and yet—
Today I counted something else:
One breath. Another. Another.
A revolution in small inhales.

THE ECOLOGY OF ANXIETY

My God, how many are my fears!
They bloom like strange flowers
In the greenhouse of my mind—
Some poisonous, some merely bitter.

In spring, the fear of inadequacy
Spreads its purple tendrils across
The landscape of potential.
By summer, rejection's thorny vines
Have claimed the southern exposure.

The fear of death is perennial,
Returning with each season,
Its roots deeper than memory,
Its scent familiar as my own skin.

I've become a reluctant gardener,
Learning which fears require pruning,
Which must be uprooted entirely,
Which—surprisingly—might bear fruit
If given proper attention.

Some nights I walk this garden,
Moonlight revealing the silhouettes
Of anxieties I've cultivated for years.
I touch their leaves, recognize their shapes,
Call them by their scientific names.

My God, how many are my fears!
Yet in this strange ecosystem,
I've discovered something unexpected:
How courage grows in fear's shadow,
A symbiotic relationship
I'm only now beginning to understand.

CELESTIAL CARTOGRAPHY

My God, how many are my fears!
I've mapped them like constellations,
Connecting dot to desperate dot
Across the night sky of my consciousness.

There—see that cluster?
The Trembling Hand, astronomers call it,
Composed of seven failures and one
Unreturned love from 2009.

And there, near the horizon,
The Shattered Mirror galaxy,
Where all possible futures fracture
Into infinite, terrifying possibilities.

I've spent lifetimes studying
This personal cosmology,
Charting the movement of anxieties
Across the heavens of my days.

But lately I've noticed something:
Between these constellations of dread,
Vast spaces exist—dark matter
Filled with potential and wonder.

Perhaps I've been looking
Through the wrong end of the telescope.
Perhaps these fears are not as massive
As they appear in my limited field of vision.

My God, how many are my fears!
But also—how infinite the universe
Where they are but distant stars,
Beautiful and terrible and impossibly small.

LITANY AGAINST UNCERTAINTY

My God, how many are my fears!
I wear them like amulets against joy,
Pendants of protection from disappointment.
I've become superstitious about hope.

Fear has its own language—
A grammar of avoidance,
A vocabulary of worst-case scenarios,
Dialects of doubt spoken fluently at 3 AM.

I've become multilingual in anxiety,
Fluent in the subjunctive tense of what-if.
I conjugate verbs of catastrophe
And decline nouns of impending doom.

When did I learn to predict rain
From the slightest gathering of clouds?
When did I start carrying umbrellas
On the clearest of days?

My shadow stretches longer than my body,
Casting darkness over moments
That haven't yet arrived.
I live in anticipation of earthquakes
On stable ground.

My God, how many are my fears!
But today, just today,
I'm learning a new language:
The present tense of breathing,
The active voice of living anyway,
The radical syntax of now,
Where fear is just another word
I don't need to translate.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text:
THE ABYSS GAZER

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Wild and fathomless as midnight tides.
There's knowledge there no sane mind should hold,
Secrets of darkness, ancient and cold.

They warned me not to venture so deep
Into the woods where shadows don't sleep.
Yet here I stand, frozen in his gaze,
As reality begins to phase.

He speaks in tongues that crawl through my mind,
Leaving sanity several steps behind.
His fingers twitch like spiders on strings,
Orchestrating unspeakable things.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
But now I see what truly there lies:
Not madness, but clarity so pure
It breaks the mind that cannot endure

The truth of our fragile existence,
The cosmic joke of our resistance.
For in his gaze, I finally see
The madman staring back is me.

BELOVED CHAOS

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Wild with love that knows no boundaries.
Rational thought scattered to the wind,
Like autumn leaves in a hurricane's spin.

They call it madness, this devotion of his,
This all-consuming, breathless, reckless bliss.
But I've grown fond of the chaos he brings,
The unpredictable joy in simple things.

His love doesn't whisper—it thunders, it roars,
Breaking windows, kicking down doors.
Conventional romance was never for me;
I'd rather drown in this electric sea.

When he holds me, galaxies collide,
And all my careful walls crumble inside.
Perhaps I'm mad too, for loving the storm,
For finding comfort where others find harm.

So let them judge what they cannot understand—
This beautiful madness, uncharted land.
For when he looks at me with a madman's eyes,
I see the universe in its rawest disguise.

THROUGH THE LOOKING GLASS

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Not with hatred, but with recognition.
I am his mirror, his window, his truth;
The world has labeled his visions 'uncouth.'

Behind hospital walls for thirty years,
Medicated smiles masking ancient fears.
I'm just an intern with a clipboard shield,
Yet something in his gaze will not yield.

He speaks of colors beyond our spectrum,
Dimensions folded like cosmic origami.
"They're not delusions," he whispers to me,
"Just truths your eyes aren't ready to see."

Each Tuesday I return, despite my dread,
To hear the prophecies swirling in his head.
Colleagues warn me not to get too close,
Yet I'm drawn to what his madness knows.

Today he touched my hand and I saw it too—
The veil of reality split clean through.
He looks at me with a madman's eyes,
And now those same eyes are slowly becoming mine.

THE DIAGNOSIS

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
My father, once steady as ancient oak,
Now lost in corridors of his mind
Where familiar faces become smoke.

Alzheimer's, they say. A clinical term
For the theft of memory, self, and time.
But science cannot measure what's lost
When recognition fades like distant chime.

Sometimes clarity breaks through the fog,
A lighthouse beam in his stormy night.
"Is that you?" he asks, and I hold my breath,
Praying this moment of knowing stays bright.

But it passes, as surely as seasons change,
And madness—if that's what this is—returns.
Not the raving kind that fiction portrays,
But the quiet confusion as recognition burns.

I hold his weathered hands in mine and think
Of all the wisdom those hands once shared.
He looks at me with a madman's eyes,
But I look back with love, unimpaired.

THE PROPHET OF FIFTH STREET

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
The homeless prophet of Fifth Street,
Cartography of suffering etched on his face,
Cardboard sign: "THE END BEGAN YESTERDAY."

I used to hurry past, coins tossed from distance,
Safe inside my bubble of normalcy.
Until the day the stock market collapsed,
And wildfires devoured the western coast.

Now I sit beside him on concrete thrones,
Two kings watching empires crumble.
"You see it now," he says, not asking.
I nod, humbled by his patience.

He was never mad—just tuned to frequencies
The rest of us had muted for comfort.
The static of impending collapse,
The white noise of societal denial.

We share stale bread and yesterday's headlines.
He points to patterns I'd never noticed before.
"Madness," he laughs, "is seeing truth
And pretending everything's fine."

He looks at me with a madman's eyes,
And I finally understand:
The truly insane were those of us
Who called clarity madness.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text:
He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Wild galaxies swirling in those midnight pools.
I should run, I know this, yet I stand
Rooted by fascination, by the terrible beauty
Of chaos unleashed in human form.

His fingers twitch like dying moths,
Mouth forming words only he can hear.
I wonder what visions plague him,
What colors exist in his fractured world
That mine, so orderly, cannot contain.

Perhaps there's wisdom in his madness,
Truth in the gibberish he whispers.
Perhaps we are the blind ones,
Sane and sensible and missing everything
That matters beyond our careful boundaries.

He reaches for me, trembling.
I should scream but instead
I take his hand and cross the threshold,
Leaving behind what I once believed,
Entering his universe of beautiful terror.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And I recognize my father again, briefly,
Before the fog of dementia swallows him whole.
Those eyes that taught me constellations,
That crinkled when he laughed at Sunday dinners,
Now burn with confusion's fever.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
The doctor said it would progress this way.
Clinical terms for the theft of memory,
For the slow dissolution of the man
Who carried me on his shoulders,
Who now doesn't know my name.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Sometimes afraid, sometimes angry,
Sometimes with a terrible, vacant peace.
I hold his weathered hands and whisper
Stories he once told me, returning
The gift of worlds he gave when I was small.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And sometimes, just sometimes,
I catch a glimmer of recognition,
A fleeting ember of the love
That illness cannot fully extinguish.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Electric, dangerous, divine.
Across the gallery his gaze
Transfixes me like butterfly to pine.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
The artist whose canvas bleeds
With colors science cannot name,
Whose paintings satisfy unspoken needs.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
I've read the tabloids, heard the tales:
The slashed wrists, the asylum stays,
The genius that both saves and fails.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And offers me his paint-stained hand.
"Be my muse," he whispers low,
"And I'll show you worlds you'll understand."

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
I should decline, maintain control.
Instead I nod and follow him,
Prepared to trade my safety for my soul.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Across the battlefield where brothers lie
In pools of crimson, still as stone.
His uniform, once proud, now torn and stained,
Matches mine in its grim decoration.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
This enemy soldier, this mirror of myself,
Both of us pawns in games of kings,
Both of us killers, both of us killed inside.
His bayonet trembles; mine does too.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And I wonder if he sees the same in mine,
The horror of what we've become,
The innocence we sacrificed to flags and anthems,
The humanity we buried with each fallen comrade.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And slowly lowers his weapon.
I do the same. Without a word,
We turn and walk in opposite directions,
Deserters from the armies of the insane.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
my lover in the throes of passion,
rational thought abandoned like clothing
scattered across our bedroom floor.
How strange that we call this madness,
this most ancient of dances,
this temporary death of the thinking mind.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
and I welcome the contagion,
let myself be infected with the fever
that makes monsters of philosophers,
children of cynics, believers of doubters.
I too go mad in his arms,
my carefully constructed self unraveling
like a sweater caught on a nail.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
and in them I see the truth:
we are all just pretending at sanity,
wearing masks of reason over animal hearts.
In these moments of beautiful madness
we are most honest, most real,
most alive in our glorious, chaotic humanity.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text:
BEYOND THE VEIL

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Wild, unfettered, galaxies swirling in those depths.
I see universes collapsing, stars being born,
Truths that mortals were never meant to know.

Those eyes, windows to chaos incarnate,
Hold secrets that crawl beneath reality's skin.
What horrors has he witnessed beyond the veil
That left his mind fractured like shattered glass?

I stand transfixed, unable to look away
As his gaze peels back my layers of pretense.
Perhaps the true madness lies in my fear,
In society's need to label and contain.

For in those eyes I see freedom untamed,
A mind unshackled from convention's chains.
What we call madness might be clarity,
A vision too pure for our filtered world.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And I wonder if I'm the one who cannot see,
Blinded by the comfortable darkness
Of a sanity that keeps us small.

LOVE'S DELIRIUM

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Burning with passion's untamed flame.
Devoted beyond reason, beyond sense,
A love that borders on sacred insanity.

Across the crowded room, his gaze finds mine,
Electric, unwavering, consuming.
Others speak of healthy love, of balance,
But what do they know of this divine possession?

In his eyes, I am everything:
Goddess, salvation, obsession, muse.
The world may call it madness
To love with such ferocious intensity.

Yet I find myself drawn to that chaos,
To the beautiful danger of being wanted
With every atom of another's being.
Isn't that what poets have always praised?

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And I surrender to that sacred delirium,
For in his unhinged devotion
I have found the love I always craved.

Rational hearts may never understand
The exquisite pleasure of being worshipped
By one who has abandoned reason
At the altar of love's sweet insanity.

FRACTURED REFLECTIONS

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
My father, once solid as stone,
Now lost in dementia's labyrinth,
Searching for memories scattered like leaves.

Those eyes that taught me constellations,
That crinkled when he laughed at my jokes,
Now dart about, suspicious, confused,
Seeing threats in empty corners.

I am a stranger in those eyes,
Sometimes a thief, sometimes a child.
Rarely his daughter, rarely myself.
We exist in parallel realities.

I hold his trembling hands and wonder
What landscapes unfurl behind those eyes.
What terror must it be to lose yourself
One fragment at a time, one face, one name?

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
But in brief moments of clarity,
Love still breaks through the fog,
A lighthouse beam in stormy darkness.

I meet his gaze and hold it steady,
Anchor to his drifting ship,
Willing to navigate these waters
No matter how strange the shore.

THE ORACLE

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
But what mortals call madness
Is merely sight beyond the veil.
The gods have touched his mind.

I approach with offerings: salt, wine, questions.
His gaze pierces centuries,
Travels between worlds like smoke.
What prophecies curl behind those dilated pupils?

The village fears him, leaves food
At the threshold of his mountain cave,
Never lingering when the wild laughter
Echoes down the slopes at midnight.

But I have always been drawn to mystery,
To the wisdom that dwells in darkness.
So I climb the winding path,
Braving ridicule and warnings.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And speaks my unborn children's names,
Describes the manner of my death,
Whispers secrets I've told no one.

I transcribe his ravings on parchment,
Deciphering cosmic truths from gibberish.
For in madness lies divinity,
And in chaos, the patterns of creation.

THE AWAKENING

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
They said, backing away in fear.
But I had finally seen the truth
Of our collective delusion.

The skyscrapers are prison bars,
The smartphones are our shackles,
The money we chase, worthless paper,
The news we consume, carefully crafted lies.

Of course my eyes seem wild now,
Unchained from comfortable blindness.
How else would one look
After seeing the puppet strings?

They medicate the visionaries,
Label the truth-speakers as insane.
Anyone who questions too deeply
Must be corrected, contained, controlled.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
They whisper as I pass by.
But slowly, others begin to see
What I've known all along.

One by one, eyes open wide,
Horror and wonder intermingled
As reality's thin veneer dissolves.
The madness spreads like freedom.

Perhaps tomorrow they'll say,
"She looks at us with prophet's eyes."

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text:
THE ABYSS GAZES BACK

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
wild, unblinking pools of obsidian,
reflecting nothing but the void within.
I stand transfixed, unable to flee
from this creature who once was human.

They say madness is contagious,
leaping like electricity between minds.
I feel it now, crackling at my edges,
eating away at reason's thin veneer.

His laughter echoes in empty corridors,
fracturing the silence like broken glass.
I wonder what demons dance behind those eyes,
what horrors carved such chasms in his soul.

Perhaps we are all one moment away
from falling into that endless dark.
One tragedy, one loss, one betrayal
from becoming the monster in the mirror.

As dawn breaks through dusty windows,
I realize I've been staring at my reflection
all night, my own madman's eyes
gazing back with terrible recognition.
The line between sanity and madness
is thinner than I ever dared believe.

DIVINE MADNESS

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
but oh, what beautiful madness this is!
A rapture that sets the world aflame,
transforming mundane moments into eternity.

His gaze holds galaxies being born,
super-novas of passion unrestrained.
Conventional wisdom falls away
like autumn leaves in a wild wind.

They warned me of his chaos,
his unpredictable nature, his storm.
But they never mentioned how his tempest
would awaken every dormant cell in my body.

In his madness, I find liberation.
In his wildness, I discover truth.
What is sanity but a prison
built by those too afraid to feel?

So let him look at me with madman's eyes.
Let his untamed spirit call to mine.
I would rather burn in this glorious fire
than freeze in the cold comfort of reason.

Perhaps this is what the poets meant
by divine madness, by sacred frenzy.
Perhaps some souls must break their chains
to show the rest of us how to fly.

THROUGH THE LOOKING GLASS

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
kaleidoscope irises shifting colors
like quantum particles refusing to be pinned down.

Reality bends around him,
warping like a Salvador Dalí painting.
Clocks melt. Doors lead nowhere.
Stairs spiral into impossible geometries.

His words tumble out in riddles:
"The raven flies at midnight
through walls that never existed."

I should be frightened, yet
I find myself following him down,
down into the rabbit hole of his perception,
where logic is merely a suggestion
and impossibility blooms like desert flowers after rain.

In this twisted wonderland of his making,
butterflies speak ancient languages,
mountains wear crowns of upside-down cities,
and the moon conducts symphonies of color.

Perhaps madness is merely a different lens,
a cracked mirror reflecting truths
too strange for ordinary vision.

I take his outstretched hand
and abandon the tyranny of reason.
Sometimes one must go mad
to see the world as it truly is.

THE ENCOUNTER

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
I freeze in the aisle of the corner store,
fluorescent lights buzzing overhead
like the thoughts surely swarming in his mind.

Coffee spills over my trembling fingers.
The cashier doesn't notice our silent standoff,
too busy with lottery tickets and cigarettes.

I recognize him from local news clips:
"Escaped Patient Still At Large."
Those eyes had stared from my television screen
for three nights running.

His hospital gown is gone now,
replaced by clothes that hang wrong,
like they belonged to someone else.
Perhaps they did.

I should scream. I should run.
Instead, I notice how his hands shake worse than mine,
how fear lives in those so-called madman's eyes.

The monster of the headlines
is just a man, lost and afraid,
searching for something familiar
in a world turned hostile.

"It's okay," I whisper, surprising myself.
"I won't tell anyone."

He blinks, humanity flickering back,
a brief candle in the darkness.
Then he's gone, bell chiming his exit,
leaving me to wonder who truly is mad in this broken system.

THE SAGE'S DISGUISE

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
or so the village claims of the hermit
who dwells where forest meets mountain,
where shadows speak and stars sing lullabies.

I sought him despite their warnings,
climbing twisted paths through thorn and stone,
drawn by rumors of his strange wisdom.

"Madman!" they called him, this exile
who rejected their comfortable certainties,
who spoke of dreams and distant dimensions
as if they were more real than bread and coin.

At his cave mouth, I stand trembling.
He emerges, wild-haired, bark-clothed,
fixed with that infamous gaze that pierces souls.

Yet in those eyes I see no madness -
only clarity so absolute it burns.
He sees beyond our careful illusions,
beyond the walls we build and call reality.

"You came seeking answers," he says,
"but first you must unlearn your questions."

The true madness, I realize with sudden shock,
lies in our blind adherence to false patterns,
our desperate clutching at comfortable lies.

In a world of sleepwalkers,
the awakened man appears insane.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text:
SHATTERED MIRROR

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Fractured galaxies spinning in those depths,
Where reason drowns in wild tides
And reality bends until it breaks.

I see myself reflected, distorted,
A funhouse version I barely know.
In his gaze, my certainties contorted,
Seeds of doubt begin to grow.

What if madness is contagious?
What if sanity's the thinnest veil?
His laughter echoes, outrageous,
As my own foundations start to fail.

He whispers truths I cannot bear,
Secrets hidden in plain sight.
The world's illusions stripped bare,
Revealed in his unfiltered light.

Perhaps he's seen beyond the pale,
Glimpsed what lurks behind the curtain.
While we, the sane, cling to our frail
Construct of order, falsely certain.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And day by day, heartbeat by beat,
I find my own gaze mirrors his,
My transformation now complete.

We stand together at the edge,
Two madmen seeing clear at last.
The world below, a broken pledge,
As we step forward, free, unmasked.

VISIONARY

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
But what is madness if not sight unbounded?
Those eyes that pierce conventional disguise,
See truths that leave the ordinary confounded.

Van Gogh saw starlight dance and swirl,
Nietzsche heard the cosmos sing.
Blake witnessed angels in this mortal world,
Madness and genius, entwined like spring.

I stand transfixed before his gaze,
As if before a storm of pure creation.
Lightning thoughts in brilliant blaze,
Unleashed beyond all limitation.

Society may lock away such minds,
Label them broken, dangerous, or strange.
But in their chaos, wisdom finds
The spark that sets the world aflame with change.

Those eyes hold visions I long to see,
Worlds undiscovered, paths untrod.
In that wild stare lives liberty,
The freedom to remake, destroy, and laud.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And I am drawn into their fire,
Where inspiration never dies
And mundane thoughts expire.

Perhaps true madness is to look away,
To choose the comfort of the known,
Rather than brave the disarray
Where genius seeds are sown.

CAREGIVER

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
My father, lost in labyrinths of mind,
Where memories scatter like autumn leaves,
And present moments leave no trace behind.

I remember when those eyes held love,
Recognition, wisdom, gentle mirth.
Now they search my face as if from above,
A stranger's gaze, despite shared birth.

Some days, brief lucidity returns,
A flicker of the man I used to know.
But like a candle that too quickly burns,
It fades, leaving only afterglow.

I feed him, bathe him, brush his thinning hair,
Read stories that once he read to me.
The reversal of our roles laid bare,
A cruel joke of mortality.

Yet in those wild, unfocused eyes,
I sometimes glimpse a different kind of truth—
A freedom from convention's ties,
A second, strange and unencumbered youth.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And I look back with patience, grief, and grace.
Love persists though reason flies;
Compassion fills the empty space.

This is not the ending we would choose,
But in its pain, there's something pure:
Even as his mind continues to confuse,
My heart's devotion remains sure.

DREAMSCAPE ENCOUNTER

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Across the shifting landscape of my dream,
Where clocks melt down and ravens speak in rhymes,
And nothing is exactly as it seems.

His pupils spiral into endless wells,
Drawing me through corridors of night.
Each chamber holds impossible hells
And paradises blooming out of sight.

We dance on ceilings made of glass,
Beneath us, stars instead of floor.
"Reality," he laughs, "will pass,
But dreams, dear heart, endure."

His fingers trace equations in the air,
Solving mysteries I never knew existed.
Logic bends around his wild-haired stare,
As natural laws become twisted.

I should feel fear, but wonder takes its place,
As boundaries dissolve like morning mist.
Time suspends within this strange embrace,
A moment endless as the abyss.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And offers me a key of ancient bone.
"Unlock the doors you've kept disguised,
And find the truths you've always known."

I wake with sunrise warming my face,
His gaze still burning in my mind.
Madness and wisdom interlaced,
A gift from slumber, unconfined.

THE SANE OBSERVER

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Or so they say, those judges of the normal.
But I have seen the method in his guise,
The reason draped in behaviors deemed informal.

For what is madness but nonconformity?
A refusal to swallow comforting lies?
While crowds embrace collective deformity,
He stands apart, clear-sighted and wise.

They call him crazy for questioning wars,
For challenging systems that crush the weak.
For opening forbidden, necessary doors,
And giving voice to truths none dare speak.

I've watched him weep for dying forests,
While businessmen calculate profit from ash.
I've seen him rage at injustice's harvests,
While politicians offer platitudes and trash.

The world spins madly toward its demise,
Celebrating consumption, ignoring collapse.
Yet he's the madman, because he defies
The collective delusion, the comfortable traps.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
And in their depths, I recognize
A sanity too sharp, too rare, too true
For a world determined to misconstrue

The difference between madness and sight,
Between comfortable blindness and painful light.
Perhaps we need more madmen's eyes
To save us from our civilized lies.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

responses.text:
REFLECTION

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
wild galaxies swirling in obsidian pools,
where reason drowns and chaos rules.
I see myself reflected, fractured there,
a kaleidoscope of my own despair.

He speaks in riddles, laughs at ghosts,
finds humor in what hurts me most.
Yet in his shattered mirror gaze,
I glimpse the truth through madness' haze:
we're not so different, he and I.

Perhaps we all wear masks so tight,
calling it sanity in morning light,
while madmen brave enough to see
the world's true face, its cruelty,
are labeled broken, cast aside.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
and I wonder which of us truly lies.

ASYLUM WALLS

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
glazed windows to a burning house.
I am the doctor, he the patient,
but sometimes I question which is which.

His fingers trace invisible patterns
on sterile walls. They speak to him
in languages I cannot hear,
yet sometimes I strain to listen.

They say he murdered three in cold blood,
but when he weeps, it's for a butterfly
that beat its wings against his window.
The gentleness in those hands haunts me.

At night, I dream his eyes follow me home,
and my reflection shows his face, not mine.
He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
and somewhere deep, I recognize the stare.

LOVER'S FRENZY

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
consumed by fire that never dies,
desire untamed, a raging sea,
that threatens to devour me.

His fingertips trace constellations
across my skin. His whispered incantations
transform my body into holy ground.
In his wild worship, I am found.

They warned me of his dangerous ways,
his storm-tossed heart, his feverish gaze.
"He'll burn too bright," they prophesied,
"and leave you ashes at his side."

But I've grown tired of tepid love,
of measured steps and cautious touch.
Give me the madman's sacred trust,
his boundless faith, his reckless lust.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
and I am finally, gloriously alive.

PROPHET OF THE WASTELAND

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
this prophet of the coming storm.
Amidst the city's gleaming towers,
he preaches doom in tattered robes.

Each day I pass him on my way to work,
briefcase in hand, necktie perfectly straight.
He points at me and howls of oceans rising,
of skies on fire, of nature's fierce revenge.

Today, as sirens wail and screens flash warnings,
as the horizon darkens with unnatural clouds,
I stop before him, my certainties crumbling.

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
now clear as morning, steady as stone.
"You see it now," he whispers, "what I've always seen."
And in this moment, I wonder who was blind.

MIRROR DANCE

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
my father, lost in memory's maze.
He calls me by my mother's name,
reaches for a woman thirty years gone.

The nurses say it's just disease,
neurons misfiring, synapses frayed.
But when he dances with empty air,
I see her shadow twirling there.

Sometimes he speaks of visitors
who slip through walls when night falls.
"They're waiting," he insists with clarity
that startles me. "Just beyond the veil."

Last night, he gripped my hand with sudden strength.
"They're beautiful," he whispered, "don't be afraid."
He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
but perhaps he's simply seeing more than I.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text:
DIVINE GRATITUDE

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That ripples through creation's stream,
For morning light that breaks the night,
And stars that through the darkness gleam.

Blessed be Thy hand that guides
The sparrow's flight, the eagle's soar,
That paints the sunset's fiery hues
And leads the tides upon the shore.

Blessed be the breath that fills
The lungs of every living thing,
From mighty oaks that touch the sky
To newborn babes whose cries now ring.

Blessed be the love that flows
From heart to heart, a sacred tie,
That binds us in communion sweet
Beneath Thy vast eternal sky.

Blessed be the gift of tears
That cleanse the soul when sorrows call,
For in their wake, joy's tender shoots
Rise stronger, greener, standing tall.

Blessed be the quiet peace
That settles when the day is done,
When we reflect on mercies given
And count our blessings, one by one.

Blessed be Thou, Divine Creator,
For joy that transcends mortal pain,
For hope that springs eternally,
Like flowers after gentle rain.

EARTH'S BOUNTY

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
O ancient Earth, O pulsing soil,
Your seasons turning, endless wheel,
Your patient growth, your quiet toil.

I've felt your joy in forest depths
Where sunlight dapples emerald floors,
And in the ocean's thunderous roar
That crashes wild on distant shores.

I taste your joy in summer fruit,
Sweet nectar bursting on my tongue,
And hear it in the thrush's song
As dawn breaks and the day is young.

You offer joy in mountain peaks
That pierce the clouds with stony grace,
In desert blooms that briefly flame,
Defiant in that barren place.

You whisper joy through autumn leaves
That dance and spiral to the ground,
And in the silence after snow
When all the world makes not a sound.

Blessed be your wild diversity,
Your creatures finned and furred and feathered,
Your patient cycles, death to life,
All elements together tethered.

I stand amid your vast display,
A humble witness, small and brief,
Yet filled with wonder, filled with thanks,
For joy that surpasses all belief.

INNER LIGHT

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
Not some distant deity above,
But the sacred self that dwells within,
The quiet center of my love.

I bless the joy of knowing me,
The landscapes of my inner world,
The valleys deep, the mountains high,
The hidden treasures there unfurled.

I honor joy in solitude,
In moments when I stand alone,
Connected to my truest self,
At home within my skin and bone.

I celebrate the joy of growth,
Of shedding what no longer serves,
Of breaking patterns, breaking chains,
Of honoring my soul's reserves.

I thank the joy of boundaries drawn,
Of saying yes, of saying no,
Of choosing paths with conscious heart,
Of letting come and letting go.

I praise the joy of healing wounds,
Of integration, becoming whole,
Of reconciling scattered parts
Into one symphonic soul.

Blessed be the journey inward,
The labyrinth of self-discovery,
The recognition that all along,
The joy I sought was found in me.

FRACTURED LIGHT

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
                                 fragments
                                           scattered
                                                     like
                                                          light

through prisms breaking white into
ROYGBIV spectrum dance

Joy not singular but plural: joys
joys joys joys joys joys joys

Be blessed in the 3 AM laughter that
wakes neighbors & makes no apologies

Blessed in unexpected text messages
from people you thought had forgotten

Blessed in the first sip of coffee
the last page of a perfect novel
the accidental harmony when strangers
hum the same tune on a subway platform

Blessed be the joy in finding
a forgotten twenty in winter coat
the way your body remembers
how to swim after decades
the precise moment when pain ends

Blessed be Thou—whoever, whatever Thou art:
god particle cosmic dust ancestor memory
microbiome collective unconscious
random chance beautiful accident

For all the joy: the measurable
the ephemeral the inexplicable
the stubborn persistent defiant joy
that insists on existing

even when
                 (especially when)
                                          we have every
                                                              reason to despair

THE CAROUSEL

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
I whispered this as we stood waiting,
My daughter's hand tight in my own,
The carousel before us rotating.

Her eyes were wide with wonder then,
Five years old and fearless, wild,
The painted horses rising, falling,
Calliope music sweet and mild.

Blessed be the moment when she chose
A golden steed with sapphire mane,
When I lifted her small body up
And saw her fear transform to gain.

Blessed be the turning world that day,
The simple pleasure, pure and bright,
The cotton candy sticky fingers,
The summer air, the fading light.

Blessed be the photograph we took,
Now yellowed, creased, upon my shelf,
A talisman of perfect joy
Before she grew to know herself.

Twenty years have passed since then,
My daughter travels distant lands,
But sometimes still I feel the phantom
Pressure of her tiny hands.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
Of watching someone that you love
Become exactly who they are—
No greater gift from stars above.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text:
DIVINE GRATITUDE

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That fills my mortal frame with light,
For golden mornings that deploy
Their armies against the night.

Blessed be Thy gentle hand that gives
The rain that quenches thirsty ground,
The breath through which each creature lives,
The silence and the sacred sound.

Blessed be Thy wisdom, vast and deep,
That orchestrates the cosmic dance,
The mysteries that make us weep,
The grace in every circumstance.

Blessed be Thou for pain transformed,
For lessons learned through bitter tears,
For hearts once cold, now fully warmed
By love that conquers all our fears.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
Unmerited, yet freely given,
A treasure nothing can destroy,
A glimpse of earth as it is in heaven.

EARTH'S BOUNTY

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
Of wildflowers dancing in the breeze,
Of sunlight dappling through the trees,
Of birdsong—nature's sweet employ.

Blessed be the mountain's ancient face,
The ocean's restless, rhythmic tide,
The desert's vast, unbroken space,
The forest where the shadows hide.

Blessed be the changing of the seasons,
Autumn's fire, winter's rest,
Spring's renewal, summer's zest—
Each brings joy for countless reasons.

Blessed be the soil beneath my feet,
The stars that guide my way at night,
The moon that makes the darkness sweet,
The dawn that paints the world with light.

Blessed be Thou, O Earth, my home,
For all the joy you freely share,
Whether I stay or whether I roam,
Your beauty finds me everywhere.

BELOVED

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
Your smile has etched into my soul,
For hands that mend what time would spoil,
For making broken pieces whole.

Blessed be the morning light that plays
Across your face while you're asleep,
The quiet strength of patient days,
The promises we choose to keep.

Blessed be the laughter we have shared,
The tears we've wiped from each other's eyes,
The burdens lightened because we cared,
The truth that cuts through all disguise.

Blessed be the mundane moments too—
Dishes washed and stories read,
Ordinary days spent loving you,
Ordinary words that need be said.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
Of loving someone through the years,
A happiness no time can destroy,
A light that shines through doubts and fears.

THE ANATOMY OF JOY

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
That ephemeral substance
We cannot touch yet feel so deeply,
Cannot bottle yet drink so freely,
Cannot see yet recognize instantly.

What is this joy but a rebellion?
A mutiny against the expected gloom,
A conspiracy of nerves and chemicals,
Of memories and anticipations,
Of sunlight striking water just so.

Blessed be the architecture of delight,
The invisible scaffolding of gladness,
The mathematics of a sudden smile,
The physics of a heart expanding.

Joy: that uninvited guest
Who arrives precisely when needed,
Who leaves footprints of gratitude,
Who transforms ordinary moments
Into extraordinary memories.

Blessed be Thou—whoever, whatever Thou art—
For this inexplicable gift,
This rebellion against darkness,
This proof that we are more
Than mere survivors of time.

DESPITE EVERYTHING

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That persists like weeds through concrete,
That finds me even on the days
When getting out of bed seems impossible.

Blessed be the stubborn happiness
That refuses to surrender to circumstance,
The unexpected laughter that bubbles up
From the depths of a wounded heart.

Blessed be the moments of reprieve—
A child's unguarded smile,
A song that breaks through the static,
A memory that hasn't been poisoned by loss.

Blessed be the defiant beauty
That blooms in war-torn lands,
The kindness that survives cruelty,
The hope that outlives despair.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That comes not despite the darkness
But somehow because of it—
A light more precious for the shadows it pierces,
A warmth more cherished for the cold it dispels.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text:
DIVINE GRATITUDE

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That filters through the morning light,
For dappled shadows on the grass
And birdsong breaking through the night.

Blessed be Thy gentle hand
That guides the rivers to the sea,
That paints the sunset's fiery glow
And sets the caged spirit free.

Blessed be Thou for tears that cleanse,
For laughter shared with those we love,
For moments when we understand
The silent whispers from above.

Blessed be Thou for broken paths
That led to vistas unforeseen,
For winter's rest and spring's rebirth,
For all that is and might have been.

Blessed be Thou for memories
That warm us when the world grows cold,
For hope that burns like steady flame
As stories of our lives unfold.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
The known, unknown, the large and small,
The sacred gift of being here,
To witness life, to feel it all.

UNEXPECTED BLESSINGS

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
I never thought to find
In broken china on the floor,
In plans left far behind.

Blessed be the thunderstorm
That canceled careful schemes
And pushed me toward the shelter where
I found my dearest dreams.

Blessed be the bitter cup
I thought I couldn't bear—
It taught my tongue to savor sweet
And made my spirit dare.

Blessed be the empty rooms
Whose echoes taught me space
To fill my lungs with deeper breath
And move with wilder grace.

Blessed be the darkest nights
That showed me stars exist
And how the moon can sculpt the world
In silver and in mist.

Blessed be the questions left
Unanswered through the years—
They keep me walking forward still,
Beyond my childish fears.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
Disguised as something less.
In everything I once called loss,
I've found a strange success.

THE ORDINARY SACRED

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
that hides in plain sight:
the steam rising from morning coffee,
the cat's slow blink of trust,
the way sunlight catches dust motes
dancing in otherwise empty corners.

Blessed be the small salvation
of fresh sheets on the bed,
the first bite of ripe summer fruit,
the text message that says
someone is thinking of you.

Blessed be the unexpected laughter
that bubbles up during grief,
the kindness of strangers,
the way music can transport you
across decades in three notes.

Blessed be the body's quiet persistence—
lungs that fill without instruction,
heart that beats without permission,
hands that remember how to create.

Blessed be the joy found
in what we've been taught to ignore:
the weeds breaking through concrete,
the imperfect symmetry of our faces,
the silent spaces between words.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
that requires no grand occasion,
no milestone or monument—
just the raw miracle
of being present
in this ordinary moment
that will never come again.

THROUGH SEASONS OF THE SOUL

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That courses through the veins of time—
Eternal current, sacred flow,
Beneath the rhythm and the rhyme.

When winter grips my barren soul
And frost encases hope in ice,
You plant the seeds of coming spring
Beneath the snow of sacrifice.

When summer burns with questions fierce
And drought makes faith a brittle thing,
You send the cooling rain of doubt
To make the deeper roots take wing.

When autumn strips the gilded leaves
And bares the branches of my pride,
You show how beauty learns to fall
And how surrender turns the tide.

Through every season, every change,
Through every death and each rebirth,
You weave the golden thread of joy
That gives our suffering its worth.

So blessed be Thou for all the joy
That often comes disguised as pain—
The alchemist who turns our lead
To gold we could not else attain.

COSMIC GRATITUDE

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
Not just the easy kind that floats
Like dandelion seeds on breeze,
But joy that's earned through fire and stone.

Blessed be the universe
That forged my atoms in star-death,
That scattered elements across
The void until they formed this breath.

Blessed be the ancient light
Still traveling from distant suns
To touch my face with morning gold—
A journey billions of years long.

Blessed be the miracle
Of consciousness from carbon made,
The strange emergence of a mind
That contemplates its own cascade.

Blessed be the brief window
Between nothing and nothing again—
This temporary collection
Of stardust aware of itself.

Blessed be the vast darkness
That makes each pinpoint of light
A rebellion against entropy,
A temporary victory song.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
Of simply being here at all—
The mathematical improbability
Of existence—the greatest blessing of all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

responses.text:
DIVINE WHISPERS

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
that cascades like mountain streams,
carrying light through darkened valleys
where doubt once planted its seeds.

Blessed be the morning dew
that glistens on spider's lace,
the silent sermon of existence
preached without words or haste.

Blessed be the child's laughter,
uncomplicated and pure,
ringing through time's cathedral
like bells that forever endure.

Blessed be the storm's passing,
the rainbow's promised arc,
reminding weary travelers
that light follows every dark.

Blessed be the stranger's kindness,
unexpected, undeserved,
revealing Your face in places
where I hadn't thought to search.

Blessed be the bread that breaks,
the wine that fills the cup,
the humble gifts of sustenance
that daily lift us up.

Blessed be the night sky's vastness,
