each mile a verse in this journey,
each moment a stanza of becoming.

And when night falls across the tracks,
you'll remember how it began—
that lingering excitement,
that early morning departure.

THRESHOLD CROSSING

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
The clock's hands have conspired with fate,
pushing us into the inevitable forward.

We are all passengers of circumstance,
carrying baggage heavier than suitcases—
regrets packed neatly beside hopes,
fears tucked between folded dreams.

The station we leave is yesterday,
its platform already fading into mist.
The rails beneath us are time itself,
unyielding, direct, predetermined.

Sometimes I wonder if we ever truly arrive
or if life is simply one continuous departure,
a series of stations glimpsed briefly
through windows smudged with rain and breath.

The excitement lingers like perfume
in an empty room, a ghost of anticipation.
We chase it across counties and countries,
across decades and decisions.

Perhaps wisdom is learning to savor
the journey's gentle sway, the rhythm
of wheels against tracks, the symphony
of lives intersecting at crossings.

For now, I press my forehead to glass
and watch the world transform
as we hurtle forward, always forward,
into the station of becoming.

THE 6:15 TO SOMEWHERE

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
Maria clutches her ticket, knuckles white,
thirty-seven years of sameness left behind.

The conductor doesn't know she's escaping.
He punches holes in cardstock, not stories.
He can't see how her husband's words
have punched holes in her for decades.

She wears her good dress, blue with white flowers,
the one he always said made her look fat.
Today it feels like armor, like permission,
like the sky somehow folded into fabric.

The train lurches forward, momentum
a promise she whispers to herself.
Through the window: her town shrinking,
her future expanding with each mile.

In her purse: two hundred dollars,
her mother's locket, a paperback novel
with a cracked spine, and the letter
from her sister in Colorado.

"Come," it had said. "Start again."
Three weeks it sat beneath her mattress
before courage found her, before
excitement lingered longer than fear.

As morning light paints the fields gold,
Maria smiles, orders coffee, and watches
the tracks behind her disappear
into the vanishing point of yesterday.

IRON MIGRATION

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
Metal beast awakening, stretching its spine
along the curved horizon where earth meets sky.

The train breathes steam like ancient dragons,
its whistle calling to birds who answer
with songs of their own migrations.
We are not so different, they seem to say.

Through valleys carved by patient rivers,
past mountains that measure time in millennia,
the train threads itself through nature's tapestry—
a modern serpent in an ageless garden.

The trees bow slightly in its passing,
their leaves applauding with gentle rustling.
Wildflowers by the tracks have adapted
to bloom in the rhythm of scheduled departures.

Passengers gaze out windows, unaware
they travel through arteries of the earth,
a collective pulse moving across landscapes
that witnessed the first wheel, the first journey.

The sun climbs higher, casting shadows
that race alongside like eager companions.
The excitement of departure transforms
into the steady communion of belonging.

We are all travelers on this living planet,
moving together through space and seasons,
connected by rails and roots and rivers—
all of us carried forward by ancient momentum.

DEPARTURE/ARRIVAL [SOUND POEM]

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.

Click-clack tick-track
whisper-wish steel-squeal
forward-thrust dust-must

Tunnels swallow daylight whole
only to birth it seconds later
chew-spit-chew-spit-chew

Voices fragment into syllable confetti
scattered across passenger cars
str/an/gers be/com/ing ne/igh/bors

Windows frame the world in staccato:
field-house-field-tree-field-river-field
cinematic jump cuts at sixty miles per hour

The rhythm rocks bodies into
unintentional synchronicity
heartbeats aligning with wheel-turns

Ding! Announcement bells
Dong! Crossing signals
Whoosh! Passing landscape
Clink! Coffee cups in dining car

Distance dissolves into sound-time
rather than mile-time
three songs until the next stop
two conversations until home

The excitement lingers in ears long after
arrival renders departure obsolete
echo-memory-echo-memory-echo

You can hear
You can hear
You can

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.'

responses.text:
RAILWAY DREAMS

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs,
steam rising like ghostly fingers
reaching for still-sleeping stars.

Platform goodbyes hang suspended,
frozen waves and misty eyes,
while somewhere distant tracks are bending
toward horizons we idealize.

The rhythm builds beneath steel wheels,
a heartbeat churning into day,
carrying futures yet unsealed
and pasts we've tucked away.

Strangers share these wooden seats,
their stories folded in their laps,
some heading home, some in retreat,
some chasing pins on mental maps.

The whistle cuts the dawning air,
a promise slicing through the doubt.
The world outside begins to flare
as darkness slowly filters out.

You can hear the excitement start to linger
in every clickety-clack refrain,
in every dreamer, every singer
whose journey starts again.

So many lives in motion now,
so many hearts in transit too,
all wondering what awaits somehow
beyond the morning dew.

DEPARTURE POINT

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
I am leaving who I was behind—
that version of myself who feared the dark.

The station shrinks to memory,
a photograph that's slowly fading out.
The landscape blurs to watercolor scenes;
my past dissolves without a sound.

Each mile marks transformation,
each tunnel passed, a shedding of old skin.
The passengers beside me never knowing
I'm not the same as who I've been.

The tracks ahead fork endlessly,
possibilities in iron and rust.
I count the heartbeats in the engine's roar,
the rhythmic clattering I've come to trust.

Somewhere between departure and arrival,
between the person left and who's to come,
I find myself suspended in the middle,
both finished and not yet begun.

You can hear the whispers of becoming
as morning light paints gold across the plain.
The world awakens to its own renewal
as I awaken on this train.

MORNING DEPARTURE

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
The conductor's call, a final bell,
echoing through sleep-fogged hearts.

The grinding gears and hissing steam
form symphonies of forward motion.
The platform's edge—a shoreline now—
recedes like tides pulled to ocean.

Clackety-clack, the wheels confess
secrets to the waiting rails.
Windows frame a fleeting world
of misty fields and fence-post nails.

The scent of coffee drifts between
the rustle of unfolded maps.
Strangers' shoulders, briefly touched,
as through the cars the ticket man taps.

Outside, the dawn breaks reluctantly,
spilling watercolors on the sky.
Inside, conversations bloom like flowers,
tentative at first, then opening wide.

Bridges, tunnels, whistle-stops—
each moment measured in the passing view.
The world awakens with each mile
as possibilities come into view.

You can hear tomorrow's promise humming
in the spaces between each breath.
The journey itself becomes the destination
as distance grows from what we've left.

THE LEAVING

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
She stands alone on platform three,
one suitcase and a trembling heart.

Twenty-two years in this small town—
each brick and lamppost knows her name.
But cities call with siren songs
of chances wild and untamed fame.

Her mother's tears still wet her scarf,
her father's hug still warms her bones.
The ticket clutched between her fingers
is the first choice truly all her own.

The engine pulls against its weight,
a metaphor she understands.
The effort needed to break free
from gravity's demanding hands.

Through windows streaked with others' prints,
she watches childhood disappear.
The water tower, the corner store,
all shrinking as her path grows clear.

You can hear the future's invitation
in the rhythm rocking her to new.
The passenger beside her smiles,
recognizing journeys brave and true.

By nightfall she'll be someone else—
a stranger in a stranger place.
But morning's train has taught her this:
beginnings come at leaving's grace.

TRANSITORY STATES

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs—
a collective exhalation of metal and mankind,
a punctuation mark between what was and what might be.

Time behaves differently here,
stretched across the parallel universe of tracks.
We exist between destinations,
neither here nor there but gloriously in-between.

The world outside becomes a blur of intention,
landscapes rushing toward their own becoming
while we sit suspended in perpetual motion,
contradictions wrapped in human form.

How strange to move forward while sitting still,
to be both passenger and cargo,
to surrender control while choosing direction,
to be alone among the many.

The train whistle pierces philosophical veils—
a reminder that even thoughts must bow to physics,
that every journey is both literal and figurative,
that distance is measured in more than miles.

You can hear the universe's ancient question
echoed in each turn of steel on steel:
Where are you going? Why? And who
will you be when you arrive?

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.'

responses.text:
IRON RHYTHM

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
Steel wheels spark against ancient tracks,
horizons unfolding like paper maps.

Passengers clutch tickets, precious passes
to somewhere new, somewhere bold.
The carriage rocks a gentle lullaby
for dreams too large to be told.

Cities shrink to miniature models,
mountains rise to meet the dawn.
The whistle cuts through morning fog—
a clarion call to those journey-drawn.

With each mile marker passing by,
possibilities multiply like stars.
You feel it in the trembling floor,
this freedom that now is ours.

The excitement lingers, a faithful ghost,
long after departure's swift kiss.
In the rhythm of rails and the promise of paths,
lies the joy of becoming, pure bliss.

ECHOES OF DEPARTURE

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
Leaving behind footprints on platform dust,
and fragments of who we used to be.

I remember your scarf, crimson against winter,
the way your breath clouded between us,
final words suspended in frozen air—
artifacts of a time now passing.

The station clock surrenders another minute.
Memories dissolve like sugar in rain.
What remains is the hollow percussion
of wheels against tracks, diminishing.

How strange that departures can feel like arrivals
at the borders of unfamiliar selves.
The landscape blurs through tear-smudged windows,
history rearranging in the distance.

Someday we'll look back at this leaving
with the gentle wisdom of traveled souls,
understanding how excitement lingers
long after the journey has transformed us all.

PASSENGERS

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
The businessman straightens his tie,
rehearsing pitches under coffee-scented breath.

Two seats over, a student thumbs through notes,
her future bright as the window's rising sun.
An elderly couple hold weathered hands,
returning to where their story first begun.

The conductor moves with practiced grace,
punching tickets, nodding knowing smiles.
He's witnessed countless lives in transit,
measuring existence in collected miles.

A mother soothes her restless child,
whispering promises of grandma's embrace.
A writer captures strangers in her notebook,
stitching moments into narrative lace.

Connected briefly by shared direction,
each heart carries its own destination.
As wheels churn toward separate fates,
the carriage hums with quiet expectation.

CHRONOS EXPRESS

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
Time itself becomes the passenger,
sliding along tracks of cosmic design.

Are we not all travelers on rusted rails,
pulled forward by unseen engines?
Yesterdays stacked behind like abandoned stations,
tomorrows appearing through mist-shrouded curves.

The universe expands with each rotation,
axles turning in perfect synchrony
with planetary bodies and stellar dust—
all of us bound to this grand trajectory.

What is a life but a brief connection
between terminals of birth and ending?
The excitement lingers in the space between,
where meaning blooms in fleeting seconds.

Listen closely to the rhythm of existence,
the steady click-clack of moments passing.
This journey needs no destination
when the miracle is simply that we're traveling at all.

DAWN DEPARTURE

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
The screech of metal awakening metal,
the hiss of steam kissing cold air.

Sunlight fractures through station glass,
painting drowsy faces in gold.
The aroma of platform coffee mingles
with diesel and dew-dampened coal.

Feet shuffle across worn wooden floors,
newsprint crinkles between anxious fingers.
Suitcases bump against legs in rhythm,
as the conductor's whistle lingers.

Windows frame a world in motion—
blurred trees, fields, and sleepy towns.
The gentle sway rocks bodies to comfort,
as distance grows from familiar grounds.

Ears pop with changing elevation,
tunnels swallow daylight then return it.
In this cocoon of collective movement,
we transform with each mile earned.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

responses.text:
ECHOES ACROSS TIME

"We have met before," whisper the stars
In constellations we traced with ancient hands.
Perhaps as pharaohs in golden lands,
Or peasants tilling unyielding sands.

I recognize the curve of your smile,
A memory etched in a thousand lives.
Your eyes hold secrets from bygone eras
When we danced beneath different skies.

Did we share bread in medieval courts?
Or fight side by side in forgotten wars?
Were we sisters, brothers, enemies, lovers?
Our souls entwined on countless shores.

The universe conspires in mysterious ways,
Threading our essence through time's labyrinth.
A tapestry of encounters, separations, returns—
Each meeting both ending and beginning.

So when you appeared at my door today,
With rain-soaked coat and questioning gaze,
I felt the weight of millennia in your presence,
And knew with certainty: we have met before.

In this life or another, it matters not.
Our souls recognize what minds forget.
The cycle continues, eternal, unbroken—
And somewhere, sometime, we shall meet again.

FAMILIAR STRANGERS

"We have met before,"
I say to the stranger with familiar eyes.
The coffee shop hums with indifferent chatter,
But between us—electric recognition.

Wasn't it you in that crowded train?
Or passing on stairs in a building I've never entered?
Perhaps in dreams where landscapes blur
And faces morph into impossible combinations.

Déjà vu—the brain's glitch
Or whispers from parallel universes
Where our paths cross in infinite variations.
Science explains away the shiver down my spine,
But cannot account for how I know
The way you'll tilt your head before speaking.

Reality fractures in these moments,
Time folding back upon itself.
I've seen this scene before—
The spilled sugar, the rain beginning outside,
The exact pattern your fingers make
Drumming against porcelain.

We are caught in time's stutter,
A cosmic hiccup of familiarity.
I know you, yet we've never met.
Or have we? In this life or another—
Something recognizes something
Across the void of forgetting.

THIRTY YEARS LATER

"We have met before," you say,
Gray now threading through your hair,
Laugh lines mapping journeys taken
Since we last shared the same air.

The playground where we traded secrets
Now renovated, strange and new.
Yet in your gestures, in your voice,
The child I knew still shines through.

What do we become in absence?
Shapes reformed by separate rains.
I've lived a thousand days without you,
Collected joys, weathered pains.

You speak of children, now half-grown.
I tell of countries I have seen.
We dance around the harder truths—
The dreams that died, what might have been.

Our conversation skips like stones
Across the surface of deep waters.
We cannot plumb those depths today;
Too much has changed, too much lost order.

Yet something sacred lingers still
In this reunion's tender space—
The recognition that we shaped each other,
Left fingerprints time can't erase.

"We have met before," I echo,
"And in meeting now, complete a circle."
Two strangers bound by shared history,
Two friends finding home in memory's temple.

RECURRING NIGHTMARE

"We have met before," it whispers
From shadows beneath my bed.
Night after night, the same visitation—
A presence I've grown to dread.

I know the sound of its breathing,
The temperature drop in the room,
The way the darkness thickens
Like ink spilled across the gloom.

We have danced this dance for years now,
This entity and I—
Me, pretending sleep might save me;
It, knowing that's a lie.

Sometimes I glimpse it in mirrors,
A silhouette just out of sight.
Sometimes in crowded places,
A face that's not quite right.

"We have met before," it reminds me
When I've convinced myself I'm free.
In childhood fever dreams, perhaps,
Or ancient family memory.

What does it want, this specter,
This shadow that knows my name?
Perhaps it's not a visitor at all,
But a part of me, unclaimed.

They say the things that haunt us
Are pieces we've tried to disown.
So when it whispers, "We have met before,"
Perhaps it means: "I am your own."

RECOGNITION

"We have met before," my heart declared
The moment you entered the room.
Though strangers by all worldly accounts,
Something ancient in me bloomed.

Was it your hands—how they moved through air
Conducting unheard symphonies?
Or the particular angle of light
That caught in your eyes like memories?

Science would call this chemistry,
Neurons firing, biology's art.
But science cannot explain away
This certainty that splits my heart.

Perhaps in dreams we've walked together
Along shores of distant stars.
Perhaps our atoms once danced close
In the heart of the same dying star.

I watched you move among strangers,
Unaware of my quiet revelation.
How strange to recognize someone
Whose name I have yet to learn.

Some connections transcend introduction,
Some knowing precedes words.
So when finally we spoke, and you paused,
Head tilted in curious wonder,

I wasn't surprised when you whispered,
Voice laden with quiet awe:
"This may sound strange, but tell me—
Have we met somewhere before?"

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

responses.text:
ECHOES ACROSS TIME

We have met before, in spaces between stars,
Your soul a familiar constellation against night's canvas.
I recognized the light in your eyes
Before you spoke a single word.

Perhaps we were ancient trees,
Roots intertwined beneath forgotten soil,
Or ocean waves that crashed together
On shores of civilizations long buried.

Did we share bread in Rome?
Dance through plague-emptied streets?
Were our hands clasped in prayer
Or in revolution's fervent grip?

I feel it in the way your laughter
Stirs memories I cannot place,
How your silhouette against sunset
Completes a painting started lifetimes ago.

Is this why my heart leapt
At the first whisper of your name?
Why my soul recognized its counterpart
Across a crowded room of strangers?

We have met before, and will meet again,
Our spirits orbiting through centuries,
Always finding one another
In the vast expanse of time's embrace.

So let us not say hello
As if this is our beginning.
Let us simply say:
At last, I've found you once more.

DÉJÀ VU

"We have met before," I whisper
to the stranger with familiar eyes.
The coffee shop hums with conversation
but between us: electric silence.

How to explain this certainty?
Your gestures trace patterns
I've witnessed in dreams,
or perhaps another life.

Scientists would speak of misfiring neurons,
temporally displaced memory formation—
a glitch in the brain's wiring.
Nothing mystical. Nothing fated.

Yet I know the scar on your wrist
before you push up your sleeve.
I can predict the way you'll tilt your head
when confused by my next question.

Is reality a ribbon, folded back on itself?
Are we merely catching glimpses
through wrinkles in time's fabric?
Or is this recognition older than language?

You smile—that smile—and say
"Impossible. I'd remember you."
But your fingers tremble slightly
as you reach for your cup.

Somewhere, perhaps, we are always meeting.
Somewhere we are saying goodbye.
Somewhere we have not yet encountered
the strange miracle of each other.

AUTUMN REUNION

We have met before, you and I,
Thirty autumns ago, beneath the maple
Whose leaves now carpet this same path.
Your hair, once midnight, now threaded silver;
Mine, once abundant, retreated like tide.

The bench remains, weathered witness
To promises youth made too easily.
I sit, arthritic fingers clutching photographs
Yellowed by decades, corners soft with handling.
You approach, hesitant as deer at twilight.

What travels have marked your face with lines?
What joys carved those creases beside your eyes?
The children we dreamed of—did they arrive
In your world without me? Did they inherit
Your crooked smile, your talent for forgiveness?

We speak of weather first, as strangers might,
Then cautiously of years between meetings,
Carefully avoiding mention of our parting—
That rainstorm of accusations, lightning-sharp words
That scorched the earth between our separate paths.

Yet somehow, as chestnuts fall around us,
Time's distance collapses like a paper fan.
Your laugh—unchanged—breaks something open in me;
A door I thought permanently sealed.

"We have met before," you say, unnecessarily,
And reach across thirty years to take my hand.

CELESTIAL CARTOGRAPHY

"We have met before," declares the Moon to the Sun
at their brief twilight convergence.
"I carry your reflection always,
though we're destined for separate skies."

We have met before, whispers Earth to Meteor
as bodies collide in spectacular destruction.
One unchanged, one forever altered
by the briefest cosmic touch.

We have met before, hums Mountain to River,
their centuries-long conversation carved in stone.
Patient erosion, persistent presence—
neither complete without the other's touch.

We have met before, sighs Winter to Spring
at the threshold of their eternal exchange.
One must always yield to the other,
their dance precisely choreographed by time.

We have met before, murmurs Seed to Soil
in darkness before the green revelation.
An ancient partnership of transformation,
burial preceding every blooming.

We have met before, thinks Human to Human
across divides of language, border, belief.
Strange how we forget this recognition—
the shared heartbeat beneath our differences.

We have met before, and in this meeting,
find pieces of ourselves long forgotten.
Every encounter an echo of the first:
stardust recognizing its scattered origins.

DIGITAL GHOSTS

We have met before, your avatar and mine,
in virtual rooms where identities blur.
I knew you as BluePhoenix92,
you called me MidnightWanderer.

We built castles in pixelated kingdoms,
fought dragons with code-forged swords,
shared secrets in encrypted channels—
strangers intimate through fiber optic cords.

Then servers crashed, accounts were lost,
and our digital selves disappeared.
Years compiled like obsolete software,
real life downloaded, installed, adhered.

Today in this analog coffee shop,
I glimpse something familiar in your eyes—
a pattern of speech, the curve of thought,
a ghost of connection I recognize.

How strange to meet your physical form,
to see the hands that typed those words,
to hear your voice unfiltered by distance,
to watch expressions unrendered by nerds.

Do you sense it too? This déjà vu
of friendship formed in binary space?
Or am I chasing electronic phantoms,
projecting pixels onto your face?

I nearly speak your username aloud—
then stop. Instead: "Have we met before?"
You smile, recognition dawning slowly,
"MidnightWanderer? Is that really you?"

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

responses.text:
ECHOES ACROSS TIME

We have met before,
In the amber glow of ancient fires,
Your eyes—the same constellation
I've traced with my fingertips
A thousand lifetimes ago.

Perhaps we were pharaohs
Sharing secrets under Egyptian stars,
Or samurai with honor-bound hearts,
Or peasants who found wealth
In simple touches and whispered vows.

I recognized you instantly—
The way light catches in your smile,
A gesture of your hands that awakens
Memories buried beneath centuries.

Some souls are tethered
Across the vast expanse of time,
Like rivers always finding their way
Back to the same endless sea.

In each life I've known you,
Sometimes as lover, sometimes friend,
Occasionally as foe—
But always significant,
Always essential to my becoming.

We have met before,
And we will meet again,
In whatever forms the universe
Chooses next for our wandering spirits—
I will know you,
As I have always known you,
In the sacred language
Only ancient souls remember.

FAMILIAR STRANGERS

We have met before—
I'm certain, though I cannot place
The where or when or how of it.

Perhaps in that café
Where raindrops raced down windowpanes
And steam rose from untouched cups.
Or was it on that crowded train,
Where shoulders brushed in passing?

There's something in the curve
Of your half-smile that pulls
At threads of memory—unraveling,
Yet never quite revealing.

Scientists say déjà vu is merely
Neurons misfiring, chemical confusion,
A glitch in perception's matrix.

But how to explain this certainty,
This bone-deep knowing
That somewhere, somehow,
We've occupied the same moment before?

Perhaps we pass each other
In infinite parallel lives,
Caught in cosmic repetition,
Always almost remembering.

Or maybe time isn't linear at all,
But circular—we're constantly meeting
For both the first and thousandth time.

We have met before,
And in this strange familiar moment,
I wonder if you feel it too—
This echo of recognition
Humming between us like a tuning fork
Struck against the universe.

SEASONS RETURNED

"We have met before,"
I whisper, as autumn brings you back to me,
Leaves burning copper like your hair once did
Between my fingers, falling just the same.

Five winters have carved their cold distance
Between the people we were and are.
Your laugh sounds weathered now,
Like pages of a book left too long in sunlight.

Remember how we danced barefoot
On beach sand turned silver by moonlight?
How we promised impossible things
With the arrogance of those who believed
Love alone could bend reality?

Now we sit across from each other,
Two strangers wearing familiar skins,
Archaeologists of our former hearts,
Sifting through artifacts of shared history—
Movie tickets, inside jokes, the scar
Where you burned your hand making me breakfast.

Time has softened our edges,
Blurred the sharp corners of our mistakes.
Perhaps that's mercy's greatest gift—
The gentle erosion of pain.

We have met before,
But perhaps today we truly see each other
For the first time,
Not through the fog of youth's desperate wanting,
But with eyes clear enough to recognize
Both the beauty and damage we caused.

BATTLEFIELD RECOGNITION

We have met before,
You and I, on fields soaked crimson,
Where banners tore like prayers
Against unforgiving skies.

I know the weight of your sword—
How it sings through air
Before meeting flesh.
I've studied your strategy
As hawks study serpents.

Enemy. Adversary. Nemesis.
Words too simple for this dance
We've perfected across battlefields.

In another life, perhaps
We might have been brothers,
Sharing wine instead of trading scars,
But fate cast us on opposite shores
Of this blood-river that never runs dry.

I see recognition flash
In your steel-gray eyes—
You remember too.

How many times must we enact
This ancient choreography?
How many lives must fall
Before we recognize the futility
Of our inherited hatred?

We have met before,
And one day, one of us will fall
By the other's hand—
Perhaps then we'll understand
That we were never truly enemies,
But prisoners of the same endless war,
Two sides of a coin
Tossed by indifferent gods.

THE AWKWARD REACQUAINTANCE

"We have met before,"
I announce with misplaced confidence
To the bewildered cashier
Who's scanning my discount yogurt
And questionable life choices.

Her name tag reads "Jennifer"
Or possibly "Jeanette"
(The font is artistically ambiguous)
And I'm CERTAIN we shared
Third-grade homeroom,
Or was it that pottery class?
Or my cousin's wedding?

I launch into elaborate reminiscence
Of memories we surely must share,
While the line behind me grows
Like my social anxiety.

Jennifer/Jeanette smiles politely,
The universal expression that screams:
"I've never seen this person before
But they might be dangerous or filming
Some terrible prank show."

I'm halfway through describing
A party that I'm now realizing
Might have been a dream I once had,
When recognition finally dawns—

She's not my childhood friend,
Or former colleague,
Or my dentist's receptionist.

She just looks exactly like
The barista I embarrassed myself in front of
Yesterday, at a completely different location,
In a remarkably similar way.

We have met before,
But only in the parallel universe
Where I possess social graces.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

responses.text:

We have met before,
in gardens where moonlight danced on ancient stones,
when your eyes held different stars
but the same knowing light.

Perhaps it was in Alexandria,
amid scrolls of forgotten wisdom,
or walking Kyoto's cherry-lined paths
as different souls in different skin.

I recognized your laugh
before I heard it—
a memory etched in some ancestral bone,
a ripple in time's gentle stream.

Sometimes I catch you looking
with that slight tilt of your head,
as if you too are trying to place
which lifetime holds our first hello.

Were we rivals once?
Lovers? Strangers passing
on a rain-soaked street?
Did we share bread or battlefields?

The universe conspires in magnificent cycles,
spinning souls together like twin stars,
again and again until we learn
whatever lesson waits between us.

We have met before,
and we will meet again,
when these bodies are dust
and our souls seek new harbors.

FAMILIAR STRANGERS

"We have met before,"
I say to the stranger on the train,
though I've never seen your face.
Yet something in me knows you—

The way shadows know light,
the way tides know the moon's pull,
the way autumn leaves know when to fall.

You smile, uncertain,
but there's recognition flickering
behind your cautious eyes.

Is it déjà vu?
A glitch in reality's matrix?
Or something science cannot name?

Perhaps we brushed past
in crowded stations of other cities,
or stood in the same museum
admiring different paintings.

Maybe our dreams crossed paths
in that ethereal subway system
where sleeping minds commute.

Or do our atoms remember
when they danced together
in the heart of a dying star?

We talk until your stop arrives.
You leave with a wave that feels
like an ancient goodbye.

I never learn your name,
but as the train moves on,
I know with certainty:
we'll meet again.

MIRRORS OF POSSIBILITY

We have met before
in quantum possibilities—
versions of us colliding
across the multiverse's thin membranes.

In one world, we never speak.
In another, we grow old together.
In this one, we stand at the precipice
of what might become.

I dream of you in parallel lives:
you as a physicist, me a poet;
you with different colored eyes;
me with memories of countries I've never visited.

The string theorists say
everything happens somewhere.
Every choice creates a branch,
every decision, a new universe.

So somewhere we are strangers.
Somewhere we are enemies.
Somewhere we save each other.
Somewhere we never need saving.

Perhaps that's why your hand feels
so familiar in mine—
because in a thousand realities,
I've already held it.

When you speak, I sometimes hear
echoes of conversations we haven't had yet.
Words that belong to other versions of us,
leaking through cosmic cracks.

We have met before,
and we are meeting still,
across infinite worlds,
forever finding our way back.

THE RECURRING DREAM

We have met before
in that recurring dream
where the sky burns violet
and the ocean stands still.

Night after night,
you appear at the edge
of that impossible beach,
your silhouette a question mark
against the frozen waves.

I never see your face clearly—
just fragments: the curve of a smile,
a hand extended, eyes that know
secrets I've forgotten while awake.

You speak in riddles
that dissolve upon waking,
leaving only impressions:
important messages
written in vanishing ink.

I've searched for you
in waking hours,
scanning crowds for that familiar
stranger from my sleep.

Last night, something changed.
You turned fully toward me and said:
"Remember this when you wake—
I am not just a dream."

Today I saw you
across a crowded café,
reading the book I finished yesterday.
Our eyes met, and I knew:

We have met before,
not just in dreams,
but in some reality
my conscious mind forgot.

TWENTY YEARS LATER

We have met before,
though time has carved new lines
around your eyes, around my smile—
maps of journeys taken separately.

You stand in my doorway,
two decades condensed
into the space between heartbeats.
How strange that you still hold your coffee the same way.

I remember the last time—
airport goodbyes, promises neither of us kept,
the future stretched before us
like an unwritten page we were too young to fill.

Now here you are,
with silver threading your temples
and stories I haven't heard
written in the calluses of your hands.

We talk of small things first—
the weather, the neighborhood, mutual friends—
dancing around the cavern of years
before diving into its depths.

"Do you ever wonder," you ask,
"what might have happened if..."
And the question hangs between us,
heavy with alternate endings.

We have met before,
but these versions of ourselves are new—
strangers built from the bones
of people who once knew each other by heart.

Perhaps that's the beauty of it:
the chance to discover you again.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

responses.text:
ECHOES ACROSS TIME

We have met before,
In the amber glow of ancient fires,
Your eyes the same constellation
I've traced with my fingertips a thousand times.

Perhaps it was in Babylon,
Where we whispered secrets beneath hanging gardens,
Or along the Nile's sacred shores,
When your laughter mingled with morning mist.

We have met before,
Though our names were different then—
Syllables lost to wind and dust,
Yet our souls recognized each other instantly.

I've held your hand through centuries,
Through wars that tore apart continents,
Through plagues that emptied cities,
Through revolutions that rebuilt worlds.

We have met before,
And will meet again,
When these bodies are memories
And we don new skin like borrowed clothes.

For now, in this fleeting lifetime,
I study the map of your smile,
Familiar territory disguised as something new,
And whisper to the universe: thank you
For bringing us together once more,
For this dance we've practiced eternally,
For the chance to remember
What our souls never forgot.

FAMILIAR STRANGERS

We have met before—
Not in flesh perhaps, but in the curved architecture of dreams,
Where déjà vu blossoms like night flowers
And time folds upon itself like origami.

That shiver of recognition
When strangers pass on crowded streets,
A glance that lingers a moment too long,
The ghost of a conversation never had.

I know the weight of your silence
Before you've spoken a word.
I've traced the outline of your thoughts
Before they've formed on your tongue.

Is it possible to miss someone
You've never actually met?
To grieve for moments
That exist only in parallel universes?

We have met before
In the spaces between heartbeats,
In the static between radio stations,
In the breath between words.

Perhaps we are quantum entangled,
Vibrating to the same frequency
Across dimensions and possibilities,
Our paths destined to cross and uncross

Like cosmic threads weaving
The fabric of existence itself—
Strangers and soulmates simultaneously,
Both unknown and utterly familiar.

RETURNING

We have met before,
You and I, beneath this same crooked oak,
Where summer light dappled your hair
And I counted freckles like stars.

Five years, three months, seventeen days—
Numbers that mean everything and nothing
As I watch you approach across the park,
Time collapsing like a house of cards.

You wear new lines around your eyes,
Soft parentheses framing unspoken stories.
I wonder if you can read the chapters
Written across my altered landscape.

We have met before,
But we are not those people anymore.
The ghosts of our younger selves
Watch curiously as we navigate this reunion.

What remains when everything changes?
The way you tilt your head when listening,
The nervous habit of twisting your ring,
The laugh that still breaks like dawn across your face.

We have met before,
But perhaps today we truly see each other
For the first time—weathered, stronger,
Humbled by the journey between then and now.

So let us begin again with "Hello,"
And discover who we've become
In the space between goodbye
And this unexpected second chance.

RECURRING NIGHTMARE

We have met before,
You and I, in this crimson corridor,
Where shadows crawl like spiders
And clocks run backward.

I recognize your silhouette—
Distorted, elongated against peeling wallpaper,
Though I've never seen your face,
Only felt your presence like a winter draft.

Night after night you wait for me,
Patient as death, inevitable as dawn.
I've tried different paths, different doors,
Yet always find myself here, breathless, heart thundering.

We have met before,
In childhood terrors and adult insomnia,
In cold sweats and silent screams,
In the paralysis between sleeping and waking.

Perhaps you are my own reflection,
Distorted by fear's funhouse mirror,
The parts of myself I've buried so deep
They've grown roots and strange flowers.

Tonight, I will not run.
Tonight, I turn to face you fully,
To ask your name, your purpose,
To understand why we're bound in this dance.

We have met before—
But this time, the ending changes,
As I reach out with trembling fingers
To touch what I've always fled,
And find myself dissolving into light.

UNIVERSAL CONSTANTS

We have met before,
Though we've never shaken hands.
I know the weight you carry
Because I too bear similar burdens.

In the currency of tears and laughter,
We share the same denomination.
Your first heartbreak mirrors mine—
Different faces, identical wounds.

We have met before
In the universal language of human experience.
The way you reach for connection
Echoes my own outstretched arms.

I know your fears without asking;
They wear the same masks as mine:
Time slipping through fingers,
Love vanishing like morning fog,
The terror of insignificance
Against the vastness of stars.

We have met before
In ancestral memories coded in our cells,
In collective dreams that bind civilizations,
In the shared rhythm of breath and blood.

Stranger, friend, enemy, lover—
These distinctions blur and fade
When we recognize the common thread
That stitches all consciousness together.

We have met before
And will continue meeting
In each act of compassion,
In each moment of understanding,
In the silent recognition
That we are never truly alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

responses.text:
ECHOES ACROSS TIME

We have met before, in whispers of ancient stars,
Your soul, a constellation I've traced with my fingertips
In another century, when our names were different
But our hearts beat the same wild rhythm.

I recognized you in the marketplace,
Among strangers and spices and forgotten languages.
Your eyes—windows to a thousand shared sunsets
That memory insists we watched together.

Perhaps we were lovers in Alexandria,
Or siblings huddled against Roman winters,
Or enemies whose swords crossed under medieval moons.
The details blur, but the essence remains.

Scientists may speak of coincidence,
Of neurons misfiring, creating false familiarity.
But how then to explain this certainty,
This gravity that pulls me toward you across crowded rooms?

We have met before, and will meet again,
In lifetimes stretched across the universe's canvas.
Our souls—cosmic travelers returning
To the comfort of recognition, the wonder
Of finding home in another's eyes.

DÉJÀ VU

"We have met before," I say,
though I know we haven't—not in this life.
Yet something in the angle of your smile
trips a wire in my mind's dusty archives.

The way you tilt your head to listen,
a gesture so familiar it aches.
Is memory just a puzzle with missing pieces,
or do some connections transcend explanation?

Scientists would call it a glitch,
a neural misfire, a temporal lobe
playing tricks with perception and time.
A rational answer for an irrational certainty.

But what if our atoms once danced together
in the heart of an ancient star?
What if our molecules remember
when we were stardust neighbors?

Perhaps we pass each other in dreams,
in that shadowland between consciousness,
where time folds like origami
and strangers become familiar ghosts.

We have met before—
in another dimension, perhaps,
or simply in the possibility
of all the people we might have been,
in all the lives we never lived.

SECOND CHANCE ENCOUNTER

We have met before,
across a coffee shop table
when we were younger, less scarred,
full of promises neither of us could keep.

Five years dissolve between us
as you stand in the bookstore aisle,
holding the novel I once pressed into your hands,
saying, "This reminds me of your soul."

Time has etched new lines around your eyes,
weathered your hands, softened your edges.
I wonder what changes you see in me—
the visible ones, and those beneath the skin.

We were hurricanes then,
destructive in our passion,
leaving debris of half-truths and almosts,
too young to understand the damage.

Now we stand as cautious lighthouses,
wiser, steadier, our beams more focused.
The conversation flows like gentle tide
rather than the tsunami of before.

Perhaps this meeting isn't coincidence
but the universe offering redemption,
a chance to rewrite our ending
or simply close the book with gentler hands.

We have met before—
and in that recognition lies
the possibility of what comes after.

SHADOWS AND LIGHT

We have met before, Despair tells Hope
as they pass in the corridor of a hospital at midnight.
I was there when she received the diagnosis,
when he read the letter of rejection,
when they lowered the small coffin into frozen ground.

Hope nods, unafraid of the introduction.
Yes, I remember you. I arrived just after,
quiet as morning light through blinds,
gentle as the nurse who held her hand,
steady as the friend who answered the phone at 3 a.m.

They circle each other, these ancient adversaries,
neither fully winning nor surrendering the field.
Despair carries weight like gravity,
while Hope moves like wind, invisible but felt.

I know your methods, whispers Despair.
And I, yours, answers Hope.

They have met before in revolution squares,
in cancer wards, in refugee camps,
in artists' studios at dawn after sleepless nights.

Their battleground: the human heart,
resilient and fragile, endless and finite.
We have met before, they acknowledge,
and will meet again, tomorrow
in countless souls at countless crossroads,
the eternal dance continuing.

NEURAL PATHWAYS

We have met before
in the architecture of memory,
where neurons fire in recognition
even when logic insists we're strangers.

The brain—that magnificent liar—
creates connections where none existed,
builds bridges between islands of experience,
convinces us of impossible familiarity.

Perhaps it's your gestures that trigger
the pattern-seeking machinery of my mind,
or the particular frequency of your laugh
that matches someone catalogued in my past.

Or maybe it's simpler: we are all
composed of the same elements,
carbon and calcium, hydrogen and hope,
all of us echoes of ancient stars.

The psychologists have terms for this phenomenon—
cryptomnesia, paramnesia, false recognition—
clinical words that fail to capture
the electricity of perceived connection.

But whether you're truly a stranger
or someone I've forgotten I knew,
this moment of recognition—real or imagined—
still creates something new between us:

A neural pathway, a bridge, a beginning.
We have met before, says my brain.
And even if it's lying,
the connection it creates is real.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

responses.text:
ECHOES IN CLAY

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its walls the color of autumn wheat,
Windows like tired eyes gazing
Across fields that once danced with life.

Fingerprints of generations pressed
Into each earthen curve and corner,
Stories hardened by sun and rain,
Whispers trapped in mud-straw mortar.

How many hands shaped these walls?
How many hearts beat within?
How many dreams settled like dust
On sills worn smooth by waiting?

Time has carved its signature—
Cracks like rivers mapping journeys,
A roof that sags with memories,
Doorways framing ghosts of laughter.

I touch the surface, rough and cool,
And feel the pulse of forgotten days,
The humble pride of those who built
A shelter from the very ground they tilled.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And in its silent, crumbling grace,
Found myself wondering which leaves
More permanent marks upon this earth—
Our monuments of stone and steel,
Or these modest homes returning
Slowly to the soil that birthed them.

CLAY DREAMING

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Hunkered down 'neath twisted oaks,
Like an ancient turtle, patient,
Breathing slowly through the seasons.

The walls—earth-born and humble—
Held secrets in their marrow:
A child's height marked in pencil,
A hidden coin beneath the floorboard,
Love letters tucked in chimney cracks.

Outside, wild roses climbed
Without permission or apology,
Their thorns etching hieroglyphs
Against the weathered surface.

I dreamt the cottage spoke at night,
In creaks and settling sighs,
Telling tales of harvest moons,
Of births and deaths and long winters,
Of hands that shaped its body
From the very field it watches over.

Something primordial pulls me closer—
This dwelling born of soil and straw,
This shelter crafted from the land itself.

We too are houses made of clay,
Temporary vessels holding light,
Destined to return to dust,
Yet somehow, for a moment,
Glorious in our impermanence.

THE CLAY KEEPER

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A sentinel at day's end,
Where shadows played hide-and-seek
Among forgotten tools and weathervanes.

The door hung crooked on its hinges
Like a drunk man leaning—
Half-invitation, half-warning.
Inside, cobwebs draped like silver bunting
From a celebration long concluded.

I imagined her, the woman
Who once swept these earthen floors,
Who mixed the clay with straw and water,
Palms callused from working the land,
Eyes bright with fierce determination.

The cottage remembers her still—
In the careful arch above the hearth,
In the smooth depression of the doorstep,
In the garden now wild with chicory and thistle.

I am a trespasser here,
A witness to stubborn persistence,
To beauty in abandonment.

The cottage stands—defiant, dignified—
Neither seeking praise nor fearing scorn,
Simply being what it always was:
A handful of earth shaped by hope,
A temporary forever,
A poem written in clay.

CLAY CHRONICLES

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And time unraveled before me—
Not in seconds, minutes, hours,
But in layers of earth and memory.

The walls held handprints of children
Long grown and scattered like seeds.
The foundation, stubborn as faith,
Clung to soil that birthed and sustained it.

Rain had carved rivulets down its face,
Nature's slow calligraphy writing
Epitaphs for dreams both realized and lost.

In the garden, twisted apple trees
Bore fruit nobody harvested,
Sweet-sour offerings to indifferent skies.

A blackbird perched on the chimney,
Surveying its unexpected kingdom,
Unaware of the lives once contained
Within these humble boundaries.

I wanted to knock, to ask permission
To enter this archive of ordinary days,
But who would answer? What ghosts
Might rise from corners thick with silence?

So I stood witness instead,
As sunset gilded the clay walls
With momentary magnificence—
A reminder that even in decay,
There is a certain slant of light
That transforms the commonplace
Into something holy.

CLAY WHISPERS

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Nestled between mountain and meadow,
A comma in earth's long sentence,
A pause between was and will be.

The windows winked in twilight—
Black squares against amber walls—
Secreting glances from another era
When hands shaped both home and destiny
From the same rich soil.

Moss claimed the northern side,
A slow-motion avalanche of green,
While swallows claimed the eaves,
Their mud nests echoing the walls below—
Creatures building homes from homes.

I circled three times, touching
The sun-warmed clay at different heights,
Feeling history hum beneath my fingers.

A fox watched from the woodpile,
Eyes reflecting questions I couldn't answer.
Who lived here? Who loved here?
Who left here, and why?

The cottage keeps its counsel,
As patient as the clay that forms it,
Neither boasting of past glories
Nor lamenting present solitude.

I leave reluctantly at dusk,
Knowing the cottage will appear
In dreams where time flows backward,
Where clay speaks, and I finally understand.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

responses.text:
THE KEEPER OF MEMORIES

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its windows like tired eyes,
Watching seasons melt away,
Beneath endless country skies.

Fingers of ivy climbed its walls,
Grasping stones worn smooth by rain.
Inside, dust-motes danced in halls
Where laughter will not sound again.

How many hands built this place?
How many hearts called it home?
Their footprints, time cannot erase—
Echoes in the weathered loam.

A cradle once rocked by the hearth,
A table that witnessed feasts and tears,
The humble walls, made of earth,
Stood sentinel through the years.

I touch the doorframe, rough and real,
And something ancient stirs in me—
A connection I cannot help but feel
To those I'll never know or see.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And in its silence, found my voice.
Some ruins don't speak of decay,
But of lives lived by choice.

CLAY DREAMS

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Crouching low against the hillside green,
Where a woman once spun tales by day
Of worlds and wonders never seen.

Her fingers shaped the very walls
That sheltered her from storm and strife.
The clay that answered to her calls
Became the vessel for her life.

Each morning as the mist unfurled,
She'd whisper secrets to the beams.
By nightfall, when the smoke-wreaths curled,
The cottage held her deepest dreams.

They say she vanished one spring night
When lightning split the ancient oak.
Some claim she melted out of sight,
Returning to the earth that spoke.

Now wildflowers breach the floor,
And swallows nest in crumbling walls.
The cottage breathes her name once more
When twilight's gentle shadow falls.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And swear it shifted under my hand—
As if something still lives in the clay,
Still shapes and reshapes the land.

FOUNDATIONS

I saw an old cottage of clay,
and thought how we all begin as earth—
malleable matter, shaped by hands
not always our own.

The walls stood despite their cracks,
proud in their imperfection,
the way our bodies carry scars
yet continue to house us.

What is a home but a second skin?
What is clay but patience made visible?

I pressed my palm against the surface,
felt the coolness of centuries,
the slow pulse of decomposition
and rebirth.

How strange to think that someday
I too will return to this—
basic elements, unnamed particles,
perhaps to be molded again

into shelter for another soul
seeking warmth, seeking walls
against the wilderness of being.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
and recognized myself in its silent standing—
how we weather, how we remain,
how we crumble only to become
foundation for what comes after,
the dust of our existence
forever caught in the mortar of tomorrow.

THE COTTAGE SPEAKS

I saw an old cottage of clay,
But the cottage, it also saw me.
"What brings you here?" it seemed to say,
"To this place where few come to be?"

The wind whistled through broken panes,
Carrying voices from long ago.
I listened to stories of joys and pains
That only abandoned homes can know.

"I've sheltered farmers and children small,
Protected them through winter's bite.
I've witnessed births within my wall,
And deaths by candle's fading light.

I've felt the weight of human grief,
The lightness of a lover's sigh.
I've given sanctuary brief
To those who had no place to lie.

My clay was dug from yonder field,
Mixed with straw by calloused hands.
In me, the earth and sky congealed
To form a haven on these lands."

I touched the cottage, felt it breathe,
And understood what time reveals—
That homes are more than what we see;
They're vessels where the past congeals.

TEMPORAL ARCHAEOLOGY

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A temporal anomaly amid steel towers.
Somehow overlooked by progress,
A footnote in the city's memoir.

Archaeologists of the future,
Take note: here stood defiance
Against the chrome-plated present,
A mud-born ancestor refusing extinction.

Carbon-date its stubborn walls—
You'll find centuries compressed
Into sedimentary memory,
Each layer a testament to survival.

The clay remembers hands that shaped it,
Palms that smoothed its rough edges,
Fingerprints fossilized in its skin,
An intimacy concrete cannot comprehend.

When they finally come with bulldozers
(And they will come, they always do),
Will they pause to consider what falls?
Not just mud and timber and thatch,

But a vocabulary of living
We've nearly forgotten how to speak—
Of building from the ground that holds us,
Of homes that breathe as we breathe.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And wondered which of us was truly ancient.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

responses.text:
ECHOES IN CLAY

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where sunlight spilled through cracks of time,
Where grandmother's hands once kneaded bread
And stories hung like laundry on the line.

The walls remembered every whisper,
Every lullaby that sweetened the air,
The patter of rain on the humble roof,
The warmth of hearth against winter's glare.

I pressed my palm against its surface,
Rough and cool, alive with history,
This earth-born shelter, shaped by calloused hands,
Stood witness to a family's mystery.

How many seasons had it weathered?
How many hearts had found their rest
Within these walls that rose from soil,
A simple home, divinely blessed?

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And in its silence, voices speak,
Of simpler days and harder times,
Of strength in what appears so weak.

The modern world may rush around,
With concrete towers scraping sky,
But wisdom lives in humble things,
In cottages that never die.

ABANDONED HEARTH

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its broken spine curved toward the ground,
As if bowing to the inevitability
Of returning to the earth it came from.

Roots pierced through floorboards,
Nature reclaiming what was borrowed,
Windows—vacant eyes staring
Into a world that left it behind.

Who were they? Those final inhabitants
Who closed the door one last time,
Never to return, leaving dishes
Still waiting on the weathered table.

The hearth, cold for decades,
No longer remembers the taste of flame,
Only spiders spin their silver threads
Where children once gathered for warmth.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A skeleton of forgotten dreams,
A monument to impermanence,
A reminder of how quickly we fade.

Soon the roof will completely surrender,
The walls will melt back into the ground,
And nothing will remain to suggest
That love once lived within these bounds.

THE KEEPER OF SECRETS

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Hidden where the forest meets the stream,
Its chimney curling dragon's breath,
More magical than it might seem.

The door, they say, appears only
To those with wonder in their eyes,
For inside dwells a collector of stories,
Keeper of truths and gentle lies.

The walls shift colors with the seasons—
Emerald spring, autumn's amber glow—
And if you listen on moonlit nights,
You'll hear the walls hum what they know.

They say a child who enters laughing
Embraces wisdom beyond their years,
While bitter souls find sweet redemption
In clay that absorbs their fallen tears.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Or perhaps it saw something in me,
For when I touched its sun-warmed wall,
I felt it pulse with memory.

Perhaps tomorrow you'll pass this way,
And if your heart is true and light,
You too might see the cottage of clay
That vanishes with morning's light.

WITNESS TO CENTURIES

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Built by hands long turned to dust,
When kings and queens ruled distant lands
And swords were bright before the rust.

Through revolutions, wars, and peace,
Through famine, plenty, drought, and rain,
The cottage stood, a silent witness
To human joy and human pain.

The candle gave way to lamplight,
Then electricity's modern glow.
Horses yielded to automobiles
As time continued, swift or slow.

Against its walls, children have played
Who later sent their children to war.
Letters of love and grief were written
On tables inside that humble door.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A testament to our brief stay,
How civilizations rise and fall
While simple things outlast us all.

Touch these walls and feel connection
To ancestors you've never known,
Who sought, like us, some small protection—
A place to call their very own.

THE PHILOSOPHY OF MUD

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And questioned what makes something last—
This humble dwelling, earth-born,
Neither reaching high nor built to boast.

We craft our towers of steel and glass,
Monuments to our brief existence,
Yet this simple home of mud and straw
Endures with quiet persistence.

Perhaps there's wisdom in the clay,
In knowing one's beginning and end,
In standing firm but holding space
For transformation's gentle bend.

What hubris drives our endless reach
Toward permanence we cannot claim?
While clay accepts its destiny—
To serve, then return from whence it came.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its imperfection somehow whole,
A meditation on the beauty
Of living true to nature's soul.

May we learn from walls of earth,
That strength lies not in fighting time,
But in embracing transience,
In being humble, yet sublime.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

responses.text:
ECHOES IN CLAY

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its windows like eyes watching time pass by,
Walls that whispered stories of yesterday,
Holding memories that refuse to die.

Handprints of children now gray and old,
Laughter embedded in earthen walls,
Hearthstones that witnessed love stories told,
And sorrows that hung in its humble halls.

Generations shaped by these simple rooms,
Where sunlight danced through dusty air,
Where life began in mothers' wombs,
And elders breathed their final prayer.

I pressed my palm against its side,
Felt warmth from centuries of sun,
The cottage spoke of human tide,
Of lives completed, lives begun.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And in its silence, found my own,
A testament to feet of clay,
To dust returning, flesh to bone.

DISSOLUTION

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Abandon-worn and sinking back to earth,
Roof collapsed like a final exhale,
Windows vacant as forgotten promises.

Rain dissolves what hands once formed,
Each droplet reclaiming, particle by particle,
What was borrowed from the soil.
Nature's patient repossession.

Inside, a bird's nest crowns a broken beam,
Spider silk drapes where curtains hung,
Moss creeps across the threshold—
No permission needed now.

I wonder who last closed this door,
Never to return, leaving ghosts
To wander rooms now open to the sky,
Their footsteps washed away by seasons.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Slowly becoming not-cottage,
A meditation on impermanence,
On how we all return to elements.

THE WITCH'S DWELLING

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Where no mortal ought to tread,
Its chimney smoke curled emerald green,
Its garden grew strange fruits instead.

The windows winked as I passed by,
The door creaked open without a hand,
A kettle whistled a haunting tune,
Though no fire I could understand.

Cats of impossible colors lounged
On a roof that shifted like the sea,
While books flew open, pages turned
By fingers I could never see.

The witch, they say, was ancient when
The mountains were merely hills,
Her cottage appears just once a year
To those with troubles or ills.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And though I hurried on my way,
A jar of something strange appeared
In my pocket the very next day.

EARTHEN SANCTUARY

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Hewn from the breast of Mother Earth,
Sturdy walls of humble birth,
Standing steadfast come what may.

Soil and water, straw and stone,
Elements in harmony bound,
Rooted deep in sacred ground,
Nature's wisdom in each zone.

Human hands with ancient skill,
Shaped this shelter from the land,
Following time's gentle command,
Bending matter to their will.

In its curves and earthen hue,
Lies a truth we've long forgot,
That we need not quite so much,
To find peace and see us through.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And in its presence understood,
That dwelling simply as we should,
Is how we find our truest way.

THE CARETAKER

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And stopped to rest my weary feet.
An old man answered my soft knock,
With smile both bitter and sweet.

"Come in," he said, "but understand,
This house is not what it appears."
He poured me tea in chipped blue cups,
His hands were maps of vanished years.

"I've kept these walls for centuries,
Though I was meant to stay just days.
The owner left for distant shores,
And I remain, always waiting."

The cottage hummed with strange delight,
As if it knew some secret jest.
The old man's eyes turned glossy bright,
A tear escaped despite his best.

"I saw an old cottage of clay,"
I tell the travelers passing through.
"If you should find it on your way,
Please tell him—she's not coming back anew."

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

responses.text:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its windows like tired eyes gazing
Across fields where children once played,
Now silent under autumn's haze.

Walls cracked like an elder's palms,
Telling stories of seasons past,
Of families who sheltered within,
Of laughter that couldn't last.

The hearth where flames once danced and leapt,
Now cold, filled with leaves and time,
While moss reclaims the weathered roof,
Nature's slow, persistent climb.

I wonder of the hands that built,
This humble dwelling from the earth,
How they mixed the clay with straw and hope,
Creating home from soil's worth.

Generations passed through that door,
Leaving echoes in the walls,
Whispered secrets, forgotten dreams,
The cottage remembers them all.

I press my palm against the clay,
Feel centuries pulse beneath my skin,
This cottage, returning to dust,
Was once where living would begin.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A sentinel standing against progress's march.
While glass towers scrape the urban sky,
This humble dwelling refuses to part.

The city grew around its stubborn frame,
Concrete rivers flowing past its door.
A relic of another century,
A question mark that architects ignore.

The old woman who lives inside
Defies the developers' generous sums.
"My grandmother shaped these walls," she says,
"From clay that knew her mother's thumbs."

Each morning, commuters stream past,
Glancing curiously at this strange sight—
A cottage made of earth and time
Amid the steel and satellite.

Some call it eyesore, others charm,
This anachronism of mud and thatch.
But I see revolution in its stand,
A memory the future cannot match.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A full stop in progress's endless text.
A reminder that some things remain
When all else surrenders to what comes next.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And thought it a mirror of self—
This body, my temporal dwelling,
Molded from earth's humble wealth.

The cottage sags as I do,
Settling into foundation's embrace.
Its cracks, like my wrinkles, tell stories
Of storms weathered with quiet grace.

The windows, clouded with age,
Like eyes that have dimmed with years,
Still filter the light of morning,
Though differently than they did, my dear.

The chimney breathes smoke to heaven,
As I exhale memories to air.
Both sending signals of living,
Proof we still exist, still care.

One day, this cottage will crumble,
Return to the soil from which it came.
As will I, in time's final season,
Earth to earth—we share this frame.

Yet something transcends the clay—
The lives sheltered, the love that grew.
The cottage was vessel, not essence;
As this body houses, but isn't you.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And recognized my transient form.
Not with fear, but understanding:
We're both just housing the storm.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
At dusk, when the veil grows thin.
A wisp of smoke from the chimney rose,
Though no one had lived therein.

The locals warned me, "Stay away,
That place belongs to them now."
But curiosity pulled me close,
To secrets time would allow.

I pushed the creaking door ajar,
Expecting dust and decay.
Instead, a table set for tea,
As if from just yesterday.

The kettle whistled though no flame burned,
Chairs rocked without any breeze.
And in the corner, shadows danced
To music I couldn't seize.

A woman's laughter, a child's song,
Footsteps across the floor.
I stood transfixed as moments passed
From some forgotten lore.

"Join us," a voice like autumn leaves
Whispered against my ear.
"This clay remembers what you don't—
The lives that vanished here."

I fled that cottage as night fell hard,
Yet something followed behind.
Now in my dreams, I serve them tea,
The family time left behind.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
While wandering fields yesterday.
I asked it, "What wisdom have you to share?"
And surprisingly, it answered me there:

"I've witnessed two centuries turn,
Stood firm while empires burned.
I've sheltered the poor and the brave,
From first breath until the grave.

I'm built of the simplest stuff—
Just earth and water and love.
No marble columns or golden domes,
Yet I've been the warmest of homes.

The rain has tested my walls,
The sun has hardened my halls.
The wind has whispered my name,
Yet humble, I remain the same.

The wealthy build towers of glass,
Transparent and fragile, they pass.
While I, though considered plain,
Outlast their temporary reign.

So traveler, take note today,
Of lessons from this house of clay:
Strength doesn't come from wealth or height,
But from being built just right.

The earth that forms you will reclaim,
All structures, humble or grand, the same.
So while you stand, be shelter, be kind—
That's the legacy you leave behind."

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

responses.text:
ECHOES IN CLAY

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Weathered by centuries of rain and sun,
Its walls holding whispers of yesterday
Where time's relentless fingers have run.

Handprints of children long grown,
Laughter embedded in earthen walls,
Stories of harvests reaped and sown
Echo through its humble halls.

How many storms has it weathered?
How many seasons watched pass by?
Its foundation, though cracked and tethered,
Still stands beneath an endless sky.

The hearth, once warm with dancing flame,
Now cold, yet memories remain,
Of families who called it by name,
Their joys, their sorrows, their pain.

I touch the surface, rough and cool,
Feel generations beneath my hand,
This cottage—a historical jewel—
A testament to those who worked this land.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A humble archive of human grace,
Reminding me how we all decay,
Yet leave behind some lasting trace.

EARTH'S EMBRACE

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Rising from soil like ancient bone,
Roots of wildflowers finding way
Through cracks where seeds had blown.

The earth reclaiming what was hers,
Borrowed materials returning home,
As moss and lichen, nature's furriers,
Dress walls in emerald-velvet roam.

Rain dissolves the edges slowly,
Blurring lines between made and grown,
This dwelling, once proud and holy,
Now with meadowgrass overgrown.

The swallows nest in crumbling eaves,
Field mice scurry across the floor,
While ivy climbs and interweaves,
Reclaiming the forgotten door.

Clay to clay, dust returning to dust,
Nature's cycle unbroken, true,
The cottage surrenders, as all things must,
To be transformed and born anew.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Not as ruin, but as rebirth,
Where human hands and nature's way
Blend seamlessly back to earth.

THE COTTAGE BETWEEN WORLDS

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Standing where worlds thinly divide,
Shimmering at the edge of day,
Where mortal and fae collide.

Smoke curls from its chimney at dawn,
Though no one has lived there for years,
Lights flicker as twilight is drawn,
Music drifts to mortal ears.

They say if you knock thrice at midnight,
And leave a small gift at the door,
The cottage might grant you the sight
To see what it's guardian for.

A doorway between realms it stands,
Neither fully here nor there,
Built with clay from otherworld lands,
And sealed with enchanted air.

I've watched as the foxfire glows,
Illuminating windows like eyes,
As the cottage shifts and grows,
Changing shape before sunrise.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Or perhaps it was seeing me,
A sentinel marking the way
To realms we rarely see.

VESSELS OF CLAY

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its walls crumbling back to the ground,
And thought how we too are but clay,
Temporary vessels, earth-bound.

Hands shaped these walls with purpose and care,
As we ourselves are molded by time,
Both fragile creations that weather and wear,
Both destined to finish their climb.

The cottage stood proud through decades of strain,
Enduring through tempest and drought,
As we bear our burdens of pleasure and pain,
Facing both certainty and doubt.

Cracks tell the story of winters endured,
Of foundations settled and shifted,
Like wrinkles on faces of those who've matured,
By life's heavy burdens been lifted.

We patch and repair what we can while we may,
But eventually yield to the sun,
Returning like cottages built out of clay,
To the earth when our season is done.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And recognized something of me,
Two vessels shaped from the same clay,
Both temporary, both free.

FIVE GENERATIONS

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Built by Samuel's calloused hands,
In eighteen hundred, so they say,
On the edge of newfound lands.

His daughter Mary raised eight souls,
Beneath its low-beamed ceiling,
While outside, as the season rolls,
Their small farm plot yielding.

Then Thomas, with his veteran's limp,
Expanded rooms for modern times,
Added glass where light was crimp,
While children's laughter climbs.

Elizabeth, fourth generation strong,
Kept it through depression years,
Preserved its walls when things went wrong,
Absorbed its share of tears.

Now David, last of family line,
Returns from city life to find,
The cottage waiting, still divine,
Though time has been unkind.

He runs his hands along the wall,
Five generations' stories held,
The cottage witnessed all their all,
Their joys and sorrows swelled.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A testament to those who came before,
Not just a home but heritage to stay,
Connecting what has been to what's in store.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

responses.text:
PASSAGE

They carry him beneath obsidian skies,
Where stars stand sentinel in silent rows.
The night, a shroud of velvet, gently flows
Around the solemn train of mourners' sighs.

Candles flicker—tiny universes
Of light against the absolute of dark.
Each flame, a memory, a glowing spark
Of life that death so quietly disperses.

The earth waits open-mouthed and patient now,
A void to match the one inside each heart.
The wooden box descends with gentle art,
As whispered prayers rise from every brow.

The shovels scratch the silence with their song—
A rhythm old as grief, as time, as breath.
The night embraces both the life and death,
Revealing how the two have danced along.

And somewhere in that velvet dome above,
A new star quietly begins to glow.
The night funeral ends, but we all know
What's buried in the dark blooms still with love.

THE NIGHT TAKES ITS OWN

The moon hangs crooked tonight,
A pale pallbearer in the procession of clouds.
We move like shadows among shadows,
Our footsteps muffled by the carpet of darkness.

No daylight to expose our red-rimmed eyes,
No harsh sun to make monuments of our grief.
Only this gentle darkness,
Cradling our broken pieces.

The night funeral moves through streets
Where windows glow like distant ships.
The living sleep behind glass,
Unaware of how we drift between worlds.

Lanterns sway, casting pools of light
That ripple across faces half-remembered.
We are becoming ghosts already,
Translucent with remembering.

The cemetery breathes with ancient patience.
Headstones rise like worn teeth from the earth's jaw.
We place her down among the others,
A seed planted in the garden of the gone.

Tomorrow will arrive without her.
The sun will rise on one less heartbeat.
But tonight, the darkness holds us all—
The living, the dead, the somewhere in-between.

NOCTURNE FOR THE DEPARTED

They say it's fitting: darkness burying darkness.
The night funeral winds through empty streets,
A black ribbon against blacker cloth.

I disagree. You were never darkness.
You were the unexpected laugh at midnight,
The warm hand reaching through twilight hours,
The voice that made shadows less lonely.

The procession moves in silence punctuated
By the soft percussion of footfalls.
Fireflies blink like confused stars
Fallen to witness this strange migration.

I carry your memory like a lantern.
It illuminates the path behind me,
Throws light on moments I failed to cherish,
Casts shadows of what will never be.

The eulogy rises like smoke—
Words inadequate as mist,
Dissipating before they capture your essence.

Afterward, we stand in constellations of grief,
Each mourner a separate universe of pain,
Connected by the gravity of absence.

The night funeral ends as all things must.
We disperse like dreams at daybreak,
Carrying pieces of you into different futures,
While you remain, eternally, in the perfect past.

ANCESTRAL LIGHTS

In my grandmother's village,
night funerals were rivers of fire—
kerosene lamps and paper lanterns
floating through darkness like earthbound stars.

The dead were carried shoulder-high,
riding waves of voices that sang them
across the threshold between worlds.
No whispered prayers, but full-throated calls

that challenged the night to deny passage.
I remember how the elders said
the darkness was thinner at midnight,
the veil between here and there more permeable.

Now, in this sterile Western ceremony,
I miss the wild grief of those processions—
the way sorrow was not contained
but released into the cosmos like birds.

Here, we stand in polite formation.
Our black clothes absorb the darkness
instead of defying it with flame.
Our tears fall inward, unseen.

I close my eyes and summon memory:
the night alive with mourning,
the dead honored with noise and light,
the funeral a final celebration.

Under my breath, I sing the old songs
for this soul's journey through the dark,
a lone flame in the proper silence,
a secret ancestral light.

THE LAST PERFORMANCE

The curtain of night has fallen early.
This wasn't on the program—
no one checked their tickets for this show.

Yet here we are, reluctant audience
to your final disappearing act.
The stage: six feet of hollowed earth.
The spotlight: a waning crescent moon.

The night funeral proceeds with terrible efficiency.
Even the stars seem to have rehearsed their positions,
glittering with cold professionalism.

I want to disrupt this performance,
to leap from my seat and shout: "Plot twist!"
to tear down the cardboard scenery of finality.

But I remain, program crumpled in sweating hands,
watching as they lower the curtain on you forever.

Afterward, we gather at the reception,
actors who've forgotten our lines.
We improvise small talk around the void
you left center stage.

Somewhere, I believe, you're waiting in the wings,
listening for your cue to return.
The night funeral may end, the audience disperse,
but I'll keep watching for you in every empty spotlight,
in every shadow between street lamps,
in every darkened theater of dreams.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

responses.text:
PROCESSION

Candles pierce the velvet dark,
Solemn footsteps, hushed and slow.
Moonlight catches teardrops' arc—
Silver streaks on faces glow.

Stars above bear silent witness,
Crickets pause their nightly song.
Shadows stretch in dark completeness,
As the bearers move along.

Night embraces all who gather,
Wraps its arms around their grief.
Winds that whisper, "Come now, rather
Let me offer some relief."

Earth awaits with patient longing,
Ready for its child's return.
Bells toll softly, gently donging,
As the torches softly burn.

Words are spoken, ancient, tender,
Rising up like smoke unfurled.
Souls commune in night's dark splendor,
Bridging this and other world.

Dawn will break, as dawns must follow,
Life continues, ever thus.
Yet tonight, in darkness hallowed,
Time stands still for all of us.

Candles flicker, slowly fading,
Stars reclaim their watchful post.
Night funeral procession wading
Through the dark, to join the host.

THE FINAL VOYAGE

They carry you beneath obsidian skies,
Your vessel carved from ancient oak,
Its surface gleaming with the tears
Of those who knew you best.

The night has donned its formal attire—
A cape of stars, a veil of shadow,
To honor your departure from these shores.

I watch from the periphery,
A stone lodged in my throat,
As they lower your body to the earth
Like a ship returning to the sea.

The night funeral moves with the rhythm
Of waves against a distant shore—
The collective breathing of mourners,
The rise and fall of whispered prayers,
The gentle sway of candlelight.

Someone speaks of your courage,
Another of your laughter.
But the night holds the truest eulogy
In its vast and tender silence.

We are all travelers here,
Casting our brief shadows
Against the infinite dark.
And you, beloved navigator,
Have simply charted your course
Beyond our limited horizon.

The night receives you
As an old friend returning home.

LANTERNS FOR THE DEPARTED

In this village where mountains touch the sky,
We do not fear the night that takes our dead.
We welcome darkness as an ancient friend,
Who veils the passage between worlds.

A thousand paper lanterns,
Each a tiny sun,
Float like earthbound stars
Above the processional path.
