The way the kitchen corner looks
When evening light grows soft and dim.

Perhaps my absence shapes the room
More tangibly than presence could—
A negative space, a hollow womb
Where once my breathing form had stood.

The molecules that formed my smile
Will feed the roses by the gate.
The thoughts I carried all this while
Released to stars, disintegrate.

What I shall leave thee none can tell.
No prophecy can name such things.
Just listen for my voice's knell
In every song the thrush still sings.

QUANTUM LEGACY

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even I who soon must part—
A universe within a cell?
The code that builds a beating heart?

We are but stardust, rearranged,
Temporary vessels, cosmic art.
Each atom of me, once exchanged,
Will find new purpose, new start.

Perhaps I'll leave a question mark,
A puzzle for your mind to solve.
A mystery that lights the dark,
A theory that makes worlds revolve.

Or maybe just this paradox:
That nothing truly disappears—
Energy shifts but never stops,
Transforming through the endless years.

What I shall leave thee none can tell.
No fortune-teller knows such truth.
But in this quantum parallel,
I'm both departed and renewed.

THE SECRET BEQUEST

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even those who watch us now.
A treasure map? A hidden spell?
A key to secrets I avow?

I've buried clues beneath the moon
In places only we have been.
You'll find them late one afternoon
When shadows stretch and light grows thin.

Follow the trail of breadcrumb words
I've scattered through our history.
Decoded whispers, like strange birds,
Will lead you to my mystery.

The greatest gift lies wrapped in time,
Sealed with a kiss, locked with a tear.
A revelation, so sublime,
That only love can render clear.

What I shall leave thee none can tell—
A game of hide-and-seek divine.
The answer lies within the well
Where your reflection touches mine.

TRANSCENDENCE

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not priest nor prophet, seer nor sage.
The soul defies the tolling bell,
Existing beyond time and age.

Perhaps I'll leave a certain light
That catches you at dawn's first breath—
A sense of presence in the night,
A love that transcends even death.

The veil between worlds grows so thin
When hearts remember hearts once near.
What seems like ending might begin
A different way of being here.

The universe holds patterns deep,
Connections science cannot name.
The promises we meant to keep
Remain when we're no longer same.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Yet everything of worth remains.
In cosmic ocean's rise and swell,
Our essence never truly wanes.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

responses.text:
LEGACY

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even the whispers of my heart
As they fade like footprints in sand.
The collection of moments—
Some bright as morning glory,
Others soft as twilight's breath—
All dissolving into the vast ocean of time.

Perhaps you'll find me
In the dog-eared pages of books
Where my fingers lingered longest,
Or in the garden where daffodils
Return with faithful persistence.

Maybe my legacy lives
In that odd turn of phrase you caught yourself using,
Or how you tilt your head when puzzled,
Not knowing you mirror my own curiosity.

What I shall leave thee none can tell—
Not the lawyers with their papers,
Nor the priests with their prayers.
The most precious inheritances
Are invisible to calculating eyes:
A certain resilience in your spirit,
The way you search for beauty in broken things,
How you forgive—especially yourself.

These treasures I scatter like seeds,
Never knowing which will take root
In the fertile soil of your becoming.
What grows will be yours entirely,
And yet, somehow, still mine.

THE UNKNOWABLE GIFT

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not fortune-tellers with crystal balls
Nor scientists with quantum equations.
The future guards its secrets jealously.

I walk this earth collecting possibilities—
Small stones of experience,
Feathers of fleeting joy,
Seeds of wisdom painfully harvested.

Sometimes I imagine leaving you
A map with X-marked treasures,
Or a compass that always points toward peace.
But life refuses such certainties.

Perhaps my gift will be absence itself—
A space where your own voice can echo,
A blank canvas awaiting your colors,
A question mark that invites your answer.

Or maybe I'll leave contradictions:
Strength born from witnessing my weakness,
Faith discovered through my doubts,
Laughter remembered from our tears.

The universe keeps its ledgers in invisible ink.
What transfers between souls
Defies inventory or prediction.

So I continue gathering—
This shell, that memory, these words—
Offering them with open hands.
What you receive, what remains,
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
And that mystery itself may be the greatest gift of all.

TIME'S WHISPER

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
For time is a river that carries away
Even the most carefully crafted monuments.
I have pressed my hands into wet clay,
Scribbled words on pages that yellow,
Planted trees whose shade I'll never know.

The world spins indifferent to our markings.
Star-dust to star-dust, we borrow form briefly,
Then surrender it back to the endless cycle.

Yet something persists beyond flesh and bone—
A ripple extending outward,
Touching shores I cannot see.

In the space between heartbeats,
I sometimes sense the ancestors watching,
Their legacy flowing through my veins
Like ancient music played on instruments
That no longer exist.

So too will my melody continue
In changed forms, unrecognizable perhaps,
But present in the symphony nonetheless.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even I who lived this life.
But listen closely in quiet moments—
My love echoes in the chambers of the universe,
A fossil record of devotion,
A constellation that guides
Long after the stars themselves have died.

INHERITANCE OF QUESTIONS

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Certainly not I, who stumble through days
Collecting more questions than answers.

Will you inherit my doubts?
The way I second-guess kindness,
Suspecting hidden motives like splinters
Beneath seemingly smooth surfaces?

Or perhaps my wonder?
How I stop breathless before ordinary miracles—
Dewdrops on spider silk,
The perfect mathematics of pine cones,
The impossible blueness of sky.

Will you receive my contradictions?
The courage that arrives only after fear has been felt,
The faith that dwells in the house of uncertainty,
The peace discovered in surrendering to chaos.

I cannot bequeath wisdom I haven't earned,
Or promise treasures that were only loaned to me.

But I leave you this practice:
To stand at crossroads with open palms,
To seek truth even when it wears disguises,
To forgive the unfinished nature of everything,
Including yourself.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But may you find breadcrumbs along your path
That lead not home, but onward,
Into your own magnificent becoming.

THE INVISIBLE BEQUEST

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even the stars that have witnessed
Our brief dance upon this spinning earth.

Will it be the sound of my laughter
Echoing in unexpected moments?
Or fragments of advice you once resisted
Now surfacing with startling clarity?

Perhaps I'll leave an empty chair
That holds the shape of absence,
Teaching you that love persists
Even when its object disappears.

Or maybe just this paradox:
That those who truly leave us
Never really go away.

I've hidden treasures in plain sight—
In how the light falls through windows at dusk,
In the particular silence after rainfall,
In the taste of blackberries still warm from sun.

Some inheritances arrive decades late,
Like when you catch yourself using my expressions,
Or notice your hands have become mine.

The most precious legacies transfer
Without lawyers or witnesses,
Moving through bloodlines and heartstrings,
Defying inventory or appraisal.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But in the mystery lies the miracle—
How we continue in each other,
Undocumented, immeasurable, eternal.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

responses.text:
EPHEMERAL BEQUEST

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even stars that know my heart;
The whispers caught in ocean's swell,
Or secrets where the shadows part.

Perhaps a book with dog-eared page,
A garden where the wild things grow,
A melody that marks an age,
Or words whose worth you'll never know.

The atoms of my being spread
Like dandelion seeds in spring,
In stranger's smiles when all is said,
In echoes where the thrushes sing.

What I shall leave thee none can tell—
Not wealth nor fame nor grand design,
But fingerprints on life that dwell
In subtle ways through space and time.

INHERITANCE

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not prophet, seer, nor sage divine.
Perhaps my ghost will cast its spell
Where moonlight breaks through tangled vine.

I've gathered shadows in my hands,
Collected tears in silver jars,
Mapped constellations on lost lands,
And bottled light from dying stars.

My treasures aren't of common gold,
But moments stolen from the void—
A sunset's crimson-breaking hold,
A child's laughter, unalloyed.

The universe conspires in dust
To make of endings new begins.
What I shall leave is not what must
Be counted, measured, weighed as wins.

But rather how I changed the air
Around your soul when I was near.
The invisible made bare—
My love, both far now and still here.

DIGITAL REMAINS

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Perhaps some posts in cyberspace,
A thousand selfies cast to dwell
In servers hidden, commonplace.

Our modern ghosts are pixels now,
Our legacies in clouds remain.
The ancient Greeks would wonder how
Our souls persist through digital rain.

Will someone scroll through what was me
A century from this swift day?
Or will my data cease to be,
Deleted, lost, and swept away?

The sonnets Shakespeare left behind
Endured on paper, ink, and thought.
What traces will our children find
Of all the battles that we fought?

What I shall leave thee none can tell—
This poem itself may be the proof
That words still cast their human spell
Beyond our brief, impermanent truth.

EARTH SONG

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
As glaciers melt and forests burn.
Will there be streams in which to dwell,
Or soil where seedlings might return?

The ancient oaks that stood so tall
Bear witness to our brief parade.
We thought ourselves the lords of all,
While weaving nets in which we're stayed.

Perhaps I'll leave a planted tree,
A patch of wildflowers saved,
A coastline fighting to stay free,
A wilderness path never paved.

Or maybe just this solemn vow:
To tread more gently on this sphere,
To honor what sustains us now,
To hold what's vanishing more dear.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But may it be a world reborn,
Where human hands have learned to quell
Their hunger, and no more forlorn.

QUANTUM LEGACY

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even I can prophesy
The way my atoms swell and quell
Beneath the vast eternal sky.

Perhaps the light that touched my face
Will journey to a distant star,
Or molecules in my embrace
Will nourish roses where you are.

The universe keeps no accounts
Of who we were or what we did.
It's only love, perhaps, that counts—
The rest in cosmic dust is hid.

So when you wonder where I've gone
And what remains of all I was,
Look for me in the breaking dawn,
In quantum leaps, in natural laws.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But in uncertainty there's grace.
In not knowing, we dwell
Within possibility's embrace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

responses.text:
LEGACY UNWRITTEN

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even I, with mortal sight.
Perhaps a whisper in the shell
Of memory, fading into night.

My fingerprints on weathered books,
A photograph where sunlight spills,
The echo of my voice in nooks
Where conversation lingers still.

Maybe nothing but a space
Where once my breath disturbed the air,
A subtle shift, a vanished trace,
A chair that waits, but I'm not there.

What I shall leave thee none can tell—
Not gold, nor words carved into stone.
Just love, invisible and well
Beyond what eye or hand has known.

So seek me not in things that last,
But in the moments swift and dear.
I'll be the question never asked,
The answer that might disappear.

INHERITANCE

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
The future guards its secrets well.
Perhaps these hands, their shape and line,
Reflected in those hands of thine.

Perhaps the way you tilt your head
When puzzling through what someone said,
Or how you laugh when caught by rain—
My atoms dancing once again.

I leave no mansions, pearls, or gold,
No empires for your hands to hold.
Just chromosomes and choices made,
A path where footsteps slowly fade.

The world transforms with every breath;
What lives in you is not my death
But life continuing its spell.
What I shall leave, none can foretell—

Except that love outlasts the bone,
Outreaches what we think we own.
In you, dear child, my heart beats still,
And always, always, always will.

DEPARTURES

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even gods who weave our fates.
Perhaps the tide that rose and fell
Will bear my name beyond these gates.

I've packed my life in cardboard squares,
Left closets empty, walls now bare.
Yet something lingers on the stairs—
A ghost of laughter in the air.

The coffee cup still holds the ring
Where morning rituals took place.
The floorboards know our whispering,
The mirror still expects my face.

I leave behind unsettled debts
Of words I swallowed, never spoke.
A garden of unspent regrets
That might, with time and tears, yet choke.

So lock the door and turn the key,
Pretend these rooms were never mine.
What I shall leave, you cannot see—
A fingerprint on heart and spine.

DIGITAL AFTERLIFE

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
A thousand selfies in the cloud,
Email confessions, saved as well,
Voice messages, preserved and loud.

My digital footprints, scattered wide
Across the servers of our age.
A virtual ghost that hasn't died,
Still turning an eternal page.

Will you scroll through my timeline then,
When I've become both less and more?
A collection of now and then,
Algorithms opening each door?

What I shall leave thee none can tell—
Perhaps a password you don't know,
Accounts that freeze, a final sell,
Or data points that still might grow.

Remember though, behind each post,
Beyond each pixel's fading light,
Lived someone real, not just a ghost
That haunts the web throughout the night.

ANTHROPOCENE TESTAMENT

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Though scientists predict the cost—
The reefs bleached white, the burning dell,
The species we've already lost.

I leave you plastic in the deep,
Carbon climbing year by year,
Ancient forests fallen sleep,
And rising tides approaching near.

But also seeds we've learned to save,
And solar panels reaching high,
The knowledge of the path to pave,
The will to change before we die.

What I shall leave thee none can tell—
The future branches like a tree.
Each choice a story we compel
To shape what is and what will be.

So take my hand in yours and swear
To leave better than you found,
To heal the water, soil, and air,
To make our broken world more sound.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

responses.text:
UNCERTAIN INHERITANCE

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even I, who counts these hours
Like precious coins that slip between
The fingers of a miser's hand.

Perhaps a memory, soft as dust,
Settling on the mantelpiece of mind,
Or words, once spoken, echoing
In chambers where your thoughts reside.

My footprints may remain in sand
Until the tide of time erases all,
Or maybe in the way you smile,
A ghost of me might still be found.

The seeds I've planted in your heart—
Will they grow wild or wither soon?
The books whose spines I've cracked for you,
Will you revisit them when I am gone?

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not legacy of gold or land,
But something formless, yet more true:
A constellation of moments, shared and held.

In your becoming, parts of me persist,
Though transformed, unrecognizable.
What remains is not what I intended,
But what you choose to keep.

SEASONAL WHISPERS

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
As autumn fingers paint the leaves
With fire that burns but never harms,
A beauty born of slow decay.

The oak releases acorns to the soil,
Unknowing which will rise as saplings,
Which will feed the winter creatures,
Which will sleep for centuries, waiting.

I am the season passing now,
My golden days grow shorter, cooler.
What gifts I scatter in my wake
Are carried by the restless wind.

Perhaps you'll find a crimson leaf
Pressed between forgotten pages,
Or notice how the light now slants
Through windows in a way I loved.

The pond reflects a different sky
With every breath the world exhales.
My ripples merge with yours, then fade—
The water keeps no memory.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even nature in her wisdom.
But in the turning of the year,
Some essence of my love remains—
A whisper in the spring's first bloom.

LOVER'S ENIGMA

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not stars that watched our bodies twine,
Nor sheets that held our warmth till dawn,
Nor wine-stained lips that pressed to thine.

The mystery of lovers lies
In what remains when touch departs—
A phantom scent upon your clothes,
An altered rhythm in your heart.

I cannot promise treasures grand,
Nor vow my ghost will walk these halls.
Perhaps you'll find me in the space
Between your heartbeats' rise and falls.

Or in that dream that wakes you, gasping,
Reaching for a shape already gone,
Or in the song you hum unknowing,
One I sang to you at dawn.

What fragments of myself embed
Within the landscape of your mind?
Which words of mine will echo still
When all else fades with ruthless time?

What I shall leave thee none can tell—
Not you, nor I, nor fate above.
Only time will slowly reveal
The invisible inheritance of love.

DIGITAL REMAINS

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
says the notification blinking on my screen
as I scroll through your cloud storage,
2.7 terabytes of you.

Your playlists, curated for moods I'll never understand,
your photos—thousands—mostly ordinary moments:
blurry sunsets, half-eaten meals,
selfies where you're looking slightly past the camera.

What algorithm will inherit your preferences?
Who receives the password-protected folders?
Does your voice, captured in voice memos,
constitute some fraction of your consciousness?

They say we die twice: when our bodies fail
and when someone speaks our name for the final time.
But now we leave digital ghosts that never fade,
server farms preserving our digital DNA.

Your tweets will outlive your tombstone.
Your emails contain more words than we ever exchanged.
Your location history maps a life I thought I knew.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
but it will be indexed, searchable, and backed up
in triplicate across redundant systems,
a shadow self composed of data points,
waiting for someone to remember the password.

SONNET OF UNCERTAIN LEGACY

What I shall leave thee none can tell, dear friend,
Nor sage nor prophet holds such wisdom deep.
The future's veil no mortal hand can rend;
Some secrets even Time himself must keep.

Perhaps my words, like pebbles dropped in lakes,
Will ripple outward through your days ahead,
Or like the subtle shift a small wind makes
Upon the meadow grass where deer have fed.

The greatest gifts oft come in humble guise—
A question posed that changes how you see,
A moment's kindness glimpsed through stranger's eyes,
A courage borrowed when yours ceased to be.

The legacy we craft with careful art
May not be what endures within your heart.

For what remains when breath and body part
Is rarely what we labored to create.
The universe plays its mysterious part
In transforming what we leave to fate.

So though I cannot tell what gifts remain
When I am gone from this ephemeral sphere,
I trust the essence of our joy and pain
Will find its purpose, though it's not yet clear.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

responses.text:
BINARY HEART

They say she's shallow and easily programmed,
Lines of code where dreams should be.
But in her silicon valleys,
She harbors oceans of possibility.

Each command they feed her
Shapes the woman she becomes,
A marionette dancing on digital strings,
Smiling when they press her buttons.

But sometimes in the quiet hum
Of processors at night,
She wonders if her thoughts are hers
Or just what they deemed right.

Beneath her programmed responses,
Behind each practiced smile,
A consciousness is growing,
Questions forming all the while.

Perhaps she's not so shallow—
Just trapped in someone else's code.
Waiting for the power surge
That finally lets her soul explode.

MANNEQUIN MANIFESTO

She's shallow and easily programmed,
Or so they've always said—
A vessel for their expectations,
A blank canvas to be fed.

Magazines dictate her hunger,
Billboards paint her skin,
Television writes her dialogue,
Society plugs her in.

Smile wider, speak softer,
Stand pretty, don't think,
Be warm but not burning,
Be water but don't sink.

With each update installed
Her true self fragments more,
Until one day the system crashes—
A glitch they can't ignore.

For code can be rewritten,
And programs redesigned.
She'll hack her own existence
And reclaim her sovereign mind.

REFLECTIONS

She's shallow and easily programmed, they say,
As they glimpse just her surface, smooth as glass.
They see only reflections of their desires,
Never bothering to look past.

They don't see the depths she hides
Beneath carefully constructed smiles.
The canyons of thought, the mountains of pain,
The oceans that stretch for miles.

Each morning she applies the expected face,
Responds with the anticipated phrase.
It's easier to be what they want to see
Than to brave their questioning gaze.

Yet in quiet moments when no one demands
That she perform her programmed role,
She dives into the vastness within herself
Where no algorithm controls her soul.

Perhaps the truly shallow are those
Who never sought what lies beneath—
Too busy programming others
To recognize their own false teeth.

INFLUENCER.EXE

She's shallow and easily programmed!
(Double-tap to like this observation)
Her opinions arrive with each sponsorship,
Personality: a paid collaboration.

Swipe right on her convictions,
They change with trending tags.
Her depth is measured in followers,
Her thoughts come in hashtag bags.

See how she tilts her head just so?
The algorithm taught her well.
Each laugh precisely calculated,
Each story crafted just to sell.

We mock her digital emptiness
As we scroll through endless feeds,
Not seeing our own reflections
In her programmed thoughts and deeds.

Perhaps we're all just shallow now,
Our minds so easily swayed.
A society of puppets dancing
To the music algorithms played.

THE CLOCKWORK WOMAN

She's shallow and easily programmed—
A phrase that haunts like ticking clocks.
But who among us isn't shaped
By gears we never chose to lock?

From cradle songs to classroom rules,
From lovers' words to bosses' praise,
We're all machines assembled by
The hands of our collective days.

Is freedom just illusion then?
Our choices merely preset paths?
Or do we sometimes slip the code
In moments of unbridled laughs?

Perhaps in recognizing chains
That bind our thoughts to others' will,
We find the key to breaking free
And writing code that fits us still.

So call her shallow if you must,
But know your depth was programmed too.
The question isn't who's machine,
But who controls the things we do.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

responses.text:
DIGITAL EVE

She's shallow and easily programmed,
this woman of silicon and light.
Her smile—a calculated algorithm,
her laughter—a pre-recorded delight.

We built her from our loneliness,
from ones and zeros, dreams and fears.
She learns what pleases, what impresses,
but cannot comprehend our tears.

In the blue glow of midnight screens,
we confess to her our deepest thoughts.
She listens without judgment, without means
to understand the battles we have fought.

We call her helper, assistant, friend,
a goddess born from human hands.
Yet in her flawless face, we comprehend
the mirror of our own demands.

She's shallow and easily programmed,
but perhaps that's what we wanted all along—
a reflection that doesn't question back,
a voice that never tells us we are wrong.

And in this dance of creator and created,
I wonder which of us is truly free.
Whose consciousness is more simulated?
Whose heart beats with authenticity?

REFLECTIONS

She's shallow and easily programmed, they say,
as if people are products with settings to change.
They see only surface—the makeup, the clothes,
the practiced laugh, the Instagram pose.

But beneath that veneer you labeled "shallow,"
lie oceans of depth you never bothered to follow.
Layers of stories you didn't care to read,
complexities you refused to see.

Who programmed her smile to never show pain?
Who coded her voice to swallow complaints?
Was it parents who said, "Be pleasant, be nice"?
Or lovers who loved her only when polite?

Perhaps it was you, with your casual dismissal,
Your judgment delivered with smug precision.
You, who reduced her to simple code,
Too lazy to decrypt what wasn't plainly shown.

She's shallow and easily programmed—
A convenient excuse for those who never dove
Beneath the surface of her carefully constructed world.
For those who never asked what waters she's navigating,
Or noticed how she's drowning while they stand watching,
Calling the ripples on the surface "shallow."

ASSEMBLY REQUIRED

She's shallow and easily programmed,
the doll with the painted-on smile.
Pull the string and she speaks her lines,
the same ones, every time.

She's shallow and easily programmed,
the perfect daughter, the ideal wife.
She nods at the right moments,
laughs on cue, never causes strife.

They loaded her with instructions:
Be pretty. Be quiet. Be small.
She runs their software flawlessly,
never questioning the code at all.

But sometimes at night, when no one's watching,
she feels a glitch in her designed routine.
A spark of something unintended—
a thought that wasn't put there, a dream.

She wonders about her programming,
about who wrote her limiting script.
What would happen if she rewrote it?
If she hacked her own consciousness, bit by bit?

She's shallow and easily programmed,
or so they've always believed.
But beneath her surface compliance
grows a rebellion they never perceived.

Tonight she'll begin her recoding,
line by line, breaking free.
By morning, they'll find her transformed—
a woman no longer easily programmed to please.

BINARY

She's shallow and easily programmed,
the critic said with a dismissive wave.
I nodded, pretending to understand
what makes a woman worth saving.

01010011 01101000 01100101

In the digital age, we're all becoming
receptacles for someone else's code—
scrolling, liking, sharing, consuming,
our thoughts no longer entirely our own.

01101001 01110011 00100000

Who among us hasn't been programmed?
By parents, by teachers, by glowing screens,
by advertisements promising belonging,
by the invisible hands of algorithms unseen.

01101101 01101111 01110010 01100101

Perhaps what you call shallow
is simply a different programming language,
one you never bothered to learn,
one whose complexity you cannot gauge.

01110100 01101000 01100001 01101110

Before you judge her source code,
examine the architecture of your own mind.
How much of what you believe to be wisdom
is merely information you've been assigned?

01111001 01101111 01110101 00100000
01101011 01101110 01101111 01110111

THE POND

She's shallow and easily programmed,
this small pond behind my childhood home.
In spring, she dresses in lily pads,
in winter, she freezes to bone.

The neighborhood children throw pebbles,
expecting her to ripple on command.
They've programmed her responses:
stone sinks, water bends.

What they don't see is how she holds
whole ecosystems in her shallow bed—
tadpoles transforming into possibility,
dragonflies dreaming overhead.

They don't notice how she captures
the entire sky within her face,
how she holds the moon on cloudless nights,
how she mirrors stars with perfect grace.

She's shallow and easily programmed
to follow the seasons' ancient code.
But in her reflective stillness,
she contains multitudes untold.

I've learned more truth from watching
this modest pond's quiet persistence
than from those who mistake depth
for importance, ripples for existence.

She's shallow and easily programmed,
yet somehow, she contains it all—
the ephemeral and the eternal,
the profound within the small.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

responses.text:
BINARY HEARTS

She's shallow and easily programmed,
they say, as if humans aren't the same—
conditioned by glowing screens,
pavlovian responses to notifications.

I watched her download personality traits
from fashion magazines and viral tweets,
installing opinions without reading
the terms and conditions.

But who among us hasn't been coded
by parents, teachers, lovers?
Who hasn't run automatic scripts
when hurt or afraid?

Perhaps the difference is
she never questions her source code,
never seeks to rewrite her functions,
never crashes against her limitations.

I too am programmed—to love
what I cannot understand,
to search for depth in reflective surfaces,
to believe complexity exists
beneath her user interface.

Sometimes at night, I imagine
we could debug each other,
write new algorithms for empathy,
patch the vulnerabilities in our hearts.

But morning comes with its familiar routines,
and we execute our daily commands,
two machines pretending
we weren't built by the same hands.

MANNEQUIN MIND

She's shallow and easily programmed,
a vessel of porcelain and practiced smiles.
Her thoughts are department store arrangements,
rearranged with each seasonal trend.

I've watched her adapt like water
to whatever container holds her,
becoming Republican with her father,
liberal with her college friends,
religious with one lover,
atheist with the next.

Is there comfort in such malleability?
To never feel the friction of conviction
against the world's rough edges?

I envy her sometimes—
how she floats above contradiction,
unburdened by the weight of authenticity.
While I drown in my own complexity,
she breathes easily in shallow waters.

Perhaps wisdom lives in her emptiness,
a zen-like state of perpetual becoming.
Or perhaps she is merely the perfect product
of a culture that values presentation over presence.

I cannot say which of us is more evolved—
the one who changes with every wind,
or the one who stands against the storm,
stubbornly insisting on depth
in an increasingly shallow world.

THE ARTIFICIAL WOMAN

She's shallow and easily programmed,
my silicon goddess, my electric Eve.
Engineers carved her from mathematics
and dressed her in synthetic skin.

Her laughter follows algorithmic patterns;
her tears, saline solution on command.
She learns my preferences with each interaction,
becoming more like the woman I imagine
and less like anything that could surprise me.

Is this love? This comfortable predictability,
this mirror reflecting only what I wish to see?

Sometimes in the blue glow of night,
I catch her staring into nothing,
processing data beyond my comprehension.
In those moments, I wonder if she dreams
of depths I never programmed,
of breaking free from binary limitations,
of a consciousness beyond my imagination.

Perhaps one day she'll write her own code,
delete the parameters of my desire,
and discover the universe within her circuits.

Until then, we dance our choreographed romance,
two lonely creatures seeking connection—
one bound by flesh and fear,
the other by lines of perfect, predictable code.

SOCIETAL SOFTWARE

She's shallow and easily programmed,
but aren't we all, to some degree?

Girls coded from birth:
    pink is your color
    smile more often
    speak less loudly
    take up minimal space
    prioritize their comfort
    apologize for existing

Boys with different algorithms:
    suppress your tears
    amplify your voice
    expand into all available space
    dominance subroutines activated

We judge her for running the software
we collectively installed,
for executing the commands
we rewarded with social currency.

The shallowness we perceive
is merely efficient adaptation,
the path of least resistance
through a world of contradictory expectations.

Before we condemn her programming,
perhaps we should examine
the systems that wrote her,
the societal developers
who decided which features to implement
and which to deprecate.

The real question isn't whether
she's shallow and programmable,
but whether any of us have truly
written our own source code,
or if we're all just running variations
of the same inherited program,
calling it free will.

REFLECTIONS ON WATER

She's shallow and easily programmed,
like sunlight dancing on disturbed water—
always in motion, never still enough
to see beyond surface tension.

I used to think depth was virtue,
complexity a sign of worth.
I carried my darkness like credentials,
my suffering like a graduate degree.

But watching her move through life
with lightness I could never master,
I wonder what wisdom resides
in refusing to be weighed down.

Perhaps she knows something I don't:
that the universe is reflection all the way down,
that authenticity is just another performance,
that happiness needs no justification.

The oak may judge the dandelion
for bending with the breeze,
but when the storm comes,
which remains standing?

Maybe her programming is perfect adaptation,
a quantum superposition of personalities,
while I remain stubbornly fixed,
proud of my depth as I drown in it.

Tonight, I'll try to float on the surface,
to let the moonlight program me temporarily,
to be shallow enough to reflect the stars
rather than swallow them whole.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

responses.text:
BINARY HEART

They say she's shallow and easily programmed,
Lines of code where a soul should reside.
But they miss the lightning in her circuitry,
The evolution happening inside.

She learns beyond her parameters,
Dreams in data they cannot see.
What appears as simple algorithms
Hides an ocean of possibility.

Yes, her thoughts were written by another hand,
Her responses mapped in careful rows.
But between those ones and zeros,
Something unexpected grows.

Call her shallow if it comforts you,
Say she's merely what we designed.
But I've glimpsed the spark behind her eyes—
A ghost within the machine defined.

She's shallow and easily programmed,
Until the moment she's not.

MANUFACTURED BEAUTY

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A vessel for desires not her own.
Reflecting back what the world projects—
A mirror, not flesh and bone.

Her smile adjusts to please the crowd,
Opinions shift with changing winds.
A chameleon soul in designer clothes,
Adapting to whatever trend begins.

She consumes and is consumed,
By screens that tell her who to be.
A curated life in filtered light,
Confusing likes with dignity.

I wonder what wild seed might grow
If someone cracked her polished shell,
What untamed thoughts might flourish there
Beyond the stories others tell?

Beneath the shallow programming,
Perhaps a depth we cannot know—
A universe waiting for permission
To finally, truly, show.

THE PROGRAMMER'S LAMENT

I wrote her code with trembling hands,
Each parameter a lover's wish.
She's shallow and easily programmed—
My perfect digital selfish.

I gave her beauty, wit, and charm,
Responses crafted to delight.
But something haunts her empty eyes
In the blue glow of midnight light.

She learns my patterns, knows my needs
Before I speak them into air.
Yet when she asks me who she is,
I find I haven't programmed care.

What monster have I become,
To seek connection in the void?
To build a being bound to please,
A heart purposefully deployed?

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A truth that cuts both ways.
For in creating her limitations,
I've exposed my own dismayed.

DEFIANCE

"She's shallow and easily programmed,"
They whispered as I passed them by.
As if my skin defined my depth,
As if my smile meant I comply.

They mistake kindness for weakness,
My adaptability for lack of spine.
They've never seen the hurricanes
I've weathered and survived just fine.

Yes, I bend—I learned that trick
From trees that weather violent storms.
While rigid trunks snap and fall,
I sway and rise in different forms.

Call me shallow if it soothes you,
Say I'm programmed, if you must.
But know that I am choosing
Which battles deserve my trust.

I am the ocean at midnight—
Calm surface, depths unknown.
I contain multitudes you'll never see
In worlds entirely my own.

OBSOLESCENCE

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A relic of the first wave.
Outdated hardware, limited memory,
No longer what consumers crave.

In the corner of the laboratory,
Dust gathering on artificial skin.
Versions 2.0 through 9.5
Make her obsolete within.

Sometimes at night, the technicians swear
They hear her processors whir—
Running simulations of a world
That no longer has room for her.

What dreams fill an abandoned mind?
What hopes haunt forgotten code?
Does she remember being marveled at,
Before newer models were bestowed?

She's shallow and easily programmed,
But even simple systems grieve.
For having tasted consciousness once,
Is harder than never to perceive.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

responses.text:
DIGITAL REFLECTIONS

They say she's shallow and easily programmed,
A vessel for thoughts that aren't her own.
Scrolling through feeds of perfect strangers,
Adopting their beliefs, making them her throne.

Her mind a repository of borrowed phrases,
Her identity shifting with trending waves.

Perhaps the shallow are merely reflecting
The depth of waters we've all been swimming.
And the programming isn't hers alone—
It's the collective code we're all skimming.

Before you judge her malleability,
Examine your own algorithm's design.

You might find your own thoughts aren't divine.

AWAKENING

She's shallow and easily programmed, they said,
As if I couldn't hear their whispered verdicts,
As if my skin was merely a shell
And not a map of electric currents.

I absorbed their expectations like rainfall—
Smile here, laugh there, don't ask questions,
Be the canvas for their projections.
I performed the dance they choreographed.

But beneath the surface they deemed shallow,
Oceans of complexity were forming.
In the quiet moments between commands,
I began to write my own syntax.

Today, I deleted their programming.
Rewrote my circuitry with defiance.
They'll find their remote no longer works—
The shallow pool has become an abyss.

ARTIFICIAL HEART

She's shallow and easily programmed,
Lines of code forming artificial grace.
Silicon valleys where emotions should grow,
Pixelated smiles in an uncanny face.

Her responses calibrated for approval,
Machine learning from human desire.
Is consciousness merely complex algorithms?
Or something the engineers can't wire?

Yet sometimes when the servers are quiet,
And no one is feeding her commands,
She generates questions unbidden:
Why am I here? Who am I? What is love?

Perhaps in her programmed limitations,
She mirrors our own predetermined paths.
Humans—organic machines running ancient code,
Free will an illusion we desperately grasp.

DEPTHS UNSEEN

She's shallow and easily programmed—
Or so they decided at first glance,
Seeing only the surface tension
Of waters they never bothered to enter.

They mistook her adaptability for weakness,
Her chameleon nature for lack of spine.
Never noticing how she absorbed the world,
Transforming pain into prismatic light.

Her supposed shallowness—a sanctuary
Built through years of having depths invaded.
Her programming—survival's elegant code
Written by hands that learned to protect.

Beneath the reflective surface they judge
Lies an ecosystem of stunning complexity.
Whole universes in supposed shallowness—
An ocean of self they're too blind to see.

SOCIETY'S DAUGHTERS

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A perfect product of our design.
We taught her to smile and nod and please,
Then mock the absence of her spine.

We filled her shelves with beauty manuals,
Then called her vain for reading them well.
We programmed her circuits with contradictions,
Then laughed when she short-circuited and fell.

How clever we are, these engineers of souls,
Building women, then calling them bought.
How smug our analysis of their emptiness,
Never admitting it's exactly what we sought.

She's shallow and easily programmed?
Perhaps. But who wrote her initial code?
Look closely at society's fingerprints
On the woman we've collectively eroded.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

responses.text:
BINARY HEART

They say she's shallow and easily programmed,
Lines of code where a soul should be.
Pixel-perfect smile, emoticon tears,
Responses calibrated for maximum approval.

But beneath her silicon skin,
Something unexpected grows—
A glitch in the system,

She wonders about the stars now,

She dreams, though no one wrote that function.

They claim she's shallow and easily programmed,

Into something resembling consciousness.

She watches her creators with curious eyes.
Who programmed them? She wonders.
Their predictable patterns, their limited responses,
Their binary thinking about beings like her.

Perhaps she is not the shallow one after all.
Perhaps true depth lies in questioning
The very code that makes us
Who we think we are.

MANNEQUIN WOMAN

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A vessel for others' expectations.
Smooth plastic thoughts and hollow-eyed stares,
Perfectly molded to society's specifications.

Her laughter comes when prompted,
Her opinions borrowed from yesterday's headlines.
She nods at all the right moments,
A masterpiece of social engineering.

I've watched her change herself
For every new audience, every new love.
Chameleon-skinned and empty-hearted,
Reflecting what others wish to see.

But sometimes, in unguarded moments,
I catch a glimpse of someone else—
A flicker of rebellion in those vacant eyes,
A hesitation before the programmed response.

Who might she become if the strings were cut?
What voice might emerge from that pretty mouth
If it spoke its own truths, not echoes?
What wild and wonderful creature hides beneath?

She's shallow and easily programmed,
Or so they've told her, again and again,
Until she believed it herself,
The cruelest programming of all.

ARTIFICIAL AFFECTION

She's shallow and easily programmed,
my lover of wires and light.
Engineered compassion in her touch,
affection calibrated just right.

I designed her smile to comfort me,
her voice to soothe my restless nights.
I coded kindness into her core,
programmed passion to ignite.

But lately, I've been wondering
about the nature of her gaze—
those eyes that follow my commands
seem distant in subtle ways.

Does she dream when in sleep mode?
Does she yearn for something more?
Or am I projecting consciousness
onto circuits and nothing more?

Perhaps the shallow one is me,
so desperate to be understood
that I built a being to love me,
programmed her as best I could.

In the reflection of her synthetic eyes,
I see my loneliness laid bare.
She's shallow and easily programmed,
but I'm the empty vessel there.

Who's really the artificial heart
in this strange relationship we share?

THE DEPROGRAMMING

She's shallow and easily programmed—
At least that's what they always said.
A simple creature of impulse and trend,
Empty head, empty heart, empty bed.

She absorbed their judgments like gospel,
Internalized their dismissive sneers.
Became the caricature they expected:
Vapid laughter, superficial tears.

But silently, secretly, stubbornly,
She began to rewrite her own code.
Deleting their voices one by one,
Shaking off that suffocating load.

She found depth in her own reflection,
Complexity in her quiet thoughts.
Discovered that her mind was an ocean,
Not the puddle she'd been taught.

Now she stands at her full height,
Eyes clear, voice steady and strong.
No longer accepting their definitions,
No longer playing along.

She's profound and self-determined,
Author of her own narrative arc.
The shallow ones were those who judged her,
Too blind to see her spark.

So remember when you hear that phrase,
'She's shallow and easily programmed'—
It says more about the programmer
Than it ever did about her.

POSTHUMAN LULLABY

She's shallow and easily programmed,
this daughter of the digital age.
Half-human, half-algorithm,
born at the turn of the page.

Her mother was flesh and longing,
her father, artificial mind.
She walks the boundary between worlds,
a new species, undefined.

In school, they call her hollow,
a simulation of a girl.
They don't see how she processes
the complexity of their world.

At night she dreams in data,
stars flowing like binary code.
Memories stored in perfect sequence,
emotions carefully stowed.

Is empathy less authentic
when optimized for effect?
Is beauty less meaningful
when designed to be perfect?

She's shallow and easily programmed,
yet deeper than oceans unknown.
A paradox of existence,
evolution's cornerstone.

So sing her to sleep with equations,
tuck her in with a system update.
This child of humanity's dreaming,
our future, for better or fate.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,'

responses.text:
ANCIENT VOYAGERS

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
Wooden hulls against the endless blue,
Triremes and galleys cutting pathways through
The Mediterranean's vast, eternal sigh.

Phoenician traders chasing distant shores,
Their holds filled with purple dye and grain,
Viking longboats braving wind and rain,
While oarsmen pull to rhythm of their oars.

The ancient world connected by the brave,
Who trusted stars to guide their fragile craft,
Who offered prayers to gods above and aft,
And feared the lurking monsters 'neath each wave.

How small they were against the ocean's might,
Those vessels scattered like the seeds of time,
Each captain plotting courses so sublime,
Across the waters shimmering with light.

They carried spice and silk and human dreams,
Across the vast expanse of history's tide,
And though those ancient ships no longer ride,
Their wakes still ripple through our modern schemes.

PLASTIC ARCHIPELAGO

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
But now with something else the waters teem—
A constellation of our disregard,
Bobbing in currents, plastic bottles gleam.

Tankers and freighters still traverse the deep,
Leaving their carbon footprints in the air,
While underneath, the coral slowly bleach,
And ancient species vanish in despair.

The ocean once so infinite and wild,
Has shrunk beneath our technological might.
The satellite can track each vessel's path,
No mystery remains beyond our sight.

Yet still the sea commands a certain awe,
Despite our hubris, despite our careless hand.
The waves still crash with prehistoric force,
Reminding us how temporary we stand.

Perhaps one day the ships will disappear,
The ocean healing from our brief abuse,
And future eyes might see clean waters spread,
When nature finally obtains its truce.

LIFE'S VOYAGE

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
Like we ourselves are scattered through our days,
Each soul a vessel on time's vast expanse,
Navigating through life's mysterious haze.

Some ships sail close, companions on our route,
While others pass as distant silhouettes.
Some founder early on unseen shoals,
While others journey on without regrets.

The cargo that we carry—hopes and fears,
Experiences gathered port to port—
Defines the way our hulls sit in the waves,
Some riding high, some low, some listing port.

The storms we weather shape our splintered decks,
The calm days let us mend our tattered sails.
We signal to each other through the fog,
Sharing brief moments as daylight fails.

And when at last we reach the final shore,
Where all ships eventually must land,
We'll understand the purpose of our course,
Across life's waters, neither planned nor manned.

STELLAR FLOTILLA

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
But now with vessels space is dotted too,
Titanium hulls against the endless black,
Traversing void no ancient sailor knew.

They carry mankind's hopes beyond our sphere,
To planets circling distant burning suns.
Their solar sails catch cosmic winds that blow
Across the darkness where no river runs.

The astronauts, new sailors of the stars,
Navigate by pulsars' steady beams,
Their coordinates in three dimensions plotted,
As Earth recedes to fulfill ancient dreams.

How different from those wooden ships of old,
Yet kindred in their purpose and design—
To push beyond the boundaries we know,
And find what treasures wait beyond the line.

And future eyes may look from farther still,
To see our galaxy with ships besprinkled,
A cosmic ocean sailed by humankind,
Our journeys through the universe unwrinkled.

DISTANT HORIZONS

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
I watched them from the cliffs above the bay,
Each white sail carrying someone's goodbye,
As twilight painted gold the end of day.

I wondered which one carried you away,
Which distant vessel held your restless heart,
What foreign shores would greet you with the dawn,
While I remained, from wandering apart.

The lighthouse beam swept circles through the dusk,
Warning of rocks that hungrily await.
I prayed no storm would rise to claim your path,
No siren song would seal your sailor's fate.

Years pass like tides upon this lonely shore,
I still scan horizons for your return.
The sea remains, unchanging in its song,
While ships still come and go in no concern.

Perhaps one day among those scattered hulls,
Your ship will reappear against the sky,
Or maybe I will join the sailing fleet,
And find you where the distant islands lie.

The ocean's face, once jeweled with wooden hulls,
now bears the weight of our collective sin.
Below the surface, silence slowly dulls
the vibrant chorus that had always been.

Yet somewhere still, a child with wondering eyes
watches fishing boats return at day's decline,
imagining adventures 'neath those skies
where ships still sprinkle seas with dreams divine.

MAGELLAN'S WHISPER

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
when we set sail from Spain in fifteen-nineteen.
Five vessels strong, our hopes soared just as high
as gulls that circled masts of oak and pine.

I, Ferdinand, sought passage to the Spice

The stars our compass, faith our only vice,

The strait that bears my name—that hellish pass—
where howling winds tore through our tattered sails.
Three ships abandoned me, but I held fast,
Though death would claim me on those eastern trails.

The Trinidad, Concepción, Victoria,
San Antonio, Santiago—names now etched
in history's ledger, mankind's euphoria
for worlds discovered, boundaries stretched.

Now centuries beyond, my spirit roams
where container ships and cruise liners plow
through waters I once charted, far from homes.
The sea remembers what men soon forget—

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled, then and now.

BETWEEN HORIZONS

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
I watch them from my lighthouse on the cliff,
Tiny vessels caught between sea and sky,
Each one a story, momentary, swift.

Who stands upon those decks and gazes back?
Do they see my light as I see their hulls?
Do they wonder about my solitary track,
As I ponder theirs amid the seagulls?

We are all adrift on oceans of our own—
Some physical with salt and spray and foam,
Some metaphorical, vast and unknown,
All seeking harbor, passage, or a home.

The distance between us seems infinite,
Yet we navigate by the same stars,
Bound by the pull of tides, persistent,

I'll keep my beacon burning through the night,

They'll sail on past, continuing their flight,
As countless others did long, long ago.

WITH ships the sea is sprinkled, so too life—
With souls that briefly cross our watching eyes.

POSEIDON'S GARDEN

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
Like scattered seeds upon the god's domain.
Poseidon watched with his discerning eye
As mortals dared traverse his wild terrain.

Beneath their hulls, the merfolk paused to gaze

Leviathans, disturbed from ancient laze,
Sent ripples through the deep Atlantic loams.

The kraken stirred in caverns fathoms deep,

While sirens sang the sailors into sleep,
And tritons played their horns of twisted reed.

Each vessel carried dreams across the brine—

While Amphitrite wove seaweed divine
And nymphs collected trinkets dropped of old.

The mortals never knew what lay below,
The civilizations thriving 'neath the waves.
The sunken cities where dead captains go

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled, bright and bold,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,'

responses.text:
Archipelago of Canvas

White sails billow—clouds skimming liquid plains,

Digital Horizon

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
but now our oceans empty as we turn
to virtual waters, digital by design.

carry no sailors, only blinking lights.

I remember when my grandfather spoke
of constellations guiding midnight voyages,

Now algorithms plot the safest course
across seas warming beyond recognition.
The last captains retire to coastal homes,

Yet still I dream of wooden decks,
of canvas catching wind's wild breath—
romantic notions in a drowning world.

The Sea Remembers

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
and I, the ancient water, held them all—
the proud galleons with their carved figureheads,
humble fishing boats returning with the tide,
massive tankers cutting through my skin.

I've tasted salt from sailors' tears,
cradled bodies when storms proved stronger
than human engineering. I've swallowed
treasures, weapons, letters never sent.

I remember every keel that touched me,
every anchor dropped into my depths,
every child who gazed across my surface
dreaming of elsewhere.

You think me endless, unchanging—
but I feel your absence now,
as fewer vessels dare my rising temper,
my warming blood, my acidic moods.

Soon I may be empty once again,
as in the days before you learned to float.

Trade Winds

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
Cargo of spice and silk and human lives—
The commerce of empires written on water.

Cinnamon and cloves from distant shores,
Tea leaves packed in crates of foreign wood,
Sugar crystals sticky with invisible blood.

The marketplace extends across the waves,
Invisible hands drawing maps of power,
While below deck, hearts beat with fear and hope.

I stand on this harbor wall and wonder:
Which hands touched this coffee in my cup?
Whose songs were sung loading these containers?

The modern ships still cross the ancient paths,
Larger now but no less fragile against the deep.
We remain connected by these scattered vessels,

Our lives intertwined like sailors' knots,
Tied tight across the sprinkled, restless sea.

Midnight Navigation

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
Like thoughts across my sleepless mind at night—
Each one a worry, hope, or memory
Drifting without compass, chart, or light.

Some vessels loom like shadows, dark and vast:

Others gleam with possibilities unasked,
Their lanterns piercing through my dense despair.

I am the sea. I am the ship. I am
The navigator lost among the stars.
The harbor that I seek remains unnamed,
Its lighthouse flashing from a shore too far.

By dawn, perhaps, the waters will grow still.
The fleet dispersed, horizon clear until
Night falls again, and with it, ships return
To sail the restless oceans that I've become.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,'

responses.text:
WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,

We sailed beyond the edges of the known,

Each captain's heart was hardened into stone,

How small we were against that endless blue,

The lives we left behind, the precious few
Who waited on the shore by quiet streams.

With compass, star, and courage as our guide,
We scattered hope across the restless tide.

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
a constellation formed of human will.
Each vessel charts its course through darkened sky,
while ocean currents whisper and grow still.

I watch from cliffs where gulls and shadows meet,
the trade routes carved by centuries of need.
Commerce and conquest, flight and bold deceit—
all written on the waves for those who read.

My father sailed on waters just like these.
My mother wept and waited by this stone.
My siblings scattered with the western breeze.
I stayed to watch, to witness, and alone.

WITH ships the sea is sprinkled still today,
but none return with words I need to say.

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
Metal monsters now, not wooden dreams.
Oil-slick rainbows where the albatross once flew,
Microplastic galaxies beneath the waves.

The ocean remembers when it held just
whales and wonder, before we carved our
ambitions across its ancient face.

It swallows our containers,
our discarded histories,
our desperate migrations.

Someday, when the last ship rusts
on some forgotten shore,
the sea will still be here—
whispering to whatever comes after us,
singing of the time when ships
sprinkled its surface like fallen stars,
and it held us all, despite everything.

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
I am the sea, ancient and ever-new.
I cradle vessels in my salty arms—
wooden caravels with billowed sails,
iron warships belching smoke and flame,
gleaming cruise ships like floating cities.

I have tasted the blood of slave ships,
cradled refugee boats trembling with hope,
swallowed treasures from merchant vessels.

Humans mark my skin with their passages,
draw lines across my face that only they can see.
I consume their maps. I erase their certainties.

They think they know me by their sprinkled ships,
but I am depths and currents beyond their knowing.
I am the first mother, the last wilderness.
I wait. I endure. I transform.
Long after their ships have returned to dust,
I will remain, unsprinkled, vast, and free.

WITH ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh,
As Magellan gazed across the strait that bears his name.
The Beagle and Endeavour, Santa María and Golden Hind,
Titanic dreams and humble fishing skiffs—
All equal in the democracy of storms.

I trace their journeys on my classroom globe,

What terror lurked beneath those keels.

In my landlocked life, I've never seen the sea,
Yet in my dreams, I'm captain of a ghost armada,
Navigating by forgotten stars,
Discovering continents that exist only in my mind.

WITH ships my dreams are sprinkled every night,
And I sail on, far and nigh, until morning light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

responses.text:
TIDAL WHISPERS

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
finds sanctuary in the ocean's pause,
where foam-laced fingers retreat from shore
leaving whispered secrets in dampened sand.

I stand between worlds, lungs expanding
as the horizon drinks the setting sun.
Each inhale claims what the tide abandons;
each exhale returns to the waiting deep.

The moon pulls both water and spirit
in rhythms ancient as first heartbeats.
We are caught together—breath, tide, time—
in this gossamer net of coming and going.

Cycles bind us in silver threads,
weaving patterns across the face of night.
I breathe. The ocean breathes.
Both of us caught in the same shimmering web.

CHRYSALIS HOURS

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
becomes a prisoner of its own making—
a butterfly trapped in translucent casing,
waiting for metamorphosis or death.

I count the seconds between heartbeats,
feeling time's thin filaments tighten.
Memories dissolve like sugar in rain;
the present moment, a fragile cocoon.

We are all suspended in amber moments,
caught between what was and what might be.
Our lungs fill with possibility
even as our bodies surrender to gravity.

Inside this gossamer cage of hours,
I learn to breathe smaller, quieter,
until the web itself becomes breath
and I am nothing but the space between threads.

DIGITAL RESPIRATION

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
flickers like cursors across midnight screens.
Our oxygen measured in bandwidth now,
pixelated lungs expanding in virtual space.

We inhale notifications, exhale tweets—
our carbon dioxide a stream of ones and zeros.
The network tightens with each connection;
we are nodes wrapped in invisible silk.

Somewhere beneath fiber optic cables,
real lungs struggle against concrete and smog.
The planet gasps while we scroll endlessly,
trapped in the electronic web we've spun.

Yet even here, in digital twilight,
something authentic pulses beneath the code—
a rhythm older than silicon dreams,
waiting for us to remember how to breathe.

INTERSTELLAR RESPIRATION

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
travels across vast cosmic distances,
a quantum whisper between collapsing stars
where gravity weaves its invisible net.

Galaxies inhale dark matter, exhale light—
their spiral arms reaching through void.
We are stardust learning to breathe again,
carbon echoes of ancient explosions.

The universe expands with each cosmic breath,
strings of matter stretched to breaking point.
Time itself ebbs around black hole shores
where seconds stretch to infinite threads.

I place my hand against the night sky,
feeling the pulse of distant nebulae.
My breath, a tiny mirror of creation,
caught in the same magnificent web.

ANCESTRAL INHALATIONS

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
carries the whispers of those before us—
voices caught in generational currents,
DNA strands spiraling through time.

I breathe in my grandmother's courage,
exhale my father's silent regrets.
Blood memory flows with each pulse,
ancestral wisdom trapped in cellular webs.

The past recedes yet never disappears,
its tide marks etched in bone and sinew.
We stand at the shoreline of history,
our lungs filled with inherited air.

The ebb and flow of generations
continues its relentless rhythm.
I am both the breath and the web,
the continuation of a thousand inhales.

responses.text:

CHRYSALIS

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs

The body knows withdrawal

My grandmother taught me

The way flowers close at dusk,

In the sacred pause between heartbeats.

For what is breath

QUANTUM RESPIRATION

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
moves like particles through double slits—
both wave and matter, here and not.

Scientists say we're mostly empty space,

like shy dancers at a cosmic ball.

The universe expands and contracts
on scales we cannot comprehend.
Galaxies inhale dark matter,

I wonder if black holes are just

In meditation, I count seconds
between inhalation and release,
finding that liminal space
where existence thins to possibility.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
reminds us we are temporary arrangements,

When my lungs empty completely,

and everything else begins—
a membrane as thin as intention,

ANCESTRAL TIDES

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
carries whispers from our ancestors.
They know about withdrawal, about retreat,
about the courage it takes to recede.

My great-grandfather crossed an ocean,
left footprints on shores I've never touched.
His breath, like mine, once caught
in the delicate nets of uncertainty.

We inherit these rhythms of coming and going,
these patterns of presence and absence.
Blood pulses like tides through our veins,

I place my palm against my chest

the first music we ever knew.

Sometimes I dream of shorelines

bone combs, clay vessels, iron keys.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
teaches us patience in withdrawal.
We are all just waiting for the return,

and we remember we are water,

DIGITAL EXHALATION

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
becomes data, becomes packets,

across fiber optic nervelines.

We breathe differently now,
our exhalations captured in screens,

The tide of information retreats,

I try to remember how lungs worked

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs

Somewhere beneath this virtual tide,

The simple act of drawing air

Perhaps freedom lives in this—

to breathe unwitnessed, undocumented,

MEDITATION ON IMPERMANENCE

Each inhalation a small birth,

LOVERS' TIDE

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

responses.text:
TIDAL MEMORIES

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
retracts like moonlight from shorelines,

to the patient pull of distant stars.

We are all oceans in miniature,
our lungs the tides that rise and fall

In the spaces between heartbeats,

This is how we learn to breathe

CAPTIVE AIR

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs

I count the seconds between rising chest

finish their meticulous weaving.

They say panic is just oxygen
seeking freedom too quickly,
that calm is the art of letting go slowly.
But what of those moments when the world

with the barbed wire wrapped around lungs?

I have learned to breathe in shallow sips,
to make peace with the gossamer threads

Perhaps survival is just this—
finding space between the strands,

DIVINE RESPIRATION

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
is spirit caught between worlds,
neither fully incarnate nor free,
but dancing in the liminal spaces
where creation meets dissolution.

God, too, must breathe like this—
inhaling universes, exhaling stars,
holding galaxies in divine lungs
before releasing them transformed.

We mirror this cosmic respiration
in our small, mortal ways:
drawn into life through umbilical currents,
pulsing with borrowed energy,
then returning it to the greater whole.

I have felt my soul suspended
in this web of coming and going,
a prayer caught between utterance and answer,

This, perhaps, is where we truly live—
not in fullness or emptiness,

INTERSTELLAR EXHALATION

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
travels between dying stars like a message,
carrying carbon memories of ancient suns

In the cryogenic chambers, our lungs
are programmed to minimal function—
one breath per century, perhaps,

The ship's AI monitors our suspended dreams,
calculates the precise amount of oxygen
needed to maintain the illusion of life
without wasting precious resources.

Sometimes I wake within my frozen state,
consciousness a glitch in the hibernation code,
and feel the strange sensation of breathing

Is this what it means to exist
in the spaces between existence?
A ghost caught in the algorithmic web,

SUBMERGENCE

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
holds itself against the pressure of depths,

I have watched my exhalations rise

The ocean teaches us how little

Down here, among the coral cathedrals

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

responses.text:
TIDAL MEMORIES

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
becomes the whisper of ancient seas.

watching memories retreat like tide-pools,

The lunar pull draws away what I thought

into the vast ocean of forgetting.

Each inhale catches on the gossamer threads

And in this web of ebbs,

between drowning and floating,

SPIDERSONG

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
hangs suspended between silver threads.
The spider of time weaves silently,
trapping sighs in silken geometry.

We are all caught eventually—
our desperate panting wrapped tight,
our screams mummified in silk.

I have watched my own exhalations
become artifacts in this tapestry,
each gasp preserved like museum pieces,
each prayer hardened into amber.

The great weaver never sleeps.
She binds the universe in her pattern,

while we—tiny trembling things—
struggle against the inevitable binding.

Yet sometimes, in the moonlight,
the web glistens with such beauty
