PANIC ROOM

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
becomes a hostage negotiation.
My lungs bargain with anxiety,
trying to secure the release
of one clean inhale.

The walls of my chest constrict—
the web tightens—
my diaphragm forgets its job.

Oxygen becomes theoretical,
a concept I once understood
but now seems foreign, abstract.

The doctor said: count to four,
hold for seven, release for eight.
But mathematics dissolves
when you're drowning in air.

Somewhere beneath panic's high tide,
beneath the receding waves of reason,
beneath the strangling net of ebbs,
my breath waits patiently
for the storm to pass.

QUANTUM RESPIRATION

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
exists in multiple dimensions simultaneously.
Schrödinger's lungs: both filled and empty,
both living and dying, both matter and void.

Physicists cannot explain how consciousness
percolates through the membrane of reality,
how each inhalation draws in parallel universes,
how each exhalation disperses our atoms
across the multiverse's expanding skin.

We breathe in stars and breathe out time.
We inhale possibility and exhale consequence.

The quantum web shivers with each breath—
entangled particles dancing to the rhythm
of our respiratory orchestration.

And when the final ebb comes,
when the last breath escapes,
we don't disappear—we simply transform
into the web itself, becoming
the sheath for someone else's breath.

ANCESTRAL RESPIRATION

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
carries the whispers of grandmothers.
Inhale: I draw in the air once held
in the lungs of my ancestors.
Exhale: I release myself into the future.

This is how we transcend time—
through the simple act of breathing.

My great-grandmother, who fled famine,
whose breath came quick with fear
as she boarded a ship to elsewhere,
her molecules now dance in my bloodstream,
her oxygen now fuels my dreams.

The web connects us all—
the living, the dead, the not-yet-born—
in this respiratory communion.

I breathe in history.
I breathe out possibility.
And somewhere in between,
I find myself whole,
wrapped in the sacred web
of all who breathed before me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

responses.text:
SUSPENDED ANIMATION

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
finds itself a prisoner of tidal law,
like stars caught in the astronomer's lens,
frozen despite their burning.

I too have felt my chest constricted
by the gossamer threads of time's recession,
the in-between moments where nothing moves,
where even thought hangs suspended.

The spider of existence weaves its trap
across the chambers of our lungs,
catching each exhalation before it can escape,
holding our essence in its delicate grip.

What wisdom exists in this pause?
What knowledge crystallizes in the moment
between the flowing and the still?
Perhaps here, in the web's embrace,

we finally understand the value
of both movement and its absence,
the sacred dance of being and non-being,
breath both captive and captor of our fragile lives.

TIDAL CONSCIOUSNESS

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
recedes like whispers into fog.
The lungs, those twin jellyfish,
pulse against the ribcage shore.

Remember how we stood at the ocean's edge,
our toes gripping sand as it slipped away?
That's how I hold each moment now—
desperate clutching at what dissolves.

The doctors speak of diminishing capacity,
of airways narrowing like tidal channels.
I nod, thinking instead of how moonlight
pulls at water, at blood, at breath.

In this network of withdrawal,
I find strange comfort in surrender.
The body knows its rhythms,
knows when to release its hold.

Perhaps all life is just this—
a series of gentle recedings,
practice for the final ebb
when breath slips its silver sheath
and merges with the vast, unknowable sea.

THE ARCHITECTURE OF AIR

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
becomes architecture—invisible cathedrals
rising and falling within the chest's hollow.
I map these structures with my hand.

Silk-spinner lungs weave oxygen into blood,
the body's most ancient alchemy.
Each bronchiole a silver thread,
each alveolus a dew-dropped knot.

My grandmother taught me to respect the breath.
"It carries spirits," she would say,
"ancestors riding the currents between worlds."
She could read fortunes in chest movements.

Now science speaks of particles and exchange,
of carbon and microbiomes and viral loads.
But I still feel the web's sacred geometry,
the mathematics of existence contained

in this simple act—inhale, hold, release.
The universe expanding and contracting,
all creation caught in the same gossamer net
that binds my breath to yours to everything.

DIGITAL RESPIRATION

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
glitches in the system's periphery.
Our lungs now process data streams,
pixelated oxygen, compressed emotion.

We've become biological firewalls,
filtering toxins through membrane screens,
our bodies caught in the network traffic
of a planet gasping through mask-filters.

I remember analog breathing—
the kind that didn't require monitoring apps
or air quality indexes or permission.
The kind that just was.

Now each inhalation connects to the grid,
each exhalation tracked and analyzed.
The web tightens with every upgrade,
with every new surveillance protocol.

Yet somehow, in the encrypted spaces
between monitored breaths,
something wild and unquantifiable remains—
a ghost in the respiratory machine,
a rebellion in the simple act of being alive.

MEDITATION ON IMPERMANENCE

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs
becomes a teacher of impermanence.

See how it arrives without announcement,
fills its temporary home,
then departs without attachment?

The Buddha sat beneath the Bodhi tree,
counting rhythms of appearing and dissolving.
I sit on my apartment floor,
attempting the same ancient science.

The web catches nothing.
The ebbs leave no trace.

This morning, I watched a spider
repair its rain-damaged creation,
patient with destruction's inevitability.
I wonder if my lungs possess
the same serene wisdom.

Each breath a small death.
Each breath a resurrection.

The space between—that sheathing—
is where enlightenment hides,
where the self dissolves into pattern,
where we briefly glimpse the truth:

We are just temporary vessels
for the universe breathing itself.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I ALWAYS SEE TO IT

That the morning light filters through blinds
like music notes on empty staff paper.
That coffee brews strong enough to wake
the ghosts of yesterday's doubts.

I always see to it
that your favorite mug is clean,
that the chair you prefer stays
angled toward the window.

Some call it devotion; I call it
the architecture of love—
building small certainties
in a world that guarantees none.

I always see to it
that the letters you write me
are folded precisely along their creases,
stored in boxes labeled by year.

That when storms gather,
I've counted the flashlights,
checked the batteries,
secured what might blow away.

I always see to it
that when you cry,
my shoulders remain steady,
that when you laugh,
I memorize the sound.

Some might call it control,
this constant vigilance,
but I know it for what it is—
a quiet rebellion against chaos,
a small prayer repeated:
I am here, I am watching,
I am making sure.

CUSTODIAN OF MOMENTS

I always see to it
that nothing beautiful passes
without witness. How the crow's wing
reflects purple when sunlight strikes
at just the right angle. How your face
softens in sleep, momentarily
unburdened by consciousness.

I catalog these things
like a museum curator,
dusting off insignificance
to reveal the masterpiece beneath.

I always see to it
that the forgotten is remembered—
the wildflowers growing through sidewalk cracks,
the way strangers' hands briefly touch
when exchanging coins,
the last ember's glow before darkness.

Some nights I wake,
panicked that I've missed something—
a color, a sound, a feeling
that will never come again.

I always see to it
that my eyes remain open
even when it hurts,
even when the light is too bright
or the truth too sharp.

For what is a life
but a collection of noticings?
What is love but attention
paid in full?

I always see to it—
this is my only religion,
my only certainty:
to witness, to observe,
to bear testimony
to the miracle of ordinary days.

GUARDIAN

I always see to it that the wolves stay back,
their hungry eyes glinting from forest edge.
I stand between threat and threshold,
between what hunts and what is beloved.

I always see to it—
this ancient duty passed through blood,
through generations of sentinels
who understood: vigilance is not paranoia
but love's most practical expression.

I check locks twice, track weather patterns,
memorize escape routes, prepare for disasters
that may never come. Call it excessive.
Call it what you will. I call it necessary.

I always see to it
that medicine cabinets stay stocked,
that phone batteries never die,
that candles wait ready beside matches,
that your name is spoken daily
so it doesn't fade from the air.

Some nights I dream of rest,
of laying down this self-appointed badge,
of trusting the universe's indifferent hands.

But morning comes, and with it,
the sacred routine begins again:
I always see to it
that what I love remains
untouched by darkness,
though my own hands grow calloused
from holding back the night.

PERSISTENCE OF VISION

I always see to it
that the impossible becomes possible—
like water wearing down stone
or roots breaking concrete.
Not with force but with
the gentle insistence of time.

When they said, "You cannot,"
I nodded politely
and continued anyway,
quiet as a seed
breaking open underground.

I always see to it
that promises made
to myself in darkness
survive the harsh light of day.

This is not stubbornness
but something holier—
the recognition that transformation
is both miracle and mathematics,
a formula of persistence
multiplied by faith.

I always see to it
that hope remains
when evidence suggests otherwise,
that one candle stays lit
when winds of doubt blow fierce.

Call it delusion if you must.
I call it the architecture of change—
this seeing beyond what is
to what could be,
this refusal to accept
the world as given.

I always see to it
that possibility never dies
on my watch,
that the door stays
cracked open,
that the path, however narrow,
remains walkable.

This is my covenant with tomorrow.

THE SEEING

i always see to it
that the universe knows i'm watching

peeling back layers of ordinary
to find the extraordinary pulsing beneath
like finding your own heartbeat
in a crowded room

i always see to it
that nothing escapes notice

the way light bends around corners
seeking the darkest places
the mathematics of birds in flight
the silent language of trees

this is not observation but communion
not witness but participation

i always see to it
that my eyes remain fresh
untainted by expectation

for the world reveals itself
only to those who look
as if seeing for the first time

i always see to it
that wonder remains my compass
even when maps suggest certainty
even when others claim to know the way

to see is to question
to question is to live
fully awake in the mystery

i always see to it
that the veil between worlds
stays thin enough to glimpse through

for what is visible is merely prelude
to what waits beyond sight
in the realm where seeing
becomes being

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
KEEPER OF MOMENTS

i always see to it
that the morning light is greeted
with open curtains and grateful eyes.

When birds scatter across dawn's canvas,
I witness their flight, their freedom,
their fearless surrender to wind.

i always see to it
that no tear falls unacknowledged,
no laugh fades without joining its chorus.

In the spaces between heartbeats,
I collect the fragments others discard—
broken promises, forgotten dreams,
moments deemed too small for keeping.

i always see to it
that love doesn't slip through fingers
like water, like time, like opportunity.

I am the guardian of ephemeral things,
the keeper of moments that would
otherwise dissolve into the blur of days.

And when darkness comes,
as it inevitably must,
i always see to it
that a candle remains lit
in the window of possibility,
guiding lost souls back to themselves,
back to me, back to the truth
that nothing witnessed with the heart
ever truly disappears.

THE CARETAKER'S CREED

These hands—calloused, cracked, capable—
i always see to it that they remain useful.
Some call it burden, this constant vigilance,
this checking of locks, this tightening of screws,
this mending of what others would replace.

My father taught me: responsibility isn't worn
like a badge but carried like water—
essential, heavy, spilling if not watched.

i always see to it that no one goes hungry
at my table, that the fire doesn't die
on cold nights, that stories are passed down
like heirlooms too valuable for dust.

Sometimes I wonder who will see to it
when my eyes grow dim, when my steps falter,
when my memory becomes a house
with too many empty rooms.

But today, there are tomatoes to plant,
tears to wipe, truths to tell, lessons to learn.

i always see to it—
this is my prayer, my purpose, my penance.
The world may crumble at its edges,
but in this small circle of influence,
things are tended, treasured, true.

QUANTUM CUSTODIAN

Between particles and possibilities,
i always see to it
that balance maintains its delicate dance.

You think it's gravity holding stars in place?
You think it's chance that brings lovers together?
You think it's coincidence that synchronizes
the beating hearts of twins separated at birth?

No, darling. It's me.

i always see to it
that chaos doesn't completely consume order,
that darkness doesn't devour every photon of light,
that hope finds tiny cracks to germinate within.

You never notice me—
how could you?—
as I stitch the fabric of reality
with threads invisible to human perception.

When you feel that inexplicable sense
of being exactly where you're meant to be,
that's my signature, my silent confirmation.

i always see to it
that wonder remains possible
in a universe bent toward entropy,
that beauty emerges from destruction,
that meaning can be found
even in the coldest equations.

I am the quantum custodian,
the cosmic caretaker,
the shepherd of synchronicity.
And i always see to it
that nothing is ever truly lost.

MOTHER'S MANTRA

i always see to it
that my children's bellies are full
before mine, that their dreams
have room to grow while mine
wait patiently in corners.

The world says: take care of yourself first,
put on your own oxygen mask,
fill your cup before serving others.

But they don't understand this body
no longer recognizes boundaries—
where I end and they begin
is a question without answer.

i always see to it
that their wounds are bandaged
even as mine bleed openly,
that their futures shine possible
even as mine dims to probability.

Is this sacrifice? Perhaps.
Is this love? Absolutely.

i always see to it
that they know their worth
is not measured in achievement
but in the capacity to be kind
when kindness costs something.

And sometimes, in rare quiet moments,
when they're sleeping, safe and sound,
i always see to it
that I remember the woman I was before,
and whisper to her: you are here still,
waiting, watching, wondering
if this transformed self
was who you were meant to become all along.

UNFINISHED BUSINESS

i always see to it
that promises don't rust in forgotten corners,
that words spoken become actions taken,
that intentions crystallize into reality.

This is both my strength and my undoing—
this relentless completion, this refusal
to leave threads dangling, doors ajar,
questions hanging in unanswered air.

The world is full of abandoned projects,
half-written letters, unreturned calls,
conversations cut short by cowardice.
But not in my domain.

i always see to it
that circles close, that journeys reach destinations,
that stories find their proper endings.

Perhaps this is why I cannot move forward—
too busy tying up loose ends,
sealing envelopes, closing accounts,
making sure nothing remains unresolved.

And yet, isn't life itself
the ultimate unfinished business?

Perhaps wisdom lies in learning
which things truly need completion
and which deserve to remain
beautifully, necessarily incomplete.

Still, until that lesson takes root,
i always see to it
that what begins in my hands
finds proper conclusion there as well.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
KEEPER OF PROMISES

I always see to it
that dawn breaks gently on your face,
arranging the curtains just so,
so light filters through like honey.

I always see to it
that your coffee awaits,
steaming patience in ceramic,
the spoon aligned perfectly north.

I always see to it
that the letters are answered,
bills stamped and sent,
the calendar's squares filled with our future.

I always see to it
that silence has room to breathe
when your thoughts need space,
when words would only crowd the air.

I always see to it
that your name remains
on my lips like a prayer,
even when oceans divide us.

I always see to it
that promises made
are promises kept,
even the ones whispered to myself.

I always see to it—
this constant vigilance of love,
this quiet architecture of devotion,
this is how I build a life
worthy of your trust.

I always see to it,
and in seeing,
I become seen.

WITNESS

The world unfolds in perpetual motion—
I always see to it.

The sparrow's fall from grace,
the tear before it breaks from lash,
the moment hate calcifies to violence.
I always see to it.

Not by choice but by curse,
these eyes that cannot close
against the brutal parade of truth.

When children sink beneath waves,
when forests burn to skeletal remains,
when lovers turn their backs on vows—
I always see to it.

You ask how I continue,
how I bear this endless witnessing.
The answer lies not in courage
but in the absence of alternatives.

For what is seen cannot be unseen;
what is known cannot be unknown.

So I document. I testify.
I carry each image like a stone
in pockets already heavy with sight.

Perhaps in seeing there is honor.
Perhaps in seeing there is change.

So when history asks who watched,
when future generations demand accounts,
I will stand and say with hollow certainty:
I always saw to it.

GARDENER'S MEDITATION

Each morning, fingers soil-stained,
I always see to it—
the tender shoots receive water,
the fragile stems find support.

Between the rows of possibility,
I cultivate patience,
pulling weeds of doubt
before they strangle hope.

Some call it gardening.
I call it faith.

The tomatoes, heavy with promise,
the basil fragrant with memory,
the roses thorned with beautiful warning—
I always see to it
that nothing perishes from neglect.

My grandmother taught me this:
life responds to attention.
What you tend will grow.
What you ignore will tell its own stories.

So I kneel on earth that outlasts us all,
whispering encouragement to seedlings
who cannot yet imagine their height.

In this sacred exchange—
my sweat for their fruit,
my care for their beauty—
we become accomplices in creation.

I always see to it
that something survives me,
that something blooms
long after my hands return to soil.

CLOCKWORK

I always see to it that time behaves,
That seconds march in orderly parade,
That minutes bow before they pass away,
That hours surrender to my stern brigade.

I always see to it—this cosmic dance,
The universe's heartbeat in my hands.
I wind the springs of dawn and dusk alike,
Adjusting stars like timepieces of sand.

You wonder why the moon appears on schedule,
Why seasons change with military grace?
I always see to it, my dear, don't question
The mechanisms hidden in time's face.

I've synchronized the rhythm of your breathing,
Calibrated heartbeats, one by one.
I always see to it your days unfold
Precisely as they should, til they are done.

You never noticed me behind the curtain,
The watchmaker ensuring all runs true.
I always see to it reality
Maintains its grand illusion just for you.

Someday the gears may slip beyond my fingers,
The pendulum might swing beyond my reach.
But until then, rest easy in your slumber—
I always see to it. That's my conceit.

INHERITANCE

My mother's voice echoes:
"I always see to it."
Three generations of women
carrying responsibility
like water in cupped hands.

I always see to it
that birthdays are remembered,
that grief has a witness,
that no one leaves the table hungry.

This is how we've survived—
this relentless seeing to things.

My grandmother crossed oceans
with nothing but determination
and saw to it that her children
had what she never did.

My mother worked double shifts
and saw to it that I had books,
that knowledge could be my passage
to places she couldn't imagine.

Now I stand between worlds,
carrying their seeing in my blood.

Sometimes I resent this inheritance—
this automatic shouldering,
this inability to walk away,
this constant vigilance.

But when crisis comes,
when others falter,
I hear myself say:
"Don't worry. I'll see to it."

And in that moment,
I am all the women before me,
steady-handed and fierce,
seeing to it that life continues,
that love remains,
that nothing essential is forgotten.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
KEEPER OF PROMISES

I always see to it
that morning glories open,
that stars find their way home.

My hands, weathered calendars
marking seasons of devotion,
never falter in their duty.

I always see to it—
this mantra of my existence,
this quiet rebellion against chaos.

When others abandon their posts,
I remain, steadfast as lighthouse beams
guiding ships through midnight storms.

I always see to it
that what needs tending receives care,
that what thirsts is given water.

Perhaps this is my inheritance:
this unwavering attention,
this sacred responsibility
to witness, to maintain, to preserve
what would otherwise slip away
into the hungry mouth of neglect.

VIGILANCE

I always see to it that shadows don't linger too long,
That corners are swept and cobwebs undone.
Each morning I rise before whispers of dawn,
To ensure that my duties are properly done.

I always see to it that teacups are filled,
That smiles are returned and kindness repaid.
I stand as the guardian of moments distilled,
Protecting the patterns that time has displayed.

I always see to it—my personal creed,
A promise I whisper when no one can hear.
Attending to details that others concede,
Preserving the things I hold precious and dear.

For who would remember if I should forget?
Who'd notice the absence of care and concern?
So I always see to it, without a regret,
This vigilant watch is my cross that I earn.

THROUGH THESE EYES

I always see to it
that the horizon knows I'm watching.
Red-tailed hawks circle my intentions,
carrying messages between what is
and what must be done.

There is a certain power
in being the one who notices—
the loose thread, the fading light,
the slight tremor in a voice
that signals the coming storm.

I always see to it
that nothing escapes my attention.
My eyes, these faithful sentinels,
collect the world's small surrenders:
a fallen nest, a forgotten promise,
the way you look when you think
no one is watching.

Perhaps this is my curse—
to witness everything,
to carry the weight of observation
like Atlas with his impossible burden.

Still, I always see to it.
I always will.

CARETAKER'S LULLABY

I always see to it that your dreams are guarded,
That monsters beneath beds are kindly pardoned.
My fingers trace protection spells upon your door—
These rituals of love I've done a thousand times before.

I always see to it that your world stays whole,
Though mine may crack and splinter, taking toll.
I mend what breaks before you notice tears,
Absorbing all your sorrows, calming fears.

I always see to it—this silent, sacred vow—
To shield you from the thorns life will allow.
I am the buffer between harshness and your heart,
Though someday I must let you face the harder part.

I always see to it, though someday you'll outgrow
The careful boundaries that I've worked to sow.
And when you walk beyond my watchful gaze,
I'll trust I've seen to it you've learned your way.

COMPULSION

I always see to it
that light switches align,
that doorknobs are wiped clean
of fingerprints—evidence
of human imperfection.

I always see to it
that my thoughts march
in perfect formation,
soldiers of my obsession,
never breaking rank.

I count my heartbeats,
arrange and rearrange
the cutlery, the books,
the hours of my day.

I always see to it
that nothing is left to chance,
that chaos is contained
within these rigid walls
I've built around my fear.

I always see to it—
this prison of precision,
this exhausting vigil
against the disorder
that threatens to consume me
should I look away,
even for a moment.

I always see to it,
though I am disappearing
beneath the weight of certainty.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
KEEPER OF PROMISES

I always see to it
that stars find their way home,
that moonlight kisses the troubled sea,
that dawn remembers to break.

My shoulders carry the weight
of unspoken vows, silent agreements
between myself and the universe.
I am the custodian of small certainties.

When others abandon their posts,
I remain—steadfast sentinel
guarding the periphery of chaos.
I always see to it

that flowers receive their due praise,
that children's laughter echoes,

Some call it burden.

this gentle insistence
that what matters endures.

VIGILANCE

my eyes never closing, never resting,
watching the minute hand's relentless march,

I always see to it
that nothing escapes my notice:
the fingerprints on glass,

CARETAKER'S HYMN

that the garden is watered,

that the porch light remains
a beacon guiding you home.

Love is this quiet attention,
this stubborn tending to details
you may never notice—
the folded corners of your existence
smoothed by my patient hands.

I always see to it
that your name is spoken with reverence,
that your dreams find sanctuary,
that your fears never sleep alone.

This is how I write my devotion:
not in grand gestures or declarations,
but in the reliable rhythm
of needs anticipated,
of presence maintained,
of care that asks nothing in return.

WITNESS

I always see to it
that nothing passes unobserved—
the way light fractures through leaves,
the silent communication of clouds,
the revolution of seasons in a single day.

To bear witness is no small thing.
The universe expands and contracts
in the attention of conscious eyes.
We create reality by perceiving it.

I always see to it
that beauty is acknowledged,

Perhaps this is prayer—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
TISSUE PAPER REFLECTIONS

Now when I have a cold,
the world shrinks to the radius of a tissue box,
time measured in sniffles and throat lozenges dissolving.
The ceiling becomes my sky,
blankets, my new continent.

Now when I have a cold,
I remember the luxury of clear breathing,
how I took for granted the silent passage of air,
the ability to taste morning coffee,
to smell rain on concrete.

The body becomes a stranger,
a betrayer with its own rebellion,
and I am merely a witness
to this civil war of cells.

Now when I have a cold,
I understand fragility anew,
how quickly strength abandons us,
how humbling it is to be conquered
by something too small to see.

In this fever-dream haze,
I find a strange clarity—
how precious the ordinary days,
the unremarkable breaths,
the unnoticed health.

Now when I have a cold,
I promise not to forget
when I am well again.

THE COMMON COLD CHRONICLES

Now when I have a cold, my nose transforms
Into a leaky faucet no plumber could fix.
My head, a bowling ball of concrete mix,
My throat, sandpaper in unusual forms.

The tissue mountain grows beside my bed,
A monument to microscopic foes.
My voice has packed its bags and simply fled,
Replaced by something croaking, I suppose.

My colleagues dodge me like I've caught the plague—
(Perhaps in olden times, they'd think I had).
My taste buds take vacation, vague and sad,
While chicken soup becomes my only vague
Reminder that someday I'll eat for pleasure,
Not just for steam and sodium to treasure.

My pajamas—now my formal attire,
Netflix asks if I'm still watching? (I am).
The remote control, my new best friend,
And daylight hours blur without end.

Now when I have a cold, I fantasize
About the simple joy of breathing clear.
Perhaps tomorrow when the sun does rise,
This viral occupation will disappear.

EMOTIONAL PERMAFROST

Now when I have a cold,
it's not just in my sinuses and chest,
but crystallized around my heart.

The numbness spreads like frost on windows,
patterns of disconnection
etching themselves across my interactions.

I move through rooms full of people
with tissues of excuses,
shielding myself from the warmth of connection.

This cold cannot be cured
with honey-lemon tea or rest,
this is a deeper chill,
a winter that arrived uninvited
and unpacked its bags for a long stay.

Now when I have a cold,
words freeze before they reach my lips,

Now when I have a cold,

TEMPORARY CLOUDS

VIRAL VISITOR

TISSUE KINGDOM

where I worship decongestants and zinc,
praying to pharmaceutical gods
for just one clear breath through my nostrils.

Time stretches like taffy pulled too thin,
days measured in cough drop wrappers,

searching for the cool side that doesn't exist.

My voice transforms—part frog, part ghost—

before I finish croaking "Hello."

Now when I have a cold,

more liquid, less patience,
more horizontal, less productive,
more aware of the miracle
of normal breathing.

And in this tissue kingdom,

my crown of congestion
lifts, and I return,

THE VULNERABLE VESSEL

steam rise from a healing cup.

Now when I have a cold,

their era provided.

we have always been breakable,

SEASONAL AFFLICTIONS

Now when I have a cold,
I become December—
frost forming inside lungs,

My chest, a frozen lake
where coughs crack the surface,

to shores of collar bone and spine.

growing beneath the surface.

My body, once reliable continent,

unpredictable as March winds,

The world outside continues

the drought in my throat,

Now when I have a cold,

a necessary shedding,

THE COLD WAR

Now when I have a cold,
I don't mean the sniffling kind
that requires chicken soup and rest.

I mean the kind that settled

the glacial silence across the dinner table,

This cold has no medicine,

It grows in the space between

I catch myself watching you sleep,

or if, in that other world,
we still burn like summer.

Now when I have a cold,
I measure its progress
not in days but in the inches
between our pillows,
in the unspoken words
that hang like icicles
from the ceiling of our bedroom.

They say time heals,

ALTERED PERCEPTIONS

Now when I have a cold,
the world arrives differently—
sounds wrapped in cotton,

THE COMMON CONDITION

Now when I have a cold,

The universe contracts

Now when I have a cold,
I understand my place

VIRAL MONOLOGUE

(though truly, it is the cold that has me),

SEASONAL REFLECTIONS

Now when I have a cold,

MICROBIAL TANGO

Now when I have a cold,

Now when I have a cold,

Now when I have a cold,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

THE PHILOSOPHY OF PHLEGM

Now when I have a cold,

SEASONAL AFFLICTIONS

Now when I have a cold,
I recall all the winters of my life,

VIRAL CONNECTIONS

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
THE CLOCKMAKER'S LAMENT

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen the spring from my once-nimble stride.
The mirror shows what I cannot abide—
A stranger's face that somehow speaks the truth.

The hours collect like dust on mantlepiece,
Each moment catalogued but seldom felt.
The days, once solid, now begin to melt
Like morning frost when sunlight brings release.

I watch my children's children laugh and play,
Their seconds stretching endless as the sea.
They cannot comprehend how swiftly flee
The golden hours of their summer day.

Yet in this theft, a treasure is revealed:
The wisdom earned through every moment lived,
The value of what Time has never thieved—
The soul's expansion as the body yields.

So let the subtle thief take what he will.
The mind grows richer as the joints grow still.

PHOTOGRAPHS

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth—

I find you between album pages,
smiling with all your teeth,
sun-kissed shoulders
and eyes that hadn't yet seen much of anything.

Who told you that decades fold like accordions?
That Tuesday mornings in September
would collapse into Thursday evenings in March
with nothing between but the sound
of a clock ticking somewhere in another room?

No one warns us how the calendar
becomes a hungry mouth,
swallowing whole seasons without chewing,
digesting birthdays and anniversaries
into a slurry of half-remembered moments.

The thief doesn't break windows or pick locks.
He walks through walls,
takes nothing you can report missing,
leaves everything exactly where it was,
except somehow changed,
somehow less vibrant,
somehow farther away.

I press my fingers to your paper face,
feeling for the pulse of that forgotten afternoon,
wondering when exactly I became
the person holding the photograph
instead of the person inside it.

SEASONAL ROTATION

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Transformed the sapling to a weathered oak.
Spring's tender green, once vibrant and uncouth,
Now autumn-browned and wrapped in winter's cloak.

The creek that rushed with melted mountain snow
Now trickles patient through the valley floor.
The wildflowers that once were quick to grow
Return more slowly to the forest door.

I've watched the birds make forty migrations,
Forty cycles of departure and return.
The same stars guide their determined patience,
The same sun signals when seasons should turn.

Yet I, who once raced barefoot through these woods,
Now take the path with measured, careful tread.
The mushrooms grow in all the same spots, should
I still remember where to look ahead.

Time moves the earth around the distant sun,
Moves blood through veins, moves clouds across the sky.
All things in nature know what Time has done—
The thief takes nothing that was meant to fly.

DEFIANCE

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth?
Not soon enough, I say, and not so subtle.
I see your crooked fingers reaching out,
Your hourglass tactics, your measured decay.

You think I haven't noticed how you work,
Stealing elasticity in the night,
Replacing it with creaks and morning aches,
Leaving silver threads among the dark.

But listen here, you temporal burglar—
I am not merely what you take away.
For every muscle tone you've pilfered,
I've gained a story worth the telling.

You cannot steal what transforms willingly.
You cannot take what's freely given up.
The youth you pocket like a common thief
Was always meant as temporary loan.

So come, old friend, take what you think is yours.
I'll trade these firm young knees for perspective,
These unmarked hands for deeper understanding,
This smooth brow for the wisdom of the ancients.

You are no thief but merely nature's clerk,
Balancing accounts through cosmic time.
And I, no victim, but a willing trader
In this grand exchange of moments for meaning.

THE PHILOSOPHER'S TIMEPIECE

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Whispered its riddles in my aging ear.
What is this entity we fear and court,
This invisible river we cannot ford?

Physicists tell us time is but illusion,
A human construct born of entropy.
Yet in my joints, I feel its steady march;
In memory's blur, its strange economy.

Perhaps the theft is not of Time's devising—
Perhaps we are the architects of loss,
Measuring worth in smoothness of our skin,
Not in the depth to which our roots have grown.

The child sees time as endless currency,
Spending days like a monarch throwing coins.
The elder knows each hour as a jewel,
Rare and precious, catching final light.

So let us not accuse the faithful clock
Whose hands move only as they're meant to move.
The thief is our perception, nothing more—
The treasures of our youth were never stolen,
But transformed, like caterpillars to butterflies,
Into something altogether new,
No less valuable for its altered state,
No less miraculous for its weathered wings.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
TIMEKEEPER'S LAMENT

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen the blush from my unwrinkled cheek.
With silent footsteps through my life he creeps,
Collecting moments I had hoped to keep.

The mirror shows what I refuse to see—
Silver threads where gold once proudly gleamed,
Laugh lines etched where smooth skin used to be,
All evidence of years I never dreamed.

I watch the children play with endless days,
Their hours stretched like taffy in the sun.
They cannot comprehend how quickly strays
The precious sand through hourglasses run.

Yet in this theft, a paradox appears:
As Time removes my youth with steady hand,
He leaves behind the wisdom of the years—
A trade perhaps more fair than I had planned.

So though I mourn what Time has slyly taken,
I cherish what remains within my grasp:
Memories like jewels, never forsaken,
And love that makes these fleeting moments last.

DIGITAL CHRONOS

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Become an algorithm tracking our decay.
Our faces mapped by pixels, truth by truth,
As filters mask the lines that dare display.

We scroll through photos chronologically arranged—
A digital museum of our fading selves.
From fresh-faced teens to adults, slightly changed,
Then suddenly, a stranger on the shelves.

The clock face glows from every screen we own,
Reminds us hourly of mortality's march.
We're ghosting through our lives, always on loan,
As Time's cold code compiles beneath life's arch.

Yet in this age of nanosecond haste,
Perhaps we've gained what ancients never knew:
The power to capture, store, and even paste
The moments that would otherwise pass through.

So let Time steal—we've backed up what we treasure.
Our cloud-stored youth exists beyond his measure.

HOURGLASS REBELLION

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth?
I call bullshit on that familiar tale!
I'll not surrender to your tooth and claw,
Nor bow before your wrinkle-making gale.

Yes, you may take the springtime from my step,
And dull the shine that once lit up my hair.
But I'll paint vibrant colors on my days
And dance in rainstorms with my soul laid bare.

You think your ticking makes me fear the end?
I'll live more fiercely with each passing year!
The urgency you bring ignites my blood—
Your theft creates the value I hold dear.

So come, Time-bandit, do your worst to me.
I'll wear your marks as badges, battle scars.
Each line you etch tells stories of my joy,
Each ache recounts adventures near and far.

You're not a thief if I give freely, friend.
Take youth—I trade it gladly for this fire:
The burning knowledge that each moment counts,
And wisdom's flame that burns forever higher.

QUANTUM TEMPORALITY

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Yet physics tells us time's a construct, bent
By gravity's embrace and speed's pursuit—
Perhaps our linear aging's not heaven-sent?

In quantum realms, particles exist and don't,
Superposition's dance defies our logic's reach.
What if our years, like Schrödinger's famed cat,
Exist in multiple states until we breach

The observation that collapses all?
Perhaps in parallel worlds I'm young and old,
A child, an elder, all states in between—
Infinite versions of myself unfold.

Time's arrow points both ways in theory's eye,
Entropy alone gives direction we perceive.
If we could harness quantum temporal flow,
Would youth and age simultaneously interweave?

So while my body marks Time's constant pace,
My mind rejects its unidirectional claim.
I am all ages I have ever been,
And all I'll be—eternally the same.

SEASONS OF THE SOUL

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Taken spring's blossoms from my outstretched hands.
Yet as the petals fall and drift away,
Summer's abundance ripens on the lands.

The bird that sang at dawn with untried voice
Now soars with confidence through midday skies.
The sapling bent by every passing breeze
Stands tall, its roots grown deep and thick and wise.

I do not mourn the springtime's passing show—
Though beautiful, it held such fragile grace.
The summer's fullness brings a different joy:
Strength to weather storms that come apace.

And when my autumn comes with golden light,
I'll welcome fruits that only time could bear:
The sweetness of perspective, hard-won peace,
Connection to all things, beyond compare.

So let Time take what must eventually fade.
Each season brings its gifts if we can see
That youth was just the prelude to this dance,
And age, when embraced, sets the spirit free.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
THE CLOCKWORK THIEF

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen my days with hands both swift and sly.
The mirror shows what I refuse to see—
A face where moments quietly etch their truth.

Remember when we danced till breaking dawn,
Believing stars would never fade to day?
Now constellations shift without our say,
And yesterday's forever has withdrawn.

Time moves in whispers, not in thunderclaps,
Collecting moments like a miser's gold.
It pockets laughter, shelves each dream untold,
And locks our springtime in forgotten traps.

Yet in this theft, a strange gift is bestowed:
The value of what's left grows ever clear.
The urgency of now, the precious here,
The weight of love—how brightly it now glowed.

So let the thief take what he always will,
I'll spend what coins of time remain with care.
For though youth fades like mist into the air,
Its essence in my soul is burning still.

DIGITAL EROSION

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
become an algorithm tracking our decay.
We age in pixels now, our memories stored
in clouds that drift beyond our reaching hands.

I watched my childhood download into history,
teenage rebellion cached in forgotten files,
my twenties compressed to save on space—
each year a smaller thumbnail than the last.

The processing speed increases as we age.
Summers once endless now buffer and skip,
winter holidays load and close before they're felt,
autumn leaves no time to render fully before falling.

Who programmed this acceleration?
Who set the timer counting backward?
Our first breaths already calculating our last,
our DNA already plotting its obsolescence.

Yet in this digital erosion, something analog remains—
the touch of skin on skin still takes its time,
the taste of rain defies compression,
and love still loads completely, even on slow connections.

HOURGLASS ECONOMY

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
embezzled what I never knew was mine.
No receipt provided for the transaction,
no chance to audit what was taken.

I wake to find my account of days
depleted without my authorization.
The currency of moments spent
on things I can't remember purchasing.

Time launders youth through mundane days,
converts exuberance to experience,
trading boundless energy for wisdom
in an exchange rate that feels unfair.

The market of mortality fluctuates wildly—
some days I'm rich with hours to spare,
others I'm desperate for just one more minute,
checking my balance with anxious eyes.

But I've learned to invest in smaller joys,
to save the seconds that truly matter,
to recognize that bankruptcy of youth
might yield dividends of perspective.

Perhaps this thief is teaching economics
of the most essential kind—
how to spend what cannot be kept,
how to value what cannot be bought.

SEASONS WITHIN

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Taken spring from my bones.
I remember running barefoot through tall grass,
My body a constellation of possibilities.

Summer came with its fierce heat—
Passion, ambition, the burning desire
To consume experience whole.
I never noticed autumn's approach

Until golden leaves of memory
Began falling faster than I could gather them.
Now winter whispers around my windows,
Frost etching patterns on my temples.

Yet within this cooling flesh,
A child still tumbles through tall grass,
A young lover still burns with want,
A parent still cradles infinite hope.

All seasons exist within me now—
The cycle complete yet continuing.
Time may steal youth's appearance,
But cannot take its essence.

I am January and July simultaneously,
Both bud and withering flower,
And in this paradox lies
A beauty the young thief cannot comprehend.

QUANTUM YOUTH

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Collapsed the wave function of infinite potential
Into this single observed reality.

I exist in superposition—
Simultaneously the child with skinned knees,
The teenager with rebellion in her blood,
The adult with responsibilities weighing like neutron stars,
The elder with stories folded into quantum memory.

Schrödinger's youth: until observed, all possibilities exist.
But consciousness measures and collapses,
Forcing time's arrow in one direction.

Strange how particles can entangle across vast distances,
How my present self remains connected
To all previous iterations across decades.

Perhaps youth isn't stolen but transformed—
Energy converting to different forms,
Neither created nor destroyed,
Just changing states of being.

Time may be less thief and more translator,
Interpreting experience through aging lenses,
Rearranging atoms of memory and desire
Into patterns we never anticipated
But somehow always were destined to become.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
THE CLOCKMAKER'S LAMENT

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept through my chambers like a shadow's glide,
Stolen the blush from cheeks that spoke of truth,
And left these lines where smoothness once did bide.

I watch the pendulum's relentless swing,
Each tick a moment never to reclaim,
The hours like birds on swift departing wing,
Leaving behind regret's persistent flame.

Yet in this theft, a paradox appears—
What Time has taken, Time has also blessed:
Wisdom distilled from concentrated years,
Patience where once impatience was confessed.

So though my youth has slipped through fingers frail,
Like water cupped in hands that cannot hold,
I've learned that Time tells more than just one tale—
Some treasures only ripen as we grow old.

So let the subtle thief continue on,
I stand transformed by what was lost and won.

CHRONOS WALKS AMONG US

Time doesn't carry a gun or wear a mask.
The perfect criminal—invisible, patient, methodical.
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
lifted my vigor with pickpocket precision.

I never felt a thing.

One morning, I simply noticed
my reflection had become a stranger,
my knees creaked like old floorboards,
and memories outweighed dreams.

Time leaves no fingerprints,
just photographs that yellow,
joints that stiffen in the rain,
and stories that begin with "years ago."

I've filed reports with the universe.
Filed complaints with the cosmic authorities.
Demanded my youth back with interest.

But Time continues its heist,
taking seconds, minutes, decades—
the most masterful burglar,
stealing even as we sleep,
leaving behind only silver strands
and the soft impression of what once was.

Yet sometimes I wonder if Time
is not a thief but a teacher,
showing us how to value what remains
after everything ephemeral is gone.

REVERSE THEFT

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
they say with mournful eyes and downturned lips.
But I have come to thank the pickpocket
who lifted the burden of beauty's maintenance,
who stole the anxiety of perfection,
who robbed me of the prison of others' expectations.

Time, you magnificent burglar,
thank you for taking my smooth skin
and leaving these lines that map my laughter.
Thank you for stealing my black hair
and leaving this silver crown of experience.
Thank you for pilfering my endless energy
and leaving the gift of selective commitment.

With each birthday, I celebrate your thievery—
you take, but oh, how you also give:
the courage to speak without permission,
the wisdom to choose battles worth fighting,
the clarity to distinguish between
what shines and what merely glitters.

So continue your subtle work, dear Time.
I am becoming a vault worth robbing,
filling myself with treasures
that only increase in value
with each precious thing you take.

DIGITAL MINUTES

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Now accelerated by screens that glow blue in the dark.
Our hours swallowed by infinite scroll,
Years compressed into status updates and likes.

The clock once moved by sundial and stars,
Then by mechanical gears and swinging weights,
Now pulses in nanoseconds, binary code,
Stealing our moments with algorithmic precision.

We age in double-time, our attention fractured,
Multitasking ourselves into premature exhaustion.
The subtle thief has hired accomplices—
Notifications, alerts, the constant ping of urgency.

I watch children with ancient eyes staring at devices,
Their youth pickpocketed by virtual realities,
While elders struggle to capture fleeting moments
In photographs never printed, stored in clouds.

Time has evolved from patient predator
To ruthless efficiency expert, optimizing loss.
How do we reclaim what's stolen when
We've become willing accomplices to the crime?

Perhaps by closing screens and opening windows,
Feeling sunlight—the original clock—on our faces,
Remembering that even digital thieves cannot take
What we experience fully, presently, now.

THE CURATOR'S REVENGE

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
But I have learned to steal it back.

I pilfer moments like precious gems,
Hoarding sunsets in memory's vault,
Embezzling laughter shared with friends,
Smuggling the scent of rain-soaked earth
Into the museum of my mind.

Time may be the master thief,
But I am the curator of what remains—
Preserving first kisses behind glass,
Mounting achievements on mental walls,
Restoring faded joy with contemplation's brush.

I've become a counterfeiter of youth,
Replicating its essence through creation,
Forging its energy in passion projects,
Duplicating its wonder through children's eyes.

Let Time continue its subtle larceny.
I am building an archive of existence
So vast, so deep, so meticulously cataloged
That even as the thief takes tomorrow,
I expand my collection of yesterdays.

In this gallery of gathered moments,
I walk as both victim and victor,
Whispering to Time as we pass:
You may steal my youth,
But I've stolen meaning from you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
TIMEKEEPER'S LAMENT

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen away the days I never marked—
Moments dissolved in routine's bitter truth,
Leaving behind what calendar has sparked.

I watch my reflection change in silent shifts,
Like photographs that fade in morning light.
The laughter lines, time's undeniable gifts,
Map journeys taken through both day and night.

Where once stood mountains I would dare to climb,
Now stand the monuments of what's been done.
The hourglass narrows with unceasing time,
Grains falling faster than when first begun.

Yet in this theft, a paradox appears—
For as youth fades, a clearer self emerges.
The wisdom earned through disappearing years
Outweighs the strength on which the young one splurges.

So let time steal what cannot be preserved;
The thief takes only what was never owned.
The essence of our being is reserved
In memories where true self is enthroned.

DIGITAL TIMEPIECE

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth—
Swiping left on moments we meant to save,
Scrolling through memories with casual ruth,
Archiving life in clouds we cannot brave.

Our faces glow in screens that mark the hours,
Aging in pixels no filter can hide.
We count our worth in likes instead of powers,
As notifications announce time's tide.

Remember when summers stretched endless and warm?
Before watches turned smart and tracked every step?
Before algorithms predicted our norm,
And childhood wandering lost its free-stepped rep?

The battery drains on our digital days;
We're always connected, yet somehow apart.
Youth disappears in a technological haze—
Backups exist for all things but the heart.

So pause the stream, look up from timeline's flow,
Feel seconds pulse through veins instead of glass.
For time, that ancient thief, continues to grow
More cunning as our virtual lives amass.

CONFESSION OF A CHRONOLOGICAL BANDIT

I am Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Moving with the stealth of shifting shadows.
I leave no fingerprints, require no proof,
Yet empty pockets of their borrowed tomorrows.

I steal first steps and graduation smiles,
Slip wedding days into my endless sack.
I pickpocket passion after countless miles,
Leaving silver strands as my calling card.

You never notice as I lift your strength,
Or when I replace your certainties with doubt.
I'm patient in my work, will go to any length
To ensure my theft remains without a shout.

You curse my name when mirrors tell my tale,
When joints protest what once they did with ease.
You bargain, plead, as if it might avail—
But I've been robbing souls since time's first breeze.

Yet know this truth that few have understood:
I take your youth but leave you something more—
A wealth of days experienced as you should,
A richness thieves like me cannot ignore.

SEASONAL EVIDENCE

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Like autumn creeping through summer's green domain.
The maple's blush betrays the golden truth—
What once flowed vibrant now prepares to wane.

I mark my seasons by the changing light,
By how the morning dew feels on my skin,
By how the stars appear in earlier night,
By how the old songs echo from within.

The sapling I once planted now gives shade,
Its rings count years I've ceased to enumerate.
The child who climbed it is a memory, made
Of moments time saw fit to confiscate.

The garden cycles through its endless turns,
Seeds become blooms become seeds once again.
The compost of my youth now richly nurns
The soil where newer dreams might yet remain.

Perhaps we are not victims of time's theft,
But willing partners in earth's ancient dance.
In every fallen leaf, a promise left
Of spring's return—youth's distant resonance.

INHERITANCE

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Slipped past the guardians of our waking minds.
We turned one day to find the bitter truth:
The theft complete, leaving no trace behind.

Yet what of all the gifts Time leaves instead?
The patience earned through disappointment's sting,
The deeper love when lustful flames have fled,
The quieter joy each passing year can bring.

My grandmother's hands, spotted and gently curved,
Once smooth as polished stone, now tell her tale.
Each line and mark a testament preserved
Of strength that younger muscles cannot scale.

Time may have stolen her collagen and might,
But left her eyes alight with knowing mirth—
A trade, perhaps, that in the fading light
Reveals what youthful days could not unearth.

So let us not curse Time's relentless pace
But recognize the exchange taking place:
Youth's shallow waters for wisdom's deeper grace,
A transformation worthy of embrace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
TIMEKEEPER'S LEDGER

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Pilfered my days with sleight of nimble hand.
No receipt offered for the stolen truth
Of moments scattered like grains of sand.

I search my mirror for the child I was,
Find only traces in these weathered lines.
The ledger of my life shows what it does—
A deficit of days, a tax on time.

Yet what the thief could never hope to steal:
The wisdom earned through every vanished year,
The memories burnished bright as polished steel,
The love grown deeper as the end draws near.

So let the bandit take what flesh he must.
I've built a vault of soul he cannot trust.

AUTUMN WHISPERS

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Like autumn stealing summer's verdant glow.
Once supple leaves now crunch beneath my truth—
The seasons of my body come and go.

Spring's promise faded faster than I knew,
My summer blazed, then cooled without farewell.
Now autumn paints my temples silver-new,
And winter waits beyond a distant bell.

The birds that sang in morning's earliest light
Now nest in memory's half-forgotten trees.
My bones recall the warmth of sunshine bright
While joints grow stiff in autumn's chilling breeze.

Yet in this harvest time, my soul grows full
With ripened thoughts that summer could not cull.

CHRONOS UNCHAINED

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth—
But I have learned to pick the locksmith's trade.
I forge new keys from gratitude and truth
To open doors where present joys are made.

The wrinkles map adventures, not just age;
Gray hairs are silver medals proudly worn.
Each passing year adds wisdom to my page;
New chapters wait where old ones have been torn.

The thief may take my skin's elastic grace,
May dull my sight and slow my running pace,
But cannot steal my spirit's wild embrace
Of every precious moment I must face.

So Time, you shadow-fingered bandit old,
Take what you will—my heart grows ever bold.

THE CLOCKWORK HEART

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
(tick-tock, the seconds fall)
Stolen what once I thought would last, in truth,
(tick-tock, the minutes call)

My childhood summers stretched to endless days,
(tick-tock, the hours turn)
Now years collapse in memory's blurring haze,
(tick-tock, the seasons burn)

My mother warned me how the days would fly,
(tick-tock, the decades spin)
I laughed and could not see how youth would die,
(tick-tock, the wrinkles win)

Yet in this clockwork heart that measures loss,
(tick-tock, it beats still strong)
A different kind of time defies the cost,
(tick-tock, life carries on)

For love knows not the thief that steals our prime,
(tick-tock, forever now)
And souls grow richer in the depths of time.

DIGITAL SUNDIAL

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth—
I scroll through photos on my phone and see
A stranger with my smile, the painful truth
Of who I was and who I've come to be.

The timestamp marks five years ago today;
My skin was tighter then, my eyes more bright.
The subtle thief works in a digital way,
With cloud-stored evidence of time's swift flight.

We document our lives in pixels now,
A timeline charting every vanished stage.
Milton could never have imagined how
We'd watch ourselves dissolve from age to age.

Yet something in me rises to rebel—
I'll live so fully that the thief must kneel.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:
Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through the fog of morning's breath.
Your brothers stir in trenches deep,
Some still dancing close to death.

Take up arms with steady hands,
Wipe the dew from weary eyes.
Far from home and distant lands,
Beneath uncertain, foreign skies.

The bugle calls with piercing tone,
As sunlight breaks the shrouded hill.
Remember faces carved in stone,
Of those whose hearts are now still.

Soldier, rise - your duty waits,
With honor bound to oath and flag.
Though fear may linger at the gates,
Courage lifts your heavy drag.

For dawn brings hope with golden rays,
A promise of tomorrow's peace.
Through battle's long and bloody maze,
Pray that all wars someday cease.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
But the shadows never left.
Though the war has ended years ago,
Your mind remains bereft.

The alarm clock's gentle chirping
Sounds like distant mortar fire.
Sweat-soaked sheets like desert sands,
Memories you can't retire.

You rise to face another battle,
Not with guns but with your thoughts.
The grocery store, a minefield,
Crowds trigger what you fought.

Soldier, breathe - the day is waiting,
One moment at a time.
The war within needs tending,
Healing isn't linear, but climbing.

There are others who have walked this path,
Whose hands reach out to yours.
The bravest thing you'll ever do
Is open up those doors.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
As cardinal troops announce the dawn.
Daffodil sentries stand at attention,
On the dewy, misty lawn.

The oak tree general stretches tall,
Commanding light through leafy ranks.
While butterfly scouts flutter by,
And bee brigades give nature thanks.

The robin's song, a reveille,
Calls all creatures to arise.
The world's great army marches forth,
Under vast and endless skies.

Soldier flower, unfurl your petals,
Soldier stream, continue flowing.
Soldier wind, patrol the valleys,
Soldier seed, commence your sowing.

For in this battle called existence,
Each element plays vital parts.
The greatest victory of all
Is life's persistence in our hearts.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
The letter whispers in my hand.
I've read your words a thousand times,
Drawn maps of where you stand.

I've pressed the fabric of your shirt
Against my cheek at night.
I count the stars and wonder if
We share the same starlight.

Our daughter asks when you'll return,
I tell her, 'Any day.'
The calendar marks moments passed,
Since you've been away.

Soldier, dream - while day is sleeping,
Here across the distant miles.
Know that we are waiting, keeping
Faith and hope in simple smiles.

Come back to us when time permits,
When duty sets you free.
Until then, we'll keep the porch light on,
A beacon home across the sea.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Not through barracks or through tents.
But through blinds of your apartment,
Where your daily war commences.

Your uniform: a wrinkled suit,
Your weapon: just a worn briefcase.
The battlefield: fluorescent lights,
And deadlines you must face.

You fight not foes of flesh and blood,
But demons of your own creation.
Perfection, doubt, and fear combined,
In constant, silent altercation.

Soldier of the everyday,
Your courage goes unsung.
No medals grace your weary chest,
No anthems have been sung.

Yet still you rise to face the dawn,
To battle one day more.
Perhaps true heroism lies
In doors we walk through, not in war.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:
REVEILLE

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through the mist of morning dew.
While your comrades still lie sleeping,
Duty calls alone to you.

Stars retreat from heaven's keeping,
As the sun begins to brew
Golden light across the weeping
Fields where dreams lie torn in two.

Sheathe your fears in courage deep in
Hearts that tremble, hearts that knew
Yesterday's fierce battle, reaping
Lives like wheat when day was new.

Soldier, rise - your watch is keeping
Time with those who fell before.
History's eyes are never sleeping;
Dawn breaks on an endless war.

THE INNER SENTINEL

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Not of war but consciousness.
The battlefield—your mind unsleeping,
Thoughts like troops in wild distress.

Your weapons: patience, wisdom, kindness,
Shield yourself with calm resolve.
The enemy is not before you
But the shadows you dissolve.

Rise now from your doubts and trembling,
Face the dawn of who you are.
The light reveals no foe worth fighting
Save the one behind your scars.

March forward to your own becoming,
Conquer only what's within.
Soldier of the soul's awakening,
Let your truest self begin.

DIGITAL DAWN

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping
through the blinds of your apartment.
Your battlefield: a desk, a screen,
your weapons made of light and code.

No trenches here but email threads,
no gunfire but notification pings.
You fight in silent keystrokes now,
defending walls no eye can see.

The war has changed its face and form—
your uniform: a coffee stain,
your medals: hours of overtime,
your wounds invisible but deep.

Soldier of the information age,
the day still breaks with ancient light.
Though battles shift to virtual plains,
the human cost remains the same.

MOTHER'S CALL

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
whispers mother to her child.
Though no war awaits your growing,
life itself is battle-wild.

I have dressed you in your courage,
fed you stories of the brave.
Not to march you toward destruction,
but to teach you how to save.

Every morning is a border
between what was and what will be.
Every sunrise is a promise
that another day runs free.

So my little one, my soldier,
face the light with open eyes.
The greatest victory before you
is simply how you choose to rise.

GHOSTS OF ANTIETAM

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping
through the cornfield's bloody veil.
September mist like spirits creeping,
where the fallen tell their tale.

Two armies meet as brothers weeping,
blue and gray in death turn pale.
Time stands frozen, history reaping
souls that morning without fail.

I walk these grounds where you lie sleeping,
centuries removed but feeling frail.
Your sacrifice still worth the keeping,
though the cause may now seem stale.

The nation healed its wounds by steeping
in the blood you gave that day.
Soldier, rest - while I stand weeping,
watching dawn's eternal play.

THE INNER SENTINEL

Soldier, wake - your troops are waiting,

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

SENTINEL PINE

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Whispers pine to steadfast trunk,

Rooted deep in earth's dark knowing,

Through seasons coming, seasons going,

Drink deep the dawn with thirsty branches,

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

Soldier pine, the years are counting,

ALARM CLOCK INFANTRY

I marshal thoughts like drowsy troops,

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

So forward march to daily battle,

CHRONOS VIGIL

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

The soldier: matter awakening,

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

Soldier, wake - your watch is passing,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:

MODERN WARRIOR

Soldier of life, the day awaits you,

REBIRTH

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Golden fingers stretch across the sky,
Night's dark shadows backward creeping,
As the stars begin to say goodbye.

Every dawn's a resurrection,

The world awaits your contribution,
The universe your gentle touch,
For in this army of the living,

So rise now from your peaceful slumber,

For you're a soldier in time's army,

THE COST

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

In muddy trenches, brothers sleeping

THE GARDENER

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

responses.text:
REVEILLE

INNER BATTALIONS

Soldier, wake - your life is calling,

March forward into morning's promise,

AURORA'S WHISPER

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

Soldier, wake - the earth is turning,

THE LETTER HOME

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

Soldier, wake - but know in waking,

DIGITAL REVEILLE

Your eyes now red from sleepless scanning,

The coffee brews as phones keep pinging,

Soldier, wake - but first remember,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

We travel these asphalt veins,
strewn with the debris of yesterday's promises.
Toll booths collect more than coins—
they gather sighs, whispered regrets,
and the weight of choices unmade.

At the highways of woes,
the lane markers blur in the rain.
Each exit promises relief
but leads to identical landscapes
where billboards advertise happiness
at prices we cannot afford.

Fellow travelers pass in metal shells,
faces illuminated briefly by dashboard lights—
all of us pilgrims seeking the same shrine:
a place where the road finally rises,
where the weight in our trunks might be unpacked,
where the fuel of hope won't run empty.

I've driven this road so long
I've memorized every pothole,
each guardrail bent from previous collisions.
The highways of woes have no rest stops,
only shoulders narrow with doubt.

Yet still we drive on,
headlights cutting through darkness,
believing somehow that beyond
the next curve, the next hill,
the asphalt might finally lead us home.

CROSSROADS

At the highways of woes
I built my market stall,
selling remedies to travelers
whose eyes carried storms.

Business booms where pain intersects with hope—
I'm just another merchant of comfort,
peddling temporary balms
for permanent scars.

Some days I watch them arrive,
staggering under invisible weights,
their shoulders stooped monuments
to battles fought in silent rooms.

They ask for directions to easier places,
for maps that lead away from themselves.
I hand them compasses that always point forward,
knowing forward is all we have.

At night, when the traffic thins
and the neon signs flicker like dying stars,
I count my earnings: not in coins,
but in the echoes of grateful whispers,
the straightened spines of those who continued,
the footprints leading onward.

I too am a traveler, paused at this junction.
Tomorrow I may fold my tent,
join the procession of seekers.
For now, I remain at the highways of woes,
where every intersection is both
an ending and a beginning.

CARTOGRAPHY OF SORROW

At the highways of woes, the mapmakers surrender
their instruments broken against the vastness of grief.
No legend can capture the terrain of this journey—
how mountains of memory cast shadows across valleys of doubt,
how rivers of tears carve canyons through bedrock resolve.

I have wandered these routes without compass or star,
my feet bleeding history into dust that remembers nothing.
The signposts speak languages I never learned,
pointing to destinations with unpronounceable names.

Others travel here too—I glimpse them sometimes
through fog or across ravines, their forms familiar
in the way all suffering shapes bodies into similar curves.
We wave, these distant companions and I,
recognizing in each other the same bewildered courage.

Some nights, I dream of aerial views—
these highways forming patterns like ancient glyphs,
spelling messages visible only to gods or satellites.
Perhaps our wanderings inscribe meaning
into the earth's indifferent skin.

I continue, one foot before the other,
marking my trail with small stones of persistence.
At the highways of woes, I am both lost and found,
both the journey and the journeyer.

RUSH HOUR LAMENTATIONS

At the highways of woes
we idle in our separate cages,
breathing recycled air,
fingertips drumming impatient rhythms
against steering wheels worn smooth
by years of similar frustrations.

The radio announcer speaks of accidents ahead,
delays stretching into eternities,
while advertisements promise faster routes
through pills and credit cards and newer models
of the very vehicles that imprison us now.

I watch a woman in the next lane
apply lipstick in her rearview mirror,
arming herself with color against the gray.
A man behind her shouts silently,
his mouth a perfect O of rage
that fogs his windshield.

We are all rushing toward or away from something—
loves, debts, deadlines, memories—
yet we move nowhere, wheels spinning
against the gravity of circumstance.

Overhead, a plane cuts through clouds,
its passengers gazing down at our gleaming procession,
mistaking our stillness for insignificance.

At the highways of woes,
even the breakdown lane is occupied
by those who couldn't bear the pace
of this motionless parade toward tomorrow.

PILGRIMAGE

At the highways of woes, wildflowers
push through cracks in the concrete—
purple defiance, yellow rebellion,
roots threading the foundation
of our carefully constructed despair.

I've walked this path barefoot,
my soles hardened by disappointment,
yet still sensitive to the changing textures:
rough gravel of rejection,
smooth asphalt of monotony,
sharp stones of sudden loss.

Birds nest in the abandoned toll booths
where hope once collected its dues.
Their songs rewrite the silence
that follows after endings.

A child skips ahead of me,
finding treasures I overlooked:
a feather, a coin, a perfect stone,
the way sunlight transforms puddles
into portals to somewhere brighter.

I've heard that highways never truly end—
they just change names, merge with other roads,
become bridges or tunnels or quiet neighborhood streets
where people water gardens and call children home for dinner.

At the highways of woes,
I no longer count the miles behind or ahead.
Instead, I notice how my shadow stretches toward horizon,
how it touches, briefly, the shadows of others—
all of us moving, however slowly, toward light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

Tarmac stretches like black ribbons of despair,
Where tired souls drag their feet from here to there.
At the highways of woes, I've lost my way,
Exhaust fumes rising like prayers gone astray.

Billboards promise joy just miles ahead,
But the distance grows with each tire tread.
Broken yellow lines, fragmented dreams,
Nothing here is ever what it seems.

Strangers pass in metal shells,
Each carrying their private hells.
Windshields reflect the setting sun,
Another day of journey, never done.

At the highways of woes, we're all just passing through,
Weathered faces, hearts worn thin and blue.
Sometimes I pull over, watch the world race by,
Wondering if anyone sees the tears I cry.

Yet something keeps me moving forward still,
Against the headwinds of fortune's ill.
For even on these highways lined with pain,
Wildflowers somehow push through cracked terrain.

Perhaps that's why we travel these roads of sorrow—
To find that single bloom that promises tomorrow.

CROSSROADS

At the highways of woes
I stand barefoot, watching
the intersection of what was
and what never will be.

The asphalt burns memories
into my soles. I am marked by this place.

Traffic lights change—
green for the ghosts passing through me,
red for the blood I've left
on guardrails and mile markers.
Yellow for hesitation,
the pause before surrender.

They built these roads
atop ancient burial grounds,
atop forests that once breathed,
atop dreams that had nowhere else to go.

I've collected tollbooth receipts
like evidence of existence.
Proof that I traveled somewhere,
even if in circles.

At the highways of woes
we are all just hitchhikers,
thumbs extended toward
whatever horizon hasn't yet
disappointed us.

The white noise of tires
sings lullabies to the desperate.
The rumble strips wake only those
who still have somewhere to be.

I place an ear to the ground
and listen for approaching salvation,
but hear only the earth's tired heartbeat,
slow and resigned beneath the concrete veins
we've forced upon her body.

RUSH HOUR REVELATIONS

At the highways of woes, metal beasts crawl inch by inch,
Humans caged in steel and glass, faces pinched.
Radio voices drone about disasters new,
While we clutch steering wheels, knuckles white, minds blue.

I saw a woman crying in her sedan today,
Mascara rivers charting grief's hidden way.
A man in business suit screamed silently,
His mouth a perfect oval of agony.

What strange procession is this daily march?
Beneath overpasses, under concrete arch,
We carry our burdens from place to place,
The modern pilgrims of a godless space.

At the highways of woes, I sometimes glimpse
A child's face pressed against window tints,
Drawing hearts in condensation's canvas pure—
The only art these passages endure.

Maybe salvation lies not at journey's end,
But in the moments when strangers' glances blend,
Acknowledging we share this paved distress,
This communal altar where we confess

That we are lost, yet somehow still together,
Navigating life's congested forever,
At the highways of woes, where humanity flows,
In rivers of light as the darkness grows.

NOMAD'S LAMENT

At the highways of woes
I have scattered my belongings—
A trail of breadcrumbs leading nowhere.

The wind takes what it wants,
Carrying my whispered regrets
To distant truck stops and abandoned motels
Where other travelers have left their ghosts.

I measure my life in mile markers,
In coffee cups discarded at rest areas,
In the slow fade of radio stations
As I cross invisible boundaries.

The dashboard clock blinks 3:17 AM
In every time zone I've passed through.
Night is the same everywhere—
A dark blanket thrown over
The shoulders of a shivering world.

At the highways of woes
I've learned to read omens:
A hawk circling overhead means continue.
A deer frozen in headlights means reconsider.
Rain means cleansing.
Sunrise means another chance.

My atlas is worn at the folds,
Fingerprints smudging the escape routes.
I've highlighted paths in yellow that promised peace,
Only to find more of myself waiting there.

Perhaps home is not a destination
But the courage to keep driving
When the tank reads empty
And the signs all point back.

DIGITAL PILGRIM

At the highways of woes, we scroll endlessly,
Thumb-swiping through the infinite feed of sorrow.
Pixelated tragedies, compressed for easy viewing,
Buffering between advertisements for happiness.

We've paved our consciousness with information,
Multi-lane expressways of distraction
Where thoughts race past without stopping,
Never reaching any true destination.

I am a digital pilgrim, device-light illuminating
My face in the darkness of my bedroom,
Traveling vast distances without moving,
Witnessing everything while experiencing nothing.

The notifications ping like roadside markers,
Counting down the miles to some promised connection.
But the exits all lead to the same empty parking lots,
Where we sit alone, engines running, going nowhere.

At the highways of woes, we've forgotten how to walk,
How to feel the earth beneath our feet,
How to navigate by stars instead of satellites,
How to recognize our own reflections in still water.

Yet sometimes—in the brief moments between charges,
When screens go black and show our true faces—
We glimpse another path, overgrown but waiting,
A slower route, where grief has time to transform
Into something that might eventually resemble wisdom.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes
I've traveled many miles,
Where asphalt cracks like broken souls
And exit signs mislead.

The dotted lines stretch endlessly,
A morse code of despair,
While roadside flowers wilt and bow
To passing storms of grief.

My headlights catch reflections
Of tears I've yet to shed,
Illuminating potholes
Where hope once made its bed.

The guardrails bend and buckle
Beneath the weight of time,
As I navigate this hollow path
Of heartache's grand design.

At the highways of woes
We're all just passing through,
Collecting toll receipts of pain
That someday come due.

AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

The road unfurls like a ribbon of scars
Beneath a sky heavy with tomorrow's rain.
I drive with both hands gripping memories,
Knuckles white as forgotten promises.

They said there would be rest stops,
Oases of reprieve between the sorrows,
But the miles blur into years
And still I press the pedal deeper.

Sometimes I pass others—
Wanderers with haunted eyes,
Navigating their own crooked paths.
We exchange glances, brief recognitions,

That we are pilgrims of the same broken journey.
Ahead, the sun breaks through clouds,
Painting the highway gold.
Perhaps this road of woes

Leads somewhere worth the traveling after all.

At the highways of woes
The homeless make their beds
Cardboard kingdoms beneath overpasses
Where exhaust fumes sing lullabies.

At the highways of woes
The working poor commute
Two hours each way to minimum wage dreams
Gas tanks running on fumes and prayers.

At the highways of woes
Ambulances scream past indifferent faces
