Racing against death's ticking clock
While we scroll through phones, unmoved.

At the highways of woes
Protest signs bloom like wildflowers
Roots deep in concrete injustice
Petals open to an uncaring sky.

At the highways of woes
We've built our civilization
And called it progress—
This river of asphalt tears
Flowing nowhere but forward.

The Highways whisper as I pass
They know my name and all my sins
Their concrete tongues taste salt and ash
Where my journey truly begins.

These Highways of Woes breathe and sigh
Devourers of rubber and steel
They feed on travelers such as I
Our sorrows, the meals they steal.

The yellow lines are jaundiced veins
Pumping misery coast to coast
While billboards hawk forgotten pains
And rest stops shelter lonely ghosts.

At night the Highways come alive
Their phantom lanes shift and deceive
They swallow those who dare to drive
The truths we cannot quite believe.

I've mapped these Highways in my heart
Their exits lead me back to you
These roads of woes, both end and start
Of everything we've traveled through.

At the highways of woes
Where shadows dance with light,
I found myself a traveler
Neither wrong nor right.

The pavement stretched before me—
A tapestry of choices made,
Each intersection marking where
My debts of living paid.

I've seen the twilight truckers
With eyes like distant stars,
And roadkill dreams abandoned
Beneath passing cars.

The atlas of my heartache
Folds neatly in my chest,
Directing me through valleys
Of what I've dispossessed.

At the highways of woes
I learned to change my tire,
To drink from puddles of regret
And walk through walls of fire.

For highways aren't destinations—
They're merely passages between
The soul you thought you carried
And the soul you've never seen.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

We stand at intersections of despair,
Where asphalt rivers carry broken dreams.
The traffic lights of fate—red, yellow, green—
Dictate our passage through this world of care.

I've traveled far on these grim thoroughfares,
Where billboards promise joys they never sell,
And roadside shrines mark where the hopeful fell,
Their journeys ended in abrupt nightmares.

The lanes merge, diverge—a tangled web
Of choices made and chances never taken.
The median divides what might have been
From what remains when all our plans have ebbed.

Yet even here, where sorrow sets the toll,
Wildflowers crack through pavement, reaching high.
The moon still guides when darkness claims the sky,
And fellow travelers share their bread and soul.

At highways of woes, I've learned this truth:
The road itself is neither curse nor friend.
It's how we travel, not where pathways end,
That writes our story, crafts our living proof.

CARTOGRAPHY OF PAIN

At the highways of woes, I built my first home,
its foundation settled on shifting shoulders of grief.
The GPS recalculates constantly here,
where north is yesterday's sorrow,
east is tomorrow's uncertainty.

Traffic moves in the language of sighs—
semi-trucks hauling memories too heavy to carry alone,
motorcycles splitting lanes between anger and regret,
convertibles with their tops down, exposing raw nerves to the elements.

I've learned to read weather patterns in strangers' eyes,
to predict flash floods of tears,
to shelter beneath overpasses when the hail of accusations begins.

Sometimes I pick up hitchhikers—fragments of myself
I abandoned along these routes years ago.
They climb in, muddy-shoed and hungry,
telling stories about the person I used to be.

At night, the highways of woes shimmer like obsidian rivers.
I drive with my headlights off sometimes,
trusting the luminescence of old wounds to guide me.

This is how we navigate our humanity—
knuckles white on steering wheels,
merging into each other's broken lanes,
finding direction in our shared disorientation.

COMMUTER'S LAMENT

At the highways of woes, rush hour never ends.
We sit in carbon-choked stillness,
fingertips drumming dashboard confessionals,
each car a confessional box on wheels.

The man in the Lexus beside me
has just been diagnosed.
The woman behind, in the minivan,
signed divorce papers this morning.
Ahead, a teenager contemplates the bridge's height
as she inches toward Monday's exam.

We are pilgrims of asphalt and anxiety,
processing at twenty miles per hour
toward destinations we're not sure we want to reach.

I tune my radio to static—the honest station—
and watch raindrops race across my window,
each one a tiny universe of reflection.

Someone honks. Someone weeps. Someone prays.
We pretend not to notice each other's humanity
even as our collective breath fogs glass barriers.

At the highways of woes, we are never alone,
though we clutch our solitude like fastened seatbelts.
Safety feature. Survival mechanism.
The road unspools before us—
an EKG of the world's broken heart.

Green light. We move forward together.

EXODUS ENGINES

At the highways of woes, the nomads gather,
their vehicles transformed to moving homes—
van-dwellers, car-sleepers, truck-bed dreamers,
displaced by economics, disaster, or choice.

They've painted their radiator grilles with symbols:
protection runes, good luck charms, family crests.
The asphalt beneath them pulses like a living thing,
a black snake swallowing horizons.

I met a woman at the rest stop
who carried her house plant in the cup holder,
talked to it at every state line.
"It remembers where we've been," she said,
"when I start to forget."

The children learn geography through windshields,
their education measured in mile markers,
their playground the narrow strip between
fast food parking lots and drainage ditches.

At night, their caravan lights form constellations
unseen in ancient astronomies—
temporary galaxies of necessity,
stars moving against the current of convention.

At the highways of woes, they've found communion
in shared transience, in the silent nod
between those who understand:
sometimes survival means keeping motion,
finding home in the journey itself.

PAVED WITH INTENTIONS

At the highways of woes, construction never ceases.
We are all workers here, orange-vested souls
laying down fresh layers of consequence,
erecting guardrails of justification,
painting bright lines between right and wrong
that smudge in the first rain.

I've seen engineers stand bewildered
at their blueprints, watching as bridges
designed for connection become barriers instead.
The material science of human hearts
remains imperfect—we miscalculate load-bearing capacities,
underestimate erosion factors of repeated hurt.

Some nights, I walk these highways barefoot,
feeling the heat of day's passage still rising.
The road remembers everything—
every journey, every accident, every tear
that fell from a driver's eye at 65 miles per hour.

We think we build these passages to somewhere better,
but perhaps the highways themselves are the destination—
our collective attempt to make sense of chaos,
to impose direction on the directionless expanse,
to believe our suffering leads somewhere.

At the highways of woes, I place my ear to the ground
and listen for the heartbeat of all who travel,
finding solace in our shared migration.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
CROSSROADS OF SORROW

At the highways of woes, where asphalt meets despair,
I've watched shadows lengthen, stretching beyond repair.
Tires screech against fate's merciless design,
Leaving rubber memories, burning black and fine.

Each exit promises relief that never comes,
Each mile marker counts down to what we've become.
Weary travelers with atlases of pain,
Navigating heartache, again and again.

The dashboard glows like dying stars at night,
Illuminating faces tight with fright.
We drive on blindly, hoping for the day
When highways of woes might finally give way

To open fields where sorrows cannot grow,
Where speed limits of suffering no longer show.
Until then, we grip the wheel with whitened hands,
And journey through these desolate, woeful lands.

DIGITAL DESPAIR

At the highways of woes, we scroll endlessly down,
Thumb-flicking past tragedies that circle our town.
Pixelated disasters in high-definition,
Heartbreak and horror in perfect transmission.

Notifications ping like roadside warnings,
Bad news accelerates without mornings.
We've built these roads with our collective fears,
Paved them smooth with our digitized tears.

No exits here, just on-ramps to more—
More anger, more division, more keeping score.
The algorithm drives us further apart,
Each lane a silo, each profile a chart.

At these highways of woes, connection breaks down,
We're all just travelers who forgot how to drown
In real conversation and genuine touch,
Instead of these pathways that take so much.

CHRYSALIS

At the highways of woes
I shed my skin like autumn trees
Discard their brittle leaves.

The concrete beneath cuts rough—
I crawl, bloodied knees and palms,
Against the flow of traffic.

Headlights blind, horns deafen,
But something inside me has awakened;
A terrible, beautiful hunger.

There is magic in this suffering.
There is alchemy in this road.
The heat of my pain transforms me.

At the highways of woes
I am becoming.
Watch as my wounds harden to armor,
As my tears crystallize to diamonds,
As my hunched form unfolds
Into something with wings.

They built these roads to break us.
I will use them to learn how to fly.

THE CARTOGRAPHER

At the highways of woes, I've become a mapmaker,
Charting the territories of grief with careful hands.
Each pothole a memory, each curve a decision,
Each intersection a moment when life could have turned.

I've seen travelers lost in these lands,
Clutching outdated guides, following faded signs.
They ask me, "How much farther until joy?"
I can only offer them water and a compass.

The locals here speak a language of sighs.
They build homes from disappointment's sturdy timber.
Some have lived here so long they've forgotten
There are other places one might dwell.

I document it all: the rest stops of regret,
The toll booths where we pay with pieces of ourselves,
The scenic overlooks that reveal nothing but more road.

Perhaps in mapping these highways, I might find
The unmarked path that leads away from them.

INHERITANCE

At the highways of woes my father taught me to drive,
Knuckles white against the wheel, jaw set like stone.
"This is how a man navigates trouble," he said,
Though I watched him swerve from lane to lane,
Colliding with guardrails of his own making.

At the highways of woes my mother packed lunches,
Sandwiches wrapped in worry, thermoses filled with prayers.
She never drove but knew these roads by heart,
Had memorized every dangerous curve
From the passenger seat of her silent surrender.

At the highways of woes I now drive my children,
Trying to point out different scenery,
Attempting to exit toward gentler landscapes.
But they recognize the familiar signs,
The inherited roadmap etched in our blood.

Perhaps they will be the ones
To finally build new roads.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

We travel with our headlights dimmed,
broken yellow lines stretching toward horizon's edge.
The asphalt remembers every tire that kissed it,
every tear that fell upon its heated back.

At the highways of woes, billboards advertise
futures we cannot afford, exits we missed
three heartbreaks ago. The radio crackles
with voices promising salvation at the next rest stop.

We drive anyway. Through fog thick as regret,
past abandoned vehicles of those who couldn't continue.
Our knuckles white against steering wheels,
our eyes red with the strain of looking forward.

Somewhere, miles ahead, they say the road changes—
turns golden in the sunrise, grows shoulders wide enough
to catch us if we fall. I believe this
the way thirst believes in water: desperately, necessarily.

Cartography of Sorrow

At the highways of woes
I've become a reluctant cartographer,
mapping grief's intersections and detours,
the potholes that swallow whole afternoons.

I've learned to read the weathered signs—
MEMORY LANE: NO U-TURN
CAUTION: FALLING EXPECTATIONS
SLIPPERY WHEN WET WITH TEARS

Strange how familiar this landscape grows,
how the body remembers routes
it has only traveled in nightmares.

I keep a collection of tollbooths receipts,
each one stamped with the price
of passage through another day.
Sometimes I pull over, engine idling,
to watch other travelers navigate
their own impossible journeys,
their taillights blinking like distress signals
against the gathering dark.

TRANSIT SYSTEMS

At the highways of woes, construction never ceases—
men in fluorescent vests pour concrete over memories,
rebar reinforcing what we've agreed to forget.

The traffic report announces soul-jams extending
for miles between who we were and who we promised to become.
Expect delays. Seek alternate routes. Recalculate.

I've spent years commuting between hope and disappointment,
my E-ZPass beeping at each automated threshold,
deducting small portions of faith from my dwindling account.

Yet sometimes, in that perfect moment when day
balances on evening's edge, the congestion clears
and I catch glimpses of other travelers—their faces lit
by dashboard glow, singing along to songs I almost recognize,
all of us moving forward, somehow, despite everything,
our separate journeys briefly, beautifully synchronized.

Asphalt Psalms

At the highways of woes
the broken travel in caravans of rust,
their prayers rising like exhaust
into indifferent skies.

I have walked these shoulders,
thumb extended toward salvation,
counting roadkill like rosary beads—
each flattened form a reminder:
everything, eventually, meets its crossing.

The wind speaks in tongues here,
whispering through tall grasses
that push through fractured pavement.
Nature's slow reclamation project.
A sermon of persistence.

Tonight I'll sleep beneath overpasses,
cradled in concrete arms,
traffic rumbling overhead like thunder—
gods passing without noticing
the pilgrim curled below,
still dreaming of arrival
at some promised destination
marked on no earthly map.

MIDNIGHT TRANSIT

At the highways of woes, stoplights flash amber
warnings to empty intersections. The moon hangs
like a broken headlight in the sky's dark windshield.

I drive these routes in dreams—familiar exits
leading to places I've never been, service stations
manned by attendants with my father's hands
and my mother's patient eyes.

The GPS keeps recalculating,
its mechanical voice growing increasingly desperate
as I ignore its directions, preferring instead
the navigation of instinct and starlight.

Sometimes I pass other nighttime travelers,
our eyes meeting briefly in the gleam
of high beams. A fellowship of the lost.
A communion of seekers.

By morning, the highways dissolve
like mist, leaving me stranded
in the ordinary world, still feeling
the phantom vibration of wheels
spinning toward some elusive dawn.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A farmer's wife, both young and gay,'

responses.text:
A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Dances through fields of golden wheat.
Her laughter carries on the breeze,
As sunshine warms her rosy cheeks.

She tends the garden, feeds the hens,
And mends the fences worn by time.
Yet dreams beyond these acres stretch,
To distant lands she hopes to climb.

Her husband's hands are rough with toil,
His back bent low from years of work.
But in her eyes, he stands as tall
As mountains where the eagles lurk.

At night, beneath the silver moon,
She whispers secrets to the stars.
Of how this simple country life
Holds beauty in its humble scars.

For in the rhythm of the land,
The changing seasons, ebb and flow,
She's found a freedom most profound,
A happiness few come to know.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Not trapped, but rooted like a tree.
Her branches reaching for the sky,
Her roots in soil, wild and free.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Hid rainbows in her heart of hearts.
Beneath the watchful rural gaze,
She played the role that was her part.

The wedding band upon her hand
A golden cage around her truth.
The man she wed, a shield, a friend,
A compromise made in her youth.

They worked the land in silent peace,
Two souls with secrets of their own.
He never spoke of letters kept,
From soldier days he'd never shown.

At harvest dances, her eyes would stray
To catch the schoolmarm's gentle smile.
Two women bound by silent words,
And glances that stretched mile by mile.

In Sunday church, she bowed her head,
And prayed for strength to bear the weight
Of loving differently than most,
In times that couldn't tolerate.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay—
Two meanings braided into one.
Her truth like seeds beneath the soil,
Await an age that's yet to come.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Arises with the morning light.
The rooster crows, the cattle low,
Another day of wrong and right.

Her hands are cracked but gentle still,
When cradling her newborn child.
The fifth one born in seven years,
Her burden heavy, but she smiled.

The drought has lasted far too long,
The bank note's due by harvest end.
Her husband's eyes grow distant now,
His spirit harder still to mend.

She churns the butter, kneads the bread,
And hangs the washing in the sun.
A thousand tasks before the dusk,
And still her work is never done.

At night she stares through dusty panes,
At stars that seem so far away.
Like dreams she buried long ago,
Beneath the weight of every day.

Yet something in her still remains,
Undimmed by hardship, time, or strife.
A spark of joy, defiant hope—
The quiet strength of a farmer's wife.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Is more than what the eye perceives.
I am the dawn that breaks the dark,
The whispered promise autumn leaves.

My hands have birthed both calves and dreams,
My back has bent, but never broke.
My mind contains philosophies
That city scholars never spoke.

I've read my Plath by candlelight,
And Woolf beside the babbling creek.
While churning butter, solved equations
That would make a professor weak.

You see the apron, not the pen
That scratches poems late at night.
You note my calluses, not how
I map the stars and track their flight.

My husband sees me, knows me true,
A woman of both earth and air.
Together we have built a life
Where intellect and labor pair.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay—
A simple phrase for complex truth.
I am the vessel and the storm,
Both ancient wisdom and bright youth.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Danced with the fireflies at dusk.
Magical creatures, some would say,
But she knew better—they were us.

Transformed by moonlight's silver touch,
The souls of those who lived before.
Returning to the land they loved,
To dance upon the threshing floor.

Her grandmother had told her tales
Of how the veil grows thin at night.
Between our world and what's beyond,
Where ancient magic takes its flight.

She mixed her herbs with whispered words,
And hung protection by the door.
The neighbors called her 'touched by fae,'
Behind her back, but she knew more.

For in this valley, time stands still,
The old ways never truly died.
And she, keeper of secrets old,
Had nothing left she needed to hide.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
A witch, a healer, seer of truth.
The land and she, forever bound,
In ageless partnership, forsooth.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A farmer's wife, both young and gay,'

responses.text:
COUNTRY SUNRISE

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Greets golden dawn at break of day.
Her apron white against the corn,
Her laughter sweet as summer morn.

She dances through the dewy field,
Embracing all the earth may yield.
With calloused hands and tender heart,
She plays her essential part.

The chickens scatter at her feet,
As wildflowers bow, so discreet.
Her husband watches from the door,
In love with her forevermore.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Spins seasons into night and day.
In her eyes the harvest gleams,
In her smile, the future dreams.

BENEATH THE SURFACE

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Or so the village folk would say.
But windows show what doors conceal—
A deeper truth her eyes reveal.

She tends the fields with practiced grace,
A smile fixed firmly on her face.
While in her mind vast oceans roar,
And dreams fly past an unseen door.

She yearns for cities she's not known,
For conversations never sown.
Yet waters seeds with faithful care,
And braids wildflowers in her hair.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay—
Complexity in simple clay.
The soil knows her secret tears;
The wind, alone, her whispered fears.

THE WANDERER'S RETURN

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Had once been wild as wind in May.
Before the ring, before the vow,
Before she learned to guide the plow.

She'd traveled lands both far and wide,
With nothing but her wit as guide.
Climbed mountains tall and sailed blue seas,
Danced with strangers, felt truly free.

Now home she tends with knowing hands,
Her adventures mapped in subtle strands—
The foreign spices in her bread,
The curious tales her children spread.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Holds worlds within her simple way.
Her hearth now anchors wandering feet,
Yet in her eyes—the world complete.

TWO MEANINGS

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Defies the labels of today.
In fields of wheat and rows of corn,
A modern truth has been reborn.

She married him—her childhood friend,
A partnership that would not end.
Though not the love that sonnets claim,
A bond of trust that has no name.

Her truest love waits in the town,
A woman of some small renown.
They meet in secret, share their souls,
While society takes its tolls.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Navigates life in her own way.
Between two worlds she builds her home,
Authentic self no longer roam.

HARVEST MOON

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Dances beneath the moon's cold ray.
While husband sleeps in earthen bed,
She communes with the ancient dead.

Her laughter rings through midnight air,
As spirits gather, pale and fair.
The crops grow lush where she has tread,
Though neighbors speak with cautious dread.

She knows the herbs that heal and harm,
The words that shield from ghostly harm.
By morning light, none would suspect
The midnight rites she does perfect.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Keeps darkness and its kin at bay.
A guardian of the threshold thin,
Where mundane ends and myths begin.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A farmer's wife, both young and gay,'

responses.text:
SEASONS OF THE HEART

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Dances barefoot through morning dew.
Her laughter chases night away,
As roosters crow and day breaks new.

Beneath her hands, the garden grows,
Wild as her spirit, strong and free.
She whispers secrets no one knows
To seedlings reaching hopefully.

Summer burns her shoulders brown,
Autumn fills her shelves with gold.
Winter's quiet settles down,
As hearth-tales of her youth are told.

Spring returns with promise sweet,
Another year of toil and joy.
The cycle that makes life complete,
A happiness time can't destroy.

UNSPOKEN

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Not as the world now understands—
Though perhaps in both ways.
Her secret heart, like folded hands,
Holds truths she cannot say.

She tends the fields with careful grace,
Married to the land as much as him.
The wide sky her confessional space,
Where whispered prayers on twilight swim
To stars that don't erase.

In town they see a proper bride,
Smiling as expected, playing parts.
But wildflowers know what she must hide,
The true nature of fractured hearts
And love that's pushed aside.

She writes her truth in furrows deep,
Planting seeds of might-have-beens.
Some dreams are not for her to keep—
Except in poems no one reads
And tears shed while they sleep.

INHERITANCE

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
I watch her through the sepia tint
Of grandmother's forgotten frames.
Her eyes hold laughter not yet spent,
Her hands still smooth before the claims
Of labor etched their testament.

I wonder if she knew what waited—
Decades of dawn-to-dusk demands,
Eight children born, one lost to fever,
The mortgage on unforgiving lands,
The Great Depression, dust storms, leaving
Nothing but what she could withstand.

Yet in this photo, possibility
Shines brighter than the certain pain.
I carry her name, her cheekbones, maybe
This stubborn hope despite the rain.
Her joy, a radical legacy,
Flows through my veins like ancient grain.

CONTRARY SEASONS

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Rises before the jealous sun.
While dew still clings to spider's silk,
Her second workday has begun.

They said the land would break her back,
That city girls weren't meant to plow.
They whispered she would wilt by June—
They should see her calloused hands now.

She learns the language of the soil,
Reads weather in the blackbird's flight.
Finds freedom in the endless chores,
Finds purpose in the constant fight.

When drought comes calling, fierce and mean,
She stands defiant, will not bow.
A farmer's wife, no longer young,
But in her stubborn joy, somehow
Still gay despite what seasons bring,
Rooted deeper than any plow.

TRIPTYCH: FARM WIFE

I.
A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Married to the rhythm of seasons.
Milk-white arms that churned and kneaded,
Sang while fingers bled from picking.
No one painted her Madonna,
Though she created life from nothing.

II.
The mirror shows a stranger now—
Sun-leathered skin maps journeys taken.
Children grown and flown to cities,
Fields that once were green lie fallow.
She wonders what became of youth,
That girl who danced through morning dew.

III.
At night she dreams in vibrant hues
Of paths untaken, words unspoken.
But wakes to find her weathered hands
Have built a world worth living in.
The farm, her life's great masterpiece,
A canvas painted day by day.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

God is the refuge of his saints,
When storms of sharp distress invade;
Where weary souls find rest from plaints,
And shadows cannot make afraid.

Like mountains rising from the sea,
Your presence stands against the tide
Of doubt that seeks to conquer me,
Of fear that whispers I should hide.

Through valleys dark as death's domain,
Through deserts parched by sorrow's heat,
Your shelter falls like gentle rain,
A cool oasis, pure and sweet.

When I am lost in tangled woods
Of my own making, blind with tears,
You find me where no other could
And calm the tempest of my fears.

A lighthouse beam across the foam,
A star to guide my wayward bark,
Your love becomes my hearth and home
When all the world grows cold and dark.

God is the refuge of his saints—
Not walls of stone or gates of gold,
But arms that hold without restraints
And grace that never grows too old.

UNCHARTED WATERS

God is the refuge of his saints,
but what of those who wander still?
Those caught between belief and doubt,
with questions time may never fill?

I've watched the faithful find their peace,
their anchor in the sacred word,
while I drift on uncertain seas,
my prayers like whispers barely heard.

Perhaps the refuge isn't found
in certainty that never bends,
but in the search, the sacred ground
where mystery and mercy blend.

For even Thomas with his doubts
was welcomed by the wounded hand.
The questions that we dare to voice
may be the faith we understand.

And so I sail these waters deep,
not sure of what lies past the mist,
but trusting that the same vast love
that shelters saints might still exist

for those who cannot simply rest
in answers that remain unclear—
a refuge wide enough for all
who seek with hearts sincere and near.

ANCIENT STONES

God is the refuge of his saints,
As ancient as the desert stones
That witnessed exodus and trial,
The wilderness of skin and bones.

I think of caves where David hid
From Saul's pursuing, jealous rage,
Of Elijah fed by ravens
When famine gripped a godless age.

Of catacombs where early saints
Carved symbols of their dangerous faith,
Of monasteries perched on cliffs
Where prayer rose like sacred wraith.

Of slaves who sang their coded hymns,
Finding shelter in the sound,
Of martyrs facing flame and sword,
Whose refuge was not earthly ground.

What sanctuary calls to me
Across the centuries of need?
What hidden place of soul and spirit
Where wounded hearts may rest and feed?

Perhaps it's not a place at all,
But presence spanning time and space—
A love that holds all history
In its unfathomable embrace.

ARCHITECTURE OF GRACE

God is the refuge of his saints,
A living architecture of grace.
Not built with human hands or tools,
But fashioned from eternal space.

I've studied grand cathedrals' spires
That pierce the heavens with their art,
Yet found more holiness and awe
Within the chambers of my heart.

For what are walls and buttressed beams
Compared to mercy's boundless span?
What stained-glass glory can outshine
The light that heals the broken man?

The nave where I find sanctuary
Is built of moments, small and true—
The kindness shown to strangers' needs,
The grace that helps me start anew.

The flying buttress of this faith
Is not tradition, cold and stark,
But love that bears another's weight
When they are falling in the dark.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A temple not confined by place—
Its foundation laid in sacrifice,
Its walls constructed out of grace.

WILDERNESS HYMN

God is the refuge of his saints,
Even here, among the thorns,
Where desert stretches, vast and dry,
And hope seems dead each scorching morn.

I've walked this barren landscape long,
My throat parched tight with thirst and grief.
The map I trusted proved too vague,
The journey longer than belief.

Yet in this wilderness I've found
Unlikely shelters, strange and sweet:
A shadow cast by broken rock,
A spring where bitter waters meet.

The saints of old knew deserts well—
They walked for forty years and more,
Complained of hunger, doubted grace,
Yet manna fell on sandy floor.

Perhaps true refuge isn't found
In perfect landscapes, lush and green,
But in discovering sacred wells
In places we'd have never been

Had comfort kept us safely home,
Had ease become our only god.
The wilderness becomes a shrine
Where saints learn holy feet have trod.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress in the tempest's rage,
Where weary souls find sweet release
And burdens lighten, page by page.

I've wandered valleys deep with doubt,
Scaled mountains steep with fear,
Yet always found within Your arms
A shelter crystal clear.

The world may crack and thunder roar,
And shadows stretch their fingers long,
But in Your presence, mighty Lord,
The weakest heart grows ever strong.

You build Your sanctuary not
With timber, stone, or human hands,
But with unfailing promises
That span across all seas and lands.

When darkness falls and hope seems lost,
When enemies surround the gate,
I need but whisper Your sweet name
And watch as troubles dissipate.

For God is not a distant star
That coldly watches from above,
But present breath within my lungs,
And every heartbeat filled with love.

So let me dwell within Your courts,
A pilgrim finding perfect peace,
For God remains the saints' refuge,
Where grace and mercy never cease.

HIDDEN IN PLAIN SIGHT

God is the refuge of his saints,
but sometimes I forget to look
for shelter in the obvious places—

Like how the oak outside my window
bends but doesn't break in storms,
its roots invisible but vast,
anchored in secret depths.

Or how my grandmother's hands,
veined like river maps,
still find strength to hold mine
when the diagnosis comes.

The refuge isn't always cathedral walls
or whispered prayers at midnight.
Sometimes it's the sudden laughter
breaking through our tears,
the unexpected kindness
from the stranger on the bus,
the way light filters through
leaves after heavy rain.

I've searched for divine sanctuary
in ancient texts and solemn vows,
only to find it waiting
in my neighbor's borrowed flour,
in the silent space between heartbeats,
in the courage to begin again.

God is the refuge of his saints,
yes, but also of his doubters,
his questioners, his wanderers—
all of us moving through this world,
sheltered in plain sight,
carried in hands we cannot see
but somehow, still, can feel.

THROUGH THE CENTURIES

God is the refuge of his saints,
As martyrs knew in ancient Rome,
When lion's jaws and emperor's chains
Could never keep their spirits home.

God is the refuge of his saints,
As monks in desert cells would write,
Their quills illuminating faith
In manuscripts of golden light.

God is the refuge of his saints,
As slaves in cotton fields would sing,
Their spirituals reaching heaven's gates
Where freedom's bell would someday ring.

God is the refuge of his saints,
As mothers in the trenches pray,
Their children hungry, homes in flames,
Yet hope survives another day.

God is the refuge of his saints,
As protesters march hand in hand,
Their peaceful hearts demand justice,
Remaking what the prophets planned.

God is the refuge of his saints,
Today, as screens glow blue at night,
And lonely souls seek connection
In worlds where faith seems out of sight.

Through centuries of human strife,
Through progress, war, and vast unknown,
This truth remains our cornerstone:
God shelters those He calls His own.

THE ARCHITECTURE OF GRACE

God is the refuge of his saints,
Not built of stone but shaped from love—
A blueprint drawn before our birth,
Foundations laid in realms above.

Imagine now this sacred space:
No walls to hold the faithful in,
But boundaries formed of mercy's touch
That keeps the chaos from within.

The ceiling? Endless as the sky,
Yet intimate as whispered prayer.
The floor? Unyielding as His word,
Supporting feet in deep despair.

No lock exists upon the door
That swings both ways on grace's hinge.
No windows filter holy light—
It pours unbroken, without tinge.

I've wandered through this dwelling place
In moments both of joy and grief,
Found corners warmed by others' faith
When mine had dwindled past belief.

The architecture shifts and breathes,
Expanding as more seekers come,
Collapsing close around the one
Who feels abandoned, cold, and numb.

God engineers this sanctuary
Unique for every soul that sighs.
A refuge custom-built for saints
Still learning how to recognize
The shelter that was always there—
Invisible, yet everywhere.

QUESTIONS IN THE SHELTER

God is the refuge of his saints,
or so the ancient verse proclaims—
but what of those who cannot find the door?
What of those who stand outside,
knuckles bloodied from the knocking,
ears pressed against the silence?

I have been both:
the one enfolded in divine embrace
and the one screaming into void.
Both saint and stranger.
Both sheltered and exposed.

Sometimes I wonder if the refuge
is not a place at all
but the courage to remain
when every instinct urges flight.

Perhaps God's sanctuary exists
precisely in the questions:
How do we love what destroys us?
How do we forgive what seems unforgivable?
How do we find home in homelessness?

The saints I've known never claimed certainty—
only persistence.
They kept returning to the well
even when it seemed bone-dry.

So I will make my refuge
in this holy uncertainty,
this sacred doubt that pushes forward,
this fragile faith that whispers:
even here, especially here,
in the questioning and quaking,
God still builds a dwelling place
large enough for all our wandering.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress in the howling storm,
When thunder breaks and courage faints,
His arms, a shelter safe and warm.

When darkness gathers like a shroud,
And hope seems but a distant star,
His presence, steady through the cloud,
Reminds us who and whose we are.

The world may crumble, kingdoms fall,
And mountains tumble to the sea,
Yet in His sanctuary's wall,
We find what eyes may never see.

A peace that passes understanding,
A light that darkness cannot dim,
A love beyond our comprehending,
A home eternal found in Him.

REFUGE

God is the refuge of his saints,
but what of those who wander still?
Those who carry doubt like water
in cupped and trembling hands?

I have sought shelter in cathedral rafters,
in the space between prayer and silence,
in the questions that bloom
like midnight flowers in my mind.

Perhaps refuge isn't always
a fortress of certainty,
but the courage to stand exposed
in the rain of not-knowing.

Perhaps God dwells
in the seeking itself—
in each step taken
through the wilderness of wonder,
in each moment we choose
to remain open despite our fear.

I am learning that sanctuary
is not always a place,
but a presence that travels with us,
even through our darkest valleys.

ANCIENT TREES

God is the refuge of his saints,
Like ancient redwoods offering shade,
Their roots entwined beneath the soil,
A thousand years of faith displayed.

We shelter in the hollow space
Between this world and what's divine—
The way a sparrow finds its nest
Amid the branches, rain or shine.

The desert wanderer seeks the palm,
The sailor yearns for harbor lights,
The weary soul turns heavenward
Through blazing days and starless nights.

We are but leaves upon the wind,
Yet held within a sacred hand,
The pattern of our falling traced
Before we touch the waiting land.

In nature's temple, wild and free,
I glimpse what faith has always known:
That we are never truly lost
When love has claimed us as its own.

SANCTUARY CITIES

God is the refuge of his saints,
so I wonder about the sanctuaries we build—
the walls we raise and the borders we draw.

In this city of concrete and glass,
where do the displaced find shelter?
Under what bridges do prayers echo?

I have seen divinity in the woman
who opens her door to strangers,
in the soup kitchen's steam rising like incense,
in hands that bandage wounds without asking names.

Perhaps heaven's blueprint
is found in our collective courage,
in every act that says:
You are welcome here.
You are safe here.
You belong here.

If God is refuge,
then surely we are called
to be doorways to sanctuary,
to become the threshold
where the weary find rest,
where the hunted find peace,
where the lost find home.

THROUGH FIRE AND FLOOD

God is the refuge of his saints,
I heard my grandmother whisper
as tornado sirens wailed
and we huddled in the cellar,
her rosary beads clicking softly
like raindrops against the window.

I've carried those words
through fire and flood,
through hospital waiting rooms
and midnight doubts,
through joy so bright it burns
and grief that hollows bones.

Sometimes I wonder if refuge
means we are spared the storm,
or if it means we are given
the strength to weather it—
to stand in the wreckage afterward
and still recognize the shape of hope.

Perhaps refuge is not escape
but presence—the knowledge that
even as the waters rise,
we are not abandoned to the current.
Even as the flames advance,
we are held in a love that endures.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY OF SOULS

God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress standing through the ages,
Where weary hearts find rest
And troubled minds find peace.

When storms of life crash wild and fierce,
And lightning splits the darkened sky,
The sanctuary doors stand open wide,
A beacon calling through the night.

I've wandered far on broken paths,
My feet have bled on stones of doubt,
Yet always when I turn toward home,
The light still burns to guide me back.

For what is faith but finding shelter
When the world offers none?
What is grace but gentle hands
That catch us when we fall?

In chambers of that timeless heart,
Where mercy flows like healing streams,
The soul finds what it always sought—
A place to lay its burdens down.

God is the refuge of his saints,
Not built of stone but formed of love,
A dwelling place beyond all time,
Where we are known, and known, we're loved.

QUESTIONS IN THE SANCTUARY

God is the refuge of his saints,
Or so I've heard them say—
But what of those who walk alone
Along the shadowed way?

Is sanctuary only built
For those who never doubt?
Or is there room within those walls
For hearts that scream and shout?

I've searched for shelter in the storm,
Half-blind and soaked with rain,
Unsure if I would recognize
The refuge should I gain.

Perhaps the sanctuary's not
A place of perfect light,
But rather where our wounded selves
Can rest throughout the night.

Perhaps God's refuge isn't found
In certainty and might,
But in the gentle questioning
That leads us toward the light.

For saints are not the flawless ones
Who never trip or fall,
But those who stumble toward the truth
And answer love's strange call.

So let me find that refuge now,
Not perfect, but still true—
A shelter for my questioning heart,
Where I begin anew.

ANCIENT WALLS

God is the refuge of his saints,
As mountains guard the plain,
As ancient walls of weathered stone
Withstand the battering rain.

Through centuries of human strife,
Through empires' rise and fall,
The faithful sought this sanctuary,
This ever-present wall.

In catacombs and hidden rooms,
In soaring cathedrals vast,
In simple homes where candles burned,
This refuge held them fast.

I stand now where my ancestors stood,
Their whispered prayers still echo here,
Their tears have stained these sacred stones,
Their joy still lingers near.

What hands have touched these sanctuary doors?
What hearts found healing grace?
What burden-bearers laid their loads
Within this holy place?

Time cannot erode this fortress strong,
Nor armies break its gate,
For God's own refuge stands beyond
The reach of human fate.

So I will add my voice to theirs,
My story to their song,
And find within these ageless arms
The strength to carry on.

WILDERNESS SANCTUARY

God is the refuge of his saints,
Not built of stone or human hands,
But found where wild geese chart their course
Across the vast untamed lands.

I've sought the sacred in the wild,
Where pine trees whisper ancient psalms,
Where mountains rise like altars tall,
And rivers flow like outstretched palms.

The desert taught me how to thirst
For waters deeper than the well,
The forest showed me how to stand
Through seasons harsh and terrible.

No temple walls could hold the truth
That blazes from a sunset sky,
No human creed could capture grace
That falls as freely as the rain.

The wind that bends the tallest trees
Yet cannot break their supple strength
Speaks more of God's abiding care
Than all our words of measured length.

So let me worship in this church
Of starlight, stone, and flowing stream,
Where God's own refuge stands revealed
In ways beyond our wildest dreams.

For saints find shelter not in flight
From life's wild beauty, pain, and awe,
But in the heart of all that is—
Unbounded love without a flaw.

REFUGE IN THE STORM

God is the refuge of his saints,
When darkness swallows light,
When illness strikes without a cause,
When nothing feels quite right.

I lost my way some years ago,
When grief became my name,
When doctors shook their heads and sighed,
And nothing stayed the same.

The sanctuary I had known—
Of health and certain days—
Collapsed beneath the weight of pain
And unfamiliar ways.

Yet somehow in that broken place,
Where nothing worked as planned,
I felt a presence holding me
With an unfaltering hand.

Not fixing all that had gone wrong,
Nor making problems cease,
But offering a deeper gift:
A strange, sustaining peace.

For God's true refuge isn't found
In absence of all pain,
But in the strength to face each day
And rise to live again.

So now I build my altar here,
Upon this shaking ground,
And claim this unexpected truth:
In weakness, strength is found.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress in the raging storm,
When thunder shakes the mountain heights,
And lightning tears the sky apart.

When floods of sorrow drown the heart,
And winds of doubt erode our faith,
His arms become our shelter safe,
A harbor in the tempest's wrath.

The world may crumble into dust,
And empires fall like broken stone,
But those who dwell within His trust
Shall never face their fears alone.

For God is refuge, God is strength,
Eternal rock that cannot move,
The saints find peace within His length,
Embodied in unending love.

QUESTION OF SANCTUARY

God is the refuge of his saints,
but what of those who wander still?
I've traced your absence in the spaces
between my fingertips and empty prayers.

Is sanctuary something earned
or freely given? The night doesn't answer.
I collect doubt like small stones in my pocket,
weighing me down as I wade through uncertainty.

Perhaps refuge isn't walls or ceiling
but the courage to stand exposed,
to feel rain on upturned face
and call it blessing.

Maybe God's protection isn't shelter
from the storm, but strength
to dance within it, lightning
illuminating our broken edges into beauty.

THE OAK AND THE SPARROWS

God is the refuge of his saints,
Like ancient oak to trembling sparrow—
Wide arms spread against the coming gale,
Roots deep in earth's eternal marrow.

The little birds with fragile wings
Seek shelter in those steadfast boughs.
They sing their trust in tiny breaths
As darkness falls and cold winds rouse.

The oak stands firm through centuries,
Unmoved by season's harsh demands,
A living temple, breathing grace,
Not built by skill of human hands.

So too, the faithful find their rest
Beneath protection heaven-sent,
Nestled safe in love's embrace,
A canopy of sweet content.

DESERT CROSSING

God is the refuge of his saints,
I heard the preacher say,
As I stood at the edge of my own Sinai,
Miles of emptiness stretching before me.

I walked when my car broke down,
The sun a merciless eye above.
Water gone by afternoon,
Hope evaporating with each step.

Nightfall brought stars so bright they hurt,
And cold that carved into bone.
I wrapped myself in prayer like a blanket,
Words I hadn't spoken since childhood.

Dawn revealed a silhouette—a small church,
Weathered wood against rose-gold sky.
Inside, cool water and kind hands.
Somehow, I had walked directly to it in darkness.

INNER CHAMBERS

God is the refuge of his saints,
but what does sanctuary feel like
within the architecture of the soul?

Is it the sudden quiet
when you close your eyes
and find yourself standing
in a room built of light?

Or perhaps it's the moment
when grief becomes bearable,
when the weight shifts
from crushing to carried.

I've felt it in the spaces
between heartbeats,
a presence indescribable
yet undeniably there.

Not walls to keep danger out
but strength flowing in—
a current of peace
that transforms fear
into the foundation
of something holy.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress in the storm,
When thunder shakes the firmament
And lightning scars the dawn.

When sorrows like the tempest rise,
And hope seems but a ghost,
His arms encircle trembling hearts
Who need His shelter most.

I've wandered through the valleys deep,
Where shadows choke the light,
Yet found His presence in the dark,
A beacon burning bright.

The world may crack and kingdoms fall,
All certainties may flee,
But in the hollow of His hand,
He gently cradles me.

Through ages long, the faithful find
What I have come to know:
That neither height nor depth nor death
Can breach His love's strong glow.

So let the earthquakes have their day,
Let doubt its questions raise,
God is the refuge of his saints,
Unchanged through endless days.

And I, among the countless souls
Who've sheltered in His grace,
Find peace beyond all understanding
In His safe dwelling place.

INVISIBLE ARMOR

God is the refuge of his saints,
but what of those who wander still?
I've felt the absence like a wound
yet somehow sense protection
in the spaces between breaths.

My grandmother called it grace—
the way light filters through leaves,
how pain subsides when least expected,
the stranger's kindness on a bitter day.

I cannot name the architecture of this shelter.
It has no walls I recognize,
no roof I can describe,
yet in my darkest hour
something held me like cupped hands around a flame.

Scientists speak of dark matter,
invisible but everywhere,
holding galaxies together.
Perhaps faith works the same—
unseen but fundamental,
supporting what would otherwise collapse.

I've questioned everything and still do,
yet find myself returning to this truth:
when nothing else remains,
when every human refuge fails,
something greater than my understanding
receives my falling self.

God is the refuge of his saints,
and maybe too of doubters,
seekers, broken ones—
all of us carried in the same
unfathomable embrace.

MOUNTAIN SANCTUARY

God is the refuge of his saints,
Like ancient mountains standing guard—
Impassive to the changing world,
Unmoved by time's relentless march.

I've seen the eagle build her nest
High on the weathered granite face,
Where winds that topple valley trees
Cannot disturb her dwelling place.

So we, who seek the higher ground,
Ascend beyond the churning flood.
The waters rise, the tempests rage,
But cannot reach the mount of God.

The desert wanderer dreams of shade,
Of water flowing cool and clear.
The hunted longs for sanctuary,
Where danger cannot draw too near.

In wilderness, I've found these springs—
Oases in the barren land.
Not made by human architect,
But hollowed by a greater hand.

The forest chapel, moss-adorned,
The canyon's solemn, sacred walls,
The ocean's thunder-sermon voiced—
Each whispers how His shelter calls.

God is the refuge of his saints,
Not built of stone but something more:
A presence spanning earth and sky,
A harbor on the farthest shore.

THROUGH THE FIRE

God is the refuge of his saints,
they said to me when flames consumed
everything I'd built.
Standing in the ashes of my certainties,
I wanted to believe them.

I had no refuge then but questions—
ragged prayers hurled at silent skies,
tears that carved new landscapes
across the desert of my faith.

They speak of shelters and of fortresses,
of mighty towers and protecting wings.
I found no such architecture in my pain,
only absence stretching horizon-wide.

Yet something strange occurred
as days bled into months:
the emptiness became a kind of space
where something new could grow.

Not answers—I have fewer now than ever—
but presence, unexplainable and real.
Not safety from the storm,
but strength to stand within it.

Perhaps this is the refuge they described:
not escape from suffering
but transformation through it.

Now when they say to me,
"God is the refuge of his saints,"
I nod, though what I understand by this
is nothing like what I once thought.

The refuge is not shelter from the fire
but becoming something that the fire cannot destroy.

THE ENDLESS EMBRACE

God is the refuge of his saints,
So speaks the ancient song—
But I have come to understand
This refuge as the vast expanse
Of sky that holds both storm and calm,
Both darkness and the light.

The breath that fills these lungs,
The silence between heartbeats,
The space between all things,
Yet dwelling deep within them.

I bow not to an image
Nor bend to distant power,
But recognize the current
That flows through all existence—
The sacred thread connecting
What seems so separate.

When fear arises like a wall,
I remember this refuge has no boundaries.
When grief wells up like midnight tide,
I recall this shelter has no roof
But stretches to infinity.

The saints of every tradition
Have given different names
To this same knowing:
That we are held within
A love too vast to comprehend,
Too close to recognize.

God is the refuge of his saints,
And saints are those who see
That they were never separate
From the refuge they once sought.

We are the wave returning to the ocean,
The breath dissolving into air,
Forever held within the endless embrace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into origami secrets,
Tucked between the pages of unread books.
The world asks too much of her bones—
To stand straight, to bear weight, to never creak.

She builds fortresses from blankets,
Constructs cathedrals from silence,
Worship in the religion of absence.
Is it wrong to disappear?
To become a ghost in your own life?

Sometimes hiding is the only prayer
That makes sense when your skin
Feels too thin to hold your spirit.

She collects shadows like old friends,
Whispers confessions to empty rooms,
Finds comfort in corners where
Expectations cannot find her.

Hiding is not always surrender—
Sometimes it's the bravest thing:
To protect what remains unbroken,
To guard the flickering light
That threatens to extinguish
In the hurricane of others' needs.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in that wanting, finds herself
Preserved, like amber-trapped moments,
Waiting for a gentler world
To emerge into once more.

CHRYSALIS

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like autumn leaves beneath December snow,
Like secrets buried in the river's flow,
Like stars that daylight forces to subside.

She wraps herself in silence, thick and wide,
A cloak of shadows where no winds can blow.
The forest understands what few can know:
Some creatures need the dark to grow inside.

The snail carries its shelter on its back,
The moth cocoons before it learns to fly,
The seed must bury deep before it blooms.

She is not broken in her need to lack
The constant gaze that measures from on high.
She's gathering strength in self-made rooms.

The world mistakes her absence for defeat,
Not seeing how she gathers what she needs—
The quiet space where scattered parts complete
The sacred work that solitude concedes.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Not vanishing, but waiting to emerge
Transformed by darkness, patient to abide
Until her hiding and her self converge.

INVISIBLE WOMAN

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
a desire that pulses with each heartbeat,
drumming against her ribs like trapped birds.

She practices the art of disappearance:
how to shrink her voice to whisper-size,
how to press her body against walls,
how to walk between raindrops.

They say women past forty become invisible.
She thinks: why wait that long?
There's freedom in being unseen,
in slipping the collar of others' expectations.

She collects hiding places like souvenirs:
the space between shower curtain and tile,
the hollow beneath staircases,
the shadow side of laughter at parties,
the pocket universe inside her headphones.

What they call hiding
she calls finding herself.

Sometimes visibility is violence—
the constant assessment,
the measuring gaze,
the requirement to perform.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
and in that wanting discovers
that invisibility is her superpower,
that she can observe the world
without being consumed by it,
that she can finally hear her own voice
when no one is listening for it.

EMERGENCE

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To dissolve into wallpaper patterns,
To become one with the dust motes
Dancing in afternoon light.

She has perfected the art of absence—
The careful step that makes no sound,
The breath held until lungs burn,
The smile that reveals nothing.

But hiding has its own geography,
And she has mapped every inch:
The quicksand of self-doubt,
The cliffs of others' disappointment,
The vast deserts of loneliness.

One day, she finds a door
She doesn't remember creating.
Behind it: her own voice,
Rusty from disuse but still strong.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
But today she wants to be found—
Not by others, but by herself.

She steps from shadow into light,
Not all at once, but finger by finger,
Toe by tentative toe,
Until she stands fully in the sun,
Casting a shadow that proves
She occupies space in this world.

She keeps her hiding places,
Like childhood toys in an attic box,
Knowing some days still require shelter,
But they no longer define her borders.

TIDAL WOMAN

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To retreat like the sea at low tide,
Leaving only impressions in wet sand,
Evidence she once covered this land.

She is lunar in her movements,
Waxing brave on certain days,
Waning into corners on others,
Following ancient, internal rhythms
No calendar can capture.

The world demands constant presence—
Always visible, always available,
Always pouring outward like a broken tap.
But nature knows better:
Even the ocean must pull back
To gather strength for returning.

In her hiding, she is not empty
But full of untranslatable thoughts,
Collecting herself like scattered shells,
Sorting through what to keep,
What to release back to deeper waters.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And the universe understands this need—
The turtle retreats to its shell,
The bear to its winter cave,
The seed to its underground darkness.

She is not lost when hidden,
But finding her way back
To the shoreline of herself,
Where eventually, like the faithful tide,
She will rise again, reaching further
Than before she withdrew.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the quiet corners
Where expectation cannot find her.
She seeks sanctuary in shadows,
In the gentle absence of being seen.

It's not escape she craves, but stillness—
A moment where the world's hands
Are not constantly reaching,
Where voices don't call her name
Like obligations she cannot refuse.

In hiding, she rediscovers herself,
The contours of her thoughts
Untouched by others' perceptions.
She breathes in darkness like medicine,
Lets silence heal what noise has broken.

She builds herself a fortress
Of books unread, of tea gone cold,
Of blankets weighted with comfort.
Her absence is not emptiness
But fullness of another kind.

And when she emerges,
As she always does,
She carries with her
That secret space inside,
A hidden room where she can dwell
Even in the brightest light,
Even in the loudest crowd,
Remembering that to hide
Is sometimes the most honest
Way of being found.

VANISHING POINT

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To dissolve like sugar in hot water,
To become invisible to the eyes that cut.

The world has made a weapon of seeing.
Each glance carries judgment,
Each gaze bears the weight of history—
All the times she wasn't enough,
All the spaces she couldn't fill.

She learns the art of disappearance:
How to make herself small,
How to speak without sound,
How to exist without presence.

She practices fading at mirrors,
Watching herself become translucent,
A ghost haunting her own reflection.
The bruises of memory press beneath her skin,
Blossoming purple where hands once held too tight,
Where words once cut too deep.

In darkness, she reconstructs herself
From fragments the world didn't want.
Piece by broken piece,
She builds a shelter of absence,
A negative space in the shape of survival.

Sometimes hiding isn't surrender—
It's the last act of defiance,
The refusal to be consumed
By eyes that never truly saw her
Even when she stood in plain sight.

THE UNRAVELING

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From herself most of all—
That stranger wearing her face,
That puppet dancing to strings
She never agreed to hold.

Who is this person she's become?
This collection of careful phrases,
Rehearsed smiles, measured steps.
A performance without intermission,
A mask grown into skin.

She hides from questions
That threaten to unravel her:
Am I living or merely existing?
Is this voice truly mine?
Who would I be if no one was watching?

In the spaces between expectations,
She catches glimpses of authenticity—
Wild, untamed moments
When she forgets to perform,
When laughter erupts unplanned,
When tears fall without permission.

These moments terrify and liberate.
To be seen in truth is to be vulnerable,
To risk the comfort of conformity.

So she continues her hiding,
But plants seeds of courage in secret soil,
Watering them with small rebellions,
Knowing someday they'll grow tall enough
To cast shadows over her disguises,
And she'll step into sunlight
As herself, at last.

CHRYSALIS

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like a caterpillar sensing transformation,
Seeking darkness before becoming light.

She builds her cocoon from silence,
From moments stolen between obligations,
From dreams deferred but not abandoned.
Within this sacred space, she dissolves—
Not into nothingness, but possibility.

The world outside continues its clamor,
Demanding, expecting, assuming.
It does not understand the necessity
Of temporary disappearance,
The power in strategic retreat.

In hiding, she is not lost but finding—
Mapping territories within herself
That no explorer has charted,
Discovering strengths dormant
Beneath years of doubt.

Her absence is not permanent;
It is the gathering of forces,
The quiet before emergence.
She is becoming.

And when she returns—
As the butterfly returns,
Unrecognizable from what entered the dark—
She will bring with her new colors,
New capabilities for flight,
New understanding of both fragility and strength.

Sometimes hiding is the bravest choice—
The refusal to emerge half-formed,
The wisdom to wait for wings.

DIMENSIONS OF ABSENCE

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To slip between the cracks of reality,
Where physics bends and logic sleeps.

She dreams of doorways in ordinary walls,
Passages that only she can see—
Portals to rooms that exist
In the space between heartbeats.

There, gravity releases its hold.
She floats among suspended teacups,
Conversations frozen mid-syllable,
Clocks whose hands move counterclockwise.
She collects forgotten moments,
Strings them like beads around her neck.

In this hiding place, trees grow upside-down,
Roots reaching for impossible stars.
She walks on ceilings, sleeps in vertical beds,
Breathes underwater without drowning.

The ordinary world searches for her
With its mundane eyes, its limited imagination.
It cannot conceive of her dimensions,
Cannot follow where she's vanished.

She leaves cryptic clues in her wake:
A single shoe filled with marbles,
A window that opens onto another window,
A mirror that reflects yesterday.

To hide is not to disappear
But to exist where others cannot follow—
In the surreal landscape of her making,
Where absence is simply presence
In a universe running parallel to our own.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the smallest space,
A paper crane with wings pressed tight,
Beneath the weight of watching eyes.

The world demands performance—
Smiles pinned like butterflies to a board,
Voice tuned to the perfect pitch of pleasant,
Thoughts filtered through acceptable sieves.

So she builds shelters in strange places:
Between pages of forgotten books,
In the static between radio stations,
Under quilts her grandmother stitched with stories.

Her hiding isn't weakness—
It's preservation, restoration,
The necessary darkness where seeds
Gather strength before breaking soil.

She retreats to remake herself,
To remember the shape of her own thoughts
Unclouded by the noise of expectation,
To hear the rhythm of her authentic heart.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Not to disappear completely,
But to find herself again
In the sacred space of solitude,
Where silence speaks her name
In a voice she recognizes as her own.

CHRYSALIS

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To slip between the cracks of perception,
Dissolve into shadow and negative space,
Where judgment cannot find purchase.

The world has grown too sharp,
Its edges cutting into soft places—
Expectations like thorns,
Words like small, precise knives.

She dreams of cocoons,
Of metamorphosis in darkness,
Of emerging only when ready,
Transformed and unrecognizable.

In hiding, she finds strange power:
The freedom of being unseen,
Of shedding the skin that no longer fits,
Of becoming something wild and unnamed.

She collects hiding places like treasures—
The space between heartbeats,
The moment before dawn breaks,
The pause between inhale and exhale.

And in these secret pockets of existence,
She whispers truths to herself
That she's never dared speak aloud,
Planting seeds of revolution
In the fertile soil of her concealment.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Not from fear, but possibility—
The sacred chance to remake herself
Beyond the world's limiting gaze.

TIDAL WOMAN

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like the moon pulling the tide away from shore,
Retracting into herself, a necessary ebb
After giving too much of her waters to the world.

She becomes the hermit crab, seeking
New shells when old protections crack,
Carrying her soft vulnerabilities
Away from hungry predators.

The world calls this selfish—
This preservation of self,
This refusal to be consumed,
This boundary-drawing in sand.

But even the most steadfast lighthouse
Must sometimes dim its warning light,
Conserve its flame against the storm,
Rest in darkness to shine again.

She has learned the wisdom of caves,
How darkness can be nurturing,
How echo returns your voice to you
When you've forgotten its sound.

In hiding, she maps her interior geography,
Charting constellations of desire and fear,
Naming the unnamed parts of herself,
Claiming territory long surrendered.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in this wanting is a kind of truth—
That to retreat is not to surrender
But to gather strength for return.

INVISIBLE INK

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To write herself in invisible ink
Between the lines of others' stories,
A ghost-presence haunting her own life.

The world has taught her well:
How to shrink at the right moments,
How to blur her edges into backgrounds,
How to swallow words before they form.

She practices the art of vanishing—
A magician's greatest trick—
Leaving only a shimmer in the air
Where her body once occupied space.

In childhood, she played hide-and-seek
And discovered the thrill of not being found,
How silence can become a sanctuary,
How stillness can render you untouchable.

Now she hides in plain sight:
Behind smiles that reveal nothing,
In conversations filled with safe words,
In clothes chosen for camouflage.

But sometimes, in dreams,
She stands in open fields,
Arms wide, face tilted skyward,
Visible to satellites and gods,
Unapologetically present.

And waking, she wonders
What might happen if she stopped hiding,
If she allowed herself to be discovered,
If the seeking was worth the finding.

QUANTUM STATE

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To exist in quantum uncertainty—
Neither here nor there, particle nor wave,
A possibility rather than a fixed point.

The universe demands definition:
Check these boxes, fill these forms,
Tell us who you are in twenty-five words or less,
Make yourself known, categorized, contained.

But she has always lived in the spaces between—
Between breaths, between heartbeats,
Between the lines of acceptable narratives,
Between the binary choices offered.

In hiding, she becomes multiplicity:
A thousand potential selves,
Unobserved and therefore unlimited,
Schrodinger's woman, both dead and alive.

She collects masks like some collect lovers,
Each one revealing a different truth,
Each concealment a kind of honesty,
A refusal to be reduced to singularity.

The world calls this deception,
But she knows it as survival—
This shapeshifting, this quantum dance,
This refusal to collapse into one reality.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Not to disappear completely,
But to remain wonderfully, defiantly
Undefined and undefinable.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
THE VANISHING

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the space between breaths,
Where the world's ceaseless noise
Cannot find her fragile edges.

She collects shadows like old friends,
Drapes them over her shoulders,
Learns to walk beneath their weight
Without making a sound.

The art of disappearing—
A skill perfected in small increments:
The lowered gaze, the shortened stride,
The voice that apologizes for its existence.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To become so still that even her thoughts
Cannot betray her location,
As if absence were a country
Where she alone holds citizenship.

Yet in that vanishing,
Something essential remains,
A heartbeat persistent as truth,
Whispering: even invisible,
You are here. You are here.

CHRYSALIS

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like a seed beneath winter soil,
Patient with the knowledge
That darkness is not an ending.

She wraps silence around herself—
A temporary cocoon,
Not an eternal tomb.

The world mistakes her absence for weakness,
Unable to see the fierce reconstruction
Occurring beneath the surface:
Bones rearranging,
Thoughts crystallizing,
Strength gathering in her marrow.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Not to diminish, but to concentrate,
To distill herself to essential elements,
To prepare for the moment when
She will emerge, unfurling
With the terrible beauty
Of something that has transformed itself
In the sacred darkness
Where all rebirth begins.

INVISIBLE WOMAN

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From eyes that see only what they expect,
From voices that name her without permission,
From hands that reach to shape her into familiar forms.

She has learned the peculiar freedom
Of being overlooked—
How people speak truth around those
They believe cannot hear,
How doors left unguarded open
To rooms where decisions are made.

In her transparency, she has become
A collector of secrets, a witness to power,
Moving through the world like a ghost
With unexpected agency.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in that hiding finds herself
More present than she ever was
When struggling to be seen.

This is not the lesson they meant to teach her,
But it is the one she has learned best:
Invisibility can be a weapon
In hands skilled enough to wield it.

NEGATIVE SPACE

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To become the pause between musical notes,
The white space that gives meaning to words,
The breath between sentences.

She dreams of evaporation,
Of molecules dispersing into air,
Of consciousness expanding beyond
The prison of defined edges.

What would it mean to exist
As absence rather than presence?
To be known by what surrounds you
Rather than what you contain?

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Not from fear but curiosity—
To understand herself as negative space,
The shape revealed by what isn't there.

Perhaps this is what the mystics meant
By emptying oneself to be filled:
The paradox of becoming most yourself
By surrendering the illusion
That you were ever separate
From the vastness that holds you.

HIDE AND SEEK

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
As she did in childhood games—
Curled beneath stairwells,
Tucked inside wardrobes,
Breath held, heart racing.

The thrill of being searched for,
The power of being unfound,
The delicious tension of waiting
To be discovered or overlooked.

Now she hides in plain sight,
Behind smiles that reveal nothing,
In conversations where she speaks
Every word except the true ones.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To return to that simple joy
Of temporary disappearance,
When being found was still a victory,
Not a surrender.

She counts backwards from ten,
Ready or not, here comes
The person she has been avoiding—
Herself, with questions
She's not yet ready to answer,
Patiently waiting in all
The places she cannot hide.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the spaces between heartbeats,
Where the world's ceaseless drumming fades.
She seeks shelter in the hollow of ancient trees,
In the soft depression her body leaves in unmade beds,
In books with dog-eared pages that promise escape.

The weight of eyes upon her skin—
A burden heavier than any atlas could bear.
She dissolves into shadow,
Gathers silence around her shoulders like a cloak,
And breathes only when the moon permits.

Do not mistake her absence for weakness.
In her hiding places, she is gathering strength,
Rebuilding the walls of her sacred self,
Learning the language of her own soul
Before the world can teach her to forget it.

PERSEPHONE'S CHOICE

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To sink beneath the earth's dark crust,
Where pomegranate seeds stain fingers crimson
And no mother's tears can reach her.

The underworld welcomes her like an old friend—
Silent, patient, without judgment or demand.
Here, among shadows and forgotten souls,
She wears her crown of night-blooming flowers,
Rules with the quiet authority of one
Who has chosen her own captivity.

Above, they call it abduction, tragedy,
The theft of spring from an unwilling world.
They do not understand how sweetly darkness calls,
How liberation lives in her self-imposed exile,
How sometimes, divinity is found
Only when hidden from heaven's blinding light.

VANISHING ACT

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To erase the map of bruises he's charted
Across the continent of her skin.
She practices invisibility like a magic trick—
Smaller voice, lighter footsteps,
Less of everything until there's almost nothing left.

She collects escape routes like souvenirs,
Memorizes the location of every exit door,
Calculates how quickly she could disappear
If the storm in his eyes breaks against her shore again.

But hiding is not the same as vanishing.
One day she will step out from the shadows,
Not a disappearance but an emergence,
Not shrinking but expanding beyond
The borders he tried to draw around her life.
She will hide no more.

INTROVERT'S ANTHEM

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And why shouldn't she?
The world is loud with its constant demands—
Speak up, show up, share everything.

They call it antisocial, as if society
Is the only worthwhile destination.
They don't understand the rich geography
Of her inner landscape, how it flourishes
Only when given room to breathe.

In solitude, she finds the universe
Expanded within her ribcage.
In quiet rooms with doors firmly closed,
She discovers conversations with herself
Worth having.

Her hiding is not retreat but return—
A homecoming to the country of her own mind
Where she is both sovereign and citizen,
And silence is the language everyone speaks fluently.

CHRYSALIS

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To wrap herself in silken threads of isolation,
To suspend all interaction with the watching world.
This is not death but necessary transformation.

Inside her self-made cocoon,
She dissolves the person she was told to be—
Daughter, lover, caretaker, muse—
Until she is nothing but potential,
Raw material for her own recreation.

The hiding place becomes a workshop,
Where she fashions new wings from the remnants
Of discarded expectations.
Time moves differently here,
Measured not in minutes but in mutations.

When she emerges, they will call it sudden,
Not seeing how each moment of hiding
Was a step in becoming.
Sometimes destruction requires privacy;
Sometimes rebirth demands darkness first.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the hollow of a tree,
Where heartbeats slow to match the ancient rings,
And breath becomes the whisper of leaves.

The world demands her brightness,
Expects her to shine without dimming,
To give without emptying,
To speak without trembling.

But in silence, she finds her voice,
In darkness, she sees her shape,
In solitude, she meets herself
Unfiltered by others' expectations.

Sometimes hiding isn't retreat
But the bravest form of meeting,
Not an absence but a gathering,
Not an ending but a seed beginning.

CHRYSALIS

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To cocoon herself in shadows,
Wrap her body in silk spun from moonlight,
And wait for transformation.

They mistake her silence for weakness,
Her absence for surrender,
Never understanding that in hiding
She is becoming.

Like the caterpillar dissolving,
She liquefies her former self,
Rearranges molecules of doubt
Into wings of certainty.

When she emerges—
And she will emerge—
The world that drove her inward
Will not recognize what it has created.

INVISIBLE WOMAN

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From eyes that dissect without seeing,
From hands that reach without asking,
From voices that name without knowing.

She practices the art of disappearing
In plain sight: shoulders curved inward,
Voice pitched to pleasant background music,
Existence thinned to accommodate others.

She's perfected transparency,
Becoming glass in board rooms,
Smoke in arguments,
Water in history books.

But even invisible women cast shadows
When the light hits just right,
And her outline grows longer and darker
With each setting sun she survives.

THE CAVE

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To retreat into the cave of her mind
Where stalactites of memory drip slowly,
Forming pools of reflection.

Outside, the storm of expectations rages,
Lightning strikes of judgment,
Thunder of unsolicited advice,
Floodwaters of others' needs rising.

In the darkness, she traces
Wall paintings of her true self,
Uses fingertips to remember
The contours of her own desires.

The cave is not escape but return,
Not absence but presence,
Not silence but the oldest language—
The one she spoke before the world taught her shame.

CHAMELEON GIRL

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To blend her edges with the wallpaper,
Change her colors to match the mood,
Become whatever they need to see.

She learned young: safety in camouflage,
Survival in adaptation,
Acceptance in reflection.
A mirror rarely gets blamed for what it shows.

But mirrors crack eventually,
And through the fractures, her true colors leak—
Wild purples no landscape contains,
Blues deeper than any sky could hold.

The hiding taught her patience,
The blending taught her boundaries,
And now she's learning the most dangerous art:
Being seen exactly as she is.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text:
And when, in the city in which I love you,
The streetlights cast gold upon your face,
I remember why concrete can feel like heaven.
Your footsteps echo mine across crosswalks,
Between skyscrapers that frame our silhouettes
Against an electric sky.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
We shelter from rain beneath awnings,
Your laughter drowns the taxi horns and sirens,
Transforming chaos into symphony.

This metropolis holds our secrets
In subway tunnels and rooftop gardens,
In coffee shops where our fingers intertwined
Across tables marked with rings from cups.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
Time suspends between traffic lights,
Each moment crystallized in memory—
The way you point to buildings with histories,
How you know the shortcuts through crowded streets,
Your silhouette against the skyline at dusk.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I am never lost, even in labyrinths
Of one-way streets and endless avenues.
You are my compass, my map, my destination.
In this urban wilderness, you are home.
