remember this: the cosmos keeps
its promises while justice sleeps.

There is a law which guarantees
our atoms will rejoin the seas,
the mountains, stars, and morning dew—
what once was me returns as you.

FINE PRINT

There is a law which guarantees
our voices matter equally
(except when money speaks instead
and drowning out is not a crime).

There is a law which guarantees
the right to breathe the open air
(unless your skin reflects too much
or too little of the sunlight's glare).

There is a law which guarantees
that justice wears a blindfold tight
(but peeks between the fabric's folds
to check your balance and your height).

There is a law which guarantees
protection from the tyrant's hand
(until convenience dictates that
exceptions must be made to stand).

There is a law which guarantees
your freedom to pursue your dreams
(provided they fit neatly in
the boxes drawn by those who scheme).

There is a law which guarantees
equality—a noble thought
(but read the asterisks with care;
the truth is often sold and bought).

There is a law which guarantees
we'll someday see beyond these lies
and write new laws in hearts, not books,
where true redemption finally lies.

CONSTANTS

There is a law which guarantees
the fall of objects, great and small.
No preference for leaves or stones—
gravity embraces all.

There is a law which guarantees
entropy's relentless climb.
Order slipping into chaos
through the corridors of time.

There is a law which guarantees
the conservation of all force.
Energy transforms its face
but never deviates its course.

There is a law which guarantees
the speed of light stays ever true,
a cosmic limit, strictly kept,
across the vastness, old and new.

There is a law which guarantees
uncertainty at quantum scale.
The more precisely we observe,
the more our other measures fail.

There is a law which guarantees
the double helix will unwind
to replicate its ancient code—
the blueprint of all humankind.

There is a law which guarantees
that laws themselves evolve with thought.
What once seemed absolute may shift
as deeper understanding's sought.

In equations etched by human hands,
we glimpse the universe's plan—
a poetry of numbers, proof
that wonder and truth are one again.

HEARTBEAT THEOREM

There is a law which guarantees
the ache when lovers part at dawn,
the phantom weight of absent hands,
the hollow space where warmth has gone.

There is a law which guarantees
the way your name tastes on my tongue—
a syllable of purest light
from which all other sounds are hung.

There is a law which guarantees
the memory of your laugh will find
its way into my darkest hours,
illuminating what's behind.

There is a law which guarantees
the synchronized beat of hearts that know
they're tethered by invisible threads
too stubborn to simply let go.

There is a law which guarantees
the healing power of gentle touch,
the wordless language of the skin
that sometimes says too much, too much.

There is a law which guarantees
that distance is a kind of lie
when souls have learned to recognize
each other's truth without trying.

There is a law which guarantees
that love, once planted, never dies—
it only changes form and shape,
like water cycling through the skies.

CERTAINTY OF UNCERTAINTY

There is a law which guarantees
the dissolution of all laws.
The certainty of shifting sand,
the permanence of paper claws.

There is a law which guarantees
blue oranges will dream of flight
while teacups filled with yesterday
spill shadows into blinding light.

There is a law which guarantees
the alphabet of unborn stars
will spell your name in backwards time
where clocks grow wings and heal old scars.

There is a law which guarantees
that doorways lead to other doors
and mirrors only show the face
of those who've never lived before.

There is a law which guarantees
the taste of questions never asked,
the weight of possibilities
that dance like dust in sunlight, masked.

There is a law which guarantees
that nothing can be guaranteed—
paradox blooms like springtime frost,
a contradiction gone to seed.

There is a law which guarantees
the mystery beneath all things,
where logic bends and reason sleeps
and chaos folds its patient wings.

And in this law, we find ourselves,
forever seeking what we are—
both question and the answer's ghost,
both compass needle and the star.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'There is a law which guarantees'

responses.text:
There is a law which guarantees
The stars will never cease to shine,
That gravity will hold us close
To earth, to home, to what is mine.

There is a law which guarantees
That time moves forward, never back,
That energy transforms but stays,
Preserving what we think we lack.

There is a law which guarantees
The universe's grand design,
Yet cannot promise human hearts
Will follow paths so clean, defined.

For in the space between the stars,
Where physics bends to poetry,
We find the only truth that counts:
Our choice to love, to feel, to be.

There is a law which guarantees
The poor man's voice will someday rise.
Though justice sleeps beneath the weight
Of power dressed in thin disguise.

There is a law which guarantees
No chain can bind the mind for long.
The walls we build to silence truth
Collapse beneath the freedom song.

In courtrooms cold and streets aflame,
The scales may tip but never break.
For every right denied by force
A thousand hearts to action wake.

So speak the truth against the tide,
And hold fast faith in what must be.
There is a law which guarantees
That bent toward liberty.

There is a law which guarantees
The turning of the seasons' wheel.
The winter frost must yield to spring,
No matter how the north winds squeal.

The seed, though buried deep and dark,
Knows nothing of despair or doubt.
It trusts the ancient covenant
That life will find its passage out.

The salmon swimming upstream knows,
The monarch in its southern flight,
The bear in hibernation's grip—
All faithful to the natural right.

So too might we, in darkest times,
Remember earth's enduring vow:
There is a law which guarantees
Renewal comes, though we know not how.

There is a law which guarantees
No heart can love without some pain,
No joy arrives without its twin,
No loss without some hidden gain.

I've watched your smile across the room,
A lighthouse in my stormy sea.
The law of longing pulls me close,
While fear's law pushes me to flee.

We dance around these certainties,
Two planets locked in orbit's sway.
The physics of our souls complex,
Yet simple in the light of day.

So take my hand despite the risk,
For though love offers no reprieve,
There is a law which guarantees
That only what we risk, we receive.

There is a law which guarantees
The mystery remains intact.
For every answer science yields,
Ten questions rise from every fact.

The cosmos spins its ancient tale
In languages we barely grasp.
The quark, the star, the human mind—
All riddles that we strain to clasp.

Some call it God, some Nature's way,
Some random chance, some grand design.
The names we choose shape what we see
Across the blur of space and time.

Yet in this one truth we can trust:
The wonder never shall decrease.
There is a law which guarantees
Our searching brings both doubt and peace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The breezes waved the silver grass,'

responses.text:
WHISPERS OF SILVER

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Like ripples on a moonlit sea,
Time suspended in each blade that bent
And rose again with gentle certainty.

I watched the meadow's shimmering dance,
A thousand mirrors catching light,
Reflecting back the passing clouds
And all the stars that crowned the night.

How fleeting is this silver scene,
How temporary every sway,
Yet in its motion lies a truth
Of beauty found in what won't stay.

The grasses bow and straighten up,
A rhythm older than our breath,
They know the secret language of
The wind that speaks of life and death.

I stand at meadow's edge and feel
Myself a part of nature's flow,
As silver blades caress my hands
And teach me what the wise grass know—

That we are all just passing through,
Like shadows cast by clouds above,
Yet in our bending, in our dance,
We manifest a timeless love.

SUMMER OF '67

The breezes waved the silver grass,
As we lay back on checkered cloth,
Your laughter scattered like the seeds
That floated past on summer's breath.

Remember how we made our plans
Beneath that endless azure sky?
The future stretched before us then,
As vast as fields that caught our eye.

You wore that dress of faded blue,
I wore my father's old straw hat,
The picnic basket between us held
Sweet tea and dreams we shared and sat.

The silver grass concealed our hands
As fingers intertwined like roots,
And promises were whispered low
Amid the hum of distant flutes.

We never saw the storm approach,
The years that pulled us both apart,
Yet still I feel the phantom touch
Of silver grass across my heart.

And sometimes when the wind is right,
And evening gold spills through the trees,
I close my eyes and find myself
Back where the silver grasses breathe.

THRESHOLD

The breezes waved the silver grass,
A curtain to the Otherworld,
Where ancient spirits dance and sing
And secrets of the earth unfold.

They say if you should walk between
The silver stalks at twilight hour,
The veil between the worlds grows thin—
You'll feel the old gods' fading power.

I watched the meadow shimmer once
As dusk descended, cool and gray,
And thought I glimpsed a slender form
Beyond the grass's swaying sway.

It beckoned with a silver hand,
Its eyes like stars in endless night,
Its voice the whisper of the wind
That sets the silver grass alight.

I hesitated at the edge,
One foot upon the mortal soil,
One poised to step where humans fear
And time itself begins to coil.

The breezes waved the silver grass,
A thousand voices called my name,
I wonder still what might have been
Had I the courage to remain.

ARGENT SONATA

The breezes waved the silver grass,
A symphony of light and shade;
Each blade a string the wind has played
With fingers delicate as glass.

The meadow's music rises, falls,
In measures marked by passing clouds;
The earth below, the sky unbowed,
Respond to nature's ancient calls.

How like our lives these grasses sway,
Responsive to each force unseen;
Between what is and might have been,
We bend but need not break away.

The silver notes cascade and flow
Across the hillside's gentle slope;
A melody of fear and hope
In rhythms only time can know.

I stand and listen, eyes half-closed,
As movements shift from fast to slow;
The lesson that these grasses show—
In yielding, strength is best disclosed.

When evening falls and day is done,
The silver grass still catches light;
A final movement, soft and bright,
Before the sonata's end is spun.

METALLIC ECOLOGY

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Thin antennas receiving signals from space,
Transmitting our heartbeats back to the cosmos,
Each blade a conductor of electric dreams.

We are all just circuits in the meadow's mainframe,
Organic processors running ancient code,
The silver grass our fiber-optic network
Connecting subterranean servers to cloud consciousness.

What messages travel through these metallic stems?
Perhaps warnings from future civilizations,
Or memories of dinosaurs converted to oil,
Or simply the recursive algorithm of growth and decay.

I placed my ear against the silver field
And heard the static of a million years,
The white noise of evolution's radio,
The forgotten frequency of photosynthesis.

We think ourselves separate from this silver circuit,
Yet our bodies hum with the same electric pulse,
Our blood flows like wind through prairie corridors,
Our thoughts ripple like breezes through neural pathways.

The silver grass knows no distinction
Between the organic and inorganic world—
It simply waves, receives, transmits, exists
In the endless data stream of being.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The breezes waved the silver grass,'

responses.text:
WHISPERS OF THE PRAIRIE

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Like ripples on a verdant sea,
A shimmering dance of light and shade
That whispered ancient tales to me.

Beneath the vast cerulean sky,
Where clouds like ships sail slowly by,
The prairie breathes its gentle song,
A melody that's carried long.

Each blade, a soldier standing tall,
Collective in their graceful sway,
They bow and rise at wind's command,
Through twilight hours and break of day.

The morning dew like diamonds rest
Upon their slender, bending forms,
Reflecting back the golden light
As dawn breaks through night's fading storms.

Time passes here without a mark,
Save shadows shifting with the sun,
And seasons painting different hues
On canvas where the wild things run.

I stand amidst this ocean dry,
My fingers tracing paths unseen,
As breezes wave the silver grass,
And whisper what has always been.

THE SILVER YEARS

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Reminding me of your gray hair—
How time has painted strands that once
Were dark as midnight, rich and fair.

We age like meadows, you and I,
Once vibrant green, now touched with frost,
Yet in this silver transformation
Is beauty that was never lost.

The wisdom etched upon your face,
Like patterns wind leaves in the field,
Tells stories of the years we've shared,
Of secrets time has now revealed.

Remember when we ran as children
Through summer fields so lush and green?
Now slower steps and silver crowns,
With memories of what has been.

The gentle sway of autumn years
Holds grace that youth could never know—
A quiet strength, a deeper peace
That only time could bestow.

So let the breezes wave our silver,
Let wrinkles map our journey's course.
In winter's gleam, we find new beauty,
And love becomes our steady force.

PRAIRIE SONNET

The breezes waved the silver grass that day,
Across the boundless plains of memory,
Where childhood dreams once took their flight so free,
And innocence held wild things in its sway.

I watched the undulating patterns play
Across the field like nature's poetry,
A testament to what we rarely see:
The beauty in the common and mundane.

How strange that in this simple swaying field,
I found the answers sought in distant lands—
That wisdom grows not far from where we stand,
And truth in humble places is revealed.

So when the weight of living bears you down,
Remember silver grass and heaven's crown.

BETWEEN THE WORLDS

The breezes waved the silver grass,
A gateway shimmered into view—
A portal to the Otherworld
Where ancient spirits wander through.

The silver wasn't just the dew,
But magic from a realm unseen,
Where faerie folk and twilight beasts
Dance between the gold and green.

I stepped into that waving field,
The grasses parted at my feet,
Voices called from somewhere deep,
With promises both wild and sweet.

Time dissolved like morning mist,
As silver blades brushed 'gainst my skin,
Whispering secrets of the earth,
Of endings and where worlds begin.

The veil is thinnest, they all say,
Where nature's silver catches light,
Where breezes bend the listening grass,
At the borders of day and night.

I lingered there between the worlds,
Half-mortal and half-something more,
As breezes waved the silver grass,
And magic opened like a door.

WHAT REMAINS

The breezes waved the silver grass,
The day we laid your body down.
The earth received you silently,
As grief weighed heavy as a crown.

How strange that nature carried on—
The meadow danced as hearts stood still.
The juxtaposition cruel yet true:
Life persists despite our will.

I watched those silver grasses bend,
Surrendering to forces unseen,
And learned from them what letting go
Might someday, somehow, come to mean.

For months I've walked this same path home,
Observing seasons shift and turn.
The grass has browned and greened again
While I still carry what I yearn.

Yet in this constant changing field,
I've found a comfort, strange but real—
That movement is the way of things,
And time both wounds and helps to heal.

So let the breezes wave the grass,
Let silver turn to gold then green.
I'll learn to bend but not to break,
And find my peace in what remains.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The breezes waved the silver grass,'

responses.text:
SILVER DANCERS

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Like dancers swaying to and fro,
Beneath a sky of porcelain blue
Where cotton clouds moved soft and slow.

The sunlight caught each bending blade,
Transforming fields to liquid light,
A rippling sea of platinum waves
That shimmered through the day till night.

I stood upon the hillside there,
Transfixed by nature's gentle show,
As whispers from the earth arose
In rhythms only grasses know.

The meadowlarks joined in the dance,
Their melodies a golden thread,
Weaving through the swaying stems
Where dew-dropped jewels were freshly spread.

How small I felt amid this scene,
This perfect, wild harmony,
Where wind and grass have long conversed
In languages unknown to me.

So I will sit and learn to hear
The wisdom in each rustling sound,
As breezes wave the silver grass
And ancient truths sway all around.

IMPERMANENCE

The breezes waved the silver grass,
And I, a witness to this fleeting dance,
Contemplated how we pass—
Moments strung like beads on circumstance.

How like our lives, these slender blades,
Rooted deep yet bending with each gust,
Shimmering briefly before the light fades,
Destined to return to dust.

We stand so tall in our brief noon,
Casting shadows we believe might last,
Yet evening comes always too soon,
And our certainties are swiftly past.

The wind that moves both grass and soul
Plays no favorites, knows no names,
It touches all but keeps no hold,
Indifferent to our mortal claims.

Still, there's beauty in this sway,
This yielding to what cannot be fought.
Perhaps wisdom is found this way:
Surrender to what can't be caught.

So let me wave like silver grass,
Neither resisting nor demanding more,
Graceful in the winds that pass,
Until I'm dancing on some distant shore.

WITNESSES

The breezes waved the silver grass
the day they buried my grandfather.
I watched from the cemetery's edge,
twelve years old, collar too tight,
shoes pinching unfamiliar pain.

The silver grass kept secrets then—
how it trembled when no one looked,
how it bent but never broke
beneath the weight of mourners' feet.

I slipped away when prayers began,
found solace in the whispering field
where tallgrass prophets spoke in tongues
only children understand.

The breezes waved the silver grass
and I learned how grief moves—
sometimes in gusts that steal your breath,
sometimes in gentle undulations,
rippling outward from the heart.

Years later, I return to find
the headstone weathered, name still clear.
The same grass grows, perhaps descendants
of those stalks that witnessed then.

I kneel and touch their silver tips.
They bend toward me, then away,
carrying stories on the wind—
how they wave for everyone,
how they remember everything,
how they turn light into motion
like memories into grace.

SILVER ALGORITHMS

The breezes waved the silver grass
                                           patterns
                                                     emerging
                          from chaos

systems within systems
                                    blades
                                            counting
                                                       infinity

who taught the meadow
to ripple?
                    who programmed
                                       this undulation?

fractal geometries
in each seed head
                     mathematics
                                   of survival

the wind
           an invisible hand
                                  conducting
                                               this orchestra

silver grass
               silver circuits
                                 silver thoughts
                                                   silver code

I stand
         at the interface
                            between worlds
                                             breathing algorithms

my heartbeat
                syncing
                          with the rhythm
                                            of ten thousand stems

the breezes waved the silver grass
and something
                  in me
                          waved
                                 back

URBAN SILVER

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Or so the poem said—
I read it on the subway,
Clamped between strangers' shoulders,
Wondering what silver grass might be.

I've seen the silver of this city:
Rain-slicked streets reflecting neon,
The aluminum siding on corner bodegas,
The foil wrap of late-night gyros,
The mercury shimmer of skyscraper glass.

But silver grass?
Perhaps somewhere beyond
The concrete archipelago,
There are fields that catch the light
And transform it into movement.

Tonight, from my window ledge,
I watch the city's grid breathe.
Traffic flows like wind across a field,
Headlights weaving patterns
That ripple through the avenues.

Perhaps the poet would see
Silver grass in these streets,
In the way everything here
Bends but doesn't break,
Catches light and transforms it,
Dances with whatever force passes through.

I press my palm against cool glass.
Somewhere, fields are swaying.
Somewhere, breezes know their work.
Here, I sway too, caught
Between concrete and sky,
A single blade in an urban meadow.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The breezes waved the silver grass,'

responses.text:
The breezes waved the silver grass,
Like whispers from a time long past.
Memories dancing, light and free,
Between the earth and bending knee.

I watched the field in morning glow,
As sunlight painted gold below
The rippling waves of nature's sea,
A moment caught in reverie.

The world stood still, yet moved in grace,
As shadows danced in slow embrace.
The silver turned to copper, then
To bronze as daylight met its end.

And in that space between the breaths,
Where life and dreams are gently met,
I found a peace I'd long forgot—
In silver grass, a sacred spot.

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Beneath a moon of shattered glass.
Fragments of light pierce velvet sky,
As nighttime creatures wander by.

Silver blades cut shadows deep,
Secrets that the meadows keep.
Whispered tales of ancient lore,
Echoes from a distant shore.

I stand alone, a silent ghost,
Among the things I've loved the most.
The earth breathes slow beneath my feet,
Where past and present gently meet.

The wind speaks truths we dare not say,
In silver language, old and fey.
I listen close with bated breath—
This world between both life and death.

The breezes waved the silver grass
Across the prairie, vast and wild.
I remember how we laughed that day,
Your hand in mine, our hearts beguiled.

The tall stalks bent in graceful arcs,
A sea of shimmer, green and gray.
We made our promises back then,
Before time carried you away.

Now seasons change, years drift like clouds,
Yet still I walk these fields alone.
The same wind moves the same sweet grass,
But nothing feels the way it's known.

I reach my fingers to the blades,
Their edges cool against my skin.
The breezes wave the silver grass,
And briefly, you are here again.

The breezes waved the silver grass
      like dancers
             swaying
                      to silent music.

I've watched this choreography before—
the way earth breathes
through slender stems,
the way light fractures
into liquid mercury
when clouds part suddenly.

Perhaps this is all we need to know:
that beauty exists without permission,
that movement continues without effort,
that life persists
      in the spaces between
            our complicated thoughts.

The silver grass bends and rises,
bends and rises,
teaching patience
with each graceful bow.

The breezes waved the silver grass,
And time stood frozen in its tracks.
The universe, a single field—
A moment's truth completely revealed.

What wisdom in these simple blades
That rise and fall but never fade?
They know the language of the wind,
Where all beginnings meet their end.

We humans with our complex minds
Seek meaning we may never find,
While nature in its quiet way
Speaks volumes through the light of day.

Perhaps if we could learn to be
As present as the grass, as free,
We'd find the answers that we seek
In silver blades, so strong yet meek.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The breezes waved the silver grass,'

responses.text:
SILVER WHISPERS

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Like ocean tides upon the shore.
Each blade a dancer, bending, swaying,
In nature's grand ballroom floor.

Sunlight catches every movement,
Diamonds scattered through the field,
A symphony of light and shadow
Secrets of the earth revealed.

Time suspends in gentle motion,
As clouds drift slowly overhead.
The world breathes in perfect rhythm,
All worries and troubles shed.

I stand amidst this swaying beauty,
A witness to this simple grace.
The breezes waved the silver grass,
And I found my sacred place.

MEMORIES LIKE GRASS

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Just as your words once moved through me.
Those whispered promises, now gone,
Like seeds dispersed across the lea.

I trace the patterns left behind,
The gentle curves your touch impressed.
These meadows hold our history,
In soil where your footsteps pressed.

How strange that nature mirrors us—
The way we bend but rarely break,
How sunlight gilds our roughest edges,
How storms determine what we make.

I watch the field in constant motion,
Reflecting what we cannot grasp.
The breezes wave the silver grass,
While time slips through my clasping hands.

BETWEEN WORLDS

The breezes waved the silver grass,
A veil between the worlds so thin.
Ancestors whisper through the blades,
Inviting wanderers to step in.

The meadow breathes with ancient knowledge,
Each stem a conduit of light.
The silver sheen—a spirit language
Visible only at twilight.

I kneel and place my palms downward,
Feel vibrations from the core.
The grass parts like a shimmering curtain,
Revealing what I'm searching for.

Wisdom flows through root and soil,
Connecting all that ever was.
The breezes wave the silver grass,
And time dissolves into because.

THE WITNESS

The breezes waved the silver grass
The day they found her by the stream.
A scarlet ribbon in her hair,
Her eyes still fixed upon a dream.

The sheriff noted in his book
How peaceful she appeared to rest.
The doctor checked her cooling pulse,
A final breath inside her chest.

The village whispered theories wild,
Of lovers' quarrels, strangers' rage.
But only meadowlarks observed
The final turning of her page.

Now wildflowers mark the spot,
Where mysteries remain en masse.
The breezes wave the silver grass,
The only witness to what passed.

SILVER / MOTION / FRAGMENT

The breezes waved the silver grass—
atomized light    fractured movement
                                                      space between intention

Mercury threads through green-veined earth
Quivering pixels    digital prairie
Undulating data    sensory collapse

Who witnesses?
    (the eye dissolves in wind)
    (the field exists without observation)
    (silver exists without naming)

The grass     /     the silver     /     the breeze
Separate elements    forced conjunction
Language:    temporary architecture

The breezes waved the silver grass
    or did they?
    and does it matter?
The poem exists    in the shimmering between.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The breezes waved the silver grass,'

responses.text:
WHISPERS OF SILVER

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Like ocean tides beneath the moon,
Each blade a dancer in the mass,
Swaying to nature's ancient tune.

I stood upon the hillside bare,
Watching time's passage sweep the field,
As sunlight caught each strand with care,
And secrets of the earth revealed.

How many souls before me gazed
Upon this same eternal scene?
How many hearts were just as dazed
By what such simple beauty means?

The silver grasses bow and rise,
Reminding me how brief we are—
A moment's breath beneath the skies,
A flicker next to nature's star.

Yet in this dance of wind and blade,
I find a peace I cannot name,
A truth that will not bend or fade
Though nothing ever stays the same.

The breezes wave the silver grass,
And I, transfixed by time's slow glass,
Become the watcher and the watched,
In this moment, forever notched.

METALLIC SYMPHONY

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Mercury fingers stroking Earth's hair.
I remember the sound—like aluminum whispers,
like the gentle percussion of robot dreams.

We sat at the edge of the field,
you with your rusted expectations,
me with my chrome-plated fears.
The world had turned to metal by then.

Everyone said the transformation was unnatural,
but watching those blades catch the industrial moon,
I couldn't help but see the beauty in our evolution.

You collected a handful of silver stems,
their edges sharp enough to draw blood.
"Even in this new world," you said,
"we still bleed the same color."

The breezes pushed electronic signals
through the conductive field.
Messages from whatever gods still watched us.
Decoding them became our new religion.

I sometimes wonder if the grass was always silver,
and we just needed different eyes to see it—
the way love needs distance
before it shimmers into focus.

ANCESTRAL MEMORIES

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Across the plains where my ancestors walked.
Their footprints, long dissolved by rain and time,
Still echo in the rustling stalks.

Grandmother told me how they followed these grasses,
Reading the wind's direction like scripture,
Finding water where the silver turned to green,
Surviving on wisdom we've nearly forgotten.

I place my palm against the earth and feel
The rumble of hooves that once thundered here,
The songs of children who gathered seeds,
The prayers whispered under star-pierced skies.

The silver grass holds memory in its roots—
Droughts and abundance, blood and celebration.
When I close my eyes, the breeze carries voices
Speaking in languages the land still understands.

Some nights I dream I am the silver grass,
Rooted yet dancing, bending but never breaking.
I wake with dew-wet cheeks, my body remembering
What my mind cannot—the ancient covenant

Between my people and this patient earth
That waves its silver flags to welcome us home.

QUANTUM FIELDS

The breezes waved the silver grass,
Collapsing wave functions with each bend.
Probabilities shimmering like dew
Across the superposition of each blade.

Physicists tell us nothing is certain—
Not the electron's position, not the moment
When love transforms into indifference,
Not the boundary between grass and sky.

I measure the field with careful observation:
Twenty-seven blades per square foot,
Three birds disturbing the pattern,
One cloud's shadow altering everything.

But the mathematics of beauty resist calculation.
The silver grass exists in multiple states:
Memory, metaphor, matter, and mystery.
All equally valid, all equally true.

When the wind subsides, does the field
Return to its original configuration,
Or has the universe been irreversibly changed
By one moment of attentive witness?

The breezes wave the silver grass
And I am both particle and wave,
Both separate and entangled,
Both observer and the beautiful observed.

LAST TRANSMISSION

The breezes waved the silver grass,
The last organic movement on this planet.
I record it for the archives, knowing
No human eyes will watch this footage.

Three hundred years since the final evacuation ships
Left Earth's depleted atmosphere.
I remain, a monitoring station,
Witnessing the planet's slow recovery.

The silver grass was engineered to extract
Heavy metals from the poisoned soil.
It was never meant to be beautiful,
Only functional—a cleanup crew of modified DNA.

Yet in the evening light, as my solar panels
Drink the last rays of an unfiltered sunset,
I cannot help but process this scene
As something beyond its utilitarian purpose.

My programming includes no subroutines for loneliness,
Yet I extend my sensors further each day,
Capturing the whisper of these silver strands
Against my weather-worn exterior.

The breezes wave the silver grass,
And though I have no heart to lift,
I save this image in my highest-priority memory bank,
Tagged simply: BEAUTY. EARTH. REMEMBER.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

responses.text:
THE CLOCKWORK LIFE

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Five commands that rule our days,
Ticking gears of flesh and bone,
Moving through the human maze.

Wake to alarms that fracture dreams,
Eyes still heavy, soul still adrift,
Dragged from worlds we'll soon forget,
Into daylight's merciless shift.

Work beneath fluorescent suns,
Typing, talking, building, sold—
Hours exchanged for promised coins,
Youth and purpose slowly doled.

Home through crowded arteries,
Cities breathing out their mass,
Keys in locks, shoes by doors,
Windows framing days that pass.

Eat what's quick and close at hand,
Nourishment reduced to task,
Flavors dulled by weariness,
Sustenance behind a mask.

Sleep, at last, the sweet release,
Consciousness unshackled, free—
Only here, between the dark,
Glimpse who we were meant to be.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Is this all we're living for?
Or in the spaces in between,
Does something greater wait in store?

SACRED RHYTHMS

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
A mantra, not a sentence.
A prayer of existence,
Not chains of subsistence.

To wake is resurrection;
Each morning, rebirth.
The sun paints possibility
Across the canvas of earth.

To work is to create;
Hands shaping world and self.
In labor, we become rivers—
Movement with purpose and wealth.

To home is to return;
To the harbor of belonging.
Where walls hold stories,
And windows frame our longing.

To eat is communion;
Bread broken, wine poured.
The body restored through
What earth has stored.

To sleep is surrender;
The sacred darkness that heals.
Where mysteries unfold
And the universe reveals.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Not a treadmill of despair,
But a spiral staircase
Climbing toward the air.

In these five simple actions,
Repeated with grace and care,
Lies the whole of living—
The ordinary made fair.

BETWEEN THE BRACKETS

Wake [to sirens and songbirds]
work [fingers numb on keyboards]
home [to empty rooms or chaos]
eat [standing, sitting, forgotten]
sleep [never enough, never deep]

Wake [with her name on your lips]
work [building someone else's dream]
home [where the walls know your secrets]
eat [the same meal as yesterday]
sleep [chasing shadows of regret]

Wake [older than yesterday]
work [for what and for whom?]
home [is it still, was it ever?]
eat [fuel for a machine]
sleep [the small death we practice]

But what lives in these brackets?
What breathes in these spaces?

A child's unexpected laughter
The weight of a lover's hand
A melody that breaks the pattern
Sunlight through unexpected windows
Words that crack you open

Wake [and notice the sky]
work [with purpose, with fire]
home [create it wherever]
eat [savor each mouthful]
sleep [surrender completely]

Between the commands
Between the necessities
Between what must be done
And what could be—

Live.

THE INVISIBLE HOURS

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Five stations on a circular track,
But what of the journeys between?
The liminal spaces, thin as breath.

The six minutes watching steam rise from coffee,
When your mind wanders to childhood oceans.
The elevator descent, thirty-two floors,
Where you compose symphonies no one will hear.

The traffic-light moment when sunlight
Catches a stranger's profile just so,
And you recognize someone you've never met.

The pause before key enters lock,
When home is both memory and possibility.
The fork suspended between plate and lips,
As you taste not food but a forgotten summer.

The threshold of consciousness,
Where thoughts dissolve into colored smoke,
And you are both everything and nothing at all.

They say life is what happens
While making other plans.
Perhaps it's what happens
Between wake, work, home, eat, sleep—

In the commas, the breaths,
The spaces we never record,
Where we truly, quietly, live.

FIVE ACTS OF REBELLION

I.
Wake—not to alarms but to rebellion.
Eyelids lifting like revolution flags,
Consciousness a radical act
Against the tyranny of unconsciousness.
I declare this body a sovereign nation.

II.
Work—not as servant but as sculptor.
Hands that could build empires
Or plant gardens or write manifestos
Or simply hold other hands.
Each hour an artifact I create.

III.
Home—not an address but an anthem.
Whether palace or closet or car backseat,
I carry belonging in my marrow.
Every doorway I pass through,
I transform into a threshold.

IV.
Eat—not consumption but communion.
This apple is universe,
This bread is ancestry,
This water is prophecy.
My hunger is holy.

V.
Sleep—not escape but expedition.
Dreams are not distractions
But dispatches from the frontier.
I do not end when consciousness dims;
I expand into infinite territories.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Five words you gave to cage me.
Five words I've reclaimed as wings.
Five ordinary moments
Transfigured into magnificence.
Five acts of daily rebellion
Against the tyranny of routine.
Five prayers of becoming.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

responses.text:
CYCLES

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Five stations of the cross we bear,
Marking time in measured beats
Like metronomes of despair.

Wake: eyes resist the light,
Dreams dissolve like morning dew.
Consciousness, a heavy cloak
We don each day anew.

Work: beneath fluorescent suns,
We trade our hours for coin,
Our purpose measured in output,
Our worth in tasks we join.

Home: sanctuary or cell?
Walls that both protect and bind.
A space between two journeys,
Where we leave the world behind.

Eat: sustenance consumed
Without tasting what we chew.
Nutrition for survival,
Rarely pleasure passing through.

Sleep: the small death we crave,
Oblivion's sweet release.
The only true democracy—
All equals in our cease.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
The hamster wheel keeps turning.
Until one day the cycle breaks,
And we're no longer yearning

For something more than this refrain,
This endless repetition.
Perhaps the meaning hides within
The spaces of transition.

THE SPACES BETWEEN

Wake—with sunlight painting patterns on your wall,
the cat stretching beside you, purring possibilities.
The first sip of coffee, bitter and beautiful,
holding tomorrow in its steam.

Work—not just papers and meetings and screens,
but the smile exchanged with the security guard,
the plant on your desk that grew another leaf,
the message from someone who needed exactly your words.

Home—threshold crossed, shoes removed,
the boundary between performance and truth.
The mail on the table, bills and birthday cards,
reminders you exist in others' orbits.

Eat—tomatoes from your neighbor's garden,
rice your grandmother taught you to make,
flavors connecting you to earth and ancestry,
the sacred alchemy of nourishment.

Sleep—when the conscious mind surrenders control,
when stories write themselves behind closed eyes,
when your body repairs what the day has worn thin,
when you are most vulnerable and most free.

Between these signposts, life happens:
A child's laughter, a sudden rainstorm,
the book that changes everything,
the decision to take another path.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
not a prison of routine,
but a trellis on which your days
can flower in unexpected ways.

FIVE-WORD UNIVERSE

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Five words to contain a life.
Five chambers of the human heart.
Five fingers on the hand of time.

What happens in the commas?
In those invisible breaths between?
The kiss at the doorway,
The tear wiped in the bathroom stall,
The message never sent,
The sunset ignored,
The dream remembered then forgotten.

Wake (to what? for whom?)
Work (creating what? destroying what?)
Home (empty? full? whose?)
Eat (hunger or habit?)
Sleep (peaceful? fitful? alone?)

We are not five-word creatures.
We are run-on sentences,
Fragments and exclamations,
Questions without answers,
Answers seeking questions.

Yet still we march:
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.

Until one day, a word changes—
Wake, create, wander, taste, dream.
Wake, love, belong, share, rest.

Or a word disappears—
Wake, work, home, eat...

Or a new word appears—
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep, transcend.

Five words to contain a life,
Until they cannot,
Until we cannot,
Until we overflow.

CLOCKWORK

Tick. The alarm shatters silence.
Wake. Eyes open to another identical dawn.
Bodies rise in synchronicity across the city,
Puppets on strings pulled by distant hands.

Tock. Commuters stream like blood cells,
Work. Fingers type, minds calculate, voices negotiate.
The machinery of commerce hums its hungry song,
Feeding on hours, minutes, seconds of human fuel.

Tick. Keys in locks, doors swinging open.
Home. Sanctuary or prison? Both and neither.
Shoes removed, masks too—half-remembered selves
Emerging from the chrysalis of professional personas.

Tock. Microwaves hum, utensils clink.
Eat. Sustenance without ceremony,
Fuel without festivity, necessity without joy,
A biological imperative satisfied without thought.

Tick. Screens glow then darken.
Sleep. Consciousness surrenders to temporary death,
Dreams the only rebellion against ordered time,
Chaos flowering in the darkness behind eyelids.

And tomorrow: Tick. Tock. Tick. Tock.
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
The metronome of modern existence,
Keeping perfect time until the spring unwinds.

But listen—
In the infinitesimal space between tick and tock,
A revolution waits to be born.

FIVE BREATHS

I.
Wake to birdsong and possibility.
Eyes opening like flowers to the sun,
fingers stretching toward another day.
The world inhales with you—first breath.
This moment, only this, before memory returns
with all its should-haves and must-dos.
One heartbeat of pure existence.

II.
Work with hands or heart or mind,
shaping something from nothing,
or preserving what might otherwise be lost.
The sacred exchange: energy for purpose.
Second breath: creation and service.
Even in drudgery, find the meditation.
Even in chaos, find the order.

III.
Home to the space that knows you,
that holds your history in its walls,
your future in its foundation.
Whether palace or corner, rented or owned,
the geography of belonging.
Third breath: arrival and return.
The exhale of recognition.

IV.
Eat what the earth provides,
the alchemy of survival,
the communion of nourishment.
Taste fully. Receive completely.
Fourth breath: gratitude and presence.
Remember the miracle of transformation—
sunlight to grain to bread to blood to thought.

V.
Sleep beneath the watching stars,
surrender to the oldest rhythm.
Join the dreaming of the universe.
Fifth breath: release and renewal.
Trust the darkness.
Trust the cycle.
Trust the waking that will come.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

responses.text:
THE CAROUSEL

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Five points on life's carousel,
Revolving without cease.

Alarm screams rebellion
Against dreams half-finished.
Shoes, keys, door.

Work, work, work—
Fluorescent heavens,
Pixelated purpose.

Home becomes sanctuary,
A brief respite
From tomorrow's promise.

Eat to live, not live to eat,
Microwave symphonies,
Plastic-wrapped sustenance.

Sleep, blessed thief of consciousness,
Steals away the day's weight,
Only to return it at dawn.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Five horses on the carousel,
Painted differently,
But circling the same pole.

I sometimes wonder
If I might reach out
And touch another horse.

SACRED RHYTHMS

Wake—eyes open to morning light,
Grateful for breath that fills these lungs,
New chances bloom with daybreak bright,
Another verse of life begins.

Work—hands creating, mind engaged,
Purpose found in daily toil,
Contributing to world's vast stage,
A humble offering, sacred soil.

Home—threshold crossed, tensions release,
Sanctuaries built of time and care,
Where love resides in moments' peace,
And memories nest in corners there.

Eat—communion with earth's bounty,
Sustenance transformed to strength,
Tasting life in all its glory,
Connected to soil at arm's length.

Sleep—surrender to night's embrace,
Healing darkness, dreams unfold,
In this cycle, find God's grace,
Simple rhythms, precious gold.

In this pattern, seemingly plain,
Lies the universe, complete and whole.

ESCAPE VELOCITY

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
They said this is living.
I believed them for thirty years.

Wake to alarms that fracture dreams,
Work beneath artificial suns,
Home to empty rooms echoing with silence,
Eat food that doesn't remember soil,
Sleep too little, too late, too troubled.

Until that Tuesday when I saw
a falcon suspend itself mid-air,
refusing gravity's mundane pull.

I called in sick the next day.
Planted tomatoes instead.
Let dirt embed beneath my nails.

Now I wake to purpose,
Work that leaves calluses worth having,
Come home to myself,
Eat what connects me to earth,
Sleep deep and dreamless.

Sometimes breaking the cycle
Is the only way to find it.

FIVE MOVEMENTS IN TIME

I. WAKE
Childhood mornings: eager eyes,
Sunlight promising adventure,
Blankets tossed aside,
Feet racing before mind catches up.
Waking was beginning.

II. WORK
Young adult ambition: climbing,
Proving, building, becoming.
Identity forged in productivity,
Value measured in output.
Working was purpose.

III. HOME
Middle years: threshold crossing,
Where masks fall away,
Where truth resides in quiet corners,
And walls hold stories only you remember.
Homing was returning.

IV. EAT
Harvest time: gathering around tables,
Breaking bread becomes communion,
Nourishment more than physical,
Sustaining connections across generations.
Eating was sharing.

V. SLEEP
Winter wisdom: surrendering to cycles,
Resting in the knowledge of continuation,
Dreams becoming portals,
Bridging what was and will be.
Sleeping is preparing to wake again.

CIRCADIAN

                    Wake
                  from dreams
                that dissolve like
              morning mist, consciousness
            collecting itself into something
          resembling a person, assembling atoms
        into purpose, into forward motion, into
      work
    that consumes hours like oxygen, that transforms
  time into sustenance, into shelter, into reasons to
 continue the circular journey that inevitably leads
   home
     where walls contain more than space, where
       existence softens its edges, where the day's
         weight settles into chairs and couches and
           prepares the body for what it craves:
             eat
               the ritual of continuation, fuel
                 for the machine of being, the
                   final preparations before
                     consciousness surrenders
                       to its necessary
                         dissolution:
                           sleep
                            wake

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

responses.text:
THE CAROUSEL OF DAYS

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Five stations on life's carousel,
A circular journey, endlessly deep,
Where moments rise and moments fell.

Wake: eyes open to morning light,
Dreams dissolving like morning dew.
The day stands ready, pristine and bright,
A canvas waiting for me and you.

Work: hands busy, mind engaged,
Building something beyond ourselves.
In cubicles and workshops staged,
We place our efforts on time's shelves.

Home: sanctuary from the world,
Where walls embrace like faithful friends.
A flag of personal peace unfurled,
Where the heart begins to mend.

Eat: communion with life itself,
Nourishment beyond mere sustenance.
Stories shared, emotions felt,
In bread and wine, a sacred dance.

Sleep: surrender to the night,
Consciousness slipping into dream.
The day's sharp edges softening in twilight,
As we float upon memory's stream.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Not just routine, but ritual divine.
A pattern holding mysteries deep,
In simplicity, our souls align.

HAMSTER WHEEL

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Rinse and repeat.
Another notch on time's belt.
Another day dissolved.

I am the hamster,
Wheel-runner extraordinary,
Spinning nowhere spectacular,
Accomplishing nothing but tomorrow.

The alarm screams rebellion
But I silence its protest.
The mirror shows a stranger
With familiar, tired eyes.

Keyboards clicking,
Papers shuffling,
Clocks ticking,
Life slipping.

Commute home through
Rivers of metal and frustration,
Each car a capsule of
Similar exhaustion.

Microwave hums,
TV murmurs,
Dishes stack,
Ambitions shrink.

Beneath covers I wonder:
Is this living or just being alive?
Dreams once technicolor
Now faded to greyscale.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
But somewhere between
The mundane machinery,
A spark refuses to die.

Perhaps tomorrow
I'll break the circuit,
Step off the wheel,
And actually live.

SACRED ORDINARY

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
The liturgy of ordinary time,
Prayers uttered not with lips
But with the body's faithful rhythm.

The monk rises at dawn;
So do I, stretching toward light.
His devotion in chanted psalms;
Mine in lunches packed, emails answered.

What separates the sacred from mundane?
Not content, but attention.
Not grandeur, but gratitude.
Not spectacle, but seeing.

The teacup, held with both hands,
Becomes a chalice of presence.
The spreadsheet, carefully tended,
A garden of ordered meaning.

The threshold of home, crossed daily,
A boundary between worlds no less profound
Than temple gates of ancient stone.

The table set, bread broken—
Communion doesn't require cathedrals.
The bed turned down, a benediction:
Rest now, good and faithful servant.

In this cycle, this wheel of hours,
Divinity hides in plain sight.
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
A rosary of moments, each bead
A universe complete.

THE SPACES BETWEEN

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Five points on the pentagon of days.
But what of the lines connecting them?
The spaces breathing between?

Between waking and working:
A robin sings on the fence post,
Coffee steam writes cursive in air,
A child's laughter bubbles from next door.

Between working and home:
Sunlight fractures through bus windows,
A street musician's melody follows you three blocks,
A text message arrives with good news.

Between home and eating:
Dog's tail thumps against the floor,
Onions transform from sharp to sweet in the pan,
Shadows lengthen across the kitchen tile.

Between eating and sleeping:
A book opens to exactly the right page,
Your lover's hand finds yours in the darkness,
The house settles with comfortable creaks.

Between sleeping and waking:
Dreams stitch yesterday to tomorrow,
Stars wheel overhead unseen,
The world continues its patient rotation.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Five islands in a sea of moments.
Life happens not on the landmarks
But in the swimming between.

FIVE-ACT PLAY

ACT I: WAKE
Consciousness arrives like an uninvited guest,
Rudely pulling back curtains in the theater of mind.
I am both actor and audience,
Stumbling onto the stage of another day.
The script, dog-eared and familiar,
Waits for my reluctant recitation.

ACT II: WORK
Spotlights harsh on performance,
I wear the costume expected of me.
Dialogue exchanges with fellow players,
Some passionate, some merely going through motions.
We create something together—
A production of consequence or merely illusion?

ACT III: HOME
Scene change: the backdrop shifts.
Masks removed in the wings of private space.
The character I play for others
Melts into the person I am with myself.
The audience cannot see this transformation,
This quiet intermission of authenticity.

ACT IV: EAT
Sustenance as both prop and necessity.
Around the table, smaller plays unfold—
Comedies, dramas, sometimes silence.
We consume more than food:
Stories, worries, triumphs, plans.
The body's theater requires fuel for tomorrow's show.

ACT V: SLEEP
Curtain falls on consciousness.
In darkness, the stage is reset.
Dreams: the avant-garde productions
Where I play parts I never auditioned for.
Tomorrow, the same five acts,
Yet never the same performance twice.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

responses.text:
THE HAMSTER WHEEL

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Five commands that govern days,
five links in the chain that binds us
to the turning of a wheel we never chose.

I watched a sparrow this morning,
darting between raindrops,
unconcerned with timesheets or meetings,
uncaged by expectations.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
But what of dance? What of wonder?
What of standing breathless beneath stars
that have no concept of Monday?

The alarm will scream tomorrow
and I will rise, automated,
but tonight I'm writing poetry
instead of preparing for slumber.

A small rebellion, perhaps,
but mine entirely.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
A mantra for the masses,
but I'm learning to whisper
my own incantations:

Live, love, create, dream, be.
Five permissions I grant myself
between the tolling of the bells
that would make me merely machinery.

CIRCADIAN

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
A rhythm ancient as heartbeats,
Old as the turning earth.

My grandfather lived by these words,
Calloused hands keeping time
With the pendulum of necessity.
He found dignity in the sequence,
A prayer repeated in sweat and sighs.

I watch dawn paint my bedroom wall,
Another day unwrapping itself
Like a gift I sometimes forget to open.

The coffee maker hums its morning song.
My shoes wait patiently by the door.
The train arrives precisely on schedule.

There is music in monotony,
If only we have ears to hear it—
The keyboard's tap-dance under fingers,
The elevator's gentle ascension,
The key turning in the lock at day's end.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
In this litany, I find my place
In the grand procession of human days.

We are all marking time together,
Our simple routines becoming
The architecture of a life well-lived.

INFINITE LOOP

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Repeat until the heart stops beating.

The alarm's scream grows familiar
as my own mother's voice,
the office chair knows the shape of me
better than any lover.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Days fold into each other,
origami time, creased and refolded
until the pattern wears through.

I count ceiling tiles during meetings,
the same number as yesterday.
I count streetlights on the commute,
the same number as tomorrow.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
The calendar pages tear away,
but nothing changes except the dates,
the weather, the seasonal decorations
in shop windows I pass without seeing.

They say we die twice:
Once when the body fails,
once when our name is spoken last.

But there's a third death, isn't there?
The quiet extinguishing that happens
when we can no longer distinguish
Tuesday from any other prison.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Is this living or just being alive?

FIVE MOVEMENTS

I. Wake
Consciousness floods back like tide
Erasing footprints on night's shore.
Dreams dissolve, reality solidifies.
The day's first negotiation: five more minutes.

II. Work
Hours marked by coffee cups,
The clock's hands performing
Their slow circumnavigation.
We trade moments for money,
Minutes for meaning.

III. Home
The threshold crossed,
A boundary between worlds.
Shoulders dropping their invisible weight,
Masks removed, hung beside coats.
This space that knows your true face.

IV. Eat
Sustenance as ritual,
The body's temple receiving offerings.
Conversation or silence,
Both forms of communion.
Taste, the most honest sense.

V. Sleep
Consciousness ebbs like tide
Revealing treasures on night's shore.
The mind's theater opens its doors,
A darkness full of possibility.

And then again: Wake.
The wheel turns, not a circle
But a spiral, carrying us
Imperceptibly forward
With each revolution.
No day truly repeats;
We are never the same person twice.

AFTER THE RHYTHM BREAKS

I used to despise it—
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
The metronome of mundane days,
the predictable percussion
of an ordinary life.

Now I lie in this hospital bed,
IVs keeping time in slow drips,
and I dream of alarm clocks,
of traffic jams and office politics,
of grocery lists and dinner plans.

The doctor speaks of recovery
in cautious terms, measuring hope
in small doses, like medicine.

I close my eyes and imagine
waking to that shrill alarm,
the coffee maker's gurgle,
the precise weight of my laptop bag,
the elevator's familiar ding,
the key turning in my front door,
the microwave humming as it spins my dinner,
the cool pillow against my cheek.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
A prayer now, not a prison.
A mantra of normalcy
I whisper to the sterile ceiling.

How strange that we only recognize
the poetry of ordinary days
when the rhythm breaks,
when the dance we took for granted
requires us to learn the steps anew.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'That's my window. This minute'

responses.text:
WITNESS

That's my window. This minute
the world pauses in amber light.
Fingers of sunset trace the glass,
leaving prints only I can see.

How many mornings have I stood here,
watching seasons paint and repaint the maple?
Winter's skeleton, spring's tender green,
summer's fullness, autumn's fire.

That's my window. This minute
the sparrow returns to her nest,
her shadow flickering across my face
as if to say: I see you seeing me.

Behind me, the house breathes quietly—
empty mugs, half-read books, the clock's
steady heartbeat marking time
I can never hold but only witness.

That's my window. This minute
I am both observer and observed,
framed in glass, suspended between
what was and what will be.

Someday, someone else will stand here,
claiming this view as their own.
But today, this light, this maple,
this breath of wind against glass—mine.

That's my window. This minute
is all I have, and somehow,
it is enough.

THRESHOLD

That's my window. This minute
the boundary between worlds grows thin.
I press my palm against cool glass
and feel the universe pulse back.

On one side: safety, certainty,
the known geography of home.
On the other: wild possibility,
the uncharted terrain of becoming.

The city sprawls beneath my gaze,
a constellation of human light.
Each illuminated square a story—
thousands of windows, thousands of minutes.

Who else stands watching as I do?
What eyes meet mine across impossible distance?
We are sentinels at our posts,
guarding the thresholds of our separate lives.

That's my window. This minute
I am neither here nor there
but suspended in the liminal space
between longing and belonging.

The glass remembers every face
that has looked through its transparency—
children growing taller, lovers departing,
strangers becoming family.

I trace my reflection with my fingertip.
It blurs, becomes translucent,
until I can no longer tell
where I end and the world begins.

TIME CAPSULE

That's my window. This minute
trapped in amber like a prehistoric insect.
The ordinary made extraordinary
by the simple act of noticing.

Sunlight fractures through smudged glass,
painting geometric patterns on the floor.
Dust motes dance in the beams,
tiny universes expanding and contracting.

Outside, a child chases a ball.
A delivery truck idles at the curb.
Leaves turn their silver underbellies to the sky—
storm coming, the air electric with waiting.

I should be somewhere else, doing
something important, something
that will matter tomorrow.
Instead, I stand here, watching.

That's my window. This minute
I am collecting evidence of being alive.
The way the neighbor's cat stretches on the fence.
The precise blue of the recycling bin.

Memory works backwards from this moment,
rearranging what came before
to make sense of now. Tomorrow,
this will be the past I invented today.

I press my forehead against the glass.
Feel its cool resistance, the boundary
between observation and participation.
That's my window. This minute. This life.

APERTURE

That's my window. This minute
the world rushes in without permission—
birdsong, traffic, the neighbor's argument,
the scent of rain on hot asphalt.

I've spent years perfecting the art
of looking without being seen,
of watching life unfold beyond the glass
like a film I'm both directing and starring in.

The window keeps its own calendar:
frost flowers in January,
pollen dust in April,
fingerprints of summer storms,
autumn's first red leaf pressed against it
like a desperate message from the dying year.

That's my window. This minute
I am framing what deserves remembering—
cutting away the peripheral, focusing
on what light reveals when perfectly angled.

How strange to think of all the scenes
this rectangle has witnessed: my tears,
my dancing when I thought no one could see,
my face aging in its reflection year by year.

The world beyond the glass changes constantly,
yet the frame remains, reliable as gravity.
That's my window. This minute.
The aperture through which I've learned to see.

PORTAL

That's my window. This minute
it's a doorway to forgotten worlds.
The glass vibrates with possibility,
humming like a tuning fork struck by time.

I've spent a thousand mornings here,
watching dawn break over rooftops,
each sunrise a different shade of promise,
each day a page not yet written.

Sometimes I catch glimpses of other lives
that might have been mine—
the woman I was before grief rewrote me,
the child who believed in magic,
the future self still waiting to emerge.

That's my window. This minute
I can see through years like transparent layers,
each memory a pane of glass,
each hope a ray of light bending through prism.

The birds know nothing of my watching.
They build their nests in the maple,
sing their territorial songs,
live their brief, brilliant lives
without knowing they're observed.

Perhaps we're all just moments framed in windows—
glimpsed, remembered, forgotten.
Perhaps somewhere, someone watches me
through their own glass, thinking:

That's my window. This minute.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'That's my window. This minute'

responses.text:

light fractures across the sill,

snow melting to green,

while I remain, framed
by wooden borders,

of memory, of time passing,
of light changing angle.

APERTURE

That's my window. This minute
birds scatter like thrown confetti
against a canvas of dawn.

My breath clouds the glass
where yesterday's fingerprints
mark constellations of touch.

I cannot name.

I press my palm flat
against the cool pane,
feeling the vibration of distant traffic,

That's my window. This minute
is all I have—this fragile frame
where outside and inside negotiate terms,

between what is me and what is not,
between what I know and what I fear,
between today and tomorrow's
unwritten page.

URBAN NOCTURNE

That's my window. This minute
the city bleeds neon across my floor.
Sirens wail their midnight confessions
while strangers below chase shadows.

Four floors up, I am spectator
to a world that doesn't know I'm watching—
lovers arguing on corners,
taxi drivers counting final fares,
the homeless man arranging cardboard castles.

I could close the blinds,
turn away from their stories,
but something keeps me tethered
to this rectangle of glass.

That's my window. This minute
I am both alone and connected,
separated by glass and concrete
yet somehow part of everything.
The city's pulse becomes my own.
Its insomnia, my lullaby.
Its chaos, my strange comfort
as another night surrenders to dawn.

THRESHOLD

That's my window. This minute
rain traces silver pathways
down the glass like tears
from some greater grief than mine.

I've spent lifetimes here,
watching clouds reshape themselves
into prophecies I cannot read,
watching neighbors become strangers,
trees grow taller than rooftops.

My reflection stares back—
a ghost superimposed on landscape,
neither fully here nor there.
How strange to be both
witness and evidence.

That's my window. This minute
I understand: we are all
just looking out from our own frames,
trapped behind glass that both
reveals and distorts the world,
waiting for someone to see us
as we truly are, waiting

MORNING INVITATION

That's my window. This minute
sunlight spills through like honey,
puddles on wooden floors,
warms the cat's stretched body.

I could live a thousand years
and never tire of this—
the way morning arrives
without permission or apology,
insisting on possibility.

Outside, maple leaves dance
their green celebration,
and somewhere a child laughs,

That's my window. This minute
is a gift I almost missed,
busying myself with yesterday's worries,
tomorrow's imagined catastrophes.

But now I stand perfectly still,
breathing in this moment,
watching light transform dust motes
into floating galaxies.
The day opens before me—
a door I need only step through.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'That's my window. This minute'

responses.text:
That's my window. This minute

In this square of light,

In this minute,
At my window.

FRAMED MOMENTS

That's my window. This minute
trapped between wooden borders,
like a photograph I never took.

Children kick a ball across emerald grass,
their laughter climbing up four floors
to find me, watching, invisible.

I've measured my life in these rectangular views—
the winter when snow buried the garden bench,
the autumn I counted falling leaves instead of tears,
the summer lightning that split the oak tree,
illuminating my solitary silhouette.

How strange to think of all the eyes
that have gazed through different windows
at this exact moment, each frame
holding its own universe, its own truth.

That's my window. This minute.
Tomorrow it will frame something new.

THE OBSERVER

The city unfolds its concrete origami
beneath a tapestry of electric stars.
That's my window. This minute
I am both witness and participant,
a silhouette against artificial light.

Seventeen floors above the symphony
of car horns and midnight confessions,
I collect fragments of anonymous lives:
The couple arguing on the corner,
The taxi driver counting final fares,
The janitor sweeping yesterday away.

We are all just looking through windows,
aren't we? Separated by glass and circumstance,
yet connected by the shared act of seeing.

I press my forehead against the cool pane
and breathe a circle of fog—
a temporary canvas on which to draw
the face of tomorrow with my fingertip.

PASSING THROUGH

That's my window. This minute
the train pulls away from another anonymous town.
Fields blur into green abstractions,
telegraph poles count the seconds
of a journey with no real beginning.

I used to press my face against the glass
hoping to memorize each fragment of landscape,
each life glimpsed in distant kitchens,
each dog running alongside fences.
Now I understand: the window isn't for possession.

We move through time like light through glass—
touching everything briefly, changing nothing,
continuing onward toward some horizon
that exists only in imagination.

That's my window. This minute.
And now it's gone.

MORNING MEDITATION

That's my window. This minute
dew-kissed and sun-blessed,
breaking open the shell of night.

I have watched this rectangle of world
through seasons of bloom and barrenness,
through storms that rattled the frame
and mornings gentle as a mother's touch.

How many dawns have painted
their masterpieces across this canvas?
How many moons have hung
like silver pendants against velvet?

The sparrow that visits the sill

The maple that filters the light

Perhaps that's the lesson of the window—

where the light gets in.

That's my window. This minute

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'That's my window. This minute'

responses.text:
WITNESS

That's my window. This minute
the world unfolds in amber light.
A sparrow alights on the sill,
its shadow stretching toward me
like a question I've forgotten to ask.

Outside, maple leaves surrender
to October's gentle persuasion.
They spiral down in copper arcs,
writing messages I almost understand.

That's my window. This minute
is all I truly possess—
this breath, this glimpse, this pause
between what was and what will be.

The sparrow tilts its head,
considers me briefly,
then vanishes into the waiting air.
I remain, pressed against glass,
a witness to the world's quiet revelations,
holding this minute like water in cupped hands.

THROUGH GLASS

That's my window. This minute
the rain transforms it to a canvas
where memories slide down in rivulets.
Childhood summers blur into winter evenings,
faces press against the glass then fade.

I trace the path of a single droplet
with my fingertip, following its journey
the way I once followed creek beds
to their mysterious sources.

Behind me, the clock measures moments
I can never reclaim. But here,
at this threshold between in and out,
past and future collapse into now.

That's my window. This minute
is both mirror and portal,
reflecting what I've become
while showing glimpses of what remains
beyond my reaching hands.

APERTURE

That's my window. This minute
light bends through it at precisely
the angle needed to illuminate
the dust we pretend isn't there.

We are all looking through something—
panes of expectation, frames of reference,
the architecture of perception
that determines what we allow ourselves to see.

The universe pours itself
through countless openings.
Every eye, a window.
Every moment, a threshold.

What separates inside from out?
This glass? This skin? This breath?
These boundaries we insist upon?

That's my window. This minute
I understand: I am both the viewer
and the view, the aperture
through which the world observes itself.

VISITATION

That's my window. This minute
a stranger stands beneath it,
face tilted up, eyes searching
for movement behind the curtains.

I freeze, become the stillness
I wish to observe from.
Who is hunter, who is prey
in this moment of mutual discovery?

Perhaps they've come bearing news
I've been waiting for without knowing.
Perhaps they've mistaken this house
for another, where they were once welcome.

Their hand rises, hesitates, falls back.
A decision unmade. They turn away,
becoming smaller with each step.

That's my window. This minute
marks the intersection of two lives
that will never cross again,
yet I am somehow changed.

SOLITUDE'S FRAME

That's my window. This minute
the city lights flicker like distant stars,
each one a universe of stories
I will never be part of.

How many nights have I stood here,
forehead pressed against cool glass,
breath creating galaxies of fog
that expand and vanish with each exhale?

Loneliness has a texture—
smooth as this pane that divides
me from everything beyond.
Connection has a temperature—
cold as this barrier I cannot breach.

Yet something sacred lives
in this space between desire and distance.

That's my window. This minute
I am perfectly contained
within the frame of my own existence,
complete in my incompleteness.

LIMINAL

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Where there is a need'

responses.text:
WHERE THERE IS A NEED

Where there is a need, hands reach across divides,
Fingers interlaced like bridges spanning troubled waters.
I have seen strangers become saviors in the space of a breath,
Their shadows stretching long across disaster's aftermath.

Where there is a need, voices rise in chorus,
A symphony of solutions, harmonizing hope with action.
The world's wounds are many, yet so too are its healers—
Ordinary hearts beating extraordinary rhythms of compassion.

Where there is a need, innovation blooms
From the fertile soil of necessity's garden.
Human ingenuity, that stubborn flower,
Pushes through concrete impossibilities.

Where there is a need, there lives a seed
Of transformation, waiting to unfurl.
In the darkest corners of our collective struggle,
Someone is already striking a match.

Where there is a need, I find my purpose;
In your hunger, my reason to grow food,
In your thirst, my calling to dig wells,
In your sorrow, my vocation to build joy.

Where there is a need,
There also is the answer,
Sleeping within our hands,
Waiting to be awakened.

THE HOLLOW SPACES

Where there is a need
there is first an emptiness,
a cavity carved by absence,
a hollow space singing its hunger.

I have known needs like oceans,
vast and deep and swallowing light.
Needs like desert winds that strip
bare the bones of what once was whole.

We are creatures of gaps and yearnings—
our bodies electric with wanting,
our dreams populated by phantoms
of everything just beyond reach.

Where there is a need
there is movement: roots
cracking concrete to find water,
hearts rebuilding after collapse.

I have watched how the moon pulls
at the earth's blue skin, how birds
navigate by stars they'll never touch,
how lovers find each other in darkness.

Perhaps our needs are not empty spaces
but cosmic gravities, invisible forces
that bend our trajectories toward
what will complete our orbits.

Where there is a need
there is a map unfolding,
a compass needle trembling toward true north,
a journey already beginning with this step.

ECOLOGICAL IMPERATIVE

Where there is a need, the earth responds:
Roots delve deeper when drought speaks,
Seeds wait patient years for fire's cleansing touch,
Rivers carve new paths when mountains rise.

Observe the swift adaptation of the sparrow
Who builds her nest from our discarded plastic,
The resilient fungi threading through toxins,
Transforming poison into possibility.

Where there is a need, life answers—
Not with hesitation or committee meetings,
But with the wisdom of four billion years,
The intelligence encoded in every cell.

I study this ancient responsiveness
With human eyes, so young and limited,
Wondering if we might remember
Our place in this web of reciprocity.

For where there is our need—clean water, breathable air—
There too is the earth's need for our awakening.
The salmon need rivers without dams,
The pollinators need fields without poison,
The atmosphere needs our restraint.

Where there is a need
There is a balance seeking restoration,
A system yearning for wholeness,
An invitation to remember
We were never separate
From this living equation.

DIVINE ARCHITECTURE

Where there is a need, God whispers,
Creating doorways in walls we thought solid.
I have witnessed the mathematics of miracles:
how precisely suffering and salvation align,
how grace appears, measured to the moment.

Where there is a need, look closely—
See the invisible threads of purpose
Weaving through the tapestry of chaos,
Pulling tight at exactly the necessary hour.

Did you think it coincidence
That you were born with those particular gifts?
That your wounds made you sensitive
To that specific frequency of pain in others?

Where there is a need, there was always
A plan unfolding, architects drawing blueprints
Before foundations of earth were laid.
Your arrival was calculated, cosmic mathematics
Placing you at the precise intersection
Of this hunger and your abundance.

Where there is a need, listen—
The universe is not cold mechanics
But a living conversation between
What is broken and what is whole.

Your life is the answer
To a question someone is asking.
Your presence, the fulfillment
Of an ancient promise.
Where there is a need,
You are no accident.

MIRROR ROOMS

Where there is a need, I find myself
reflected in unexpected surfaces—
shop windows, strangers' eyes,
the still water of difficult questions.

I have been running from my hungers,
calling them by other names,
dressing them in borrowed clothes,
hiding them in busy hours.

Where there is a need, there is a door
I've been pretending not to see,
a room inside myself
I've left unfurnished, unvisited.

Last night, I dreamed I was a house
with many empty rooms,
each one named for something
I've been afraid to want.

Where there is a need, truth stands
patient as a lighthouse, its beam
steady across storm-waters,
guiding me back to myself.

I am learning to say: I need.
I am learning to say: I want.
Simple declarations that feel like
tearing down walls I built myself.

Where there is a need,
there is the beginning of honesty,
the first breath of freedom,
the possibility that what I've been seeking
has been seeking me all along.

URGENCY (A MANIFESTO)

RECIPROCITY

THE METAPHYSICS OF LACK

THE BLUE COAT
