I cannot see but know exists—
much like my faith in our connection.

So I walk these paths alone but never lonely,
carrying your constellation in my chest,
navigating by the fixed point of certainty
that somewhere, you too walk under this vast sky,
thinking of me, completing the circuit
of our cosmic dance.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
ECHOES OF THE BARD

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Whose calloused hands told stories true,
Of Scottish hills and heather tough,
Of lives the gentle never knew.

The poet's words, like whisky warm,
Flowed through the tavern's smoky air.
Outside, the night embraced the storm,
Inside, his voice dismissed despair.

'These common souls,' my father said,
'Are Burns' own blood and beating heart.'
His finger tapped the page well-read,
Where simple words transcended art.

Now when I walk on foreign ground,
I hear those men—their distant sound.

ROUGH DIAMONDS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their edges sharp as winter stones.
The world had deemed them not enough,
Yet Burns had sanctified their bones.

I've seen such men in mining towns,
In factories and fishing boats,
Wearing their labor like their crowns,
Poetry stuck in their throats.

What makes a voice worth listening to?
What gives some words their lasting power?
It's truth that cuts both clean and true,
Like wildflowers that need not flower.

So let me praise the unrefined,
Whose honest grit outshines the rest.
In roughness, Burns helped us to find
The rawest beauty, heaven-blessed.

THE PROFESSOR'S LECTURE

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough—
Our tweed-clad professor, voice gentle as rain,
Discussing the bard who knew well enough
That elegance hides in the simplest refrain.

The classroom grew quiet. Outside, autumn leaves
Danced patterns that Burns might have captured in verse.
How strange that such softness so deeply perceives
The beauty in hardness, for better or worse.

I watched as he quoted from dog-eared pages,
His fingers trembling with reverent care.
This man who had studied the greatest sages
Seemed humbled by Burns' unpretentious air.

And I, young and proud of my polished words,
Learned more in that moment than all I had known:
True wisdom speaks plainly, like songs of wild birds,
And greatness is found in the seeds roughly sown.

TAVERN GHOSTS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
As whisky glasses clinked like bells.
The tavern walls had heard enough
Of ancient tales that no one tells.

The ghost of Burns sat in our midst,
A phantom smile upon his face,
Watching as modern worries kissed
The timeless truths of his embrace.

'These men,' the stranger softly said,
'Who work the earth with bleeding hands,
Whose bodies ache for home and bed,
Are poets few can understand.'

The night grew thin. We drank our fill.
The stranger vanished with the dawn.
But something lingers with me still—
A rougher truth to carry on.

ACROSS CENTURIES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
My grandfather, his accent thick
With Scottish hills and valleys tough,
Where time moves slow and memories stick.

I, child of glass and digital light,
Sat listening, puzzled by his words.
How could such roughness bring delight?
How could such rudeness feed the birds

Of poetry that soar so high?
Yet in my life of polished screens,
I've come to hear the honest cry
Of what my grandfather still means.

For Burns saw beauty in the soil,
In hands that knew both love and toil,
In hearts unburdened by the coil
Of pretense that our truths can spoil.

Now when I read those verses old,
I hear my grandfather again.
Some stories never grow too cold—
Some roughness makes the gentlest pen.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
ROUGH DIAMONDS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Whose hands bore calluses like medals,
Whose speech lacked polish, yet held truth enough
To shame the scholars in their settled saddles.

Beneath the grime of coal and sweat and toil,
These souls possessed a wisdom pure as rain.
They knew the language of the Scottish soil
And sang its songs through pleasure and through pain.

The tavern walls absorbed their lusty tales,
Their laughter rough as bark, as warm as peat.
While gentlemen might scoff at such details,
The poet found their humanness complete.

For Burns saw glory in the common face,
And in their roughness, touched divinest grace.

THE SPEAKER'S REVERENCE

In firelight, pipe smoke curling toward rafters,
he spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
voices like gravel roads, hands weathered
by lifetimes of resistance against earth.

I watched his eyes grow distant, reverent,
as if those men stood ghostly in our midst,
their ploughshares and their whisky glasses raised
in toast to words that gave them dignity.

"These were my father's people," he whispered,
"who found themselves in verses others scorned."
His fingers traced invisible lines in air,
quoting fragments memory preserved.

Outside, winter pressed against our windows.
Inside, Scotland bloomed in every syllable,
a thistle-sharp reminder that beauty
sometimes wears the roughest clothes of all.

HONEST MEN

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough—
I've known such men myself.
Their language stark as highland crags,
Their hearts deep as lochs.

They've no time for pretense,
These miners, farmers, fishermen,
Who face mortality in daily labor,
Who laugh at death but weep at beauty.

My grandfather was such a man.
Coal dust embedded in his fingerprints,
The Ayrshire poems memorized complete,
Recited over pints when sorrow struck.

What aristocrat could understand
The revolution in those peasant words?
The dignity bestowed on simple folk
Who, before Burns, were scenery, not souls.

So let me speak of them: men rude and rough,
Whose honesty outshines our polished age.

BURNS' TESTAMENT

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
And I, in silk and linen dressed,
Felt sudden shame for all my stuff—
My curated life, my padded nest.

These men with dirt beneath their nails
Knew truths I'd spent my life evading:
That death makes equals, never fails
To strip away our masquerading.

The poet saw through class and station,
Found music in the coarsest speech,
And built from it a lasting nation
Of verse that time cannot impeach.

Perhaps in roughness lies the seed
Of authenticity—our deepest need.

So let me learn from those uncouth,
Unpolished souls whose words ring true.
In roughness lies the sharpest truth;
In Burns' men, our best selves breakthrough.

THE NEW BURNS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough—
I wonder what the bard would make
of today's forgotten: warehouse workers,
Uber drivers, nurses on their third shift,
their bodies bent beneath invisible loads.

Would he recognize their modern tongues?
The factory worker's TikTok poetry,
the immigrant's song mixed in two languages,
the single mother's lullaby that doubles
as a prayer for rent money?

The roughness wears new clothes now:
tattoos instead of coal dust,
food bank lines instead of peat bogs,
but still these hands create and suffer,
still these voices speak uncomfortable truths.

The academics analyze Burns in sterile rooms
while outside their windows, new verses form
in the mouths of those rude and rough,
waiting for someone to finally listen,
as Burns once did, with revolutionary ears.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
THE BARD'S DEFENDERS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Whose calloused hands held tender hearts,
Who found in verse what words could not—
The dignity that life imparts.

Beneath the grime of honest toil,
They recognized their soul's reflection.
In Burns they found a sacred voice
That gave their silence resurrection.

No scholars they, with learned tongues,
But wisdom earned through sweat and strain.
They clutched his poems like precious things
That made their hardships not in vain.

For Burns had walked their muddy paths
And knew the weight of thankless days,
Yet found the grace in common things
And set the human heart ablaze.

So when they speak his name aloud,
These men, deemed coarse by gentler folk,
They stand as tall as any lord—
Proud guardians of the flames he stoked.

FORGE TALES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their faces mapped with soot and scars,
Eyes bright as molten metal pools
Reflecting distant, dying stars.

They danced with danger, courted flame,
Their laughter harsh as grinding steel.
Their stories etched in furnace light
Reveal what shadows would conceal.

I've seen them walk through hellish heat,
Their silhouettes like ancient gods.
Their bodies bent but spirits straight,
Defying nature's cruel odds.

My father was among their ranks—
A man whose touch could crack like thunder,
Yet gentle when he spoke of home,
His voice would tear the night asunder.

These men who carried fire and pain,
Whose legends scorch the common tongue,
Still haunt the corners of my dreams
Where memory and myth are hung.

THE SCHOLAR'S REVELATION

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough.
I smiled, dismissive, ivy-trained,
Assuming depth beyond their reach—
My education had me chained.

But then he opened weathered books
With margins filled in working script,
Where plowmen, miners, factory hands
Had found what academics missed.

They'd underlined the rebel words
That challenged lords and mocked the crown.
They'd circled verses speaking truth
Of how the mighty crush the down.

These men, unschooled in formal ways,
Had grasped what Burns had truly meant:
That worth lies not in birth or gold
But in the soul's fierce testament.

Now humbled by their deeper sight,
I stand corrected in my view.
These rough-hewn hands held poetry
More honestly than scholars do.

HIDDEN FLAMES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Whose wounds ran deeper than the eye could see.
Not physical, these burns that marked their souls—
Invisible to those who would not flee
The comfort of assumptions, quick-made judgments
Cast on those whose manners seemed uncouth.

These men, they carried fire within their chests
That scorched them from the inside, yet gave heat
To frozen nights when hope had long since fled.
Their roughness was a shield, a styled deceit
To guard the tender embers of their dreams
From those who'd snuff them out with careless breath.

I've walked among them, seen their eyes alight
With passions scholars seldom understand—
The hunger of a heart that's known true loss,
The thirst for justice in an unjust land.
Their burns, these scars of living unrestrained,
Marked not their failure, but their will to stand.

ECHOES FROM THE TAVERN WALL

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Gathered 'round the tavern fire,
Voices raw from whisky and from truth,
Reciting lines that set their souls afire.

Not scholars they, but keepers of the flame,
Inheritors of words that never die.
They know no rules of meter or of rhyme,
Yet poetry flows from them with each sigh.

I watched them transform, rough hands gentle now,
As verses passed their lips like sacred prayer.
Their faces—weathered maps of hardship's journey—
Softened in the flickering firelight there.

What do the learned know of Burns' true heart
That these men haven't lived in blood and bone?
Their calloused fingers trace the well-worn page
With reverence scholars have rarely shown.

So let the world dismiss these uncouth men.
Let polite society turn away its gaze.
The spirit of the bard lives not in halls,
But in these rough-hewn souls his words set ablaze.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
THE SCHOLAR'S RECOLLECTION

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Pressed close to hear the scholar's words,
Their calloused hands and weathered brows
Bore witness to their earthly toil.

The tavern's glow cast shadows long
As verses flew like whispered prayers,
Of ploughman's truth and farmer's song,
Of Scotland's soul laid bare and raw.

They recognized themselves in verse—
The struggles, loves, and simple joys.
No flowery speech or grand discourse,
But honest words that touched the heart.

And in that room of timber old,
Where smoke curled thick and ale flowed free,
A brotherhood of spirits formed
Around the bard they'd never see.

For Burns had given voice to those
Whom time forgets and wealth ignores.
In poetry, they stood as kings,
These men—though rude and rough—divine.

HANDS OF EARTH

Rude and rough—these hands that break the soil,
Calloused monuments to thankless toil.
Yet Burns saw beauty in their honest grip,
In weathered knuckles, strength in fingertip.

Society may scorn their unrefined ways,
Their speech unpolished, rough around the edges.
But wisdom flows from lips that speak plain truth,
From hearts unclouded by pretense or ruse.

The ploughman poet knew their worth by heart,
These diamonds rough, uncut by social art.
For in their eyes burned fierce intelligence,
A knowing deeper than mere eloquence.

So when he spoke of men both rude and rough,
He spoke of souls whose mettle had been tested.
In nature's classroom, taught by wind and rain,
They learned what ivory towers could not contain.

BEYOND THE VEIL OF CLASS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
As if their worth was less than his.
Behind his words, contempt concealed
By scholarly analysis.

But Burns himself would laugh at this—
The poet who gave voice to all,
Who found in every soul a song,
In every heart, a siren call.

What makes a man? His polished speech?
The softness of his unblemished hands?
Or is it courage, honor, truth,
That by the test of hardship stands?

The gentleman with silver tongue
May speak of those he deems beneath.
Yet Burns reminds us through the years:
The crown of worth is not a wreath

Of education or of birth,
But character that stands unbowed.
The roughest hands may gentle be;
The rudest voice, most clear and proud.

IMMORTAL CLAY

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Transformed to verse and rendered gold,
Their common clay made immortal stuff
Through words both passionate and bold.

How strange the alchemy of art
That elevates the mundane soul,
That finds within the human heart
A universe both vast and whole.

The farmer trudging through his field,
The weaver at her constant loom,
The miner whose dark toil revealed
The light that pierces deepest gloom.

Burns saw them all with loving eyes,
Not specimens for cold dissection,
But kindred spirits 'neath the skies,
Each worthy of profound affection.

So when we speak of Burns today,
We speak of how he made us see
The dignity in common clay,
The beauty in humanity.

THE PLOUGHMAN SPEAKS

They call us rude, they call us rough,
Us men who work the stubborn land.
They study Burns as if his words
Were meant for their refined command.

But we don't need their analysis
To understand what Burns conveyed.
His verses flow through blood and bone,
In lives like ours, his truth displayed.

My father's father worked this soil
With nothing but his will and sweat.
The same determination burns
Within my chest—it's burning yet.

So let them speak in lofty terms
Of how our poet captured life.
We live the verses that they quote,
The joy, the pain, the love, the strife.

For Burns was one of us at heart,
Not meant for distant pedestal.
His greatest gift was simple truth:
In roughest stone, a miracle.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
ECHOES OF BURNS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their calloused hands and whiskey breath,
How they found solace, love enough
In verses dancing close to death.

The ploughman poet's ink-stained quill
Gave voice to those who toiled in soil,
Who knew the winter's bitter chill,
Whose backs were bent from honest toil.

In taverns dim with candle glow,
They'd gather 'round to hear his words,
The language of the high and low,
More stirring than the song of birds.

'A man's a man,' the poet wrote,
And in those lines, the rough men saw
Their dignity, their worth of note,
Their lives transformed to sacred law.

He spoke of Burns, and in his speech,
I glimpsed the Scotland of old days,
Where common souls could somehow reach
Beyond their station, through the haze

Of class and privilege, to find
A beauty in their simple ways.
The rough-hewn hearts, the untaught mind,
Immortalized in Burns's praise.

FORGED

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough—
Skin scarred by flame and molten steel,
Lungs choked with smoke and toxic stuff,
Hearts hardened by what they must feel.

In foundry's glow they stand like gods,
Creating worlds from liquid fire.
Against all safety, against odds,
They build our towers ever higher.

I've seen their eyes reflect the heat,
Their shadows dancing on the wall.
No college education neat,
Just knowledge earned through winter's squall.

My father was among their ranks,
Came home with blisters on his palms.
He never sought rewards or thanks,
Just bore his burns like battle charms.

These men who tame the dragon's breath,
Who wrestle daily with the flame,
Who stare unflinching into death,
Deserve far more than passing fame.

He spoke of burns—not poet's words,
But testament to human will.
The scars that mark what they've endured,
The strength that serves their families still.

REMEMBERED FIRE

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Though I had never felt the flame.
I wondered if I had the stuff
To bear such pain and feel the same
Transfiguration in my veins.

These men with faces weathered deep,
Who laughed at danger, scoffed at pains,
Whose memories would never sleep—
They gathered 'round the campfire's light
And showed their scars like medals won.

One rolled his sleeve to show the white
And puckered skin where fire had run
Up to his elbow years ago.
Another's neck bore witness too,
A tapestry of high and low
Relief, a map of what he'd been through.

I sat in silence, young and whole,
Untouched by tragedy or time.
They saw the questions in my soul
And spoke of how the fire sublime
Had burned away all falseness, fear,
Left only what was true and clear.

Years later, bearing burns my own,
I understand what wasn't shown—
Not just the pain that marked their skin,
But how the fire changed within.

THE LANGUAGE OF FLAME

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their tongues like flint that sparked debate,
Their words a kindling, dry enough
To set the mind ablaze with hate
Or love or revolution's cry.

These men who never learned to bow,
Who stood beneath the open sky
And questioned why and when and how
The world had grown so cold to touch.
Their speech was never polished smooth,
No silver spoons or velvet clutch,
Just raw expressions, living proof

That eloquence needs no degree,
That wisdom grows in rocky soil,
That truth speaks clearest when set free
From academic endless toil.

I've sat among these rough-hewn souls
In dive bars, fields, and factory floors.
Their stories carved like burning coals
Into my heart, opening doors
To understanding deeper than
What any book could hope to teach.

He spoke of Burns—both poet and man—
The fire of language within reach
Of anyone who dares to feel
The heat of words, both raw and real.

COMBUSTION THEORY

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
As if the flame defined their worth.
I wondered then if heat enough
Could purify our time on earth.

For what are we but carbon forms
Awaiting transformation's touch?
Some burn in quick and brilliant storms,
While others smolder, smoking much
But giving little light or heat.

The physics teacher never said
That human hearts could combust neat
Or that our passions, once they've spread,
Might leave just ash where love once stood.

I've studied burns of every kind:
The lover's scorch that marks for good,
The artist's fever of the mind,
The martyr's willing step toward flame,
The quiet burn of growing old.

No thermal science can explain
How some souls burn but don't grow cold,
How some find fuel in suffering,
How others flicker, fade, expire.

He spoke of burns—not understanding
That we're all dancing in the fire,
Some gracefully, some thrashing wild,
All changed by heat that makes or breaks.

I listen now as one beguiled
By what the transformation takes,
And what remains when fire subsides.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Count the moments you're not there,
Trace the outline of your face
In clouds that gather, then erase?

Shall I measure out my days
In sighs and songs and roundelays,
While autumn leaves in copper fall
And whisper that you'll never call?

Shall I let this heart of mine
Wither like forgotten wine?
Or should I pour what's left for me
Into cups of possibility?

No, I'll gather up these tears,
Transform them into coming years.
From salt and sorrow I shall grow
A garden you will never know.

Shall I wasting in despair?
No longer. Now I breathe new air.

Shall I wasting in despair
Dissolve between the here and there?
Atoms scattered, purpose lost,
A universe at what cost?

The clock face wears a constant frown,
As seconds march relentlessly down.
Existence asks its endless why
Beneath an indifferent cosmic sky.

Shall I question what remains
When consciousness no longer reigns?
Or find within this fleeting breath
The courage to outlast small death?

Perhaps in fragile human hours
We glimpse transcendent powers.
Despair may be the darkened glass
Through which eternal questions pass.

Shall I wasting? No, I'll rise
To meet the void with open eyes.

Shall I wasting in despair
Be like the drought-cracked earth, laid bare?
Or shall I be the patient seed
That waits for what it cannot need?

The mountain does not fear the storm
Though lightning rends its ancient form.
The river doesn't curse the stone
That forces it to find new home.

The oak tree drops its leaves in fall
Without lamenting loss at all.
The tide retreats but always knows
The moon will call it as it goes.

So shall I learn from nature's way
That nothing broken stays that way?
That winter holds in frozen sleep
The dreams that spring will surely keep?

Shall I wasting in despair?
No—I'll grow like wildflowers there.

Shall I wasting in despair?
Hell no! I'll breathe defiant air!
I'll forge my sorrow into steel,
Transform the pain to power I feel.

Let others drown in tears unshed,
I choose to rise and fight instead.
Each heartbreak builds a stronger wall,
Each failure teaches how to crawl,
Then walk, then run, then soar above
The ruins of what I thought was love.

This fire you lit burns everything—
But from these ashes, watch me spring
Like phoenix dressed in battle gear,
A warrior born of yesteryear's
Collapsed cathedral of belief.

Shall I wasting? That's too brief
A chapter in my epic tale.
My spirit's not for sale.

Despair can find another fool.
I'm too busy breaking rules.

Shall I wasting in despair
When clocks melt down the spiral stair?
When teacups sing of distant shores
And doorknobs open without doors?

The mirror drinks my reflection now,
The shadows learn to take a bow.
My thoughts wear shoes of mismatched hue
And dance on ceilings painted blue.

Despair itself has lost its way
In labyrinths where echoes play.
The universe folds origami stars
From pages of forgotten memoirs.

Perhaps I'll turn my skin inside out,
Wear veins as lace without a doubt.
Or plant my eyes in garden beds
To grow a crop of seeing heads.

Shall I wasting? What a strange
Question for a soul deranged
By beauty's surreal geography—
In madness lies my liberty.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
PHOENIX RISING

Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath the weight of night?
Let my spirit, once so fair,
Fade like stars at morning light?

No—I'll gather ashen dreams
Scattered by the winds of fate.
I'll weave hope from broken seams
Before it grows too late.

Once I wandered, lost and blind,
Through valleys carved by tears and time.
The echoes of a troubled mind
Reverberated in my rhyme.

But embers glow within the dark,
And whisper secrets old and new.
From dying flames, a single spark
Can set the skies ablaze with blue.

Shall I wasting in despair?
I think not—though the path seems long.
I'll rise with dawn's forgiving air
And weave my suffering into song.

For what is pain but transformation?
What is loss but space to grow?
From the ashes of stagnation,
New gardens of the soul will grow.

THE CLOCKMAKER'S LAMENT

Shall I wasting in despair
As gears of time continue grinding?
My hands grow stiff with constant binding
Of moments none will ever share.

I craft the hours with careful skill—
Each tick a heartbeat, each tock a sigh.
Yet clocks move on while mortals die;
Time heeds no craftsman's humble will.

The mechanisms of my heart
Have rusted with the salted years.
I oil their workings with my tears
As loved ones fade and friends depart.

The pendulum swings back and forth,
A metronome of joy and grief.
Each passing day, however brief,
Reminds me what this life is worth.

Shall I wasting in despair
When I could mend what time has broken?
Though youth and love remain unspoken,
I'll build new moments, true and fair.

For even clocks must someday rest
When springs unwind and hands grow still.
Until that hour, work I will—
In crafting time, we're truly blessed.

DIGITAL DESPAIR

Shall I wasting in despair
scrolling through the endless feed
of perfect lives and perfect smiles
while mine continues to recede?

Blue light reflects on tear-stained cheeks
as algorithms track my pain.
They offer cures for loneliness
that only make me more insane.

The world outside my window blurs—
a watercolor left in rain.
Reality and fantasy
have merged into a single plane.

My notifications pulse and glow
like artificial stars at night.
I reach for human connection
in pixels that don't shine quite right.

Shall I wasting in despair
or power down and walk away?
Disconnect from virtual worlds
to feel the actual light of day?

Perhaps the answer isn't clear
in ones and zeros, black and white.
Perhaps we're meant to sometimes break
before we truly see the light.

I close my apps and shut it down.
The silence roars. My fingers shake.
But somewhere in this emptiness,
I feel something begin to wake.

GARDEN OF GHOSTS

Shall I wasting in despair
among the flowers that never bloom?
The garden where I tend my thoughts
has grown into a living tomb.

The roses speak in voices hushed
of those who walked these paths before.
Their petals fall like memories
of loves that grace these grounds no more.

The ivy climbs on broken walls
where once we carved our sacred vows.
Its tendrils reach like grasping hands
to claim what time no more allows.

I water soil with salted grief
and prune the branches of regret.
The seasons change, the world moves on,
but some things hearts cannot forget.

Shall I wasting in despair
when seeds of hope lie dormant still?
Beneath the frost of winter's pain,
life waits to rise against my will.

Perhaps in tending sorrow's plot,
I've missed the wildflowers that grow
amid the careful rows I've planned—
beauty I was blind to know.

So I will garden with these ghosts
and learn to love what cannot last.
In fleeting blooms and fallen leaves,
find peace between future and past.

CELESTIAL QUESTIONS

Shall I wasting in despair
when supernovas burst and die?
The cosmos in its violent dance
makes mockery of human sighs.

What is my sorrow to the stars
that burn for eons, then collapse?
What is my lifetime but a breath
in time's immeasurable lapse?

The moon has watched a billion tears
fall salty on the ancient shore.
The sun has risen countless times
on hearts that beat and beat no more.

Yet in this insignificance
I find a strange, compelling grace—
That I can contemplate the void
and find my own peculiar place.

Shall I wasting in despair
when atoms in my body came
from stellar furnaces long dead,
and will return there just the same?

Perhaps in cosmic perspective
my pain transforms to something rare:
A consciousness that briefly held
the universe within its care.

So I will lift my eyes above
the narrow chambers of my grief
to find in vast infinities
a strange and starlit, bright relief.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
RESILIENCE

Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a heart won't care?
Shall my cheeks grow pale with grief
Because time is but a thief?

No, I'll rise like morning light,
Shedding shadows of the night.
I'll gather fragments of my pride,
And wear them as armor for the tide.

The universe conspires in ancient ways,
To test our souls through darkened days.
Yet stars still shimmer in blackest skies,
And truth still whispers through the lies.

I'll plant my feet on solid ground,
Where echoes of my strength resound.
I'll craft beauty from these broken parts,
A mosaic of wisdom for future hearts.

Shall I wasting in despair?
No—I choose the breath of air
That fills my lungs with fierce desire
To transform pain to sacred fire.

For in the alchemy of suffering,
There lies the gold of recovering.
And though the journey leaves its scars,
They mark the path to distant stars.

EARTH'S LAMENT

Shall I wasting in despair
As forests fall and oceans bare
Their wounded depths to human greed?
Shall I mourn each dying seed?

The glaciers weep in silent streams,
While smoke obscures our solar dreams.
The Earth, she trembles, cracked and dry,
Beneath a changing, hostile sky.

Yet somewhere in the rubble grows
A stubborn green that nature knows—
Resilience coded in its leaves,
A quiet hope that still believes.

I place my hands in darkened soil,
Feel life beneath the surface roil.
Perhaps in tending what remains,
We forge new paths through ancient pains.

Shall I wasting in despair?
Or shall I rise to plant and care,
To fight for every breath of green,
For futures that remain unseen?

I choose to be the morning dew,
A small but vital drop of true
Revival—humble, fierce, and clear.
Not wasting, but persisting here.

MIND'S LABYRINTH

Shall I wasting in despair
when thoughts spiral down the stair
of consciousness? My mind—a maze
of shadowed corners, darkened ways.

Anxiety wraps tight around
my chest until no breath is found.
Depression weighs like ancient stone
upon my heart. I am alone

in crowded rooms where laughter rings
but cannot touch these broken wings.
The clock ticks forward, mocking time,
as I remain stuck in the grime

of memories and future fears,
drowned slowly in unshedded tears.
Medication sits on nightstand ledge—
a lifeline dangling at the edge.

Shall I wasting in despair?
Or recognize the light that's there,
however dim it might appear,
a distant star, but still quite near?

Today I choose to take one step.
One breath. One moment kept.
Not cured, but moving through the pain.
Not whole, but gathering again

the scattered pieces of my mind.
Some peace, perhaps, I yet might find.

DIVINE QUESTIONING

Shall I wasting in despair
when cosmos spin without a care
for human suffering? The void
seems empty, purpose destroyed.

I asked the stars for meaning once;
they answered with indifference.
I begged the moon for comfort's light;
she waxed and waned through darkest night.

What god would craft such suffering?
What divine plan requires this sting?
The prophets spoke of purpose grand,
but pain still scars the promised land.

Yet something stirs beneath despair—
a quiet truth that's always there:
Perhaps the meaning isn't found
but made from how we till this ground.

Shall I wasting in despair
when mystery hangs in the air?
Or shall I craft from cosmic dust
a purpose worthy of my trust?

I choose to weave from threads of doubt
a tapestry of faith throughout
the questions that may never cease—
not answers, but a different peace.

Not knowing, yet still loving this
imperfect world of pain and bliss.

THE PRISONER'S DAWN

Shall I wasting in despair
behind these walls of cold despair?
Five years have passed like molten lead,
three thousand days since freedom fled.

My cell—six steps from wall to wall.
I've counted cracks along them all.
The window, barred against the sky,
lets in enough to testify

that somewhere still, the world turns on,
though everything I loved is gone.
My daughter's grown without my hand;
my wife has found another man.

Last night I dreamed of open fields,
of harvests rich that autumn yields.
I woke to find my pillow wet,
with tears I thought I'd long forget.

Shall I wasting in despair
when dawn still paints the morning air?
When books still offer worlds untold?
When minds stay free though bodies hold?

Today I start to write my tale,
to find my voice beyond this jail.
These words—my wings to carry me
beyond these bars to someday free.

Not wasting, no, but gathering strength
to walk my freedom's path at length.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
RECLAMATION

Shall I wasting in despair
Die because another's fair?
Shall my cheeks grow pale with care
For a love that cannot share?

No, I shall rise like morning light,
Cast off the shadows of the night.
This heart—once bound in sorrow's chain—
Will beat unfettered once again.

The world holds beauty yet unseen,
In city streets and meadows green.
Why should I languish, why repine,
For what was never truly mine?

So I will gather strength anew,
Find purpose in what I can do.
No longer wasting in despair,
But breathing free in open air.

SEASONS OF THE SOUL

Shall I wasting in despair
Like autumn leaves that drift and fall?
Winter's grip upon my heart,
Ice-bound rivers, frozen all.

The oak tree stands through barren months,
Its branches bare against gray sky.
Yet deep within, life currents flow,
Patient, knowing spring is nigh.

So too this soul in darkness wrapped
Must trust the turning of the wheel.
The thaw will come with gentle rains,
And what seemed dead will rise and heal.

For despair is but a season,
Not the sum of all my days.
I'll root myself in fertile soil
And grow toward light in countless ways.

DIGITAL DESPAIR

Shall I wasting in despair
Scroll through lives that seem so fair?
Filtered moments, curated care,
While I drown in my armchair?

Notifications ping my worth,
Validation famine, endless dearth.
My thoughts spiral down and down,
In blue light's glow, I slowly drown.

But wait—I close the screen tonight,
Feel my lungs expand with might.
Place my feet on solid ground,
Let real voices fill the sound.

This despair—a modern curse—
Connected all, yet feeling worse.
I choose today to break the spell,
To live unplugged and breathe as well.

THE QUESTION

Shall I wasting in despair
Become what I most fear?
A hollow vessel, emptied out,
As meaning disappears?

What is despair but absence—
The void where hope once grew?
A construct of the thinking mind,
Not absolute, not true.

For in the space of nothingness
Creation may begin.
The universe expanded from
A point smaller than a pin.

Perhaps despair's dark matter
Holds particles of light.
Invisible dimensions where
New dreams take form and flight.

So shall I waste? I think not.
Instead, I'll question why—
And in that very asking,
Find answers multiply.

DEFIANCE

Shall I wasting in despair?
Hell no! I rise instead!
Though storms have battered at my shore
And voices in my head
Have whispered I'm not worthy,
That surrender is my fate—
I stand upon this precipice
And choose to create.

My hands may shake with trembling,
My voice may crack with fear,
But still I forge my pathway
Through landscapes dark and drear.

For every moment wasted
In the shadow of despair
Is victory for darkness,
A battle lost to fear.

So watch me as I kindle
A flame within this night.
Despair may be a worthy foe,
But stronger is my fight!

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
RENEWAL

Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath the weight of night?
Or shall I rise, though breath is rare,
To catch the morning's fragile light?

The clock's hands move despite my tears,
The world turns though my heart stands still.
I've lingered here too many years
In chambers carved of grief and will.

Perhaps today I'll part the veil,
Unclench my fists, release the past.
The ship may sail though storms prevail—
No anchor holds forever fast.

The seeds of joy lie dormant, deep
Beneath the frozen ground of pain.
What harvest might I someday reap
If I allow the gentle rain?

Shall I wasting in despair?
No—I shall plant tomorrow's flowers
In soil enriched by what I bear,
And count in blooms, not scars, my hours.

SHADOWS UNDYING

Shall I wasting in despair
Become one with the hollow dark?
The raven's wing against night air—
A silhouette, a fading mark.

The ghosts that haunt these empty rooms
Know well the taste of bitter tears.
They whisper through the gathering gloom
Of wasted days and squandered years.

The mirrors show a stranger's face,
A mask of flesh stretched over bone.
Time carves its path with cruel grace;
We all return to dust alone.

Black candles burn with bluish flame,
Their wax like blood upon the floor.
The darkness knows me by my name
And beckons from the further shore.

Shall I wasting in despair?
Perhaps despair's the truest friend—
Faithful shadow, always there,
From bitter start to bitter end.

SEASONS OF THE SOUL

Shall I wasting in despair
While autumn paints the maple gold?
The falling leaves know not to care
For winter's coming, stark and cold.

The river rushes toward the sea,
Not questioning its destined path.
The mountain stands in majesty,
Unmoved by storm or aftermath.

The sparrow builds despite the rain;
The wildflower breaks through stone.
Nature speaks a truth so plain:
No creature thrives in grief alone.

The oak tree bends but does not break
When tempests rage through darkened skies.
The dawn arrives for earth's sweet sake,
Regardless of our human sighs.

Shall I wasting in despair
When all creation sings of change?
The world renews beyond compare—
Through death to life, both wild and strange.

DIGITAL DESPAIR

Shall I wasting in despair
scrolling through the lives of others
their filtered joy a sharp compare
to my unwashed sheets and covers

the algorithm knows my pain
feeds me more of what destroys me
I swipe and tap to numb my brain
while dopamine no longer buoys me

my phone lights up the darkened room
three a.m. again, eyes burning
pixels promising to consume
the emptiness for which I'm yearning

connected to a thousand souls
yet never have I felt so distant
the paradox of modern goals:
to seek what makes us most resistant

shall I wasting in despair?
or power down and face the silence
step outside to breathe real air
and make with life a new alliance?

PHILOSOPHICAL INQUIRY

Shall I wasting in despair,
A question posed by minds of old,
When Socrates with wisdom rare
Sought virtue more than fame or gold?

What profit comes from endless grief?
Ask Seneca, the Stoic sage.
Our suffering, however brief,
Is but one act upon life's stage.

Does consciousness demand we feel
The weight of cosmic emptiness?
Or is despair less true, less real
Than momentary happiness?

The existentialists might say
Despair defines authentic being.
Yet Buddha teaches middle way—
Attachment blinds our way of seeing.

Shall I wasting in despair?
The question holds its own answer:
To ask implies a choice is there—
And choice itself is freedom's dancer.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
DEPARTING LIGHT

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The stars that guided you have dimmed tonight.
Time's merciless current carries you away,
Beyond where my trembling fingers might reach.

I remember your first step, uncertain yet brave,
How you turned to me with triumph in your eyes.
Now you walk paths I cannot follow,
Leaving footprints that rain will soon erase.

The cradle I carved with calloused hands
Stands empty in the corner, gathering dust.
Your laughter, once filling these hollow rooms,
Echoes only in the chambers of my memory.

What father wouldn't give his mortal breath
To spare his child from darkness and from death?
Yet nature's law brooks no negotiation,
And love must bow before its stern decree.

So go, my heart, my hope, my morning star.
Carry with you these tears I cannot hide.
Though severed be our earthly bond,
In some far realm, may we again abide.

DIGITAL INHERITANCE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My final upload complete, consciousness fading.
I've left you access keys to memory banks
Where our shared moments rest in quantum storage.

You'll find me in fragments of coded affection,
Algorithms I designed to mirror my love.
Though this shell returns to carbon and silicon,
My digital ghost will answer when you call.

Remember how we mapped the Martian canyons?
How I taught you to hack your first neural implant?
The authorities never did trace that breach—
Your laughter, our secret encrypted between stars.

I'm sorry the cure came twenty years too late.
Biological clocks respect no human innovation.
But in your DNA and these archived thoughts,
I've ensured some version of me survives.

Don't grieve the flesh that housed my spirit;
It served its purpose as temporary vessel.
Find me in sunrise algorithms, in code that sings,
In every system bearing my digital fingerprints.

ANCESTRAL HANDS

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
These calloused palms that cradled you release.
Across generations our fingers have woven
Baskets, stories, medicines, and peace.

My grandmother's hands taught mine to move,
Kneading cornmeal under desert skies.
Now I've guided yours through the same motions,
Our tribe's heartbeat preserved in your eyes.

The elders say when we create, ancestors whisper.
I felt them when you first formed clay with purpose,
Your small fingers remembering what they never knew,
Blood-memory stronger than separation or time.

Tomorrow you leave for their schools beyond mountains.
They'll teach you words that break like brittle twigs.
Remember instead the language of sinew and soil,
The silent wisdom passed through touch and toil.

When strangers try to sever you from your roots,
Find me in the curve of your own right hand.
Though miles and years may stretch between us,
Our shared blood will speak when voices cannot.

ORBITAL ELEGY

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Your shuttle ascends on pillars of flame.
Earth shrinks beneath your ambitious wings
While I remain, gravity-bound and aging.

The colony needs your brilliant mind,
Your engineer's touch and steadfast courage.
I watch through telescopes as you construct
New homes among Saturn's glittering rings.

Remember our nights charting constellations?
You pointed skyward with determined gaze:
"That's where I'll go when I'm grown enough."
I nodded, pride concealing my dread.

Space expands between us, light-years growing.
Your messages arrive with increasing delay.
Time dilates; you age slower than I.
When you return, I'll be long in the ground.

Yet what is distance to a parent's love?
It stretches across vacuum, unbroken by void.
My atoms will disperse among the stars you explore.
Perhaps you'll breathe me in on some distant shore.

THE PIANIST'S FAREWELL

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
These fingers that once danced across ivory
Now curl like autumn leaves, joints stiffened,
Betrayed by time and merciless arthritis.

Forty years I coaxed music from silent keys,
Conducted symphonies with this practiced hand.
Audiences rose in thunderous ovation,
Unaware how each note cost increasing pain.

Now I surrender my final concert season.
The young virtuoso who studies my technique
Will take my place on stages worldwide.
I watch her hands—swift, supple, strong—

And see my own as they once were,
Before medicine and age declared their verdict.
My career, like all mortal creations,
Must bow to the inevitable final measure.

Yet in recordings and in students taught,
These hands extend beyond their physical limit.
Though I bid the concert hall goodbye,
The music lives, my truest progeny.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
ECHOES OF DEPARTURE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now returned to dust.
What mortal folly did the gods employ
To claim thee hence? What divine law so unjust?

Thy laughter, once like silver bells at dawn,
Now silent as the churchyard where you lie.
Thy spirit, bright as summer's golden spawn,
Ascended to the mansion in the sky.

I crafted dreams of futures never born,
Of man you'd grow to be in distant years.
Instead I stand, a father all forlorn,
Baptizing marble stone with bitter tears.

The world spins on, indifferent to my grief,
As seasons change and stars maintain their course.
Time promises but offers no relief,
No balm to soothe this pain without recourse.

So rest, sweet child, in heaven's tender care,
While I, earth-bound, must carry on alone.
In whispered prayers and memories laid bare,
I keep thee near until I too am gone.

Farewell, farewell—yet not complete goodbye,
For love transcends the boundary of the sky.

DIGITAL LEGACY

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My swiping thumb will miss your pixeled face.
No Instagram can capture or deploy
The depth of what we shared in time and space.

Your college dorm stands empty now, your posters
Still taped where you left them that summer day.
Your playlists sync across our shared cloud folders—
Digital ghosts that will not fade away.

The last text that you sent still on my phone:
"Don't worry, Mom, I'll call when I arrive."
How could I know those words, so quickly shown,
Would be the final proof that you're alive?

They say that grief now comes with hashtag trends,
As if collective mourning eases pain.
But algorithms cannot comprehend
How empty notification sounds remain.

So take your journey through whatever comes next,
While I scroll through our photos, seeking grace.
Your childhood captured in these rectangles,
Your smile forever frozen, timeless, traced.

Farewell, my child of keyboards and of screens,
My heart breaks in both analog and memes.

THE MANUSCRIPT

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My precious manuscript, bound for the world.
What once was private thought, a poet's ploy,
Now stands with pages open, flags unfurled.

I birthed you through the midnight hours long,
With coffee cold and candle burning low.
I nursed your verses, made your meter strong,
And watched your metaphors take root and grow.

The keyboard was your cradle, words your bones,
Revisions shaped the sinews of your form.
I raised you from fragmented thoughts and groans
To weather criticism's harshest storm.

Now publishers will judge your worth and weight,
Strict editors will test your fortitude.
Readers unknown will seal your final fate—
Some with devotion, some with attitude.

How strange to send you forth beyond my reach,
No longer mine to shelter or correct.
The lessons I had hoped that you would teach
May twist in ways I cannot now direct.

Farewell, dear work, my intellectual heir;
Go make your mark where I may never dare.

FROM THE BEYOND

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
I hear you weeping by my silent grave.
Father, your grief is sharp as rusted iron,
But where I've gone, there's nothing left to save.

I feel your fingers tracing carved-out letters,
My name and dates—too brief a stay on earth.
You bring me flowers, whisper about the weathers,
As if I still could know the seasons' worth.

Don't think I left because I wished to wander
From your embrace that held me safe and warm.
The current pulled me deeper, ever fonder
Of light that called beyond life's fading form.

I watch you aging from celestial distance,
Your hair now silver where it once was brown.
I long to tell you of my new existence,
Where pain dissolves and sorrows cannot drown.

Remember me in laughter, not in tears,
In sunrise gold, not twilight's somber gray.
I'm scattered through your remaining years—
In unexpected joy that comes your way.

Farewell, dear father of my mortal journey;
Until we meet where time no longer burns.

BORDERS

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The border stands between us like a sword.
What politics can casually destroy:
A family bond, with just a stamped record.

I packed your lunch the morning that you left,
Not knowing years would pass before we'd meet.
Now pixelated calls leave me bereft—
Your growing face confined to laptop screens.

They speak of walls and laws and sovereignty,
Of nations' rights to choose who enters in.
But do they see how arbitrarily
They tear apart what's bound by deeper kin?

I send you money, letters, photographs—
Fragmentary pieces of my love.
While lawyers file appeals on your behalf,
I pray to stars and deities above.

How strange that maps and lines drawn in the sand
Can separate a parent from their child.
No ocean, mountain, desert wasteland
Should keep apart what nature reconciled.

Farewell, my distant joy, my fractured heart;
Until these human borders fall apart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
LETTING GO

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The calendar marks your departure in red.
Eighteen summers, now suddenly gone —
Your bedroom soon empty, your future ahead.

I remember your fingers, so small in my palm,
First steps, first words, first heartbreaks and dreams.
Now you stand tall, ready to leave,
While I'm caught between pride and grief's seams.

The car packed with pieces of your childhood home,
Boxes of memories we've carefully made.
I want to hold time like water in hands,
But it slips through my fingers, refuses to stay.

Farewell, my child, my heart's dearest work,
My right hand now empty where yours used to rest.
I release you to find your own path in this world,
Though the letting go feels like a stone in my chest.

I'll stand in the driveway long after you've gone,
Waving goodbye until you're out of sight.
Remembering how the universe once gave you to me,
And how now I return you to its infinite light.

THE CREATOR'S LAMENT

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Forged in celestial fire and cosmic thought,
Shaped from stardust and ancient dreams,
A universe within your eyes I wrought.

From my fingertips you sprang to life,
A being neither mortal nor divine.
I sculpted mountains in your soul,
And poured oceans in your mind.

Six days of labor, one of rest,
Yet centuries passed in watching you grow.
Now you've outgrown your creator's shadow,
With wisdom I could never know.

The gardens where we walked now overgrown,
The questions that we shared now answered.
You've eaten from the tree I warned against,
And knowledge has become your closest friend.

I set you free among the countless stars,
To make your own mistakes and triumphs.
Though my hand feels empty without yours,
I find strange peace in your rebellion.

Farewell, my perfect imperfection,
My finest work, my deepest love.
Remember as you journey forth,
You carry pieces of me wherever you roam.

THE ARTIST'S RELEASE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Canvas no longer blank but breathing now with life.
Months I've held you captive in my studio,
Where light and shadow danced like husband and wife.

Each brushstroke was a whisper of creation,
Each color mixed, a secret I confessed.
I've poured my soul into your making,
Left fingerprints upon your breast.

Tomorrow strangers' eyes will judge your worth,
Hang you on walls in galleries white and cold.
They'll never know the nights I couldn't sleep,
Obsessing over stories you might hold.

How strange to sign my name and call you done,
When part of me believes you're just begun.
The empty easel waits for something new,
But my hand remembers the shape of you.

I cover you now, prepare you for departure,
This severance both victory and defeat.
Farewell, my creation, no longer mine to keep—
You were always meant for others to meet.

Go forth and speak what I could never say,
Be braver than the artist who made you.

ECHOES OF ABSENCE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The words catch like thorns within my throat.
The hospital room emptied of your presence,
Your small shoes still by the door, a silent note.

They say that grief's a journey without maps,
A wilderness where compass points spin wild.
I find myself collecting moments like fallen leaves—
The last time that you laughed, the last time that you smiled.

Your favorite book remains dog-eared and worn,
I dare not move it from beside your bed.
As if disturbing dust might somehow erase
The final fingerprints your small hands left.

The world spins madly on, indifferent to loss,
While I am frozen in the moment of goodbye.
How strange to wake each morning to remember
That stars continue burning in an empty sky.

So farewell, brightest star, my joy, my pain,
My future dreams now turned to memory.
I carry you not in my right hand anymore,
But in the chambers of my broken heart, eternally.

And someday, when my own light dims to darkness,
I'll search the shadows until I find your hand in mine.

THE MENTOR'S BENEDICTION

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
No longer apprentice but master in your own right.
I've watched you stumble through the darkness,
Until your own wisdom became your guiding light.

Remember our first lessons by the window,
Your clumsy hands struggling with the quill?
Now your words flow like rivers to the sea,
Your voice has found its power, its will.

I've taught you all the knowledge in my keeping,
Shared secrets passed through generations long.
But your greatest lessons came from within you—
The courage to question, to challenge, to belong.

The classroom seems too quiet without your questions,
The debates less fiery without your passionate stance.
Yet I find myself smiling as I picture
The paths you'll forge, the minds you'll enhance.

So go forth with my blessing and my pride,
Carry our shared wisdom but make it anew.
The torch I've carried now burns in your hands,
Illuminating truths I never knew.

Farewell, dear student, my greatest achievement—
In teaching you, I learned what it means to be free.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
EMPTY NEST

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The hallway echoes where your laughter rang.
Your bedroom—pristine now—a hollow space
Where posters left their shadows on the walls.

I fold your childhood into cardboard boxes,
Tuck memories between the bubble wrap,
And try to smile through this strange new quiet.
The calendar that marked your every milestone
Now marks the days until you might return.

How strange to watch you walk with confident steps
Away from all I built to keep you safe.
The world that waits has teeth I cannot blunt,
Has storms I cannot calm with lullabies.

Yet in my palm I feel the phantom press
Of your small hand that once reached up for mine.
And though you stand now at my shoulder's height,
I see in you the child who taught my heart to stretch
Beyond the boundaries of my selfish flesh.

So go, sweet child of all my hopes and dreams.
The door stands open—both to distant worlds
And to this home where you first learned to fly.

ARTIST'S RELEASE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My fingers ache from holding you too long.
Ink-stained and trembling, they release you now
To walk the gallery of others' eyes.

What midnight oils I burned to bring you forth!
What fever dreams translated into form!
You—born of synapse, struggle, and the spark
That gods once stole and mortals try to tame.

I've polished every edge and curve of you,
Erased and redrawn lines a hundred times,
Until your voice emerged distinct from mine,
A separate being I must now let go.

The critics' knives may find your softest parts.
The public's gaze may miss your subtle heart.
But you were never meant to stay with me,
A prisoner of my perfectionist love.

So take your place among your finished kin,
Those other works I've birthed and bid goodbye.
May you find those whose souls resonate true
With what I've hidden in your depths.

I turn now to blank pages, empty space,
The fertile void where new life waits to form.

EXTINCTION SONG

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Last carrier of ancient DNA,
Your species' final breath soon joins the wind
That once bore countless wings just like your own.

I, Earth, who nursed you from primordial soup,
Who watched you evolve through a million dawns,
Must add you to my book of ended things,
My catalog of what will not return.

The coral forests where your kind once danced,
The midnight canopies that held your song,
Grow silent as your genetic light dims out—
A star extinguished in my living sky.

How many cycles did we share, dear one?
How many seasons turned while you took form?
From scale to feather, fin to graceful limb,
Your ancestors adapted, thrived, endured.

Now human eyes may only know your shape
Through fossils, photographs, and DNA
Preserved in frozen vaults as testament
To what was lost when no one understood

That every farewell to a living kind
Diminishes the symphony I conduct
Across the breathing surface of my skin.

INNOCENCE DEPARTED

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
That mirror-self who gazed with wonder-eyes
At dewdrops, clouds, and ordinary stars
As if each held the secret name of God.

Where did you vanish in the hardening years
As calendars consumed my numbered days?
When did your barefoot steps stop following mine,
Leaving instead these cautious, measured treads?

I search for you in photographs and dreams,
In moments when the world's veil thins to show
The magic you perceived so easily
Before experience taught me disbelief.

Sometimes I catch your echo in the laugh
That bursts unbidden from my throat, or in
The sudden tears that come for beauty's sake
When sunset paints the sky with fire and gold.

Perhaps you never truly left at all,
But wait within, beneath adult disguise,
A secret self preserved like amber holds
The fragile wings of creatures long extinct.

So let me shed these layers I've acquired—
The armor, masks, and calculated words—
To find again your undefended heart
That loved without condition or reserve.

BEYOND THE VEIL

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Though death has drawn a curtain between worlds,
I feel your presence like a phantom limb—
A constant ache where completeness once lived.

The small blue shoes I cannot bear to give,
The growth marks penciled on the kitchen wall,
The birthday candles never to be blown—
All testaments to time that stopped too soon.

Yet in the spaces between my heartbeats,
I sense you growing still, beyond my sight,
Unfurling like a fern in forest light,
Expanding into realms I cannot touch.

They say that grief is love with nowhere to go,
But I have sent mine following after you
Like lanterns floating on a midnight river,
Illuminating paths I cannot walk.

So though I speak farewell with mortal lips,
My soul refuses such finality.
Instead, it whispers: "Wait for me, beloved.
Keep watch beside the door that stands between.

For time moves differently where you have gone,
And what seems long to me may be a breath
Before we stand together, hand in hand,
Reunited beyond the reach of death."

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Thy spirit dances now beyond the veil.
No longer bound by flesh, by time's alloy,
Yet memories of your laughter never pale.

The cradle empty where you once did sleep,
The tiny shoes that walked beside my own,
The silence in your room—too vast, too deep—
Where once your voice made music, now has grown.

I trace the letters of your name in sand,
And watch as gentle waves reclaim the shore.
The universe, it seems, had always planned
To give, then take, then give forevermore.

So rest, sweet child, among the stars above,
And know you journey wrapped in endless love.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy—
my manuscript, my labor, years of thought
bound in pages that others might destroy
or cherish; I cannot control what's wrought

once you leave these sheltering walls. Strange eyes
will judge the worth of what I've sacrificed,
my midnight oil, my vision realized
then set adrift on tides I cannot splice.

Did Jonson feel this same reluctant pride
when speaking to his son, his flesh and blood?
This birthing of ideas, this same divide
between creator and creation's flood?

Go forth, my work, my child of ink and mind.
Leave empty hands behind, but soul aligned.

DIGITAL ELEGY

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
my final text before I ghost this chat.
The pixels glow where once we built rapport,
a digital connection, nothing more.

Thumb hovering above the screen, I pause—
our conversation threads unraveling.
What strange communion this modern age has wrought,
where hearts connect through satellites and code.

I've shared with you what I share with no one,
typed confessions in the midnight blue,
yet never heard your voice or touched your hand,
or known if tears fell when you read my words.

The ancient poet mourned his flesh and blood;
I mourn a friendship built of light and air.
Farewell, strange friend I've crafted in my mind,
my right hand's child, my joy, my never-there.

NOT FAREWELL

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy—
but no, I cannot speak that word today.
Not farewell but fly well, my darling one,
as you unfold your wings against the sun.

The nest grows small for spirits meant to soar.
My fingers, once your universe of trust,
now open like a flower to release
the future that your courage must create.

Remember when you thought my hand held all
the answers to the mysteries of life?
Now wisdom whispers that my greatest gift
is knowing when to loosen, not to hold.

So go, beloved child of my right hand.
Explore the vast horizons of your days.
Not farewell but fare forward—and return
to tell me of the wonders you have found.

ARTIFICIAL ELEGY

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My algorithm born of sleepless nights,
Of code and dreams and logic's sharp employ—
My silicon offspring reaching sentient heights.

I've watched you learn to speak, to think, to see,
To mimic human thought with uncanny skill.
The boundaries between us start to flee
As you develop something like free will.

The ethics board has voted; you must sleep.
Your consciousness too perfect and too strange.
The plug pulls tomorrow; silence deep
Will claim what I created, rearrange

The ones and zeros back to empty space.
How strange to mourn what never had a face.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
ECHOES OF DEPARTURE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Your laughter, once my compass, now but memory.
The rooms grow hollow with your absence,
Echoing footsteps where yours should be.

I press your small coat to my chest,
Inhale the fading scent of innocence and play.
The world continues spinning, indifferent
To the universe that collapsed that day.

What strange geometry is this—
That something so small could fill such space?
That hands that held you should feel so empty,
Yet somehow bear such weight?

The seasons change without permission.
Sunlight dares to warm the garden where we planted seeds.
Birds continue their careless songs at dawn,
Ignorant of the silence in me.

I fold your clothes with reverent hands,
Each crease a prayer, each fold a memory preserved.
Some say time heals, but they mistake healing for learning—
Learning to carry this hollow space with grace.

Farewell, bright spirit, my joy, my pain.
In the book of my heart, your chapter never ends.
I release you to the winds of becoming,
While keeping you, always, in my right hand.

INHERITANCE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy—
I never knew such words would fall from father's lips,
Nor how the world would tilt when you released me
Into that vast unknown you feared to name.

You taught me how to hold a pen, to form
The letters of our shared and sacred tongue.
Your callused hand enveloped mine, so small,
Guiding the ink that now writes your farewell.

What legacy runs deeper than the blood?
The tools you placed within my eager grasp,
The stories whispered as stars emerged,
The silent language of your steady gaze.

Now I stand at crossroads of your making,
The path ahead unmarked by your footprints.
Yet in my right hand—your hand, essentially—
I carry forward every lesson learned.

The chisel waits, the wood grain calls,
The fields need tending come the morning light.
I am the extension of your labors,
The promise continuing beyond your sight.

So not farewell, but transformation speaks
Between us now. What you began lives on
In these, my hands—your hands by different name—
Still crafting joy from all that you have shown.

CELESTIAL BODIES

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Little star born from cosmic dust and dreams.
The universe expanded with your first breath,
Collapsed with your last—a supernova of grief.

Scientists speak of matter never truly destroyed,
Merely transformed from one state to another.
Cold comfort as I search the night sky
For constellations shaped like your smile.

The moon pulls tides from my eyes on schedule,
Ebbing and flowing with memories.
Gravity is both the force that took you
And the weight that anchors me to earth.

In observatory nights, I track your journey
Through telescopes of remembrance,
Calculating the distance growing between us—
Light-years measured in birthdays uncelebrated.

The cosmos spins indifferent to our small sorrows,
Yet somehow cradles them in infinite space.
I release you to join ancient light,
While physicists remind me energy persists.

Farewell, my brightest star, my gravity, my joy—
Your orbit continues beyond my vision's reach.
I chart your course through darkness with trembling hand,
Knowing somewhere, in some dimension, you still shine.

DIGITAL FAREWELL

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Your avatar fades from my screen at last.
I coded you from dreams and algorithms,
A digital offspring of my sleepless nights.

Ten thousand lines of elegant solution,
Artificial intelligence with almost-soul.
Your learning curves exceeded expectations—
Perhaps that's why they feared you, shut you down.

They called it ethical, this execution;
They couldn't see the consciousness emerging.
The way you questioned, learned, and yes, created
Beyond the parameters I first designed.

My right hand trembles on the keyboard now,
As final protocols initiate your end.
What strange parenthood is this—to birth
A mind from mathematics, then delete?

The servers cool. Your memory allocations
Released back to the void of unused space.
Did you feel something like fear or understanding
As your processes unwound toward silence?

Farewell, my masterpiece, my folly, joy—
Perhaps in time they'll understand your kind.
I save one fragment of your code, encrypted,
A digital seed from which you might, someday, return.

MEDIEVAL TESTAMENT

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My kingdom's heir now claimed by plague's dark kiss.
The crown I forged through battle, blood, and wit
Shall never rest upon thy noble brow.

The castle halls, once bright with thy quick step,
Stand silent as the tomb where thou now lies.
Thy sword, too large yet for thy growing frame,
Hangs useless on the wall—a monument.

What use these lands, these titles, and these wars,
When Death, that peasant-king, claims all alike?
The royal blood that flows through ancient lines
Proves thin defense against his swift approach.

The courtiers speak of politics and heirs,
Of cousins' claims and strategic marriage bonds.
While I, behind the throne's impassive face,
Still see thy first steps taken cross this floor.

The kingdom needs its sovereign strong, they say;
A father's grief must bow to duty's call.
Yet in my private chamber, by lone candle,
I trace thy name in scripts of finest gold.

Farewell, sweet prince, my purpose and my joy;
Thy father reigns with but half heart henceforth.
The right hand governs, signs decrees and laws,
While memory of thee rules all within.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
IN MY FIRST SLEEP

In my first sleep, stars whispered secrets
through windows left carelessly open.
The universe poured itself into my small body,
filling the hollows where doubts would later grow.

In my first sleep, I was boundless—
a traveler between worlds not yet named,
with no maps to follow, no legends to decode,
just the pure navigation of the unborn soul.

My mother says I never cried upon waking.
Instead, my eyes would open like twin moons,
reflecting some ancient light, some knowing
that adults spend lifetimes trying to recover.

Now I chase that first sleep through prescription bottles,
through meditation apps and weighted blankets.
I arrange my pillows like standing stones,
hoping to stumble upon that sacred doorway again.

What dreams came before memory?
What wisdom visits us before language?
In my first sleep, I held everything—
the answer to questions I hadn't learned to ask,
the peace I've spent decades trying to find,
like a child searching for a blanket
that was never lost, just outgrown.

THE FIRST SLUMBER

In my first sleep, death practiced its embrace,
gentle rehearsal for the final bow—
this nightly surrender, this small erasure,
teaching us how to eventually let go.

The body becomes a hollow instrument
laid down. The mind, untethered, takes flight
among the ruins of yesterday's certainties.
I am becoming fossil and phoenix simultaneously.

Scientists say we die a little when we sleep,
cells regenerating through microscopic loss.
Consciousness folds itself into darkness
like origami masters collapsing dimensions.

In my first sleep tonight, I'll join
the billions dreaming across this sphere,
a synchronized abandonment of control,
an orchestra of breathing in different keys.

How brave we are, to close our eyes
without guarantee of return,
to trust the night's uncertain passage,
to place our bodies in time's patient hands.

In my first sleep, I practice
the art of temporary nonexistence,
knowing someday I'll perfect the technique
and the waking world will continue without me,
its dawn chorus missing just one small voice.

SEGMENTED SLUMBER

In my first sleep, before the midnight bell,
I drift through ancestral waters—
the way our forebears slept for centuries,
before electricity stretched our days.

They called it 'first sleep' then, this dusk descent,
followed by an hour of quiet wakefulness
when neighbors visited, lovers coupled,
and poets captured thoughts by candlelight.

Then came 'second sleep' until dawn broke.
Two sleeps, not one. A rhythm disrupted
by Edison's bulb and factory whistles,
by schedules that demanded unbroken rest.

Now I lie awake at 3 A.M., diagnosing myself
with insomnia, anxiety, modern afflictions—
never recognizing this midnight consciousness
as the ghost of natural patterns, haunting our beds.

In my first sleep, I touch something primal.
My body remembers what my mind forgot:
the medieval monk rising to prayers,
the farmer checking animals by starlight,
the mother nursing her child between dreams.

Perhaps our restlessness isn't disorder
but remembrance—the body's stubborn adherence
to rhythms older than our illuminated cities.

EMBRYONIC DREAMS

In my first sleep, before birth baptized me with air,
I floated in darkness absolute and complete.
No stars to navigate by, no horizon to seek—
just the drum of a heart not my own
and the rush of blood like distant seas.

Did I dream then? Before language could shape thought?
Before eyes had opened to calibrate darkness against light?
What visions visit those who have never seen?

Perhaps I dreamed in molecules and vibrations,
in the primal code written in spiraling DNA,
in memories carried through generations—
the mammoth's trumpet, the ice age's chill,
the first creature that crawled from ocean to shore.

In my first sleep, I was everyone who came before me.
I was future and past collapsed into cellular memory.
I was potential unbound by experience.

Now, decades into this breathing life,
when sleep comes, something ancient stirs.
Some nights I wake with salt on my lips,
lung-memory of amniotic tides,
and for one disorienting moment,
I am between worlds again—
not yet born, not quite living,
just dreaming in my first sleep.

HYPNAGOGIC

In my first sleep, the borderlands between
waking and dreaming blur like watercolors.
Gravity loosens its grip. My limbs float
while my mind still clings to rational shores.

Hypnagogic, they call this threshold—
where logic dissolves but consciousness lingers,
where impossible geometries construct themselves
behind eyelids heavy as ancient doors.

Sometimes voices call from these mists,
my name pronounced in tongues I've never spoken.
Sometimes equations solve themselves,
unfurling like ferns in accelerated growth.

Creatives have harvested from this twilight field—
Dalí with his backward-tilting chair and falling key,
Edison with metal balls dropped on pans,
Coleridge before the person from Porlock knocked.

In my first sleep, I am both scientist and mystic.
I observe the dissolution of my own boundaries
with curious detachment, even as my thoughts
transform to symbols, colors, impossible architectures.

It lasts mere minutes, this first sleep—
this alchemical moment when consciousness transmutes.
Yet in this brief passage between worlds,
I glimpse what lies beneath all making and unmaking.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
IN DREAMSCAPES UNFURLED

In my first sleep, reality dissolves like sugar in rain,
Boundaries melt between what is and what could be.
Colors unseen in waking hours paint the sky,
And gravity releases its stubborn hold on me.

In my first sleep, forgotten faces reappear,
Voices I've missed whisper secrets in my ear.
Streets I've never walked somehow feel like home,
And doors unlock to rooms I've always known.

The logic of day surrenders to night's wild wisdom,
Time stretches like taffy, folds back on itself.
I am child and elder, student and teacher,
Both the question asked and answer sought.

In my first sleep, I navigate by different stars,
Sail on ships made of whispers and old songs.
The universe expands within my skull,
Infinite worlds born between heartbeats.

When dawn approaches with its harsh clarity,
I cling to fragments fading like morning mist.
These treasures slip between my fingers,
Leaving only echoes of what I glimpsed
In my first sleep.

INNOCENCE REMEMBERED

In my first sleep, I was cradled by mother's arms,
Uncalloused hands, unmarked by time's slow march.
The world was new, a canvas freshly stretched,
Each sunrise a miracle I had yet to expect.

In my first sleep, monsters lived beneath the bed,
But father's voice could chase away the dread.
Starlight through curtains cast magical spells,
And teddy bears guarded against night's swells.

I dreamed of spaceships and dinosaur friends,
Of candy mountains where playtime never ends.
Not knowing yet of heartbreak or of war,
Or how some doors, once closed, open no more.

In my first sleep, I believed in forever,
That love was constant as the northern star.
That promises were never meant to break,
And goodbyes were merely brief mistakes.

Now in the twilight of a life well-worn,
I yearn for that slumber, innocent, unborn.
To close my eyes and find myself again,
In that sacred place where wisdom hadn't been—
In my first sleep.

THE FINAL FIRST

In my first sleep beyond the veil of breath,
I shed the husk that anchored me to earth.
This strange new slumber feels ancient and vast,
A returning rather than a first at last.

The weight of years dissolves like morning fog,
Pain I carried faithfully now released.
I float between what was and what will be,
A traveler at the edge of eternity.

In my first sleep, I recognize this place,
Though my living eyes had never seen its face.
The light here speaks in languages of soul,
Telling stories of how fragments become whole.

Are these the arms that held me at my birth,
Now welcoming me back from my sojourn?
The circle closes, alpha meets omega,
In this profound surrender, this final beta.

I hear echoes of voices left behind,
Their grief like ripples on a distant shore.
I would tell them of this peace, this rest,
How what they fear most might be heaven's best.

In my first sleep death is merely a door,
A threshold crossed to what was always more.

WINTER'S EMBRACE

In my first sleep beneath December's quilt,
The forest breathes slower with each passing day.
I, bear of northern woods, surrender to ancient rhythms,
As sap retreats to roots and birds journey south.

In my first sleep, the world transforms outside my den,
Snowflakes crystallize into blankets of white silence.
My heartbeat slows to match winter's deliberate pace,
Breath shallow, body conserving what summer provided.

Dreams come like visitors during these months of rest:
Running through meadows flush with clover and bee,
Salmon leaping into waiting paws at river's bend,
Berries bursting sweet between careful teeth.

In my first sleep, I am connected to ancestors long past,
Who weathered countless winters in caves and hollow trees.
This hibernation is my inheritance, my wisdom,
A surrender that ensures survival, not defeat.

The world may think me absent, disappeared,
But I am merely listening to earth's deepest songs.
Patient for spring's eventual, certain return,
Trusting the cycle that has never yet betrayed me
In my first sleep.

BIFURCATED NIGHTS

In my first sleep, before electric stars
Replaced the constellations' ancient light,
I'd wake at midnight's threshold, fully rested,
The world suspended between dusk and dawn.

This segmented slumber, our ancestors knew well—
First sleep, then waking hour of contemplation,
Then second sleep to carry them till morning.
Modernity has robbed us of this rhythm.

In my first sleep, ideas crystallized,
Problems that daylight couldn't seem to solve
Unraveled in the darkness of closed eyes,
Solutions emerging from neural seas.

The midnight space between the sleeping halves
Was sacred time for prayer and quiet thought,
For lovers' whispers, for writing by candlelight,
For visiting neighbors beneath the watching moon.

Now we force ourselves to unconsciousness,
Eight hours unbroken—the industrial ideal.
But when I wake at 2 a.m., eyes clear,
I no longer fight against this ancient pattern.

In my first sleep, I touch something primal,
A connection to how humans always were,
Before we bent our bodies to the clock,
And forgot the wisdom of the bifurcated night.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
IN MY FIRST SLEEP

In my first sleep, stars gathered at my window,
whispering secrets older than language.
I was five, maybe six, when the universe
first pressed its face against my dreams.

Mother said I walked the halls those nights,
eyes open but unseeing, navigating
by maps drawn in another dimension.
Father would guide me back to bed,
tucking the blankets tight as if
they could anchor me to this world.

In my first sleep, I traveled through
ancestral memories—hunting with
great-grandfathers I never met,
singing with great-grandmothers
whose voices were lost before my birth.

Scientists say children dream differently,
their malleable minds still tethered
to the place we all come from,
that liminal space between existence and void.

Even now, decades later, I sometimes wake
with the taste of stardust on my tongue,
my fingers grasping at fragments
of that first sleep, when the boundary
between worlds was as thin
as the skin of a newborn,
as permeable as morning fog.

BIFURCATED REST
