LIQUID BETRAYAL

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon ship at the first sign of sinking.

I cry, but my tears are disloyal soldiers,
deserting the battlefield when the war turns inward.

I cry, but these droplets of liquid betrayal
refuse to witness what they were born from.

I cry, but my sorrow evaporates
before I can prove it existed at all.

I cry, but the evidence disappears,
leaving me to question if I feel anything.

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
Perhaps they know something I don't—
that some pain is too heavy
even for water to carry,
that some grief is best
not remembered.

DEAR TEARS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They were born from my sorrow
yet refuse my company.

Dear tears, why such hurry to depart?
Are you ashamed of your maker?
Do you seek better company than mine?
Or is it simply your nature to fall away?

You slide down pathways worn familiar,
yet never linger long enough
to learn the contours of my face.

Such disloyal companions—
called forth in moments of breaking,
only to abandon the broken.

Perhaps I should envy your freedom,
your ability to separate from pain,
to evaporate into something else,
to become sky instead of sorrow.

Perhaps one day, I too will learn
to leave myself behind.

WHAT REMAINS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They vanish like whispered promises,
leaving no proof of their passage.

Yet something remains after they've gone—
a clarity that only comes
when vision is briefly blurred.

Perhaps tears were never meant to stay,
their purpose not in lingering
but in the momentary release,
the washing away, the cleansing.

Like rain that falls to feed the earth
then returns to the waiting sky,
my tears complete their cycle
whether I witness their journey or not.

So I will cry when crying calls,
and I won't beg the tears to stay.
I'll thank them for their brief companionship,
their silent testimony to my humanity,
and let them go—
as all things must be released,
eventually.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
HOLLOW VESSELS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon like everything else,
slipping between fingers that once held promises,
evaporating before they can validate my pain.

The hollowness expands—
a universe of absence where even grief
refuses to make its home.

I've become so empty that sadness
cannot find purchase within me,
a desert too barren for even salt water to mark.

Perhaps this is the final loneliness:
when your own sorrow disowns you,
when the physical evidence of your breaking
vanishes before witnesses can confirm
that you were, indeed, broken.

I press palms against dry eyes,
begging for the relief of wetness,
for the company of something
that came from within me
and chose to remain.

WATERMARKS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race toward earth like they've somewhere to hide.
They streak down my face with such terrible haste,
Leaving nothing behind, not a track, not a trace.

The ocean inside me keeps rising and falling,
The tide of my grief is forever appalling.
Yet nothing remains when the storm passes through,
No evidence showing what I'm going through.

My sorrows leave no watermarks upon my skin,
No proof of the battles I fight deep within.
The world sees a face that appears calm and dry,
Never knowing how often these eyes testify.

So I weep in a silence that swallows me whole,
As even my tears won't bear witness to soul.
Alone in a crowd, with my pain unconfessed,
Abandoned by droplets my heart has expressed.

EVAPORATION

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They become mist, joining clouds
that drift away without looking back.

The rain falls elsewhere—
nourishing gardens I'll never visit,
watering flowers I didn't plant.

My grief transforms into someone else's beauty.
My pain, recycled into distant consolations.

The salt remains, though,
crystallized beneath my skin,
preserving what's left of me
like an ancient ocean bed,
dry but remembering water.

Perhaps someday the cycle will complete—
those clouds, heavy with what they took from me,
will return as gentle morning dew,
and I will recognize in their coolness
the parts of myself I thought were lost forever.

Until then, I am a shoreline
waiting for the tide to remember my name.

FAITHLESS COMPANIONS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
Faithless companions, born in my sorrow,
yet so quick to depart.

I created you from my own salt and water,
gave you passage through the windows of my soul,
entrusted you with the weight of words
I could never speak aloud.

Yet you betray me—sliding away,
disappearing into handkerchiefs,
soaking into pillowcases,
evaporating into nothing.

What loyalty should I expect?
You are merely the physical form
of something too vast to hold.

Still, I wish just once you'd linger,
stand as evidence that I am human enough to break,
strong enough to leak,
real enough to leave a mark.

Instead, you vanish,
leaving me alone
even in my weeping.

WHAT REMAINS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They journey away like all temporary things—
visitors, not residents, in this landscape of loss.

Yet in their leaving, they carve canyons,
rivers through stone, patient architects
of something more enduring than themselves.

Perhaps it's better this way—
the evidence washing clean,
leaving behind only the essential:

A face, renewed.
A vision, cleared.
A heart, hollowed out but spacious.

What remains when grief's water recedes
is not emptiness, but possibility—
the smooth stones at the bottom of the riverbed,
polished by what once flowed over them.

I am becoming a vessel shaped by absence,
readied for whatever next arrives
to fill these spaces my tears
have so graciously abandoned.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
EVAPORATION

My grief is a desert
where even sorrow refuses to linger.
I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me to this parched existence,
evaporating before they can trace
the contours of my face.

Empty-handed, I collect absences –
the ghost-weight of what should remain,
the hollow where connection should grow.
Even the salt of my sorrow
refuses to mark me as its own.

Is there loneliness more complete
than when your own body betrays you?
When the evidence of your breaking
disappears before anyone can witness it?
When your pain becomes invisible
even to yourself?

I am becoming a monument to what leaves.
A catalog of departures.
A vessel that cannot hold
even the water of its own making.

WATERLESS GRIEF

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They flee like friends who've sensed my hollow tide.
Numb to the touch, my cheeks remain bone-dry,
As emotions drown beneath an unbroken sky.

What strange betrayal of the human form,
When sorrow strikes but brings no weeping storm.
My body refuses the ritual of release,
Denying me grief's temporary peace.

Perhaps I've spent too long being strong,
Or perhaps my heart knew all along
That once the dam breaks, the flood won't cease—
So it cauterized the well, a desperate release.

I envy those whose grief pours free and clear,
Whose bodies honor pain with every tear.
I stand here desert-faced, with oceans trapped inside,
Betrayed when tears refuse to stay by my side.

PHANTOM WATERS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They join the procession of all that has left me—
my mother's voice, fading with each passing season,
my childhood home, now inhabited by strangers,
the dog who knew only my hands as gentle.

Each tear becomes another small desertion,
another lesson in the impermanence of comfort.
They roll away like marbles, these crystalline betrayers,
leaving tracks too temporary to follow home.

I've become skilled at losing,
adept at watching things depart—
first people, then memories, then even
the physical evidence of my mourning.

Perhaps there is wisdom in this:
that nothing, not even grief,
will consent to be possessed.
That even the salt of my sorrow
knows better than to remain.

THE MIGRATION OF SORROWS

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They grow tiny feet and scurry across the floor,
collecting in the corners where dust gathers.
Sometimes they sprout wings, translucent and trembling,
and flutter toward the ceiling like confused moths.

Last Tuesday, I found one tear swimming
in my coffee cup, diluting my morning ritual.
Another had frozen itself to the bathroom mirror,
a tiny glacier of unwitnessed pain.

My neighbor reports seeing them in her garden—
my wayward tears watering her reluctant roses.
The weatherman warns of unusual precipitation:
"Someone's sorrows are gathering in the atmosphere."

I've set traps along the baseboards,
little cups of salt to draw them home.
But they've tasted freedom now, my rebellious griefs,
and they refuse to belong to me anymore.

IMPERMANENCE

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side—
Like morning dew that vanishes by noon,
Like cherry blossoms scattered by April winds,
Like the moon's reflection broken by a stone.

The world teaches impermanence through small departures:
Footprints in sand erased by tireless waves,
Breath becoming visible then invisible in winter air,
Fireflies signaling briefly before the darkness claims them again.

Perhaps there is mercy in this constant leaving—
How the body releases what it cannot bear to hold,
How grief transforms itself from solid to liquid to air,
How nature refuses to let anything stagnate, even pain.

So I will honor these tears that will not remain,
These temporary witnesses to my human heart.
Their leaving is their wisdom, their gift to me—
Teaching that nothing, not even sorrow, is mine to keep.

I Hunted Words Of Skill

Some days I returned empty-handed, spent,

I Hunted Words Of Skill

I hunted words of skill

I Hunted Words Of Skill

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

responses.text:

DIGITAL EXPEDITION

We are all hunters now, in this wilderness of information.

Hashtags like trail markers, search engines our guides,

APPRENTICE'S INCANTATION

I hunted words of skill
when masters said I never would.

WHISPERS FROM THE VOID

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

responses.text:
THE LEXICAL HUNTER

I hunted words of skill through forests of old tomes,

Now my cabin walls are lined with mounted meter,

WORDSMITH'S PILGRIMAGE

I hunted words of skill
in crowded marketplaces of conversation,

I hunted words of skill
beneath ocean depths of meditation,

I hunted words of skill
among the ruins of abandoned poems,

I hunted words of skill

SPELLCRAFT

I hunted words of skill beneath moonlit skies

Now I stand atop the mountain, tongue heavy

DIGITAL EXPEDITION

Hashtags became breadcrumbs leading deeper in

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

responses.text:
THE LEXICAL HUNTER

Now I build sanctuaries of stanzas

WORDSMITH'S APPRENTICE

I hunted words of skill

They breathe, they dance, they sing, they sting.

So I learned patience, sitting still as stone
While verbs darted past like silver fish,

Years passed. My hands grew calloused but sure.
What once was hunting became conversation—
The words no longer fled from my approach

Now I craft spells from willing phrases,

The hunt transformed to collaboration,

And sometimes, in dreams, I remember

DIGITAL EXPEDITION

I hunted words of skill
across the glowing wasteland
of my screen at 3 a.m.,
chasing elusive eloquence
through the labyrinth of language.

Keyboard clicks like footsteps

Backspace—my eraser of mistakes,
deleting failed attempts

Once, we carved meanings into stone,

each medium demanding its own reverence.
Now my fingertips conjure and vanish

In this age of infinite text,

I hunt not just for skill

ANCESTRAL TONGUES

I hunted words of skill

THE SILENCE BETWEEN

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

WORDSMITH'S ALCHEMY

through dictionaries vast as oceans,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
SOLITUDE'S EMBRACE

She lies alone upon her bed,
Thoughts like autumn leaves scattered,
Dancing through chambers of her mind.
The ceiling—a canvas for projections
Of what was and what might be.

Moonlight filters through lace curtains,
Painting silver across her still form.
The world outside continues its symphony,
But here, in this room, time suspends
In the space between heartbeats.

Her fingers trace invisible patterns
On cool sheets that hold no memory
Of another's warmth. Yet in solitude
She finds her borders, rediscovers
The geography of her own soul.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Not abandoned, but sovereign—
A queen in the kingdom of herself,
Crowning silence with meaning,
Transforming absence into strength.

THE FEVER DREAM

She lies alone upon her bed,
Burning with celestial fire.
The sickness bends reality—
Walls breathe, shadows whisper
Secrets from distant stars.

Sweat-damp sheets twist like serpents
Around limbs that have forgotten
Their earthly purpose. Time fractures,
Expands, contracts with each labored breath.
Memories bleed into hallucination.

In this delirium, she travels
Between worlds without moving.
Ancestors gather in corners,
Their voices a chorus guiding her
Through fever's labyrinth.

Perhaps this is how transformation begins—
In surrender, in breaking apart.
She lies alone upon her bed,
A chrysalis of flesh and bone,
Dying into something new.

AFTER HE LEFT

She lies alone upon her bed,
The indent where he used to sleep
Still visible, a geography
Of absence she cannot smooth away.

The room holds echoes of arguments,
Of laughter, of bodies finding home.
Now silence hangs heavy as fog,
Settling into every corner.

Outside, the city continues—
Lights flicker on in neighboring windows,
Cars rush toward destinations,
Lovers meet under streetlamps.

She traces the constellation
Of water stains on the ceiling,
Renames them after everything
She never said aloud.

Tomorrow, she will change the sheets,
Open windows to new air.
But tonight, she allows herself
To inhabit this hollow space completely.

COSMIC DREAMER

She lies alone upon her bed,
But boundaries of flesh dissolve
As consciousness expands beyond
The prison of ordinary perception.

Her body: a vessel temporarily vacant,
While her essence traverses dimensions,
Dances with nebulae, converses with planets,
Remembering her cosmic inheritance.

In dreams, she collects stardust,
Writes equations of universal harmony
With fingers that touch both infinity
And the mundane cotton of her pillowcase.

The mystics spoke of such journeys—
How the soul, unfettered by daylight logic,
Returns to its original vastness.
She has always known this truth.

Morning will reclaim her eventually,
But something of the stars remains,
Glittering behind her eyes
As she moves through earthly days.

THE WITNESS

She lies alone upon her bed.
I watch from across the street,
Binoculars focused on the frame
Of her window—a living portrait.

She doesn't draw the curtains.
Perhaps she doesn't know I'm here,
Or perhaps this is a performance—
Her solitude a silent challenge.

I've catalogued her habits:
The book she reads before sleeping,
How she braids her hair precisely,
The way she stares at nothing.

Sometimes I imagine crossing the distance,
Knocking on her door, confessing
This obsession that consumes me.
Instead, I remain in shadows.

What keeps me here night after night?
Not desire, but recognition—
In her isolation, I see reflected
The contours of my own emptiness.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
Moonlight painting silver on her hair,
A universe contained within her head,
Wandering galaxies without a care.

Dreams cascade like meteor showers,
Behind eyelids fluttering with light,
Her solitude holds hidden powers,
As she traverses through the night.

The empty space beside her form
Is not a void but possibility,
A canvas waiting for the storm
Of tomorrow's wild intensity.

For in this quiet, sacred hour,
She's not alone but truly free,
Recharging like a sleeping flower,
Becoming who she's meant to be.

She lies alone upon her bed,
The weight of absence crushing chest.
Echoes of words once said
Haunt corners where his clothes once rest.

Four walls witness silent tears
That carve canyons down her face.
The clock marks hours like years,
This room, her exile place.

Sheets cold where warmth once lived,
A phantom limb still aching deep.
Love's memory—unforgiving—
Denies the mercy of her sleep.

Yet dawn will break despite her pain,
And time will soften grief's sharp edge.
From broken hearts, we rise again,
Though now she can't imagine this pledge.

She lies alone upon her bed
A warrior resting from the fray
The battle scars invisible but red
Another victory claimed today.

Against the illness in her bones
Against the doctors' grim forecast
Against the pain that no one knows
She fights a war designed to last.

Her weapons: pills in orange vials
Her armor: hope that will not fade
Her strength revealed in subtle smiles
When asked about the progress made.

Tomorrow brings another test
Another chance to prove them wrong
Tonight she earns her healing rest
Preserving fire that burns so strong.

She lies alone upon her bed
While city lights perform their dance
A thousand stories overhead
In stars obscured by circumstance.

The urban symphony plays on—
Sirens, laughter, distant trains—
The soundtrack to her thoughts upon
Life's unexpected joys and pains.

Her fingers scroll through digital seas
Of others' lives displayed with care
While wondering if her soul's disease
Is knowing others are not there.

Connection in disconnection's age
A paradox she contemplates
As sleep arrives to turn the page
On loneliness that isolates.

She lies alone upon her bed
—the bed observes with patient wood—
I've held her form since she was wed
I've witnessed more than others could.

I cradled her when life began
Within her womb, those sleepless nights
I steadied her when grief's harsh hand
Collapsed her world despite her fights.

I've felt the dampness of her tears
And trembled with her lovers' joy
I've been the constant through the years
As time worked hard to build, destroy.

She lies alone upon me now
Her silver hair spread like a crown
I hold her gently, as her bough
Until the day she lays fully down.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
MIDNIGHT SOLILOQUY

She lies alone upon her bed,
Moonlight painting shadows on the wall.
Echoes of conversations unsaid
Haunt the chambers of her recall.

The clock's hands move with solemn grace,
Ticking away what cannot return.
Memories flood the empty space
Where love once flickered, bright to burn.

She counts the cracks along the ceiling,

Of how the present bends and flees.

Her fingers trace the vacant sheet,
The hollow where his shape should be.
The ghost of touch, bitter yet sweet,
A phantom dance of memory.

She wonders if he thinks of her
In some distant, unfamiliar place.
If in his dreams, her face occurs,
Or if new loves have left no trace.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Not sleeping, simply being still.
Learning to live with what's unsaid,
And slowly bending to her will.

CHRYSALIS

She lies alone upon her bed,
A garden of fever blooms beneath her skin.
The illness that once threatened has fled,
Leaving her hollow, ready to begin.

Sunlight filters through gauzy curtains,
Painting her new world in gentle gold.
What emerges after pain's certain?
What shape takes the spirit, once controlled?

Yesterday's woman has dissolved away,
Cells rearranged by suffering's tide.
The cocoon of sheets where she lay
Witnesses the transformation inside.

Strength returns not as it was before—
But strange and magnificent, newly formed.
Like a river finding a different shore,
Her essence shifts, beautifully transformed.

Her fingers, once weak, now slowly reach
Toward the ceiling, testing newfound power.
The lessons that only breaking can teach
Bloom within her, a resilient flower.

She rises now from where she's lain,
A phoenix with still-drying wings.
Reborn through the crucible of pain,
To discover what tomorrow brings.

THE WAITING ROOM

She lies alone upon her bed,
Three thousand miles from where you sleep.
Across oceans and continents spread
Promises too fragile to keep.

The digital clock glows merciless red,
Calculating the hours between.
She refreshes messages left unread,
Searching for words that might convene.

Outside her window, a city breathes,
Indifferent to her private war.
The distance between you both seethes
With possibilities closing each door.

She crafts a life in your absence—
Career advancing, friendships tight.
Yet in twilight's persistent resonance,
Your ghost appears in fading light.

She wonders how long hearts can suspend
Between devotion and letting go.
If love's elastic will finally bend
Or snap beneath time's steady blow.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Half-present in two different worlds.
One where your future together spreads,
One where independence unfurls.

WINTER'S DAUGHTER

She lies alone upon her bed,
Ninety-three years etched upon her face.
The winter's frost creeps 'round her head,
Silver crowning her with time's embrace.

Her hands—once strong, once soft, once skilled—
Rest lightly on the handmade quilt.
The room contains the life she's filled
With choices made and houses built.

Photographs crowd the bedside table,
Faces young that now are old or gone.
She remembers each, as much as able,
Their stories threaded through her dawn.

The window frames the falling snow,
Silent as the passing years.
She watches crystals come and go,
Transient as human fears.

She doesn't fear the coming night,
Having witnessed countless suns descend.
Her breathing slows, growing slight,
Ready for beginning or for end.

She lies alone upon her bed,
But solitude is not loneliness.
A universe contained inside her head
Expands beyond time's fineness.

DREAMWALKER

She lies alone upon her bed,
But only her body remains earthbound.
Her spirit soars, silver threads
Connecting worlds without a sound.

Beyond the ceiling, beyond the sky,
She travels realms of shifting light.
Where logic bends and colors fly,
Free from daylight's rigid might.

In dreamscape kingdoms she commands
Powers daylight never permitted.
She builds and destroys with phantom hands,
Rules broken, remade, then transmitted.

She meets herself in mirrored lakes,
Younger, older, never born.
Discards the paths she never takes,
Revisits choices, unmade, unworn.

She dances with shadows of might-have-beens,
Converses with those long departed.
Navigates labyrinths unseen,
Explores the wild and uncharted.

Morning will come with its mundane call,
Pulling her back to flesh and bone.
But for now, she soars beyond the wall,
In midnight realms entirely her own.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
THE SILENT HOURS

She lies alone upon her bed,
Silver moonlight on silver hair,
Tracking shadows that crawl like time
Across walls that have witnessed years.

Fingers trace the quilt's patterned map,
Each stitch a memory preserved—
Children's laughter, a husband's touch,
Dances shared on forgotten floors.

The house creaks its familiar song,
A symphony of settled beams,
While photographs watch from shelves,
Faces fading like evening light.

She counts heartbeats instead of sheep,
Each pulse an echo of the past,
When beds weren't islands in the night
But continents of shared warmth.

Morning will come with tea and toast,
Routines that anchor drifting days.
But in this moment between worlds,
She sails on seas of remembrance.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Not lonely, but beautifully complete—
A universe contained in bones
That carried life and now carry on.

DREAMWEAVER

She lies alone upon her bed,
But solitude is just a door
Through which her spirit freely soars
Beyond the ceiling, past the clouds.

Her eyelids, curtains to the world,
Conceal the journeys of her mind—
Where constellations bend to touch
The fingertips of her desires.

In daylight hours, they call her shy,
This quiet woman with downcast eyes.
They cannot see the universes
She architects when darkness falls.

Cities of light and crystal spires,
Oceans where mermaids know her name,
Forests where trees bow as she passes,
Mountains that whisper ancient truths.

The pillow cradles cosmic thoughts,
The blanket warms a voyager
Whose soul traverses realms unknown
While others merely count their breaths.

She lies alone upon her bed—
A sorceress, a queen, a god—
Creating worlds with every dream
That others might someday glimpse in art.

MENDING

She lies alone upon her bed,
A shipwreck survivor on shore,
The tempest of his leaving now
A distant thunder in her chest.

The sheets still hold the shape of two,
A phantom limb she can't ignore.
Each night a lesson in relearning
How to occupy this space.

The first week, tears mapped territories
Of grief across her pillow's landscape.
The second, anger burned the maps
And left her hollow as a drum.

By month's end, silence was a friend
Who asked for nothing, gave the same.
She learned to stretch across the mattress,
Claiming inches lost to love.

Today, she planted red geraniums,
Laughed at something on the radio,
Wrote her name without his attached,
And felt the fracture start to heal.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Body curved like a question mark
Slowly straightening to an exclamation—
The punctuation of becoming.

MIDNIGHT ARITHMETIC

She lies alone upon her bed,
Counting anxieties like sheep.
Three bills unpaid, divide by hope,
Multiply by consequences.

The ceiling's cracks form equations
That her restless mind can't solve.
The fan's rotation measures hours,
Subtracting rest with every turn.

Outside, the city never sleeps,
Its lights a morse code of insomnia.
Sirens wail the common language
Of urban night's mathematics.

Four walls contract with each breath,
The room an ever-shrinking box.
She calculates escape velocities,
The force required to break orbit.

Digital numbers glow accusingly:
2:17, 3:42, 4:05—
Each increment a small defeat
In the battle against dawn.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A prisoner of consciousness,
Solving for x in darkness where
x equals peace, and peace eludes.

CHRYSALIS

She lies alone upon her bed,
Roots growing from her fingertips,
Seeking soil through mattress springs,
Ancient wisdom through modern frames.

Her breath exhales as morning mist,
Condensing on the windowpane.
Her heartbeat syncs with distant tides
That she has never seen but knows.

The ceiling blooms with wildflowers,
Painted by her dreaming eyes.
Butterflies emerge from corners
Where shadows pooled like standing time.

Her body, vessel and terrain,
A landscape changing with the moon.
The blood that courses through her veins
Is river water, sweet and wild.

The world outside may call this sleep,
This sacred transformation space,
Not seeing how she dissolves and forms,
Dying nightly to be reborn.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A priestess in communion with
The universe that dwells within—
The cosmos in a human form.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
SOLITUDE'S EMBRACE

She lies alone upon her bed,
Thoughts like shadows on the wall,
Dancing to the rhythm of silence
That fills the empty hall.

Moonlight streams through parted curtains,
Painting silver on her skin,
A celestial visitor
Where human touch has never been.

The clock ticks forward, never back,
Minutes fall like autumn leaves.
Her breath creates the only wind
In this garden of reprieve.

Memories visit uninvited,
Ghosts that never learned to knock,
They slip between the folded sheets,
And whisper what the heart forgot.

She counts the cracks along the ceiling,
Maps constellations in the paint,
Finds universes in the patterns
Where loneliness grows faint.

In solitude, she finds her strength,
In emptiness, a kind of peace,
For in the quiet of her room,
She learns that she is all she needs.

FEVER DREAMS

She lies alone upon her bed,
Burning with a fever's fire.
The world outside continues on,
While hers has shrunk to four pale walls.

The ceiling swirls with phantom shapes,
As sweat beads crown her furrowed brow.
Time loses meaning, stretches thin—
An hour? A day? She cannot tell.

The doctor's words hang in the air,
"Rest now," they said, "This too shall pass."
But in the grip of illness' hand,
Eternity feels trapped in glass.

She drifts between two worlds at once:
Reality and something else,
Where colors speak and shadows sing
And pain transforms to strange delight.

Beneath her skin, a battle rages,
Cells at war with invaders,
Yet in her dreams, she's dancing free
Across a field of endless stars.

Tomorrow may bring wellness back,
Or deeper into fever's hold,
But even in this suffering,
A strange beauty unfolds.

THE WAITING

She lies alone upon her bed,
Letters scattered by her side,
Each one worn from reading twice,
Then thrice, then more—his words her guide.

The war has taken him so far,
Across an ocean, past the stars,
Or so it seems when nights grow long
And silence deepens all her scars.

"Be brave," he wrote, "I'll soon return."
Three seasons since those words arrived.
The radio speaks of battles won,
But not of those who've survived.

She keeps his picture by the lamp,
Smiling in his pressed uniform,
A moment frozen before goodbye,
Before the world was torn.

Each passing car, each knock, each ring,
Sets her heart to racing wild.
Is this the moment he returns?
Or news that steals her smile?

She lies alone upon her bed,
Hope wrapped around her like a shawl,
Faith her only company
As darkness claims the hall.

DREAMWEAVER

She lies alone upon her bed
But solitude is just illusion,
For worlds unfold behind closed eyes—
A universe of her creation.

Reality may claim the day
With duties, tasks, and expectations,
But nightfall brings her freedom's key
To unlock boundless explorations.

Tonightʼs journey takes her sailing
On ships with sails of spider silk,
Across a sea of liquid stars
Where mermaids sing of ancient guilt.

She climbs the peaks of candy mountains,
Dances with wolves of gentle heart,
Converses with the moon herself
About the secrets of her art.

In dreams, she wields a painter's brush
That colors skies with emotions,
Blending courage with desire,
Stirring celestial oceans.

So pity not the sleeping form
Who seems abandoned to the night,
For in her mind, she's never alone—
A queen of realms beyond our sight.

METAMORPHOSIS

She lies alone upon her bed,
A chrysalis of flesh and bone,
Shedding the person she once was—
A self now outgrown.

The ceiling watches, witness to
The silent revolution within,
As she dismantles every truth
That once lived beneath her skin.

Yesterday's certainties fall away
Like autumn leaves from dying trees.
She welcomes the essential death
That transformation guarantees.

Tears carve rivers down her temples,
Not of sorrow, but release,
As she surrenders to becoming—
Pain and wonder intertwined.

The world outside continues spinning,
Unaware of magic taking place,
How ordinary rooms transform
To sacred, liminal space.

By morning light, she'll rise anew,
Not finished, but forever changed,
Reborn through night's dark alchemy,
Her spirit rearranged.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
MIDNIGHT REVERIE

She lies alone upon her bed,
Moonlight painting silver on her face,
Thoughts like constellations spreading
Across the dark canvas of her mind.

The clock ticks accusations into silence.
Four walls witness her quiet breathing,
The rise and fall of dreams deferred,
Of conversations never spoken.

She counts the shadows on her ceiling,
Each one a memory she cannot shake—
The touch of hands now absent,
The weight of words now hollow.

Yet in this solitude, she finds
A curious kind of freedom:
The space to stretch her limbs and soul,
To claim each inch of cotton kingdom.

She crafts new worlds behind closed eyes,
Populates them with possibilities,
Until dawn breaks through curtain cracks,
And reality gently beckons.

She lies alone upon her bed,
But solitude is not the same as lonely—
Sometimes the universe exists
In the quiet spaces between heartbeats.

FEVER DREAMS

She lies alone upon her bed,
Sheets twisted like ancient maps,
Leading nowhere and everywhere.
Fever paints her skin with watercolor heat.

The ceiling fan spins stories
She's too weak to catch,
Whispering promises of cooler days
When her body will remember itself again.

Time becomes liquid here,
Hours dripping through cracked fingers,
Morning, evening blur together
In the haze of medicine and memory.

Visitors come as ghosts—
Some real, some conjured—
Leaving impressions of concern
That fade like footprints in sand.

In delirium she travels
To childhood rooms and future homes,
To places that exist only
In the geography of her mind.

She lies alone upon her bed,
But illness is a crowded country—
Populated by pain and patience,
By the slow crawl toward healing.

Tomorrow, perhaps, she'll rise
And claim again her solid self.
Tonight, she drifts between worlds,
Anchorless but not afraid.

THE WIDOW'S VIGIL

She lies alone upon her bed,
The left side still neatly pressed,
As if preserving the impression
Of a body five years gone.

Widowhood is a foreign language
She never wanted to learn,
Yet now she speaks it fluently—
The grammar of absence,
The vocabulary of grief.

Night stretches before her,
An ocean of hours to navigate
Without the lighthouse of his breathing.
She clutches his pillow, inhaling—
Searching for molecules of him
That science says cannot remain.

Outside, the world continues:
Children grow, seasons change,
Streets fill and empty with strangers.
Inside, time moves differently,
Circling like a patient vulture.

Yet something green and tender
Grows within this desolation—
A resilience she never knew she owned.

She lies alone upon her bed,
But carries within her ribs
A constellation of memories,
Brighter than any star
Visible from her window.

DIGITAL DREAMER

She lies alone upon her bed,
Face illuminated by the electric glow
Of a screen that promises connection
In this disconnected age.

Thumb scrolling through filtered lives,
Curated moments of strangers and friends,
While her own reality sits quiet,
Undocumented, unfiltered, unseen.

Notifications ping like modern prayers,
Little dopamine rewards for existence.
She crafts careful responses,
A digital performance of selfhood.

Beyond her window, stars struggle
Against city light pollution,
As authentic as the freckles
She photoshops away each morning.

Is loneliness still loneliness
When surrounded by virtual voices?
Is solitude the same when shared
With followers and friends lists?

She lies alone upon her bed,
Tethered to the world by invisible strings,
Wandering through endless corridors
Of a house built from ones and zeros.

Tonight, she'll power down early,
Watch shadows play across her ceiling,
And remember what it feels like
To be unobserved but fully present.

CHRYSALIS

She lies alone upon her bed,
A butterfly mid-transformation,
Neither what she was
Nor what she will become.

The old skin of expectations
Shed like unwanted clothes—
Too tight across the shoulders,
Too narrow in the heart.

She's learning to inhabit
This in-between existence,
This sacred pause between
Departure and arrival.

The world outside her door
Continues its impatient dance,
Demanding participation,
Resolutions, forward motion.

But wisdom grows in stillness,
In these fallow hours of waiting,
In the courage to remain
Unfinished and becoming.

She traces patterns on her palms,
Maps of possible futures,
Rivers of potential flowing
From this moment of surrender.

She lies alone upon her bed,
And in this solitary cocoon,
She gathers strength for flight,
For the unfolding of new wings.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
DESCENT

Per me si va nella citta dolente—
Through me you enter the city of sorrow.
The ancient words carved in stone remain,
though I wear no robes, carry no candle.

Modern Virgil, I navigate concrete canyons,
where skyscrapers replace stalactites,
and the damned wear business casual.
The circles of hell redrawn as subway lines.

What suffering have we reimagined?
The gluttony of consumption,
the greed of golden penthouses,
the violence of indifference.

I descend escalators instead of rocky paths,
pass through turnstiles, not infernal gates,
yet the journey remains the same—
downward, always downward.

The city of sorrow breathes around me,
its pulse the rhythm of forgotten footsteps,
its voice the whispers of those who believed
they were building paradise.

Abandon hope, the poet warned,
but I carry mine like contraband,
a small flame cupped against the wind
as I navigate this modern inferno.

THROUGH THE DOORWAY OF GRIEF

Per me si va nella citta dolente.
Through me is the passage to sorrow's domain.

I did not choose this journey,
yet here I stand at grief's threshold,
where breath becomes shallow
and memories turn to stone.

They did not tell me how ordinary
this city would appear—
the same sun rising over rooftops,
the same moon pulling at absent tides.

Yet everything is altered.
Colors drain like water through fingers.
Voices reach me as if through glass.
Time bends and fractures around corners.

In this city of lament,
I learn a new language:
the syntax of absence,
the grammar of what remains.

My heart, once a compass,
now spins without direction.
I wander streets named for what was lost,
tracing the map of what can never return.

Per me si va—through me, the way forward.
Even in the city of sorrow,
footsteps still echo,
leaving impressions in the dust.

RUST BELT REQUIEM

Per me si va nella citta dolente.
Through these abandoned factory gates,
you enter the city of sorrows.

Once, furnaces breathed fire and promise.
Now, broken windows stare like vacant eyes
across parking lots where weeds
claim victory through concrete cracks.

This American inferno of forgotten labor,
where pension dreams rust alongside machinery,
and opioids flow like the rivers
that once carried coal and commerce.

The diner still serves coffee in chipped mugs
to ghosts dressed in work shirts,
men who measure their worth
in shifts that no longer exist.

Children play in the shadows of shuttered mills,
inheriting a geography of absence,
learning early that some hells
are built through boardroom decisions.

I walk these streets named for prosperity—
Progress Avenue, Industry Road—
ironic markers of a paradise lost
to offshore accounts and shareholder value.

Yet in this dolente city,
some plant gardens in abandoned lots,
a defiant green against the gray decay,
a different kind of revolution.

CARTOGRAPHY OF SHADOWS

Per me si va nella citta dolente—
a whisper between dimensions,
an invitation written in smoke.

The city of sorrow exists
in the space between heartbeats,
in the static between radio stations,
in the pause before answering difficult questions.

Its architecture defies physics:
stairways spiral into themselves,
rooms expand with each entry,
streets rearrange when you look away.

The residents wear faces
that shift like reflections in disturbed water.
They speak in languages composed of
sighs, silences, and forgotten lullabies.

Time moves differently here—
sometimes thick as honey,
sometimes quick as mercury,
always measured in losses, not hours.

I have visited this city in dreams,
in fever, in the depths of winter nights.
I have brought back artifacts:
a hollowness beneath the ribs,
a taste of ash upon waking,
a shadow that doesn't quite match my movements.

Per me si va—through me, the passage.
I am both the doorway and the traveler,
the city and its reluctant cartographer.

BEYOND THE GATES

Per me si va nella citta dolente.
The warning etched above the archway,
yet I enter with eyes wide open,
seeing what Dante could not.

Yes, there is sorrow here—
in abandoned corners where hope collapsed,
in the eyes of those who carry invisible burdens,
in systems designed to crush rather than cradle.

But watch how sunlight persists
through narrow alleys between tall sorrows.
Notice how children find playgrounds
in the rubble of broken promises.

Even in the city of pain,
windows bloom with geraniums,
music escapes from basement clubs,
laughter erupts unexpected as summer rain.

Dante saw only circles descending,
but I find spirals that sometimes climb.
He documented punishment eternal;
I witness resilience renewable.

Per me si va—through me, the passage,
not just into darkness but through it.
If this is hell, then know this truth:
even here, we create constellations,
mapping our way with light we generate ourselves,
navigating toward something
the old poet never imagined possible.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
GATES OF THE MODERN INFERNO

Through me lies the city of sorrow,
Where souls scroll endlessly through digital despair.
Smartphone glow illuminates hollow faces,
Each swipe a step deeper into the abyss.

Connection promised, yet isolation delivered—
Through me lies the path to eternal noise,
The cacophony of a thousand voices
Speaking without being heard.

In this concrete inferno, we wander,
Circles of fluorescent lights our guides,
Desperately seeking meaning in the void,
As advertisements scream salvation.

Through me lies the city of the lost,
Where we trade our hours for paper promises,
Where dreams are commodified and sold back to us,
And time—our most precious coin—slips away.

Enter, for you have already arrived;
You carry this hell within your pocket.

DOLENTE

I carry grief like a city within me,
Its streets mapped in blue veins beneath my skin.
Each heartbeat, a reluctant citizen
Traversing avenues of remembrance.

Through me lies the passage to sorrow,
A metropolis built from absence,
Where memories hang like laundry
Between buildings of regret.

I have become the gatekeeper
Of my own suffering—
Doorways open to rooms
Where your ghost still lingers.

The architecture of loss
Is both ancient and new;
I am both visitor and monument
In this landscape of lament.

Through me, through me, through me—
A mantra of survival,
As I learn to inhabit
This sorrowful city I've become.

URBAN DECAY

Through me lies the forgotten metropolis,
Where dreams rust like abandoned factories.
Windows boarded, hope foreclosed,
Promises vacant as empty storefronts.

The city breathes pollution and poverty,
Its concrete skin cracked and weeping.
Once-proud towers bow their heads,
Monuments to capitalism's casualties.

Children play in shadows of what could have been,
Their laughter echoing against indifference.
Elders remember when these streets held promise,
Before policy and neglect carved out its heart.

Through me lies the way to systematic sorrow,
Redlined neighborhoods and food deserts,
Where sirens sing the city's broken lullaby,
And opportunity feels like mythology.

Yet beneath the surface, resistance grows—
Community gardens in vacant lots,
Murals blooming on condemned walls,
A new city waiting to emerge from dolence.

PASSAGE

Through me lies the city of sorrow,
But do not fear to enter its gates.
For only by walking these shadowed streets
Can you find the path that liberates.

The river of tears that cuts through downtown
Eventually flows to the healing sea.
The tower of grief that scrapes the sky
Offers vistas your heart needs to see.

In the museum of loss, exhibits change;
What once paralyzed now instructs.
The theater of pain stages tragedies
That teach compassion's gentle flux.

Through me lies necessary darkness,
A darkness that nurtures the light.
For joy cannot exist without knowing
The depth and texture of night.

So enter this dolorous city—
Not to dwell, but to pass through.
Its citizenship is temporary,
Its lessons, eternally true.

ONTOLOGICAL TRANSIT

Through me one enters the city of suffering—
Not a place, but a state of consciousness,
A realm we all inhabit between breaths,
Between the synaptic firing of thought.

What is this dolorous metropolis
But the awareness of our own impermanence?
Streets paved with the paradox of existence,
Buildings constructed from questions without answers.

We are simultaneously citizen and city,
The observed and observer of our own condition.
Dante knew this when he placed those words
Not just on Hell's gate, but on the human heart.

For what is more universal than passage?
What journey more inevitable than through pain?
The city dolente exists because we exist—
A necessary geography of being.

Through me, through you, through us all,
The way unfolds, neither cruel nor kind,
Simply present, like the space between stars,
Defining by distance what cannot be named.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
THRESHOLD

Per me si va nella citta dolente—
Through me you enter the grieving city,
where ancient words carve stone warnings
and hope abandons those who cross.

I stand at this archway, fingertips tracing
letters worn by centuries of tears.
What circles await below? What shadows
dance in flames that never consume?

Dante knew of descents, of guides
who lead us through our necessary hells.
He knew that to reach paradise
we must first witness suffering's architecture.

I hesitate, one foot suspended
between the world I know
and the city of lamentations.
The air shifts, grows heavy with memory.

Perhaps all journeys of consequence
begin with such a threshold—
a moment when we choose to enter
our own dolente cities, eyes wide open.

DOWNTOWN DETROIT, 2AM

Per me si va nella citta dolente.
The neon sign flickers above the abandoned theater,
its Italian letters a strange prophecy
for this American wasteland.

Rust-belt desperation hangs in the air
like industrial exhaust. Broken windows
watch me pass, their glass teeth jagged
against midnight's hollow cheek.

Emptied factories stand as cathedrals
to forgotten prosperity. Each shuttered storefront
a circle of hell Dante never imagined—
the inferno of economic collapse.

Yet in this concrete underworld,
music still pulses from underground clubs,
graffiti blooms like defiant flowers,
and hands still reach for other hands.

Even in the city of sorrows,
beauty persists in rebellion.
I walk deeper into its wounded heart,
where redemption waits in unexpected corners.

GRIEF'S GEOGRAPHY

Per me si va nella citta dolente—
the doctor's voice becomes a gateway
as she delivers the diagnosis,
and suddenly I am crossing over.

The city of sorrow has no map
but I learn its streets by heart:
Chemotherapy Avenue, Radiation Road,
the cul-de-sac of waiting rooms.

Time moves differently here.
Clocks tick in slow motion while
calendar pages burn too quickly.
I count my life in vials and doses.

Other citizens nod as we pass,
recognizing the same haunted look,
the same passport stamps on our souls.
We speak the dialect of survival.

Dante wrote of nine circles,
but grief's architecture is more complex—
a labyrinth that changes daily,
where exit signs appear and vanish.

Yet even here, in the city of pain,
sunlight sometimes breaks through.

DIGITAL INFERNO

Per me si va nella citta dolente.
I swipe to unlock my phone, enter
the city of endless sorrow, where
notifications fall like acid rain.

Circle One: The Timeline—
where friends display curated happiness
while I scroll through my inadequacy,
comparing my reality to their filtered lives.

Circle Two: The Comments—
where strangers tear each other apart
with keyboard claws, their words
leaving digital wounds that never heal.

Circle Three: The News Feed—
where tragedies compete for attention
and compassion fatigue builds walls
around hearts too broken to feel more.

Dante had Virgil to guide him,
but I navigate alone through
this hellscape we've created,
addicted to the very thing that torments.

Yet even in this electronic inferno,
I search for genuine connection—
a message from someone who sees me,
a bridge across the virtual void.

THE ARCHAEOLOGIST'S MEDITATION

Per me si va nella citta dolente—
I translate as I brush dust
from pottery shards, uncovering
Pompeii's fossilized screams.

The grieving city preserves its dead
in perfect postures of terror,
children and lovers frozen mid-embrace,
their last breaths captured in ash.

I catalog suffering with scientific precision:
dog still chained to post,
pregnant woman clutching belly,
baker never returning to his ovens.

Time collapses as I walk these streets.
Two thousand years become nothing.
Disaster recognizes no epoch—
Vesuvius could be any modern catastrophe.

At night in my tent, I dream
of cities built on fault lines,
of civilizations blind to their precarity,
of our shared human vulnerability.

Through me you go into the grieving city—
the past whispers to the future,
and I am merely the translator,
recording what the dead still need to say.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
THRESHOLD

Through me you pass into the city of grief,
Where cobblestones weep beneath ashen skies,
And monuments of regret stand tall and stark.
I am the gate that separates light from shadow,
The threshold between what was and what remains.

Here, memories hang like tattered flags
From buildings carved of ancient pain.
The river that bisects this realm
Runs thick with tears of the forgotten.

Yet still they come, the pilgrims of remorse,
Clutching maps that lead nowhere but inward.
They whisper my name as they enter,
As if permission could absolve their trespassing.

I offer no comfort, only passage.
I promise no return, only descent.
For once you've walked these streets of sorrow,
You carry their dust within your lungs forever.

Per me si va nella città dolente—
Through me, the journey has no end.

METROPOLITAN PURGATORY

Through me you enter the dolorous metropolis,
Where neon signs flicker like dying stars
And subway trains howl through arterial tunnels.

Here, the homeless prophet mutters Dante
Between sips of forgotten sacraments,
While suited specters swipe their plastic indulgences.

The city devours its children each morning,
Regurgitates them each evening,
Exhausted and hollowed by fluorescent eternity.

We build our own circles here,
Concentric rings of privilege and desperation,
Each believing we're climbing when we're descending.

I too once entered this concrete inferno,
Thinking ambition would be my salvation,
Only to find myself another shade,
Another echo in the canyon of glass and steel.

Yet even in this urban underworld,
Sometimes a flower cracks the sidewalk's resolve,
And we remember what mercy feels like.

THROUGH THE GATES

Through me lies the city of sorrows,
Yet I am not what Dante described—
I am the necessary darkness
Before transformation begins its work.

The pain you feel as you cross my threshold
Is not punishment but awakening.
The tears that fall on these ancient stones
Water the seeds of your becoming.

Yes, there are wails here, and gnashing of teeth,
But listen closer: beneath the lamentations,
A different music plays—the subtle harmony
Of souls shedding what no longer serves them.

The city of sorrows has many districts,
Each one a lesson waiting to be learned.
Some visitors linger for years in its shadows,
Others pass through like summer rain.

So enter, if you dare, with eyes wide open.
This journey through grief leads not to damnation
But to that most sacred of destinations:
The country of your own resilient heart.

INTERIOR CARTOGRAPHY

Per me si va nella città dolente—
Through me one enters the grieving city.
I have become that gate, that dark passage
Leading to the landscape of my own making.

I map the coordinates of regret daily,
Charting the rise and fall of remembered sins.
Here lies the district where I failed her;
There stands the monument to words unspoken.

I am citizen, architect, and prisoner
Of this internal metropolis of pain.
Its walls built from childhood disappointments,
Its rivers flowing with adult compromises.

Sometimes I glimpse tourists at the perimeter—
Those who claim to know me but have never
Ventured past the carefully maintained façades
Into these labyrinthine streets of truth.

Each night I walk these avenues alone,
A Virgil with no Dante to guide,
Wondering if redemption might be found
Not in escaping this city, but in embracing it.

THE DREAM COLLECTOR'S DOMAIN

Through me you enter the sorrowful city,
Where clocks melt against impossible architecture
And doorways open into childhood bedrooms.

The Dream Collector greets you at the plaza,
His coat of peacock feathers and shadow,
His ledger filled with names you almost recognize.

"Your contribution?" he asks, extending
A glass jar filled with iridescent moths.
You reach inside yourself and find the memory
You've carried longest, heaviest, most precious.

It transforms as you surrender it—
Becoming a blue flame, a crystal tear,
A small bird that flies to join the others
In the aviary of collective mourning.

The buildings here shift like thoughts,
Streets rearrange themselves when unobserved.
Rain falls upward into clouds of forgotten languages.

You realize this dolorous city exists
In the space between heartbeats,
In the pause before waking,
In the moment we admit we are lost.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
THRESHOLD

Through me lies the city of sorrow,
Where skyscrapers weep acid tears,
And subway tunnels echo with yesterday's promises.
I am the gatekeeper of my own undoing,
Holding the key to streets paved with regrets.

Each morning, I dress in the garments of the damned—
A tie that strangles, shoes that pinch,
A smile that doesn't reach my eyes.

The city welcomes all who surrender hope,
Who trade dreams for security,
Who whisper 'tomorrow' but mean 'never.'

I have mapped every alley of this metropolis,
Memorized the shortcuts through despair,
Learned which corners to avoid after dark
When memories prowl like hungry ghosts.

Yet sometimes, between condemned buildings,
A flower breaks through concrete—
And I remember there are other cities,
Ones I might still find the courage to enter.

DESCENT

Per me si va nella città dolente—
Through me the path to sorrow winds.
I carry this ancient warning beneath my skin,
Etched in veins that pulse with inherited grief.

My body: a gateway to territories unmapped,
Where pain blooms like night flowers,
Where thoughts circle like vultures
Over the carcass of what might have been.

I did not choose to be this doorway.
I did not carve these words above my heart.
Yet daily I translate their meaning:

Abandonment tastes like copper.
Loneliness has the texture of stone.
Memory burns colder than ice.

I stand guard at my own threshold,
Neither fully in nor out,
A Virgil with no Dante to guide,
Whispering: this too shall pass,
Though passage itself is the punishment.

RECLAMATION

Through me one enters the city of sorrow,
But who says we cannot dance in its streets?
Who claims its architecture cannot be beautiful?

I have wandered its abandoned squares,
Traced fingers along its crumbling walls,
And found, in ruins, possibilities.

The city of sorrow has gardens
Where strange flowers grow,
Nourished by tears and resilience.

Its inhabitants speak a language
Of broken things made whole again,
Of wounds that become doorways.

I no longer fear its darkened alleys.
I have learned to carry light within.
The city of sorrow taught me this:

Despair is not the final destination
But the beginning of the journey home.
Through me one enters—and through me, one leaves.

BORDERS

Through me one enters the city of sorrow—
This is what the powerful have always claimed.
They inscribe warnings at every border,
Build walls of policy and prejudice,
Call some places unfit for human dwelling.

But I have seen children play in these condemned zones,
Witnessed gardens grow from rubble,
Heard laughter echo between bullet-holes.

The city of sorrow exists only in maps drawn by fear.
Its coordinates shift with each regime change.
Its population counts are always wrong.

We who live in these marked territories
Know a different geography:
Of hands extended across arbitrary lines,
Of kitchens where strangers become family,
Of languages that borrow from each other.

Through me one enters not sorrow
But the truth that no human place
Is beyond redemption.

MIGRATION

Through me one enters the city of sorrow,
The monarch butterfly whispers
As it leads its orange-winged procession
Toward extinction.

I am the last coral reef,
The melting glacier,
The forest reduced to stumps and silence.
I am the gateway to what comes after.

The city of sorrow has no walls
But expands with each degree of warming,
With each species that vanishes,
With each river that forgets its course.

You have been traveling toward this city
All your life without knowing it,
Burning fuel for the journey,
Packing plastic for the road.

Now you stand before its invisible gates
Where the inscription reads not in Latin
But in the language of consequence.
Through me, it says. Through me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
GATES OF THE INFERNO

Per me si va nella città dolente,
Through me, the weary souls must pass—
Words etched in ancient stone, unrelenting,
As I stand before judgment's looking glass.

The city sprawls beneath ashen skies,
Streets paved with regrets and broken vows.
Here, truth strips bare all mortal lies,
And time's mercy never allows.

I descend these spiraling stairs,
Each step heavier than the last,
Where lamentations fill the air,
Echoes of futures and the past.

Circles within circles, pain refined,
Each suffering tailored to its sin.
What contrapasso shall be mine
For the shadows I harbored within?

The ferryman waits at the sullen shore,
His eyes—twin embers in the gloom.
He needs no coin to row once more;
My conscience is payment enough, I assume.

Per me si va nella città dolente—
Through me lies the sorrowful city's heart.
I am both pilgrim and penitent,
And my journey has only just start.

THROUGH GRIEF

Per me si va nella città dolente,
I whispered as I entered grief's domain,
Not Dante's hell, but my own invention—
A landscape built from personal pain.

The city rises not from brimstone depths
But from the ruins of what once was whole.
Its buildings, memories I've wept;
Its streets, the questions that erode my soul.

Yet in this sorrow-laden metropolis,
I find I am not citizenship of one.
Others walk these shadowed boulevards,
Faces lined by battles lost and won.

We nod in passing, knowing glances shared,
A language of the heart, no words required.
For though each grief stands uniquely bare,
In common wounds, we find ourselves inspired.

And slowly, as I wander through these streets,
I notice tiny gardens in the cracks,
Wild resilience blooming bittersweet,
Small beauties that the darkness cannot tax.

Per me si va—through me the path winds on,
Not endless suffering, but transformation.
The city dolente teaches as I roam:
In deepest loss lies deepest revelation.

METROPOLIS OF SHADOWS

Per me si va nella città dolente—
Through me lies entry to the grieving city.
I stand before steel and glass monuments
To capitalism's relentless pity.

The subway breathes like Charon's ferry,
Swallowing whole the morning crowd.
Faces blank as coins, equally wary,
Souls bent but somehow never bowed.

In this concrete inferno, circles form:
The penthouse sinners floating high above,
The middle-ring of endless, pointless storms,
The lowest depths where forgotten bodies move.

I navigate these streets of modern hell,
Where sirens wail like ancient damned souls crying.
Each intersection tells a different tale
Of dreams pursued and quietly dying.

The city feeds on hope like fuel,
Converting it to exhaust and empty eyes.
We are all Dante now, eternal fools,
Searching for stars in light-polluted skies.

Yet somewhere in this metropolitan maze,
Perhaps a Beatrice still waits to guide
Those brave enough to question paved ways
And seek what paradise might still reside.

INTERIOR CARTOGRAPHY

Per me si va nella città dolente—
Through me one enters the city of sorrow.
I am the gate to my own suffering,
The architect of each tomorrow.

I map the landscape of my mind,
A city built from memory and fear.
Streets named after loves left behind,
Squares where doubts appear.

In the north district: childhood wounds,
Towers of early rejection reaching high.
In the west end: broken promises bloom
Like strange flowers beneath a leaden sky.

The river of regret divides the east,
Where bridges I've burned still smoke and smolder.
In southern quarters, my demons feast
On possibilities growing older.

I wander these internal avenues,
A tourist in my own constructed hell.
Sometimes I recognize the views
As places where I've chosen to dwell.

Per me si va—through me, yes, through me,
Lies passage to this sorrowful domain.
But if I am the entrance, could I be
The exit too? The path to light again?

SURREAL LAMENTATIONS

Per me si va nella città dolente
where clocks melt over telephone wires
and buildings breathe like sleeping beasts.
The city of sorrows has no map—

I follow melancholy's breadcrumb trail
through streets that rearrange themselves
when I blink. Here, shadows fall upward
and gravity collects in puddles.

The residents wear faces inside out,
their smiles revealing bone, not teeth.
They invite me to tea parties where cups
fill with the drinker's own tears.

In the central square, a fountain flows
with the ink of unwritten letters.
Pigeons with human hands for wings
scatter when I approach.

The mayor is a woman made of glass,
her transparent heart visibly cracking.
She hands me the key to the city—
it's warm and beats against my palm.

Nightfall comes suddenly, like a curtain dropped.
Stars arrange themselves into equations
that could solve everything if only
I could remember how to read.

Per me si va nella città dolente—
I entered willingly, this dream-built place,
only to find I've always been a citizen,
my sorrows just another neighborhood.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Born in the famine struck Africa'

responses.text:
ROOTS OF RESILIENCE

Born in the famine struck Africa,
where dust claimed more lives than the census counted.
My first breath pulled in heat and history,
my small lungs expanding against impossibility.

Mother's milk was thin but sacred,
each drop a promise that tomorrow existed.
We measured wealth in raindrops,
hoarded hope like water in clay pots.

The elders said hunger makes the spirit strong—
when the body empties, ancestors fill the void.
I learned to dance with hollow bones,
to sing when my stomach spoke louder than my voice.

The baobab taught me patience:
centuries of waiting for brief moments of bloom.
The desert taught me persistence:
life finding ways where logic says it shouldn't.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I am not a tragedy to be pitied.
I am the descendant of those who survived
what should have killed them.

My hands may be small, but they hold
the strength of generations who refused to vanish.
When you see me now, see beyond the headlines.
See how beauty emerges from broken earth.

THE DUALITY OF DUST

Born in the famine struck Africa,
where sunsets paint the sky crimson
while children's bellies swell with nothing.

How strange to witness such beauty
in a place where death walks openly,
unmasked and unashamed.

The acacia spreads its branches like arms
in perpetual offering to the heavens
while beneath its shade, mothers rock
infants too weak to cry.

The land contradicts itself:
fertile with stories, barren of food,
rich in minerals, poor in mercy,
abundant in courage, empty of comfort.

I was shaped by this paradox,
learning to find sweetness in bitter roots,
to harvest joy from fields of sorrow.

The same sun that scorches also illuminates.
The same earth that fails to yield grain
produces art that feeds the soul.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I became a living testament to contradiction—
a flower that blooms in drought,
a song composed in silence,
a feast made from memory,
a river flowing through desert.

This duality is not tragedy.
It is the complete truth of existence.

CARRIED MEMORIES

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I now eat at tables where food is discarded without thought.
The weight of abundance is sometimes heavier
than the weight of hunger ever was.

I dream in two worlds:
One where children chase dust devils for sport,
One where children chase trends and likes.

My passport has changed but my blood remembers
the rhythm of drums that called us to community meals
when there was something to share.

In this new land of plenty,
I am asked to speak of hardship
as if it were the only story worth telling.
They want tales of flies on faces,
not the mathematics my father taught me
using pebbles under starlight.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I carry a continent inside my chest.
It expands with each heartbeat,
reminding me that distance is an illusion.

When I close my eyes, I smell the rain on dry earth—
that moment of transformation when possibility returns.
This is what I brought with me across oceans:
the knowledge that renewal always follows emptiness,
that feast inevitably answers famine.

THE POLITICS OF HUNGER

Born in the famine struck Africa,
where borders drawn by foreign hands
created artificial scarcity.

The land remembers its abundance
before colonizers renamed ownership,
before cash crops replaced sustenance,
before aid became another form of control.

We did not lack resources—
we lacked power over our resources.
We did not need charity—
we needed justice.

The news cameras captured our hollow cheeks
but missed our hollow victories:
seeds saved despite prohibition,
knowledge passed in whispers,
resistance disguised as resignation.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I learned early that hunger is manufactured,
that famine is political architecture.

The same ships that carried away our minerals
brought back expired medicine and secondhand clothes.
The same nations that drafted our poverty
offered bandages for the wounds they inflicted.

Yet we remained.
We cultivated persistence like a crop,
harvested dignity from barren policy.

Remember this when you speak of Africa:
Our hunger was not our failure.
Our survival was our revolution.

BIRTHRIGHT

Born in the famine struck Africa—
yes, this is how my story begins,
but not how it continues.

I come from the continent that cradles humanity's first footprint,
where stars were mapped before books existed,
where mathematics was practiced before it was named.

The famine was a moment.
Africa is millennia.

My inheritance includes hunger, yes,
but also the ingenuity that built pyramids,
the astronomy that tracked constellations,
the medicine that healed with plants,
the music that made pain beautiful.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I claim all of it as my birthright:
the struggle and the splendor,
the hardship and the harmony,
the deprivation and the dance.

When you see my continent through pity's lens,
you miss the magnificence that raised me.

I stand at the intersection of ancient wisdom
and future possibility,
fed by roots that reach deeper
than any temporary devastation.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I am neither defined by lack
nor confined by circumstance.

I am Africa complete—
enduring, evolving, eternal.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Born in the famine struck Africa'

responses.text:
INHERITANCE

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I carried hunger as my first memory.
My mother's milk, thin as morning mist,
Dried before I learned to crawl.

The elders say our ancestors dance
In the curves of the baobab,
But all I saw were skeletal branches
Reaching toward cloudless skies.

I collected dust as others collect toys.
Built castles from cracked earth,
While satellites photographed our bones
For distant fundraising campaigns.

Yet here—
In this place where death seemed the only inheritance,
I found life stubbornly persistent.

Wild amaranth pushing through parched soil,
Grandmother's stories flowing like phantom rivers,
The taste of one precious mango
Shared between seven children.

They expected us to disappear,
To become statistics, cautionary tales.
Instead, I grew strong as drought-resistant sorghum,
Roots digging deeper when the surface fails.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I carry within me both hunger and feast,
The memory of lack and the promise
That even the driest season eventually yields.

DROUGHT LULLABY

Born in the famine struck Africa,
Cradled by hands thin as reeds,
Your first breath drawn from air
Heavy with dust and prayers.

Hush now, little one.
The vultures circle but cannot claim you.
Your mother's eyes, though hollow with hunger,
Still flash with lioness fury.

The world watches through camera lenses,
Capturing your distended belly,
Your matchstick limbs,
But missing entirely your perfect fingers,
The way sunlight catches in your lashes.

They do not see how the village women
Form a circle around your cradle,
How they sing the ancient songs
That survived the Middle Passage,
Colonial whips, and now this—
This newest testing of our endurance.

Sleep, child of drought.
Dream of green seasons.
Your ancestors cross deserts to reach you,
Carrying water in cupped palms,
Whispering: survive, survive, survive.

One day you will tell them
How being born in famine struck Africa
Made you not a victim
But a miracle of persistence,
A testament to life's stubborn flame.

THE GEOGRAPHY OF HUNGER

Born in the famine struck Africa—
That's what the caption said
Beneath my photograph.
As if a continent could be summed up
In four horsemen of apocalypse.

They never printed my name.
Never mentioned that my country
Exported roses to Europe
While my siblings withered.
That foreign companies owned our best farmland.
That my father once grew enough to feed a village
Before the banks claimed our seeds.

On your television screens,
I am all eyes and fragile bones.
In reality, I contain multitudes:
Mathematics prodigy. Daughter. Singer of ancient songs.
Future doctor, perhaps.

You see a tragedy.
I see politics rendered in flesh.

The textbooks speak of climate change,
Of drought cycles and failed crops.
They rarely mention trade agreements,
Structural adjustments,
The colonial ghosts that still haunt our soil.

Born in the famine struck Africa—
I am not your charity poster child.
I am evidence of systems failing.
I am also proof of what survives.

Remember this when you look away.

SEASON OF BONES

Born in the famine struck Africa,
When the sky turned brass
And the earth to powder.

My birth cry joined the chorus
Of cattle collapsing on brittle plains,
Of mothers singing to silent children,
Of men whose pride dissolved
As their fields turned to ash.

The missionaries brought rice
And bibles bound in leather.
The journalists brought cameras
And left with our faces.
The aid workers brought medicine
And their own exhaustion.

I was baptized in absence—
The absence of rain,
Of full bellies,
Of simple certainties.

At night, my grandmother tells stories
Of the time before the hunger,
When the land was generous
And our bodies were round with living.
"Remember this famine," she whispers,
"But do not let it remember you."

I collect small mercies:
A lizard's graceful dance across hot stone.
The perfect geometry of a thorn tree against sunset.
The taste of water, sweeter than any wine could be.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I learned early that life persists
Not despite emptiness,
But somehow within it.

WHAT THE RAINS REMEMBER

Born in the famine struck Africa,
you emerged between worlds—
one dying, one struggling to begin.

The midwife wiped dust from your face,
marked your forehead with ochre,
and whispered the names of rivers
that had run dry before your conception.

You were lighter than a memory,
yet somehow contained entire histories:
ancestors who survived the colonial blade,
grandmothers who could call rain from clear skies,
uncles who knew which roots could nourish
when all else failed.

The foreign doctors measured your chances
on clipboards and probability charts.
They did not account for how stubbornly
life clings to possibility,
how even in barren landscapes
the smallest seed waits patiently.

Years later, when the rains finally returned,
you stood beneath the deluge,
mouth open to catch the sweetness,
body remembering a thirst it inherited.

This is what it means to be born of drought—
to recognize abundance as miracle,
to carry both famine and feast in your marrow,
to know that survival itself
is a kind of defiance.

The rains remember you.
The earth remembers you.
And in this remembering,
you are never truly orphaned.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Born in the famine struck Africa'

responses.text:
DROUGHT LULLABY

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I learned to measure life in raindrops,
not years. My mother's milk dried
like the cracked earth beneath our feet.
The elders say I arrived with the dust storms,
a child of resilience wrapped in hope.

The aid workers photograph my hollow cheeks,
but cannot capture how I dance when
no one watches, how I collect stories
like others collect water.

My grandmother whispers ancient proverbs
into my ear each night—wisdom outlasts hunger.
She tells me our people have survived
a thousand droughts before this one.

I am more than empty bowls
and extended palms.
I am the future,
born of those who refuse to disappear.

THE DIASPORA REMEMBERS

Born in the famine struck Africa,
you carry the weight of absent rainfall
in your shoulders, even now,
three decades and two continents away.

In this American kitchen of plenty,
you still finish every grain of rice,
still flinch at the sound of running water,
still wake from dreams of your mother's hands
dividing one meal among seven children.

Your colleagues marvel at your patience,
your ability to find solutions in scarcity.
They don't know how you learned mathematics—
dividing portions, multiplying hope,
subtracting expectations, adding days to lives.

When your own children complain of boredom,
you bite your tongue against stories
that would frighten them.
Instead, you teach them to garden,
to respect the soil that always remembers.

HEADLINES AND HEARTBEATS

Born in the famine struck Africa—
three words that conjure skeletal children
on Western television screens.
Three words that collapse
fifty-four nations into one tragedy.

Yet here, beneath the baobab's ancient shade,
life persists in defiance of statistics.
A mother sings while planting drought-resistant seeds,
children invent games requiring no toys,
and elders preserve knowledge that outlasts catastrophe.

The rains will return. They always do.
The question is who will remain
to welcome them?

Meanwhile, we adapt, create, survive—
our innovations invisible to those
who only see us through the lens
of what we lack, never what we build
from the ashes of necessity.

Remember: famines end, but stories endure.

KEEPER OF SEEDS

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I became a collector of possibilities.
My pockets filled with seeds
salvaged from market floors,
rescued from abandoned fields.

The agronomists came with clipboards,
told us our methods were outdated,
while I hid my grandmother's legacy
beneath the floorboards—
heirloom varieties that survived
three centuries of colonizers.

At night, I catalog them by touch:
those that grow with little water,
those that resist the new pests,
those that remember how to thrive
in soil others declared dead.

When the foreign agencies departed,
I opened my hands to neighbors.
We planted our future in rows,
a rebellion of green against
the expected narrative of dust.

Some call it science. I call it memory.

THE RAINS WILL RETURN

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I learned to read the clouds
before I could read books.
My umbilical cord buried beneath
soil that had forgotten moisture.

They named me Nyarai—the one who brings rain.
A prayer disguised as a child,
my first cries piercing the dust-heavy air
as my father scanned the horizon
for signs of changing winds.

I grew alongside the withered maize,
both of us stretching toward possibility.
The aid trucks came and went like seasons,
but we remained, rooted.

Now I study meteorology at university,
marrying ancestral knowledge with satellite data.
My people no longer wait for foreign saviors.
We build reservoirs and plant windbreaks,
preparing for the future we will shape ourselves.

Remember this: every drought ends.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Born in the famine struck Africa'

responses.text:
THE HUNGER'S CHILD

Born in the famine struck Africa,
My first breath drawn where dust replaces air.
Mother's milk dried by grief and thirst,
Yet her eyes held oceans she couldn't spare.

The earth cracked like my newborn skin,
Both of us parched under merciless sun.
The elders said my cries brought clouds,
A miracle child when hope was none.

I grew between absence and persistence,
Learned to find nourishment in stories told,
By voices thin but spirits vast—
Ancestral wisdom more precious than gold.

My playground: the skeletal remains
Of what once was verdant, lush, alive.
My toys: imagination's gifts,
The will to create, endure, survive.

Now I stand tall like the baobab,
Roots deep in soil that knew such pain.
Born in the famine struck Africa,
I am drought's child who learned to make rain.

My hands now plant what couldn't grow then.
My voice now sings what couldn't be said.
Born in the famine struck Africa—
Not just surviving, but rising instead.

INHERITANCE OF DUST

Born in the famine struck Africa,
Where history's teeth left permanent marks.
Continental wounds carved by colonial hands,
Borders drawn blind to ancient tribal lands.

The cameras came when the children thinned,
Captured hollow eyes and distended skin.
But failed to frame the centuries before—
The plundered gold, ivory, and diamond shore.

The baobabs remember a different time,
When granaries swelled with millet and maize.
Before cash crops replaced sustenance,
Before aid became both savior and maze.

The drought may claim the land for years,
But cannot take the drumbeat of resilience.
In village circles, elders pass down songs
That outlast hunger's temporary violence.

The child born to famine's cruel embrace
Inherits both struggle and strength untold.
Hands that know how to coax life from dust
Carry wisdom that never grows old.

Born in the famine struck Africa—
Not a story of pity, but of power unfurled.
The birthplace of humanity still teaches
How to face death and rebirth in a withering world.

BETWEEN SCARCITY AND STARS

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I emerged between scarcity and stars.
My first lullaby: the whispered prayers
Of women who painted hope with henna hands.

The earth, they say, was eating itself—
Soil turning to sand, rivers to memory.
Yet somehow, flowers still found ways
To crack the hardened ground with defiance.

I learned hunger before language,
Thirst before tears could properly form.
My body: a small revolution
Against statistics that predicted doom.

The world knew us only as numbers then—
Death tolls, donations, dwindling resources.
They never counted our stories, our songs,
The way we transformed suffering to purpose.

Now I cross continents carrying
The weight of those who didn't survive,
Their dreams folded carefully in my pocket
Like seeds waiting for the right time.

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I am neither tragedy nor miracle.
I am the continuation of a people
Who have always known how to make
