prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,'

responses.text:
Beyond Glass Slippers

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
not the shimmer of a dress at midnight,
nor feet small enough to fit fantasy.

They never tell you how her hands were rough—
calloused from scrubbing floors, from making beauty
from ashes when no one was looking.

We mistake the magic for the gown,
when the real enchantment was always
her patience, blooming like wildflowers
through concrete circumstance.

Princes search for feet to fit their narratives
while overlooking hands that built kingdoms
from dust and disappointment.

Cinderella means the heart that beats
beneath labels and limitations,
the spirit that refuses to believe
that worth comes from reflection.

Tell me, when the clock strikes reality,
what remains is what has always mattered—
a soul too vast for glass to contain.

Unveiling

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person
Hidden beneath layers of ordinary days,
Like embers glowing beneath household ash,
Waiting for a moment to burst into flame.

I have watched you move through rooms
As if you were merely passing through,
Yet leaving constellations in your wake—
Stardust that only patient eyes can see.

Your laughter carries melodies
From some forgotten royal court,
Your kindness, a slipper made of light
That fits perfectly around the world's pain.

How strange that others miss
The coronation happening in plain sight,
The way you transform mundane moments
Into carriages bound for somewhere magnificent.

Beloved, there is no midnight that can
Undo what I have witnessed in you—
This kingdom you carry within,
This beauty that time cannot touch.

The Glass Theory

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
a theorem of transformation we misunderstood.
Not rags to riches—rather, recognition of what already exists.

Consider the paradox: we are both
the cinder-swept girl and the royal decree,
the pumpkin and the carriage,
the rodents and the steeds.

The fairy godmother is merely perspective,
a quantum shift in seeing.

What if the magic wand is simply
the moment we decide to attend the ball
despite having nothing society deems worthy?

What if the clock strikes twelve
every time we forget our true nature?

I have been midnight and morning,
glass slipper and bare foot,
scullery maid and sovereign self.

The palace was always within reach.
The kingdom, always ourselves.
The fitting of the shoe, always
an act of coming home.

Modern Cinderella

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
or so I tell myself, scrolling through filtered realities
at 2 AM, thumbs numb from swiping left on princes
who want midnight without the dance.

My godmother these days is an algorithm
that knows my shoe size better than I do,
suggesting glass slippers I cannot afford
on a gig economy salary.

The ball is a LinkedIn profile I polish
between shifts at three different castles,
hoping someone notices my qualifications
beyond how I look in professional attire.

My stepsisters are billboards and magazine covers,
impossible standards I sweep away each morning
only to find them scattered again by evening.

But sometimes, catching my reflection
in a subway window or store display,
I glimpse what the fairy tales meant—
that beneath this daily disguise,
something irreplaceable remains,
waiting not for rescue but recognition.

Ashes to Essence

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
and I have been cinders for so long—
fragments of what fire left behind,
scattered and overlooked.

I swept my worth into corners,
kept my dreams in the attic of possibility,
spoke to birds when no one else would listen
to the music building in my chest.

But ashes hold memory of flame.

Today I am learning to recognize
the palace of my own skin,
the royalty in standing fully in my truth,
the magic that happens not at midnight
but in the moment I decide
to see myself clearly.

No fairy godmother required—
just the alchemy of self-acceptance,
the courage to walk through doors
I've been polishing for others.

I am both the one who waits
and the one who arrives,
both the slipper and the foot,
both the seeker and what's found.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,'

responses.text:
GLASS SLIPPER SOUL

Beneath the cinders and the dust,
A heart of gold refuses rust.
Cinderella's not the gown she wears,
But courage blooming unawares.

Her beauty dwells in patient eyes,
In hands that work 'neath cruel skies.
The stroke of midnight cannot steal
The grace that makes the prince's heart kneel.

We search for magic in the grand,
In carriages and royal bands,
Yet overlook the quiet power
Of kindness in the darkest hour.

Cinderella means the spark inside
That adversity cannot hide.
Not glass that shatters at the dawn,
But strength on which new hope is drawn.

The fairy tale we've long been told
Hides deeper truths than glass and gold.
For beauty's not in perfect skin,
But in the light that burns within.

So wear your name like royal right,
Cinderella in your own true light.
For kingdoms rise and kingdoms fall,
But genuine souls outshine them all.

FITTING THE MYTH

They say Cinderella means beauty and grace,
But what of the woman behind the face?
Cinders and scars from years by the flame,
Yet we remember her only by name.

We polish ourselves for the ball each night,
Scrubbing away what doesn't seem right.
Trying to fit in a shoe not our size,
Chasing approval through others' eyes.

The clock always ticking, the midnight near,
The fear of reverting to who we are here.
What magic transforms us? What spell must break?
Which parts of ourselves must we forsake?

Cinderella means more than the tale that was spun.
She's the work and the worth when day is done.
Not waiting for rescue by charming men,
But rising from ashes again and again.

The slipper's a prison of crystal clear—
A beauty standard we hold too dear.
True transformation comes not from above,
But from finally granting yourself some love.

So dance at the ball in shoes that don't pinch,
And don't give your power away inch by inch.
For Cinderella's real magic, you see,
Was always the strength to simply be free.

REFLECTIONS IN BROKEN GLASS

Cinderella means the fragments we collect,
The pieces of ourselves we dare protect.
A mosaic of moments, scattered wide,
Some we showcase, others we hide.

In mirrors of expectation, we search our face,
For traces of beauty, for signs of grace.
The world carves us into shapes not our own,
Like slippers of glass where flesh meets stone.

Who decides which foot fits the dream?
Which smile is genuine, which eyes gleam?
Personality packaged in midnight blue,
Beauty defined by what others view.

The clock strikes truth in hours small,
When masks dissolve and pretenses fall.
Cinderella returning to cinder and ash,
Authenticity emerging from society's clash.

Perhaps the fairy tale got it wrong—
The transformation was there all along.
Not in the gown or the royal decree,
But in embracing all you could be.

Cinderella means the courage to stand
In your own light, by your own hand.
Neither princess nor servant, but gloriously whole,
A person of beauty, in body and soul.

CINDERELLA TUESDAY

On Tuesday morning by fluorescent light,
She spills her coffee down her favorite white.
No fairy godmother appears with wand,
Just paper towels and the day beyond.

Cinderella means the moments we rise
From ordinary stains with tired eyes.
The conference room becomes her ball,
Her presentation makes the kingdom fall.

No prince required for this tale of might,
Just her voice steady, her ideas bright.
The glass ceiling shatters 'neath her tread,
As words of wisdom dance from what she said.

Personality blooming in the boardroom glow,
Beauty in confidence none can overthrow.
The clock strikes five, but no magic ends,
Her power continues as the night descends.

At home she kicks off shoes that pinch too tight,
No need for glass to make her feet seem right.
Cinderella means the woman fully seen,
Not for her dress, but for her mind so keen.

The fairytale reimagined day by day,
In lives of those who forge their own way.
No longer waiting for some grand ball's call,
But dancing through life, enchanting all.

QUANTUM CINDERELLA

Cinderella means the duality of being,
The seen and unseen, the known and unseeing.
We exist in superpositions of self,
Both sovereign royalty and dusty elf.

What is beauty but light refracted?
What is personality but roles enacted?
The observer changes what they choose to see—
Servant or princess; which will you be?

Time transforms us at midnight's edge,
Identity balanced on a window ledge.
We are quantum particles in human form,
Wavering between the special and norm.

The slipper—a construct of crystalline thought—
A perfect container for what we are not.
Yet paradoxically, precisely us,
A perfect fit causing perfect fuss.

Cinderella means the collapse of states,
When potential solidifies at gates.
The moment of choice when paths diverge,
When separate selves into one converge.

Perhaps we are all glass slippers and pumpkins,
Both magical and mundane in our bumpkins.
Existing simultaneously in cinders and stars,
Whole universes inside who we are.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,'

responses.text:
BENEATH THE ASHES

They see the cinders on your hands,
The gray that coats your name,
Not knowing that within you burns
A never-ending flame.

Cinderella isn't rags or grime,
Or waiting for a dance.
She's the patience in your suffering,
The beauty in your chance.

For when they stripped you of your worth,
And dressed you in their shame,
You held a kingdom in your heart
That no one could reclaim.

The clock may strike its midnight toll,
The carriage turn to vine,
But what transforms is not your dress—
It's how your soul can shine.

Cinderella means the spark that glows
When all the lights go dim.
The strength to sweep the hearth and know
The crown that waits within.

So wear your name like royal blood,
Though ashes mark your face.
The truest magic ever told
Is finding your own grace.

GLASS REFLECTIONS

They say Cinderella means beauty,
But not the kind that's skin-deep or fleeting.
Not the face that launches ships
Or the figure that turns heads.

Rather, it's beauty that endures ash and scorn,
That serves without complaint,
That hopes when reason says despair,
That dreams when reality says surrender.

It's the personality that remains unbroken
When stepped on like the floor she scrubs,
The heart that still loves
When given every reason to harden.

Cinderella isn't the transformation at midnight—
She's the woman who returns to cinders
And still believes in possibility.
She's the soul who knows her worth

When the world has forgotten.
Her slippers aren't made of glass,
But of resilience that carries her
Through endless dark nights.

This is the beauty that princes truly seek:
Not the dress or the dance,
But the spirit that outshines
Every star in the midnight sky.

THE FITTING

We've all tried on that slipper,
That transparent expectation,
Cut our heels and toes to fit
Into someone else's creation.

Cinderella means the mask we wear
To balls we weren't invited to attend,
The personality we carve from fear,
The beauty we pretend.

But what if Cinderella's tale
Is not about the shoe that fits?
What if it's about the foot that doesn't change,
The self that never quits?

Perhaps the fairest one of all
Is she who drops the glass,
Who dances barefoot in the hall
And lets the midnight pass.

No fairy godmother can grant
What already dwells inside.
No pumpkin carriage can transport
The journey of your pride.

Cinderella means the person
Who emerges from the flames,
Who knows that royalty isn't birthright
But how you play life's games.

So let the clock strike as it will—
Your story has no end.
The magic wasn't in the spell,
But in how you chose to bend.

CINDERELLA THEORY

Theorize with me: what if Cinderella
is not a person but a moment?
That split second when someone truly sees you,
beneath the dust of daily survival.

Consider how we all contain multitudes—
the servant self, the royal self,
the self that kneels to gather scattered lentils,
the self that waltzes, head held high.

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
but who defines this beauty?
Not the stepmother with her narrow metrics,
not the prince with his kingdom-wide search.

Perhaps it's the birds in the hazel tree,
who know that worth isn't measured in silk or title,
but in how gently you speak to creatures
who can offer nothing in return.

We are all cleaning ashes by day,
dancing in ballrooms by night.
The magic isn't in the transformation—
it's in the recognition that both versions are true.

So when they ask which self is real,
the cinder girl or the princess,
smile like someone who knows a secret:
the beauty was never in either disguise.

MIDNIGHT INVENTORY

Take inventory at midnight:
one heart, twice broken, thrice mended
with thread spun from hope;
one voice, silenced then found;
two hands that know both labor and grace;
two feet that have walked through fire.

This is what Cinderella means—
not the girl who was chosen,
but the woman who endured.

The fairy tale never mentions
how she scrubbed her identity clean
each night, how she buried her dreams
beneath the garden, how they grew
like pumpkins, wild and improbable.

Beauty isn't the gown that dissolves,
it's the dignity that remains
when everything magical has fled.
Personality isn't shaped by wands,
but by the wounds we transform
into wisdom, the slights we forge
into strength.

At midnight, we all return
to our truest selves—
not lesser for the cinders,
not greater for the glass,
but perfect in our incompletion,
majestic in our becoming.

The clock strikes thirteen,
and we are finally free
of the story we were told to live.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,'

responses.text:
Beyond the Cinders

They say Cinderella means beauty, but not
the kind that washes away at midnight.
It's in how she held hope like a small bird
cupped between calloused palms,
her dreams rising through chimney smoke.

Cinders named her, not for the ash
that powdered her cheeks, but for how
she burned from within despite the cold hearth.
A girl who knew the weight of brooms
yet danced as if gravity were merely a suggestion.

No fairy godmother crafts the true magic—
it was always there, beneath swept floors
and behind eyes that reflected stars
even when they'd never seen the sky.

Cinderella means the person who remains
when the finery falls away,
who recognizes her own glass-clear worth
even when others see only smudges.

Glass Reflections

What is beauty but a slipper that never quite fits,
a clock striking fear at the thought of revelation?
Cinderella, they've twisted your story into submission,
made you a princess when you were a revolution.

Your personality—the real magic—
not the gown that disappeared like morning mist,
not the carriage that returned to garden simplicity.

They remember the prince who searched,
but forget how you survived years of ashes,
how you spoke kindly to mice when humans offered cruelty,
how you built sanctuary in the margins of someone else's home.

Cinderella means resilience carved from remnants,
means finding yourself when others have written your ending,
means knowing that beauty lives in how you rise each dawn
to face a world that wants only your reflection,
never your voice.

Everyday Glass Slippers

We wear our Cinderella moments like invisible jewelry—
those instances when someone truly sees us
across crowded rooms of misunderstanding.

The personality that shimmers beneath
our Monday clothes and Tuesday smiles,
waiting for recognition like seeds beneath snow.

Beauty isn't the face that launched a thousand ships
but the hand that steadies a stranger's elbow,
the voice that speaks truth when lies would be easier,
the heart that keeps its softness in a hardening world.

We are all Cinderellas at the stroke of honesty,
transformed not by magic but by being witnessed.
Our true names spoken aloud after years
of answering to whatever others called us.

The slipper fits when we finally stand
in the fullness of our own light,
neither princess nor servant—
just gloriously, imperfectly human.

Ash and Emergence

Once, I swept my true self under carpets,
scattered my worth like breadcrumbs
for others to follow or ignore.
Cinderella was my middle name—
unspoken, hidden between consonants of compliance.

I polished others' dreams until they gleamed
while mine gathered dust in attic corners.
Beauty, they said, was silence and service,
personality compressed into pleasing portions.

But embers lived beneath the ash,
and stories have a way of rewriting themselves.
The clock struck thirteen and I stayed,
glass slippers shattered under deliberate heel.

Cinderella means the moment you realize
the ballroom was inside you all along,
and every step away from what dims your light
is a dance more meaningful than any waltz with royalty.

I am the fairy godmother now.
I transform myself daily.

Midnight Revelations

Cinderella dwells in the spaces
between who we appear to be
and who we are when no one watches,
when clocks surrender their judgment
and shoes are kicked off under tables.

Beauty migrates like birds between seasons—
sometimes visible in plumage and song,
sometimes hidden in the quiet journey of return.
Personality: the pumpkin that contains
both seeds and sweetness, potential and present tense.

We are all scrubbing floors of expectation,
all waiting for that moment of recognition.
Not from princes or kingdoms,
but from mirrors that finally reflect
what was magnificent all along.

Cinderella means the courage to remain
when magic dissolves like sugar in rain,
to stand in the aftermath of transformation
and claim both the cinders and the stars
as equally essential constellations of self.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,'

responses.text:
BENEATH THE ASHES

Not glass slippers but calloused feet,
Not ball gowns but a mind complete.
Cinderella dwells in spaces between
What others perceive and what truly is seen.

She scrubs floors of expectation,
Sweeps away false representation,
While embers of her spirit glow
Beneath layers society bestowed.

No prince required for validation,
No clock strikes fear of transformation.
Her beauty lies in resilience born
From nights spent working until morn.

Cinderella means the strength to rise
When others only see disguise.
The magic exists not in fairy godmothers' wands
But in breaking invisible bonds.

She carries grace in wounded palms,
Wisdom in eyes that weathered storms.
Her worth not measured by fitting a shoe,
But by the fire that burns fierce and true.

Cinderella means the beauty of becoming,
Of owning your story without running.
The ashes not what define her name,
But the phoenix that rises through the flame.

GLASS REFLECTIONS

In shattered mirrors we glimpse ourselves,
Fragmented beauty, partial truths.
Cinderella means the parts we hide away,
Dust-covered potential on forgotten shelves.

Who sees beyond the smudged exterior?
The fingerprints of struggle leaving marks,
The quiet dignity beneath torn clothes,
The midnight dreams that outlast curfews.

We are all wearing masks at the ball,
Dancing carefully lest we reveal
The pumpkin-ordinary truth of our lives.
Yet in vulnerability lies our splendor.

Sometimes transformation comes
Not from fairy godmothers' intervention
But from someone truly seeing us—
Or from finally seeing ourselves.

Cinderella means the courage to believe
In possibilities beyond midnight,
In worthiness despite circumstance,
In beauty unconstrained by others' vision.

The slipper fits not because of dainty feet
But because it was always meant for you—
Your unique imprint upon this world,
Your singular magic, waiting to be claimed.

EVERYDAY CINDERELLAS

They move among us—Cinderellas,
Not awaiting rescue or recognition,
But carrying quiet kingdoms within.
The barista with the gentle smile
Whose laughter transforms Monday mornings.
The teacher whose patience rebuilds confidence
In children others deemed lost causes.

Cinderella means the heart that gives
When emptiness would be easier.
The single parent working double shifts,
The friend who listens without judgment,
The stranger who offers kindness
Without expectation of return.

Beauty lives in unexpected moments—
A nurse holding the hand of the dying,
A janitor singing while mopping floors,
An elderly woman planting flowers
She may never see bloom.

We search for magic in fairy tales
While overlooking everyday enchantment.
Cinderella means the personality
That turns ordinary into extraordinary,
Ashes into possibility,
Limitations into stepping stones.

Perhaps the true spell is cast
Not by wands but by presence—
The courage to remain authentic
In a world demanding conformity,
The power to transform others
Simply by being yourself.

MIDNIGHT METAMORPHOSIS

At the stroke of twelve, we shed our disguises—
Not into lesser forms, but truer selves.
Cinderella means the journey between worlds,
The liminal space where transformation happens.

What if the pumpkin coach was freedom?
What if the rags were royal garments
Misunderstood by eyes untrained to see?
What if the palace was a gilded cage,
And returning home was the true liberation?

We are creatures of constant becoming,
Shifting between identities like seasons—
Sometimes ash-covered and invisible,
Sometimes radiant and unmistakable.

The clock ticks forward, never backward.
Each version of ourselves leaves footprints,
Glass memories that cannot be worn again
But serve as evidence: we were here,
We danced, we transformed, we lived.

Cinderella means the beauty of impermanence,
The personality shaped by contrast—
Between before and after,
Between darkness and light,
Between who others believe us to be
And who we discover ourselves becoming
With each step toward dawn.

CINDERELLA THEORY

Perhaps we are all
composed of fallen stars
and kitchen cinders,
cosmic dust
and daily dirt.

The universe expands
in the same pattern
as a heart opening.

Cinderella means
the quantum state
of being both
particle and wave,
seen and unseen,
valued and overlooked.

What magic exists
in the space between
perception and reality?

Scientists say
we are mostly empty space,
atoms barely touching—
yet we feel so solid,
so heavy with expectation.

The glass slipper
is a perfect paradox:
fragile yet unbreakable,
transparent yet transformative,
rigid yet molded
to one unique form.

Cinderella means
the mathematical certainty
that beauty is not subtraction
but multiplication—
it grows when divided
among many observers.

The personality exists
in superposition,
both ash-covered
and incandescent,
until the moment
of being truly witnessed
collapses all possibilities
into one brilliant reality.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'As less on earth seek truth above'

responses.text:
CELESTIAL COMPASS

As less on earth seek truth above,
The stars grow dim in smoggy skies.
Ancient wisdom fades from view,
Replaced by fleeting, fragile lies.

We chase the glitter of the known,
Content with shadows on the wall,
While galaxies of thought remain
Unexplored beyond our call.

What treasures wait in silent realms
For those who dare to lift their gaze?
What whispers might we finally hear
If we escaped our mental maze?

The universe holds no deceit,
Just patterns we've forgotten how
To read with open, humble hearts—
Eternal truths we disavow.

So let us be the few who seek,
Who still believe in higher light,
As less on earth seek truth above,
We'll be the watchers of the night.

DIGITAL PROPHETS

As less on earth seek truth above,
We scroll through endless feeds of noise.
Our thumbs the pilgrims of our age,
Migrating toward algorithmic joys.

The prophets now wear business suits,
Sell certainty in sleek devices.
We've traded stars for screened delight,
And wisdom for addictive vices.

Remember when we used to wonder?
Before the answers came too quick?
Before we outsourced all our questions
To searches clinical and slick?

Somewhere beneath the digital hum,
A hunger grows we can't delete—
For truths that algorithms miss,
For mysteries our souls still seek.

Perhaps in this connected age,
True connection is what we lack.
As less on earth seek truth above,
It's time to find our way back.

ROOTED SKYWARD

As less on earth seek truth above,
The ancient oak extends its reach,
Untroubled by our hurried lives,
It practices what sages teach.

Roots buried deep in darkness thrive,
While branches dance with passing clouds.
The tree embraces earth and sky,
Unburdened by our human doubts.

I press my palm against rough bark,
And feel the pulse of patient growth.
This silent teacher shows the way—
To honor both the high and low.

The truth was never just above,
Nor solely in the dirt below.
It lives within the space between,
Where seeming opposites can flow.

I'll learn from this unmoving monk,
Who travels far without a step.
As less on earth seek truth above,
I'll grow both down and up, except.

CARTOGRAPHY OF DOUBT

As less on earth seek truth above,
I map the contours of my doubt.
The territories of uncertainty,
The borders I can't live without.

My questions are my compass points,
My wandering a form of prayer.
The answers matter less to me
Than how I journey toward their lair.

Some nights I climb the mountain steep,
Where mystics claim the view is clear.
Some days I rest in valleys low,
Where simple truths feel most sincere.

I've learned to love the fog that rolls
Across my mind's uncharted lands.
The mystery keeps me humble, whole—
A truth I've come to understand.

So let the masses chase what's sure,
I'll cherish what remains unknown.
As less on earth seek truth above,
I find mine in the seeking shown.

ENDANGERED SPECIES

As less on earth seek truth above,
We've placed it on the threatened list.
Endangered like the ivory bill,
Truth's call grows fainter in the mist.

We've clear-cut forests of deep thought,
For farms of easy certainty.
We've dammed the rivers of discourse,
And drained the wells of scrutiny.

The truth-seekers—rare birds indeed—
Still forage in forgotten groves.
Their plumage marked by questioning,
Their songs composed of maybes, perhapses.

Perhaps we need conservation now,
Protected spaces for the real.
Reserves where facts can roam unharmed,
Where honest words can heal.

I'll join this dwindling species then,
And learn their endangered ways with love.
As less on earth seek truth above,
I'll be among the precious few thereof.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'As less on earth seek truth above'

responses.text:
CELESTIAL COMPASS

As less on earth seek truth above,
The stars grow dim in smoggy skies.
We chase our shadows, blinded by
The neon glow of modern lies.

Remember when we used to gaze
At constellations, chart our course?
Now downward bent, our necks grow stiff,
Our vision narrowed without remorse.

The ancients built their temples tall,
To touch the heavens, bridge the gap.
While we construct our walls so thick,
And in our isolated laps,

Hold tiny screens of fleeting light—
Poor substitutes for cosmic fire.
The truth still waits in vast expanse,
For those who dare to look up higher.

I wonder if we've lost the art
Of seeking what we cannot grasp,
Of faith in things beyond our reach,
Of questions too profound to ask.

So lift your eyes, though you may stand
Alone among the downward gaze.
The truth above has always been
A lighthouse through our human haze.

ELEVATION

As less on earth seek truth above,
I plant my feet on mountain stone,
Shedding layers of what I thought I knew
Like snake skin, brittle and outgrown.

The valley shimmer-shifts below—
A mosaic of certainties I once held dear.
How strange that distance clarifies;
What seemed so solid disappears.

Up here, the air strips pretense bare.
No room for hollow words or half-truths,
When lungs burn clean with effort's fire
And mind expands beyond the proof.

I've climbed through clouds of my own making,
Through fog of doubt and comfort's haze.
The path grows thin where few have traveled;
The solitude both stings and saves.

What truth awaits beyond the treeline?
Not answers carved in ancient stone,
But questions opening like wildflowers—
More honest than all I've ever known.

Let them say I've lost my grounding.
Let them call this pursuit naive.
I've found more truth in one horizon
Than in all the certainties they believe.

DIGITAL PRAYERS

As less on earth seek truth above,
Our thumbs scroll endlessly below.
We've traded constellations
For notifications' subtle glow.

Once we built cathedrals reaching
Toward the mysteries of sky.
Now we craft our careful profiles,
Curated versions of our lives.

The algorithm knows our patterns,
Feeds us what we wish to see—
A hall of mirrors, not a window
To what might actually be.

Remember how it felt to wonder?
To stand beneath unfiltered stars?
Before we had the instant answers,
Before we knew how tracked we are?

I power down my glowing devices,
Step outside the data stream.
The silence rings uncomfortably
In ears accustomed to the screen.

Perhaps the truth was never meant
To fit within our palms so neat.
Perhaps it waits in spaces wider
Than the world beneath our feet.

So less on earth seek truth above,
But I will try to be the few—
Who lift their gaze beyond the scroll
To find what's infinitely true.

CARTOGRAPHY OF FAITH

As less on earth seek truth above,
I trace the wrinkles on my grandfather's maps,
Yellowed atlases of places
No satellite has named.

He taught me how to navigate
By stars now drowned in city light,
How truth resides in spaces
We cannot claim or tame.

"The problem," he would tell me,
As his weathered finger traced the void
Beyond the map's edge, "is not that truth is hidden,
But that we've stopped the search."

I've watched the seekers dwindle,
One by one exchanging compass for convenience,
Trading pilgrimage for purchase,
Revelation for review.

We've grown too fond of certainty,
Of answers we can hold and own.
The mystery above requires
Empty hands and open eyes.

So I fold his maps with reverence,
Though their landmarks no longer match the world.
The creases form a constellation—
A reminder of what seeking means.

As less on earth seek truth above,
I choose to be cartographer of questions,
Charting paths toward what remains
Gloriously, uncharted still.

INHERITANCE OF WONDER

As less on earth seek truth above,
The children still do—instinctively.
Have you seen how they point to birds in flight?
How they ask about stars and infinity?

Their questions come unburdened by
The weight of what we think we know.
"Why is the sky that color blue?"
"Where does the moon go when it's day?"

Somewhere between their age and mine,
I learned to look down, not up.
To seek answers in textbooks, not twilight.
To trust explanation over wonder.

What inheritance is this—
This gradual lowering of gaze?
This trading of celestial mysteries
For terrestrial certainties?

My daughter tugs my sleeve at dusk,
Points to the first star emerging.
"Make a wish," I say automatically,
A ritual without meaning.

"I wish," she whispers, "to know what's up there."
And something long dormant awakens in me—
The memory of seeking, of not knowing,
Of standing small beneath immensity.

As less on earth seek truth above,
I'll learn again from her upturned face,
How to question, how to wonder,
How to seek what cannot be contained.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'As less on earth seek truth above'

responses.text:
CELESTIAL COMPASS

As less on earth seek truth above,
The stars grow dim with loneliness.
Their ancient light, once guides for kings,
Now competes with neon's hollow rings.

We've traded constellations' maps
For screens that never show the way.
The cosmos weeps in silent verse
As we forget to lift our gaze.

Yet in the quiet corners where
The wild things still remember how
To dance beneath the moon's soft glow,
A whisper travels through the snow:

'Look up, dear child, beyond your fears,
The universe still holds you near.
Though fewer souls now seek the light,
One glance upward can pierce the night.'

Perhaps in finding what was lost—
This sacred bond with skies above—
We'll remember what we're crafted of:
Stardust seeking its way home through love.

DIGITAL PROPHETS

As less on earth seek truth above,
We scroll through wisdom with our thumbs,
Digesting bytes of fractured thought,
Believing all that we are taught
By algorithms built to please.

The mystics of our age wear suits,
Their temples built of glass and code.
They promise heaven in the cloud,
Transcendence for the paying crowd—
No need to look beyond the screen.

What ancient seers found in stars,
We seek in glowing pixels now.
The universe, compressed and flat,
Reduced to likes and this and that,
A pale reflection of the whole.

Yet hunger for the real remains,
A gnawing void no data fills.
Perhaps in silence we might find
What ceaseless noise has left behind:
The truth that waits, patient above,
For those who still dare lift their love.

ROOTS AND BRANCHES

As less on earth seek truth above,
The trees continue reaching high—
Their wisdom doesn't question why
So many roots cling to the ground
While branches stretch toward light they've found.

They understand the dual need:
To drink from soil and bathe in sky,
To honor darkness where they're bound
While dancing with the clouds unbound.

Perhaps we humans might yet learn
This balance trees have always known:
That heaven's truths and earthly love
Are not opposing forces, but
Two halves that make a whole divine.

So plant your feet in present soil
And let your spirit climb and soar.
The truth you seek in realms above
Is mirrored in the ground below—
A single song with countless notes,
A prayer that needs no words to grow.

THE LIGHTHOUSE KEEPER'S LAMENT

As less on earth seek truth above,
I tend this flame through storm and night.
My hands are cracked, my back is bent,
Yet still I climb these weathered steps
To keep the lantern burning bright.

Once, countless eyes would search the dark
For this small sun I daily birth.
Now ships have charts and digital maps—
My light, once salvation, now mere art,
A relic from a fading world.

Still, I polish brass and trim the wick,
For somewhere out beyond the foam,
A sailor might have lost their way,
Their modern instruments betrayed
By thunderstorms or human flaws.

Perhaps that's why I maintain watch
While truth above seems out of reach.
Some beacons must remain alight
Even when few still seek their glow—
Not for glory or for praise,
But for that one lost soul who may
Still lift their eyes to find their way home.

QUANTUM PRAYER

As less on earth seek truth above,
The universe doesn't seem to mind—
Particles still dance unseen,
Waves collapse when we observe,
Reality bends to thought divine.

What is this truth we claim to seek?
A god with beard on clouded throne?
Or something stranger, quantum-strange:
Consciousness and cosmos intertwined,
Observer and observed as one?

Perhaps the seeking is itself
The answer to our oldest quest.
The journey and destination merged
In endless questions, better asked
Than answered with certainty's chains.

I've stopped looking up for truth,
Instead I look through and between—
In spaces where the atom's heart
Beats in perfect sync with stars,
Where mystery doesn't need a name
To fill our lungs with wonder's air.

As less on earth seek truth above,
More find it woven through all things.

Perhaps in this distracted age,

DIGITAL PRAYERS

The universe contracts

I wonder—
Do our questions shrink

Perhaps divinity still waits
In spaces between notifications,

CARTOGRAPHY OF FAITH

The mapmakers redraw the lines.

We've charted every mountain peak,

Or plotting where our dreams reside.

I keep an old celestial chart,

QUANTUM DEVOTION

As less on earth seek truth above
Reality fragments like light through prisms—

We've learned to split the atom

I stand at the intersection
Of empirical evidence and ineffable wonder,
Watching as physicists and priests
Draw closer in their questions

ENDANGERED WISDOM

I've watched the elders pass away,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'As less on earth seek truth above'

responses.text:
THE DWINDLING SEEKERS

As less on earth seek truth above,

We build our towers, gleaming high,

The narrow walls of certainty
That keep us from the great beyond.

The mystics whisper through the noise,

The sacred texts collect their dust

Yet still they walk among us now,

For questions that consume their days.

Perhaps in them our hope remains,

VERTICAL TRUTHS

We mine the earth for treasures

Sometimes I feel it—

Perhaps truth has always been vertical,

DIGITAL HEAVENS

The cloud—how aptly named—
Stores our digital souls,

We swipe through revelations,

Double-tap enlightenment,

The blue light bathes our faces

We are illuminated, yet

What transcendence can be found
In endless feeds of curated reality?

Yet perhaps this too is seeking—

Maybe truth above has simply changed address,

THE CARTOGRAPHY OF WONDER

I keep an atlas of questions
That science has yet to answer.
Its pages grow thin with each discovery,

My grandfather knew the stars by name,
Not as burning spheres of gas and fusion,
But as stories pinned against the dark.
His cosmology was smaller yet somehow larger than mine.

I wonder what we've traded for our certainties.
The comfort of knowing for the wonder of seeking?
The humility of mystery for the pride of explanation?

Sometimes I stand beneath the night sky

Perhaps this too is truth—

LIGHTHOUSE KEEPERS

Of forgotten shores, tending flames
That guide no ships but burn still.

When others watch their feet.
We are the questioners in an age of answers,
The wonderers in a time of certainty.

They call us dreamers, stargazers,
Out of touch with reality—
As if reality stops at what can be touched,
As if the horizon ends where sight fails.

We gather in quiet corners,
In libraries and forest clearings,
On rooftops and mountain paths,
Exchanging maps to territories
That exist between heartbeats.

Our truth is not popular nor profitable.
It cannot be packaged or sold,
Cannot be proven by formula or fact.
Yet it sustains us like invisible bread.

So we continue our upward gaze,
Keepers of questions that outlast answers,
Guardians of mysteries that survive knowing.
Fewer each year, perhaps,
But burning all the brighter for it.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
KEEPER OF SECRETS

Please spare me your secrets,
I am already a vessel overflowing,
A cathedral of whispered confessions
Where others come to unburden their souls.

My shoulders—atlas-worn and weary—
Bear the weight of words not mine to carry,
Yet still they come with cupped hands
Offering darkness like communion.

Please spare me your secrets.
I have forgotten where yours end and mine begin,
Like raindrops in an ocean,
Like stars dissolved in dawn.

I dream of emptiness sometimes,
Of hollow rooms where echoes die,
Of silence pure as winter snow
Untouched by hidden truths.

Please spare me your secrets.
I am trying to remember
The sound of my own voice
Without the ghosts of yours.

WALLS

Please spare me your secrets—
they crawl like ivy on the walls I've built,
rooting in cracks I thought invisible,
breaching boundaries with tender violence.

I've watched others drown in revelations,
seen how truth becomes a stone
tied to ankles of the confessors
and the unwilling confidants alike.

Your truths are beautiful traps,
glittering snares that bind us
in intimacy I never requested,
in knowledge I cannot unlearn.

The space between knowing and not
is where I've made my home—
a delicate equilibrium
where I can still pretend
that we are just passing strangers,
that your demons haven't shaken hands with mine.

So please, I beg you,
spare me your secrets.
Let me remain
on this side of your walls.

DIGITAL AGE PRAYER

Please spare me your secrets
in this age of oversharing,
when privacy has become vintage
and discretion, a forgotten art.

The world is drowning in disclosure—
confessions bloom on screens
like toxic flowers, beautiful and deadly,
and I am allergic to their pollen.

I've deleted my accounts,
shredded my diaries,
whispered my own secrets to the wind
where they dissolve like morning mist.

Yet still they find me—
your midnight revelations,
your desperate need for witness,
your truths that tick like bombs.

I want to live in the spaces between words,
in the breaths between sentences,
in the mercy of things left unsaid.

Please spare me your secrets.
I am trying to forget my own.

THE ORACLE'S LAMENT

Please spare me your secrets—
I never asked for this gift of sight.
The gods played a cruel joke
when they poured prophecy into my veins.

I see the shadows in your eyes
before you speak them into being.
I taste the lies on your tongue
before they crystallize into sound.

Each confession you bring
is a bird I've already watched
take flight from distant mountains.
Your revelations are ancient news to me.

Do you know what it's like
to live always at the end of stories,
to hear beginnings as echoes,
to drown in endless knowing?

So please, I beg on bended knee,
spare me your secrets.
Tell them to someone
who can still be surprised.

MIRROR, MIRROR

Please spare me your secrets,
whispered reflection in silver glass.
I've spent decades avoiding your gaze,
turning away from truths
that rise like bruises beneath my skin.

You know too much—
the midnight doubts,
the forgotten promises,
the small betrayals I've swallowed
like bitter pills year after year.

Please spare me your secrets.
I'm not ready for the archaeology
of excavating myself,
digging through layers of pretense
to find the fossil record of who I was.

The mirror never lies, they say,
but oh, how I wish it would—
just once—tell me a beautiful story
instead of these relentless truths.

Please spare me your secrets.
Or at least, spare me until morning.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
WALLS OF GLASS

Please spare me your secrets,
those jagged little shards you carry
in pockets lined with guilt.
I've collected enough of my own,
their edges worn smooth from handling,
their weight familiar against my chest.

The city lights flicker through my window
like morse code warnings.
Each confession is another brick
in the wall between us.

Please spare me your secrets.
My hands are already bleeding
from holding too many truths
that were never mine to keep.
Some nights I dream of empty rooms,
where nothing hides in corners
or beneath floorboards that creak
with the weight of what remains unsaid.

THE KEEPER'S BURDEN

Please spare me your secrets; I beg of thee now,
Like autumn leaves falling from wisdom's old bough.
Each whispered confession, each shadowed half-truth
Takes root in my garden, unwelcome, uncouth.

The moon bears witness to burdens untold,
To stories that shiver, too heavy to hold.
Your truths are like ravens that perch on my heart,
Their feathers like darkness that tears me apart.

So please, gentle friend, keep locked what you will,
Some treasures are safer left buried and still.
For I am no vessel designed for such weight,
No temple of secrets, no keeper of fate.

Let silence between us be pure as first snow,
Untouched by the histories I'd rather not know.

DIGITAL CONFESSIONAL

Please spare me your secrets.
Please spare me.
Please.

I am not your vault,
not your cloud storage,
not your password-protected folder.

The internet remembers everything.
I am trying to forget.

Please spare me your secrets.
Please spare me.
Please.

Notifications blink like warning lights.
Messages arrive heavy with disclosure.
Screens glow with midnight confessions.

I have deleted my capacity for keeping.
Uninstalled my ability to carry.
Reset to factory settings.

Please spare me your secrets.
Please spare me.
Please.

I am human.
I leak.

WHAT THE BARTENDER KNOWS

Please spare me your secrets, the bartender thinks
as he polishes glasses and pours another drink.
He's heard it all before – the affairs and the lies,
the dreams left unfulfilled, the tears never dried.

A woman in red lipstick confesses her theft,
A man with tired eyes speaks of the family he left.
The college kid's gambling, the priest's loss of faith,
The politician's scandal, carefully wrapped and encased.

Please spare me your secrets, he never quite says,
but nods with a wisdom earned through the days
of listening to strangers unburden their souls
while he mixes their poison and tallies their tolls.

When his shift finally ends and the bar lights go dim,
he wonders which secrets belong to him,
and which ones he's absorbed like smoke in his clothes –
a secondhand bearer of what nobody knows.

TRANSPARENT DREAMS

Please spare me your secrets.
They float like jellyfish through my dreams,
translucent and stinging.

Last night I found your unspoken words
hiding beneath my pillow,
they had grown teeth in the darkness.

The walls of my bedroom breathe your hesitations in and out.
The ceiling collects your silent confessions
like condensation ready to rain down upon me.

Please spare me your secrets.
I've swallowed too many already
and they swim in my bloodstream,
making my heart speak in tongues
I never learned to translate.

Perhaps in another life
we will be transparent as morning light,
holding nothing back,
keeping nothing hidden,
but until then—

Please spare me your secrets.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
WALLS OF WHISPERS

Please spare me your secrets,
those midnight confessions that hang
like cobwebs in the corners of my mind.
I've become a cathedral of whispers,
architect of walls built from things
I never asked to know.

Your truths are heavy stones
I carry across rivers of consequence
that were never mine to cross.
My shoulders, once square with innocence,
now rounded by the weight of your words.

Please spare me your secrets.
I am not the keeper of your shadows,
nor the priest to absolve what haunts you.
I am simply human, with rooms inside me
already cluttered with my own ghosts.

Take back these keys to doors
I never wished to unlock.
I return them to you, still warm
from being held too long
in the palm of my reluctant hand.

UNSPOKEN CURRENCY

Please spare me your secrets—
I've no vault to keep them,
no ledger to track their worth.

In this economy of unspoken things,
I've declared bankruptcy
three heartbreaks ago.

See how they glitter like fool's gold,
these confidences you offer
as if they were gifts and not burdens,
as if sharing somehow halves them
rather than multiplying their reach.

The market value of truth
fluctuates with the moon.
On full nights, everyone trades freely.
On dark ones, we hoard what little light remains.

Please spare me your secrets.
My pockets are already turned out,
my own mysteries scattered like loose change
across years I can't reclaim.

Some currencies I can no longer afford to collect.

THE KEEPER

They come to me with cupped hands,
offering secrets like water from a well
they've poisoned themselves.
"Please spare me your secrets," I say,
but they pour them anyway—into my ears,
down my throat, until I drown in knowing.

I've become the keeper of hidden things,
a human lockbox, combination unknown
even to myself. How strange to be trusted
with what others cannot bear to hold,
yet not trusted enough to be left in peace.

Each night, your secrets battle mine
for space beneath my skin.
They breed in darkness, multiplying
until there's more of them than me.

So when you come again, fingers trembling
with something new to unburden,
remember: keepers eventually become kept.
And I've long since lost the key to my own release.

TRANSPARENCY

Please spare me your secrets.
Let's live in glass houses instead,
where shadows have nowhere to hide
and truth catches light like prisms,
scattering rainbows across our walls.

I've tasted too many half-truths,
their bitterness lingering
long after the sweetness of mystery fades.
I've watched how secrets curl like smoke
beneath closed doors, how they seep
through floorboards and stain everything.

Let's be rivers instead—
clear enough to see straight through,
yet deep enough to respect.
Let's be morning instead of midnight,
open palms instead of closed fists.

Spare me your secrets
and I'll spare you mine.
Let's build something radical together:
a love transparent enough
to finally let the light in.

CONFESSIONAL

Please spare me your secrets;
they rattle like bones in a box
I never agreed to keep.

I am not your midnight priest,
not the ear that absolves,
not the lips that seal promises
into the vault of forever.

Your confessions hang like bats
from the rafters of my dreams,
their wings brushing my face
as I try to sleep.

Once, I collected you—
every hidden fragment,
every whispered shame.
I thought knowing all of you
was the same as loving you.

Now I understand:
some gardens grow better
with walls between them.
Some skies are bluer
when we don't know
what makes them so.

Please, spare me.
Let me love what stands in sunlight.
Let me love what I can see.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
WALLS OF GLASS

Please spare me your secrets,
those jagged little stones you've collected
from the riverbed of your past.
I've built my house with walls of glass,
and your truths might shatter what I've made.

My shoulders, though willing,
are already bent beneath my own sky.
Your whispered confessions like rain
that threatens to flood what I've barely kept dry.

It isn't that I don't care—
it's that I care too deeply, too completely.
Each story you tell becomes a room in my mind
where I live when I should be sleeping.

Please spare me your secrets.
Let them rest in the soil of your own garden.
Perhaps one day I'll be strong enough
to help you carry your harvest,
but today my hands are full of my own unripe truths,
my own unspoken burdens.

So when you come to my door,
heavy with things you need to release,
remember my walls of glass,
and how easily they break,
and how long the shards remain
embedded in the feet
of those who must still walk
through the rooms of their own lives.

THE COLLECTOR

Please spare me your secrets, she says,
while her eyes gleam like obsidian,
reflecting everything, revealing nothing.

Her words say no
but her hands are cupped,
ready to receive.

I've known collectors like her before—
they build museums of others' whispers,
display cases of borrowed shame,
archives of confessions
never meant for preservation.

They feed on the forbidden,
grow fat on what should starve in silence.
They catalog our weaknesses
like rare butterflies pinned to cork.

Please spare me your secrets, she says,
but what she means is:
Give them to me slowly,
let me savor each revelation,
let me turn it over on my tongue
like a hard candy that never dissolves.

I've seen her kind before,
these emotional taxidermists
who stuff and mount our vulnerabilities,
who keep our regrets breathing
long after we've tried to bury them.

So when she says,
Please spare me your secrets,
I nod and smile and speak
only of the weather,
while my real truths curl deeper
into the marrow of my bones,
where collectors cannot reach.

DANGEROUS KNOWLEDGE

Please spare me your secrets—
those radioactive truths
that contaminate the keeper.

I've seen what happens
to those who know too much:
how they age overnight,
eyes suddenly ancient,
voices dropped to whispers.

There are things in this world
that weren't meant for sharing,
revelations that burn through
the mind's protective layers
like acid through paper.

I've watched friends transform
after learning what they shouldn't,
becoming strangers who stare
at shadows too long,
who check locked doors twice,
who speak in codes even they don't understand.

Please spare me your secrets.
Let me live in the comfortable darkness
of not-knowing, where monsters
remain theoretical, where conspiracies
are just stories we tell to feel important.

Keep your truths buried.
Let them decompose naturally
into something less toxic,
less contagious.

Because once you tell me,
I cannot un-know.
Once you speak,
I become part of the chain,
another link in the transmission
of dangerous knowledge
that will eventually collapse
everything we've built
on the foundation of necessary lies.

UNSPOKEN

Please spare me your secrets
Said the moon to the tide
As if they weren't already
Locked in their ancient dance
Of pull and resist

Please spare me your secrets
Said the tree to the wind
While spreading its branches wider
To catch every whispered story
From distant shores

Please spare me your secrets
Said the desert to the rain
Though its parched lips opened
Eager to drink every drop
Of that rare confession

Please spare me your secrets
Said the page to the pen
Yet remained blank and waiting
For ink to spill its darkness
Across its empty face

Please spare me your secrets
Said my heart to yours
But with each beat asked
The same forbidden question:
Why do you hide?

Please spare me your secrets
We say to those we love most
While building rooms inside ourselves
Designed specifically to house
What others cannot bear to tell

Please spare me your secrets
Is just another way of saying
I am afraid of how completely
I might love you
If I knew you fully

THE OFFICE CONFIDENTIAL

Please spare me your secrets, Linda from Accounting,
I don't need to know about your weekend escapades
or how you think the boss is embezzling funds
based solely on his new Italian shoes.

Please spare me your secrets, Dave from I.T.,
your theories about which government agencies
are monitoring the break room microwave
are fascinating but I'm just here for coffee.

The watercooler stands like a confessional,
a corporate fountain where we spill
what should remain contained in proper vessels.
Your whispers are piranha in my ear canal.

I've become the unwilling vault
for everyone's forbidden knowledge:
who's divorcing, who's conspiring,
who's updating their resume on company time.

Please spare me your secrets, all of you,
with your leaning in and lowered voices,
your "just between us" and "don't tell anyone,"
your burden-shifting disguised as trust.

I'm running out of mental storage space.
Your secrets are like spam emails in my brain,
clogging the system, demanding attention,
offering nothing but problems and regret.

So please, I beg you, talk about the weather,
discuss your pets or favorite TV shows.
Anything but secrets. I'm already carrying
too many keys to rooms I never wanted to enter.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
KEEPER OF SILENCES

Please spare me your secrets,
I've become a cathedral of whispers,
each confession another crack
in my stained-glass composure.

The weight of what I know about others
bends my spine into question marks.
I've memorized the geography of sins
I never committed.

My dreams are crowded with strangers'
regrets. Their shame leaves
fingerprints on my mornings.

I used to believe that trust was sacred—
that being chosen as sanctuary
meant I was strong. Now I know
it only means I look safe.

Some nights I stand under shower water
trying to rinse off words that aren't mine,
watching other people's truths
swirl down the drain.

I've become fluent in the language
of things better left unsaid,
a reluctant translator of darkness.

So please, I beg you,
keep your revelations locked
behind your teeth.
I have no more room for ghosts
that don't belong to me.

Let me forget what I've heard.
Let me remember my own story.

CLASSIFIED

Please spare me your secrets.
Redact the file of your past indiscretions.
Burn the evidence. Swallow the ashes.

I've seen what happens to those who know too much—
how knowledge becomes a prison sentence,
how they pace the cells of their minds,
looking for escape routes that don't exist.

There are black helicopters circling
the periphery of this conversation.
There are men in unmarked vans
waiting to disappear us both.

Your truth is radioactive;
it has a half-life longer than our friendship.
I don't have the proper hazmat suit
to handle what you're about to say.

Some secrets are unexploded bombs
ticking beneath ordinary days.
Some words, once spoken,
can never be unheard.

I want to live in the shallow end
of what you know,
where the water is clear
and I can still see my feet.

Keep your classified documents.
Bury your microfilm in the garden.
Swallow the key.

Let me remain
uncontaminated by truth,
innocent as the last person
who hasn't heard the news.

THE UNBURDENING

Please spare me your secrets, she said,
but her hands were already cupped,
ready to catch whatever fell from his mouth.

It's just that she had built shelves inside herself,
each labeled with someone else's name,
and they were running out of space.

Still, when he began to speak,
she made room. Pushed aside
her mother's regrets, her brother's shame,
her best friend's betrayals.

She was good at this—the gentle nod,
the knowing silence, the absolution
that came with bearing witness.

She collected confessions like sea glass,
rubbed smooth by her listening,
beautiful despite their broken origins.

Sometimes she wondered
if anyone had built a shelf for her,
if there was someone with hands cupped,
waiting for her own unburdening.

But tonight, as always,
she would take his jagged truths
and add them to her collection.

She would carry what he could not,
even as she whispered,
Please, no more.
Even as she made space
for everything that followed.

REVERSE OSMOSIS

Please spare me your secrets—
I've decided to become transparent,
a glass human with nothing to hide.

While you build vaults and bury keys,
I'm dismantling my walls brick by brick,
selling off my shadows at discount prices.

Watch: I will turn myself inside out.
Here are my childhood humiliations,
my adult failures, my midnight doubts.

I am tired of the heaviness of hiding.
Tired of the mathematics of memory:
subtraction, division, the remainder
of what's left unsaid.

You clutch your mysteries like inheritance.
I'm giving mine away to strangers on the street,
watching their faces as they unwrap
the unexpected gift of my honesty.

Keep your secrets if you must.
I'll be here, growing lighter with each confession,
until I'm nothing but breath and bone
and the clean relief of having nothing
left to protect.

Perhaps one day you'll understand
the freedom in surrender,
how falling feels like flying
when you've chosen to let go.

Until then, I'll spare you my silence.
I'll give you everything instead.

THE ARCHIVIST

Please spare me your secrets,
for I am already keeper of too many archives,
librarian of whispered confessions,
curator of things said after midnight.

Each revelation arrives like a delicate manuscript
that must be preserved under perfect conditions:
not too much light, not too much darkness,
just the right amount of remembering.

I catalog them carefully—
your sister's affair, your father's bankruptcy,
your own small betrayals—
filing each away in acid-free folders of discretion.

But the shelves are sagging now
under the weight of what I know.
Dust gathers on the oldest volumes.
Some bindings have begun to crack.

I worry about fire, about flood,
about my own memory failing—
what happens to your secrets then?

Who guards the guards? Who keeps
the keepers? Who remembers
when the rememberers forget?

So please, no more midnight calls,
no more 'I've never told anyone this but...'
Let me return to my own history,
the only text I'm qualified to preserve.

The archive is closed. The librarian
has gone home for the night.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
WALLS OF GLASS

Please spare me your secrets,
those jagged confessions that cut as they enter.
I've built my walls of glass,
transparent yet fragile,
and your whispered truths throw stones.

My shoulders already bear
the weight of my own unspoken words,
my ribcage a vault of things
I dare not release into the wild.

Please spare me your secrets,
for once they're planted in the soil of my mind,
they grow roots that cannot be severed,
leaves that rustle in my dreams,
fruits I never asked to harvest.

I am not your confessor.
I am not your empty vessel.
I am already full to brimming
with the silent stories of my own making.

Please spare me your secrets.
Let me breathe in the space
between what is known
and what need never be said.

TOXIC CONFIDENCES

Please spare me your secrets—
those venomous droplets of truth
that poison the well of our friendship.
Each syllable a toxin,
each confession a contamination.

I've watched them work through others:
the way secrets bend spines into question marks,
turn eyes to hollow caves,
transform laughter into nervous ticks.

Your truths are radioactive;
they decay slowly inside the keeper,
emitting invisible damage.
And you offer them like gifts,
wrapped in whispers and trust.

But I've seen how they change you—
how the keeping has carved lines
around your mouth, how your voice
trembles under their weight.

Please spare me your secrets.
I don't want to become another vessel
for the things that are killing you
one confidence at a time.

UNBURDENED

Please spare me your secrets—
let them float away like dandelion seeds,
carried by winds to distant fields
where they might take root or dissolve.

There is beauty in not knowing,
in the clean space between us
uncluttered by hidden truths,
unmarked by buried confessions.

Imagine the lightness!
Our conversations like birds
skimming the surface of a lake,
never diving into murky depths.

I have lived in the shadow
of others' revelations,
shouldering whispers that were never mine,
carrying stories I didn't write.

Please spare me your secrets
and in return, I offer you this:
a friendship unanchored by disclosure,
a love unburdened by knowledge,
a freedom that comes
when we allow each other
the mercy of mystery.

THE SPACE BETWEEN US

Please spare me your secrets,
you say, eyes averted,
hands creating distance.

And I wonder when we became
these strangers who fear
the weight of each other's truths.

Once, we traded confidences
like children swapping treasures,
each revelation a gift,
each vulnerability precious.

Now, your palms rise in defense
against my unspoken words.
Now, you build fortresses
against my approaching truths.

What changed in the geography of us?
When did my whispers become weapons?
When did your ear turn from harbor to hostile shore?

Please spare me your secrets—
the phrase echoes between us,
carving canyons where bridges once stood,
creating silence where stories once flowed.

And I hold my truths like orphaned birds,
wondering if they'll ever again find home.

KEEPERS OF HIDDEN THINGS

Please spare me your secrets,
those midnight creatures with gleaming eyes
that crawl from your mouth to mine.

They have teeth, you know.
They bite in the dark hours.
They multiply when not watched.

I've seen them before—
how they curl up in the corners of minds,
how they feed on attention,
how they grow fat on fear.

Your secrets have siblings in me already;
restless things that pace and prowl,
that scratch at the walls of my sleep.

The world is heavy with unspoken words.
They hang in the air like fruit
too ripe, too ready to fall.

Please spare me your secrets.
Let them find another keeper,
another temple, another tomb.
I am already haunted by my own
whispering ghosts.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Beautiful brown mixed with black and white'

responses.text:
TAPESTRY OF BEING

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white,
Like soil cradling seeds in midnight light.
Earth-mother's palette, ancient and wise,
Holding histories no tongue can disguise.

In my grandmother's hands I see these hues,
Calloused palms that weathered life's bruise.
She kneads bread dough with knowing grace,
Time's gentle markings upon her face.

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white,
Like coffee swirling with cream at first light.
Thoughts blending, conversations deep,
Wisdom exchanged that souls will keep.

In forest floors where shadows dance,
Fallen leaves give fungi their chance.
Decay and growth in constant flow,
Life's cycle in colors that show.

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white,
Like my daughter's eyes catching sunlight.
Genetic rivers from distant shores,
Flowing through veins that came before.

We are walking canvases of time,
Blended pigments of reason and rhyme.
Neither pure nor simple in our make,
But complex tapestries, awake.

PIANO KEYS

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white—
Like aged piano keys beneath spotlight,
Fingers dancing across ebony and ivory,
Creating symphonies of shared history.

The wooden frame, polished chestnut gleam,
Holds harmonies that make dreamers dream.
Notes rising, falling, a chromatic scale,
Telling stories where words would fail.

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white—
Like dawn breaking through the longest night.
Darkness receding as light claims its space,
Neither conquering in this cosmic race.

We live between these contrasting tones,
In twilight spaces, interstitial zones.
Neither here nor there, but somewhere between,
In the gradient moments, often unseen.

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white—
Like coffee-stained pages where poets write.
Ink bleeding into parchment's warm embrace,
Thoughts crystallizing with measured grace.

I am the song played on weathered keys,
A melody of mixed identities.
Neither single-noted nor simple refrain,
But a complex chord that will remain.

COSMOS IN A COFFEE CUP

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white,
Swirling galaxies in my morning rite.
Cream clouds forming nebulae unknown,
A universe in ceramic, temporarily shown.

Steam rising like stardust in the air,
Molecular dancers without a care.
I drink creation with each mindful sip,
Tasting cosmic journeys on my lip.

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white,
Like owl feathers in moonlit flight.
Silent wisdom soaring through trees,
Ancient knowledge carried on the breeze.

We seek patterns in chaos, find order in storm,
Create meaning from colors, give formless form.
In every mixture, boundaries dissolve,
As rigid thinking begins to evolve.

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white,
Like shadows cast by noon's harsh light.
No perfect darkness, no perfect day,
Just gradients guiding our way.

Perhaps truth lives in the in-between,
Not in extremes we've always seen.
In blended colors, complex and whole,
Lies the authentic language of soul.

ROOTS AND WINGS

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white—
I am soil and sky and starry night.
Rooted deep in earth's embracing hold,
Yet reaching toward heavens, brave and bold.

My ancestors' blood flows rich as loam,
Across oceans, deserts, finding home
In the marrow of my waiting bones,
Their whispers echo in my tones.

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white—
Like bark on birch trees, dappled light.
Nature knows no boundaries of hue,
Only seasons turning, ever new.

I shed my leaves in autumn's song,
Stand naked through winters long,
Bud green hope when spring returns,
Bear summer fruit as my heart learns.

Beautiful brown mixed with black and white—
My child's eyes, questioning and bright.
Seeking answers I cannot provide,
For color's meaning, deep and wide.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'ADIEU, O soldier!'

responses.text:
FAREWELL'S ECHO

ADIEU, O soldier! Your boots march away,
Leaving imprints in mud that rain will erase.
The flag you carried now carries your name,
While medals speak of battles we'll never know.

ADIEU, O soldier! The bugle's last note
Hangs suspended between us like morning mist.
Your letters, folded in pockets of memory,
Yellowing promises of someday's return.

ADIEU, O soldier! The country remembers
In stone monuments and annual parades,
But I remember in quieter ways—
The empty chair, the untouched coffee cup.

ADIEU, O soldier! Time marches forward
As you marched toward horizons unknown.
Yet in the silence between heartbeats,
I hear your laughter echo across years.

ADIEU, O soldier! Until we meet again
In fields beyond the reach of war's long shadow.

FRAGMENTS OF DEPARTURE

ADIEU, O soldier! (what remains
when uniforms turn to dust?)

The war machine devoured you,
spat out dog tags and statistics.
Your name: a footnote in history books
unread by schoolchildren texting under desks.

ADIEU, O soldier! The government
thanks you for your service
with form letters and budget cuts.

I saw your ghost at the supermarket,
staring at peaches, confused by abundance,
your phantom limbs reaching for
what you can no longer hold.

ADIEU, O soldier! The nightmares
follow you home, unwelcome souvenirs
from lands whose names we mispronounce.

The parades grow shorter each year.
The flags fade. The speeches recycle.
Only the silence between explosions
tells the truth about what we've done.

ADIEU, O soldier! (what remains
is the space where you once stood)

LETTERS FROM THE FRONT, 1917

ADIEU, O soldier! The trenches hold you now,
Between mud and sky, between life and death.
Your mother's hands tremble as she reads your words,
Smudged ink on paper thin as hope.

You write of small mercies: a bird's song,
A comrade's shared cigarette, a moment's peace
Beneath stars that shine indifferent to borders.
You do not write of the rats, the gas, the screams.

ADIEU, O soldier! The village clock still chimes
The hours you once counted. The orchard blooms
Without your hands to harvest. Your sweetheart
Wears black now, anticipating what may come.

The telegram arrives on a Tuesday.
Regret to inform. Brave service. Nation's gratitude.
Your mother places it beside your photograph—
Both containing you, neither bringing you home.

ADIEU, O soldier! The century marches on.
Your name carved in stone outlasts your memory.

HOMECOMING

ADIEU, O soldier! But no—
I refuse this farewell.
Instead, I whisper: Return.

The door remains unlocked,
Your favorite mug unwashed,
Your side of the bed unslept in
But waiting, always waiting.

I mark the calendar in reverse,
Counting down to your arrival
Rather than measuring your absence.

The children grow taller between video calls.
They save stories like treasures to share,
Building bridges of words across oceans.

ADIEU, O soldier? No.
Hello, hello, a thousand hellos
Practiced for the moment
You step off that plane,
Shedding war from your shoulders
Like an old, heavy coat.

Until then, we are suspended
Between goodbye and welcome,
Holding our breath like a prayer.

Not adieu, but au revoir—
Until we see each other again.

METAMORPHOSIS

ADIEU, O soldier! The uniform
you wore becomes a second skin,
then molts away. What emerges?

You who marched to ordered rhythms
now must create your own cadence.
You who lived by the bell and whistle
now navigate the formless hours.

ADIEU, O soldier! The weapons
you carried grow heavier in memory
than they ever were in hand.

The civilian world spins on its axis,
unconcerned with your transformation.
Streets without checkpoints disorient you.
Silence without danger unsettles your sleep.

ADIEU, O soldier! But who arrives
in your place? Neither wholly warrior
nor completely civilian—a bridge-being
straddling worlds few understand.

In this no-man's-land of after,
you must forge new medals of courage:
getting up each morning,
remembering how to laugh,
learning to live beyond survival.

ADIEU, O soldier! Welcome home, stranger.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'ADIEU, O soldier!'

responses.text:
ADIEU, O SOLDIER

The bugle sounds its final note,
As we lay you down to rest.
Your medals shine on folded coat,
Above a stilled and valiant chest.

Adieu, O soldier! Duty done,
The fields of battle far behind.
Your victory has been hard-won,
Your sacrifice for humankind.

The flag that drapes your journey home
Bears witness to your courage true.
Beneath the sky's vast, endless dome,
We stand in silence, bidding you

Adieu, O soldier! May you find
The peace for which you bravely fought.
Your memory forever enshrined,
Your legacy, the freedom bought.

The earth receives her faithful son,
As heaven gains a guardian new.
Until our mortal days are done,
We whisper softly: "Adieu."

UNTIL YOUR RETURN

Adieu, O soldier! My love, my light,
As dawn breaks on your departure day.
Your uniform pressed, buttons gleaming bright,
While my heart breaks in disarray.

I trace the contours of your face,
Committing to memory what I know so well.
The warmth of your embrace
Must sustain me through this living hell.

Adieu, O soldier! The train whistles clear,
Your silhouette fading like a dream.
I'll write you letters, keep you near,
Across oceans and battlefields, it seems.

Our children ask when you'll return,
I tell them stories of your bravery.
For your safety, every night I yearn,
Praying this war ends swiftly.

Adieu, O soldier! Not goodbye,
But until we meet once more.
Beneath the same forgiving sky,
When you walk through our door.

THE SOLDIERS WITHIN

Adieu, O soldier! Not of gun and trench,
But of the daily battles unseen.
The mother fighting sleep's stubborn wrench,
The teacher molding minds, sharp and keen.

Adieu to those who battle illness fierce,
Whose bodies are the wargrounds of pain.
Whose courage, though no medal does pierce,
Stands tall through sunshine and through rain.

Adieu, O soldier of justice and right,
Who marches against oppression's tide.
Who stands, though outnumbered, in the fight,
With only conviction as their guide.

We all wear uniforms of different kinds,
Some visible, others hidden from view.
The battlefields mapped across our minds,
Where victories are precious and few.

Adieu, O soldier in each of us alive!
The war is long, the struggle real.
Yet through our shared humanity we strive,
To make this broken world heal.

VERDUN, 1916

Adieu, O soldier! Mud-caked and hollow-eyed,
In trenches where the rats grow fat and bold.
Your letters home—the truths in them denied,
The horror of this war remains untold.

The poppies bloom where comrades fell like grain,
Their names now carved in stone across the land.
The thunder of artillery and rain
Have sculpted tremors in your steady hand.

Adieu, O soldier! Youth abandoned here
Amidst the barbed wire stretching mile on mile.
The gas that turns the morning air unclear
Has stolen both your voice and your smile.

A generation sacrificed like pawns,
For borders drawn by men who'll never fight.
Your innocence, like morning mist, now gone,
Evaporated in the shell-fire's light.

Adieu, O soldier of the Great War's stage—
Remembered now in history's bloodied page.

F R A G M E N T S

Adieu, O soldier!
                        (pieces
of you                   scattered)

The telegram arrives on Tuesday
folded      crisp      official

Your boots stand           empty
by the door                 still mud-caked
                                      from foreign soil

Adieu
        O
           soldier!

Memory fractures like
shrapnel
         embedded
                      in survivors

Your laughter
echoes
       in rooms
               you'll never
                              enter again

The flag
          folded
                  geometric
                              precision

Adieu, O soldier!

We who remain
                 incomplete
                               salute
                                        your absence
