                            of you

The desert dust still falls from your duffel
Though you've washed it seven times
Since coming home.

ADIEU, O soldier! The uniform hangs
In the closet corner, straight-backed
Unlike your shoulders now
Which curve around memories
Too heavy to set down.

The neighborhood sounds—
Car doors, children's laughter, fireworks—
All carry echoes of things
You cannot explain to us
Who never heard the real thunder.

ADIEU, O soldier! Yet you remain
Standing guard in your own mind
At checkpoints no one else can see.

Who salutes the warrior
When the battlefield
Has followed him home?

UNTIL YOUR RETURN

ADIEU, O soldier! My trembling hands
Straighten your collar one final time.
The train whistle wails its command,
And steals you away in your prime.

I press lavender sprigs in your letters,
Count days on a calendar's face.
Though distance may bind us in fetters,
My heart knows no physical space.

ADIEU, O soldier! The stars overhead
Will watch you on foreign shores.
I'll whisper your name from our bed,
As night presses hard on our doors.

Your photograph stands on the mantle,
Your absence fills every room.
This waiting—a burden to handle,
This silence—a garden in bloom.

ADIEU, O soldier! But not goodbye,
For goodbye suggests an end.
Instead, I'll keep watch, and I'll try
To send love that distance can't bend.

QUESTIONS FOR THE DEPARTED

ADIEU, O soldier! Did they tell you why
The borders you defended were drawn by wealthy men
Who'd never smell the copper tang of fear,
Or feel their comrade's final breath against their cheek?

ADIEU, O soldier! Your courage stands unquestioned—
A mountain of resolve amid valleys of doubt.
You carried out your duty while politicians argued
About the price of victory in marble hallways.

I honor not the war, but you,
Not the orders, but your heart,
Not the cause, but your sacrifice.

ADIEU, O soldier! The earth receives you now,
Without asking which flag you carried,
Without checking your papers or rank.
In death's democracy, you're finally free
From the artificial lines that men drew
To separate what cannot be divided:
Our common humanity, our shared breath.

Sleep now, beyond the reach of anthems and orders.
Rest, beyond the clash of ideologies.
Peace, at last, O soldier. Peace.

THE FINAL DEPLOYMENT

ADIEU, O soldier! The celestial gates await,
Your spirit mustered for one final flight.
No mortal general commands your fate,
As you trade earthly dark for divine light.

The wounds you carried are memories now,
Transcended as you cross the astral sea.
No need for weapons, helmet, or vow,
In this dimension, you're completely free.

ADIEU, O soldier! The cosmic war is won
Not through destruction but through grace.
Your essence, brighter than any earthly sun,
Finds harmony in this timeless space.

The medals here are stars that gently glow,
The uniform, a robe of peaceful light.
The battles fought are seeds of love that grow
Across the universe's endless night.

ADIEU, O soldier! Your soul stands tall,
Reporting for eternity's long watch.
Answering the divine commander's call,
As heaven's gates silently unlatch.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'ADIEU, O soldier!'

responses.text:
FAREWELL MARCH

ADIEU, O soldier! Your boots leave imprints
in the soft earth that will outlast
the memory of your name.

The bugle calls you forward
into that dark mist where glory
and oblivion share the same bed.

I press wildflowers between pages
of letters you sent—pressed like memories
between the leaves of my mind.

ADIEU, O soldier! The flag you carried
now carries you, draped in colors
that bleed into one another like watercolors in rain.

Your medals tell stories your lips never could,
shining with the light of distant stars
that died long before we saw their glow.

I trace your photograph with weathered fingers,
wondering if the boy who left
recognized the man who never returned.

ADIEU, O soldier! Time marches on
with the precision you once displayed,
leaving us all behind eventually.

In the quiet moments between heartbeats,
I hear your laughter echo
across the chasm of all our unfinished conversations.

THE LAST SALUTE

ADIEU, O soldier! Not with a whisper
but with thunder rolling across marble fields
where white stones stand at attention.

You traded youth for duty,
heartbeats for honor,
futures for a flag.

Who were you before the uniform
claimed your civilian skin?
Before you learned to sleep standing,
to eat sorrow, to drink fear?

ADIEU, O soldier! The nation bows its head
while forgetting your name by morning.
Monuments rise where bodies fall;
speeches fill the silence of the dead.

I saw you once—before the medals,
before the posthumous praise—
laugh until tears came,
holding your daughter to the sky.

The war that claimed you
continues in dreams,
in startled awakenings,
in empty chairs at tables.

ADIEU, O soldier! History will record
the battle but not your birthday,
the victory but not your voice,
the date of death but not how you danced.

DIGITAL DISCHARGE

ADIEU, O soldier! Your pixelated face
flickers across my screen—a virtual farewell
from some desert outpost where the sun
bleaches bones and ambitions alike.

We fight our wars remotely now,
drones humming elegies above foreign soil,
while satellites track the migration
of refugees and classified intel.

Your combat boots have trodden
across my news feed for years,
between celebrity scandals and political memes,
your sacrifice reduced to scrollable content.

ADIEU, O soldier! I confess I've grown numb
to your perpetual departures, your endless returns,
your flag-draped homecomings that punctuate
my timeline like commercial breaks.

Yet tonight, as your glitching image salutes
from a hemisphere away, I pause my mindless scrolling.
For one sacred moment, I truly see you—
not as symbol or statistic or strategic asset,

but as someone's child, someone's love,
someone's entire universe,
compressed into bandwidth and beamed
across oceans of indifference.

THE INNER BATTALION

ADIEU, O soldier! I release you from your post
within my ribcage, where you've stood guard
for decades against invasions of vulnerability,
against the insurgency of feeling too deeply.

You served me well, stone-faced sentinel,
building barricades around my heart,
firing warning shots at approaching intimacy,
interrogating every emotion for hidden threats.

I decorated you with medals of isolation,
promoted you after every successful retreat,
celebrated your tactical suppression
of tears that threatened national security.

ADIEU, O soldier! Your war is finished now.
I sign your honorable discharge with trembling hands
that remember how to reach for connection.
I decommission your weapons of self-protection.

The territory you defended so fiercely
needs to feel the rain of authentic expression,
the sunlight of unguarded laughter,
the soft invasion of compassion.

Rest now, faithful warrior of my wounded years.
I fold your uniform with gratitude and grief,
knowing we both survived a war
that no one else could see.

QUANTUM WARRIOR

ADIEU, O soldier! Across all possible worlds,
you march into different fates—
in one universe, returning with stories
in another, becoming one.

The multiverse branches with each bullet fired,
each order followed or questioned,
each letter sent home or left unwritten
in your pack when they found you.

Physics tells us energy never dies—
so where does courage go when bodies fall?
Does it disperse like light through a prism,
coloring the actions of those who remain?

ADIEU, O soldier! In this particular reality,
I stand at this particular grave,
wondering about the parallel dimensions
where we grow old together.

Schrödinger would say you exist
in superposition—both gone and eternal,
both forgotten and remembered,
both dust and dancing.

The mathematics of loss defy calculation.
Time's arrow moves in one direction,
yet memory pulls against its flight,
creating a quantum entanglement

where you are forever both
departing and arriving home.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'ADIEU, O soldier!'

responses.text:
ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

Your boots leave imprints in foreign sand,
Flags and medals cannot measure
The weight you carried in your hands.
Your country called; you answered true,
While we who stay behind make do
With photographs and memories
Of who you were before the war.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!
The bugle plays its mournful tune,
As shadows lengthen 'cross the field.
You march away too soon, too soon.
The letters home grow sparse with time,
Your words like ghosts between the lines.

We stand and wave until our arms
Are heavy with the strain of hope.
The poppies bloom in distant fields
Where you now walk alone.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!
May peace find you where cannons roar,
May courage be your shield,
May memory be your homeward star.
When battles end and silence reigns,
Return to us, not just in name,
But whole in spirit, mind, and form.

Until then, we keep vigil here,
Whispering always: ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

Not of flesh and blood,
But of my own making—
The warrior I fashioned
From years of internal battles.

You stood guard at the borders of my vulnerability,
Rigid, unyielding, necessary.
Your armor—my defenses.
Your weapons—my sharp words and distance.
Your vigilance—my sleepless nights.

How faithfully you've served,
Taking blows meant for my tender heart,
Fighting enemies both real and imagined.
You've grown weary in your constant watch.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

I release you from duty,
Lay down your heavy shield.
The war within has changed its nature;
No longer requiring your particular strength.

I honor your service with this farewell,
Recognizing how you protected me
When I knew no other way to survive.

But now I must learn to live unarmored,
To feel the world without your intervention,
To risk being seen as I truly am.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!
Rest now in the quieter chambers of my history,
As I step forward, vulnerable but whole,
Into a peace you never permitted yourself to know.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

Time has folded your uniform
into museum displays and history books,
the gunpowder scent replaced
by the sterile perfume of preservation.

Your letters home, once urgent messengers,
now yellowed artifacts behind glass—
fingerprints of a ghost
on paper turned brittle with age.

The grandchildren of your enemies
sit beside the grandchildren of your friends,
sharing coffees in rebuilt cities
where bombs once fell like terrible rain.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

The borders you defended
have shifted like restless sleepers,
the cause you bled for
reduced to paragraphs in textbooks.

Yet something of you remains
in the silent pause during anthems,
in the flame that never extinguishes,
in the way we still search for meaning
in sacrifice.

The world spins forward,
forgetful and grateful in equal measure.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!
History may blur your features,
but in that sacred space
between remembrance and letting go,
we carry you still—
not as weapon or symbol,
but as human, finally at peace.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

Digital warrior, logging out at dawn,
Fingers cramped from holding virtual lines,
Eyes red-rimmed from battles fought
Across screens that pulse like heartbeats.

You've defended truths in comment sections,
Marched through forums with your facts as shields,
Fought disinformation with citations,
Bleeding time into the endless field.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

The information war has claimed your hours,
Turned your mind to strategic terrain,
Transformed your words to ammunition—
Each argument a hill to take or lose.

How many nights have you sacrificed
To battles that reset by morning?
How many relationships have withered
While you stood guard at democracy's firewall?

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

Log off now. Power down.
The world will spin without your vigilance.
The algorithms march relentlessly onward.

Find again the touch of rain on skin,
The conversation unmediated by screens,
The slow unfurling of moments not spent in combat.

Your service noted, but your life awaits—
A different kind of bravery calls you home.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

The cosmos bids farewell
As your celestial armor catches starlight,
Your campaign across galaxies complete.

What wars you've waged against entropy,
Against the cold indifference of space,
Against the gravitational pull of despair.

You, stardust warrior,
Forged in the same stellar furnace
That birthed suns and moons and possibilities,
Now return to that eternal cycle.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

The universe remembers your brief brilliance—
How you defied the odds of existence,
How consciousness bloomed within you
Like a rare flower on a desolate planet.

Your atoms—once arranged in human form,
Once capable of love and thought and dreams—
Now scatter to continue their ancient journey.

The elements that composed your blood and bone
Will travel on, perhaps to form new stars,
New worlds, new soldiers in the cosmic dance.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

This is not an ending but a transformation.
Not a defeat but a change of mission.
The energy of your being
Surges onward in the quantum field,
Undying, unchanged, eternal.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I told her that her two teams weren't playing'

responses.text:
Game Day Ghosts

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
on the screen that flickered blue across her face.
She nodded, but her eyes remained fixed,
watching phantom players on an empty field.

Her grandfather's team, her father's rivalry—
both jerseys hung in her closet like saints' relics,
patched and faded, still bearing the scent
of peanuts and beer from decades past.

I didn't understand at first how she could
sit there, watching strangers compete
when her heritage wasn't on the line,
when no family honor was at stake.

'It's not about who's playing,' she said,
not turning from the screen, 'it's about
remembering who used to watch.'

And then I saw them—the ghosts beside her,
three generations leaning forward at each play,
arguing calls, celebrating runs, their voices
echoing in her cheers for teams that weren't her own.

Some loyalties outlive the game itself.
Some stadiums exist only in memory.
Some teams play forever in hearts
that refuse to acknowledge the season's end.

The Divided Self

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
those warring factions of her fractured soul
yet still she stood at center field, surveying
the empty stadium, refusing to be whole.

One team wore colors of her past—bright reds
of childhood dreams and family expectations.
The other dressed in future blues, the threads
of who she hoped to be, her aspirations.

They never played each other, these two sides.
Instead, they practiced on divided ground,
each building strength while the other hides,
each waiting for a whistle's starting sound.

'They must compete,' I said, 'for you to choose.'
She smiled at my simplicity, my youth.
'The game,' she said, 'is one I'm meant to lose
no matter which side claims to know the truth.'

I watch her now, coaching both teams with care,
no longer waiting for some final score.
The field has become a place of prayer
where winning means nothing, and being, more.

Perhaps someday I'll learn what she has shown:
Our divided selves need not play to win or lose,
but rather dance together, fully known,
in a game where opposition is a ruse.

Spectator

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
and watched her shoulders fall like stadium lights
after the final buzzer. How strange to witness
someone's anticipation dissolve so completely.

She had prepared: the worn jersey washed,
lucky socks arranged, the remote positioned
just so on the coffee table's edge. A ritual
developed over years of devotion to the game.

What is disappointment but the sudden absence
of expected joy? The blank space where
celebration was supposed to bloom?

I offered alternatives—other games, movies,
a walk beneath evening's gentle surrender.
She shook her head, smiling slightly at my attempt.

'You don't understand,' she said, not unkindly.
'It's not about watching something else.
It's about mourning what I thought would be.'

I sat beside her then, in the quiet living room,
both of us facing the dark television screen
that reflected our still forms like a lake at night.
Sometimes companionship means sharing
the emptiness where hope once lived,
waiting together for the next season to begin.

Fantasy League

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
The unicorns and dragons had been benched
Due to a rainfall of stardust and moonbeams
That made the cosmic court too slick for mythic hooves.

She laughed, tossing her rainbow-colored scarf
Across shoulders that carried invisible wings,
'Of course they're playing! You just can't see
The dimension where the game unfolds.'

And then she took my ordinary hand in hers,
Traced constellations across my skeptic's palm
Until my fingers tingled with impossible light.

Suddenly, I could hear the roar of phoenix fans,
The thunderous applause of mountain giants,
The referee mermaid's bubble-whistle blow.

How had I missed this league of wonder?
This tournament of things that couldn't be?
The scoreboard made of northern lights
The trophy carved from philosopher's stone?

'Next time,' she whispered, 'bring your imagination
Instead of your facts. The best games
Are played in realms where disbelief
Is the only thing that's ever truly benched.'

Now I cheer for teams that science says don't exist
And find that victory is sweeter when impossible.

Overtime

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
on the day we packed your things in cardboard boxes,
simple words to break the heavy silence
as we dismantled what remained of us.

Your baseball cap still hung beside my scarf,
opposing colors that once caused playful arguments
on Sunday afternoons when we'd divide the couch,
your loyalty to blue, mine steadfast to red.

We'd wage friendly wars with foam fingers pointing,
trading statistics like ammunition,
kissing during commercials to declare brief truces.
Our love, a game with ever-changing rules.

But on that final day, no scoreboard mattered.
No referee could call the fouls we'd committed.
No instant replay could undo our mistakes.

I mentioned the teams to remind you of simpler conflicts,
when our divisions could be healed with nachos and beer,
when competition was something outside ourselves.

You paused, holding a framed photo of us,
both wearing jerseys, both smiling in the stadium light.
'Maybe,' you said, 'that was always our problem.'
'What?' I asked, folding empty space into boxes.
'Thinking we were playing on different teams.'

The clock ran out before I found an answer.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I told her that her two teams weren't playing'

responses.text:
THE SCOREBOARD OF US

I told her that her two teams weren't playing,
watching disappointment shadow her face,
the way clouds drift across stadium lights.
She'd painted her cheeks in rival colors,
ready for a Sunday of divided loyalty.

What do you do with prepared joy
when the game is canceled?

We sat on her couch anyway,
television dark as a rain delay,
while she told me about childhood bleachers,
fathers and daughters and foam fingers,
the religion of statistics,
the communion of collective gasps.

Sometimes love is knowing
which teams someone carries,
even when they aren't on the field.
Sometimes care is sitting through
the silence between seasons.

Later, we walked to the park
and played our own scrimmage game,
two against none,
our breath fogging like stadium crowds,
our laughter the only commentary needed.

I never told her
that I came for her, not the game—
that I would watch anything
or nothing at all
just to see her cheer.

DIVIDED LOYALTIES

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
against each other tonight, that the war
she'd been waging inside could pause,
if only for these twilight hours.

She carries oceans and deserts within her,
two incompatible landscapes
that have never learned to touch
without tsunami or sandstorm.

One team wears the colors of what she wants;
the other, what she believes she deserves.
They scrimmage daily across her ribcage,
leaving cleat marks on her heart.

I've watched her cheering both sides,
exhausted by her own spectating,
hoarse from screaming contradictory plays,
bruised from switching bleachers mid-game.

Tonight, I fold her hands into mine,
tickets torn and scattered at our feet.
The stadium of her body grows quiet.
No whistles, no roaring crowds.

Just the gentle rhythm of her breathing
as both teams head to locker rooms,
and for once, she doesn't have to choose
which victory would feel more like losing.

SPECTATOR THEORY

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
and watched philosophy bloom in her eyes.
"Perhaps they never were," she said,
"perhaps we're all just watching shadows
on Plato's cave wall, mistaking
movement for meaning, scores for significance."

What game do we think we're attending
when we purchase our lives on installment plans?
Who are we cheering for when we scream
into the marketplace of identity?

Her two teams: reason and desire,
logic and longing, mind and marrow,
the empirical versus the experiential—
all benched today by cosmic rain delay.

She removed her metaphysical jersey,
folded it neatly beside ontological debates,
and stepped barefoot onto the field
where no whistles govern possibility.

"If my teams aren't playing," she whispered,
"then I'm free to leave the stadium entirely."

That evening, we walked beyond scoreboards,
beyond the binary of victory and defeat,
into the unmapped wilderness
where no one keeps statistics.

FANTASY LEAGUE

I told her that her two teams weren't playing,
but she'd already painted half her face blue,
the other half red, her hair a tornado
of foam fingers and miniature pennants.

"Not playing?" she laughed, pointing to her laptop
where digital athletes performed impossible feats,
"They're always playing in here!"
She tapped her temple with statistical glee.

Her fantasy league roster spread across the screen
like battle plans for a war fought in decimal points.
She drafted real players for imaginary teams
to score theoretical points in her parallel sports universe.

I brought nachos as a peace offering
to her competitive ecosystem.
She calculated the caloric advantage
while explaining point spreads to the cat.

Love is strange arithmetic:
How she tracks rushing yards but forgets birthdays,
how she remembers batting averages
but loses her keys in the refrigerator.

I kiss her divided cheeks,
taste face paint and devotion,
and add myself to her roster—
a free agent in her league of extraordinary passion.

THE GAME THAT WASN'T

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
on that rain-soaked Tuesday in November.
The stadium lights remained dark,
no anthems sung, no crowds gathering.

She'd been holding tickets for months,
fingers tracing their edges each night,
as if they were tarot cards predicting
a future where opposing forces might reconcile.

What she never said: these teams
were her parents, separated by years
and grievances, their faces on opposing
sides of her childhood bedroom.

What I never asked: how long she'd been
waiting for a game that would never start,
for rivals to share the same field,
for a scoreboard that could somehow end in tie.

She placed the tickets in a memory box
among other impossible things:
her mother's wedding ring, her father's promises,
a family photo with uncut edges.

Sometimes the most important matches
are the ones that stay unplayed—
the conflicts never resolved,
the reconciliations never attempted,
the love that remains theoretical,
like a season perpetually postponed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I told her that her two teams weren't playing'

responses.text:
The Scoreboard

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
while rain tapped gently on the window pane.
Her shoulders fell, a silent disappointment
like autumn leaves that never rise again.

The tickets clutched between her fingers,
crumpled dreams in red and blue,
she'd planned this day for weeks of waiting,
a ritual her father taught her to pursue.

She placed them on the counter slowly,
smoothed them flat with careful palms,
then smiled the way that broken hearts do
when they're trying hard to carry on.

"Perhaps," she said, "there's something better
than watching others win or lose."
She took my hand and led me outside
where the sky had cleared, revealing truths.

Divided Loyalties

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
Against each other in the fields of her mind.
The warring factions she'd been surveying
Were merely shadows of a different kind.

She'd drawn her lines in shifting sand,
Placing bets on outcomes never meant to be.
Her heart and head on separate stands,
Spectators to a game they couldn't see.

"But I can hear the crowd," she said,
"The roaring chaos of conflicted thought."
I watched her scoreboard flicker red,
Keeping tallies of the battles fought.

Perhaps one day she'll understand
That in this contest of divided soul,
Victory comes not from taking sides
But from erasing all the painted goals.

Game Called Off

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
And watched galaxies collapse behind her eyes.
Time suspended in the living room's half-light,
The universe contracted to a sigh.

She'd been balancing worlds on either shoulder,
Lovers past and present, teetering like stars,
Hoping somehow they might face each other
Across the field of her fractured heart.

What game was this, where everyone must lose?
What victory could she possibly claim
When the players refused to take the field,
When the scoreboard showed only her name?

She folded into herself like origami,
Creases sharp along her spine and doubt.
"Then who," she whispered to the empty air,
"Am I supposed to cheer for now?"

Season Cancelled

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
through static-broken radio waves.
She laughed like thunder breaking distance,
said she knew it all along.

Her faith and fear—those rival captains—
had trained for years inside her chest,
practicing formations in her bloodstream,
running drills beneath her breath.

The stadium of her patience
stands empty now, concession stands
shuttered tight against expected crowds
that purchased tickets to a phantom game.

She turns the dial between her fingers,
searching frequencies for different news.
I watch her mapping constellations
where her teams might someday meet

to play the championship she's dreamed of:
the one where neither side must lose.

Fantasy League

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
this Sunday or the next or ever after.
She'd drafted them from whispers and from wishes,
from promises that broke like hollow laughter.

She'd painted her face in colors never mixed,
half sunrise, half midnight, an impossible blend.
She'd practiced cheering for opposing sides,
believing love could bend where it shouldn't bend.

The statistics she'd collected—
glances, texts, and midnight calls—
all charted on her bedroom wall
like evidence of games that never were.

"But I have tickets," she insisted,
"Reserved seats in the future tense."
I couldn't tell her that the stadium
existed only in her present tense.

So instead we walked through autumn leaves,
the season changing without scorecards.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I told her that her two teams weren't playing'

responses.text:
SCOREBOARD

The bar lights flickered across her face,
reflecting hope that shouldn't have been there.
I told her that her two teams weren't playing,
but she kept watching the screen anyway.

Sometimes we cheer for impossible things—
marriages long dissolved,
dreams abandoned in childhood closets,
faces we'll never see again.

She ordered another drink,
traced the condensation down the glass
like counting years or missed opportunities.
"I know," she said, "but I still wear their colors."

We sat in silence then,
watching games that didn't matter,
scoring points in conversations
we'd never have the courage to start.

DIVIDED LOYALTIES

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
On fields of green or courts of polished wood.
They played instead across her fractured heart,
Where loyalty splits like lightning-splintered trees.

One team: the life she built with careful hands,
The mortgage paid, the children nearly grown.
The other: dreams she folded, paper birds,
Too fragile for the winds of compromise.

She laughs and says I've missed the point entirely—
Her teams are simply Pittsburgh, Boston, names
Embroidered on the caps she collects
Like souvenirs from places never visited.

But in her sleep, I've heard her call the score,
And neither side has won in all these years.

OFFSEASON

I told her that her two teams weren't playing.
She smiled, removed her glasses, set them down
beside the coffee gone cold hours ago.
"I know," she said, "but isn't that the point?"

We've spent decades this way—
watching for signals, waiting for the perfect season,
when what we want and what we have
might finally wear the same uniform.

The children ask why we stay together.
I want to tell them about statistics,
about averages and long games,
about how sometimes the scoreboard lies.

Tonight, we'll sleep with our backs touching,
two countries with a peaceful border,
and tomorrow we'll wake up
ready for another day of not keeping score.

FANTASY LEAGUE

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
and watched her universe collapse like breath.
She'd crafted careful brackets, statistical prayers,
placing bets on outcomes she couldn't control.

Isn't that what we all do?
Dress ourselves in colors of tribes we never joined,
celebrate victories we never earned,
mourn defeats that leave no actual scars?

She tore her ticket stubs to confetti,
danced them across the kitchen table,
and said, "Then we'll have to make our own game."

That night, we invented new rules,
drew boundaries with our fingertips,
and became the only teams that mattered.

SIDELINES

I told her that her two teams weren't playing.
The stadium of her heart emptied slowly.
Vendors packed away unsold hopes.
Janitors swept up discarded expectations.

We've been coaching different games—
mine: careful defense, calculated risks;
hers: all offense, beautiful in its recklessness,
scoring points I couldn't count.

When did we stop being players
and become spectators in our own lives?
When did we start requiring tickets
to access each other's dreams?

Tonight, the field lies empty under stars.
No scoreboard. No referee.
Just open space where anything could happen
if we remembered how to play.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I told her that her two teams weren't playing'

responses.text:
THE GAME BEYOND

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
in the championship she'd waited months to see.
Her face fell like autumn leaves,
disappointment pooling in her eyes.

We sat on the porch swing instead,
watching neighborhood children kick a ball
across unmowed grass, their shouts
carrying through evening air.

"Look," I said, "at their unwritten rules,
their boundless joy in simply moving."

She leaned against my shoulder,
the weight of her sadness slowly lifting
as twilight painted the sky in colors
no stadium lights could replicate.

"Perhaps," she whispered, "we've been watching
the wrong game all along."

I nodded, knowing sometimes
the contests we pin our hopes on
are merely distractions from the true match—
the one between who we are
and who we might become.

That night, we drafted new teams:
patience versus hurry,
presence versus distraction,
love versus fear.

And in this league of moments,
every second played
was a victory.

SIDELINES

I told her that her two teams weren't playing.
She clutched coffee gone cold between palms
that once clapped thunderous at touchdowns,
at three-pointers sinking like perfect truths.

We've spent seasons this way—
rivalries mapped across living room floors,
alliances declared in jersey colors,
Sundays sacred as any church service.

Now, remote untouched, screen dark as January evenings,
she says, "Then what's the point?"
and I recognize the question stretches beyond sports,
beyond brackets and statistics.

We've been spectators too long.
In our own game, we've forgotten to keep score.

So I reach across the couch-field between us,
take her hand like catching something precious,
and suggest we play ourselves—
two hearts, no substitutions,
no time-outs, no sidelines.

She smiles slow as sunrise after overtime,
and we begin again, not as fans
but as players in this tender match
where no one has to lose
and the season never ends.

DOUBLE ALLEGIANCE

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
the truth hung between us like stadium lights
illuminating what we'd both avoided:
the impossibility of divided loyalty.

She'd worn both colors for years,
stitched together identities like patchwork,
chanting different anthems depending on the weather,
belonging everywhere and nowhere at once.

Two cities claimed her childhood,
two sets of heroes signed her memory's walls,
two rhythms of celebration lived in her bones.

But today, the schedule showed blank spaces
where her certainties should be.

"Then who should I cheer for?" she asked,
voice small as a forgotten pennant.

The question wasn't about games or scores.
It was about anchors in shifting waters,
about finding home when maps fail.

I offered no jerseys, no easy answers—
just my hand and the quiet suggestion
that sometimes the bravest victory
is in dropping the flags we carry
and running unburdened across open fields,
claiming nothing but the moment,
belonging only to ourselves.

SCOREBOARD PHILOSOPHY

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
and watched philosophy bloom in her disappointment.

"Like life," she mused, remote dangling forgotten,
"we prepare for contests that never materialize,
we paint our faces in colors of anticipated battle,
only to find the arena empty, the lights dimmed."

She laughed then—unexpected as a perfect game—
and kicked off slippers to dance across hardwood floors,
sudden freedom in the absence of competition.

"Don't you see?" Her voice crescendoed with each spin.
"We're released from choosing sides today,
from calculating odds and nursing rivalries.
We're spectators without a spectacle,
fans without allegiance."

I watched her twirl beneath ceiling fans
that hummed like distant crowds,
her body keeping score of some private joy.

"Perhaps," I ventured, joining her orbit,
"we've been our own opposing teams all along—
expectation versus presence,
desire versus acceptance."

We waltzed between coffee table and couch,
our movements keeping perfect time
to the game no one was playing,
and somehow, impossibly,
we both won.

OVERTIME

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
those words like winter settling in summer,
frost claiming green things too soon.

She'd been betting on both sides of herself for years—
the woman who stayed, the woman who left,
the heart divided like a field at halftime.

In her closet: two scarves, two histories.
On her calendar: two possible futures circled in red.
In her dreams: two versions of happiness
competing for a trophy that couldn't be shared.

The news shouldn't have shattered her.
Yet there she stood, game-day snacks
halfway to the table, whistle of kettle
like a referee calling time.

"Then what now?" she asked,
and I recognized the vertigo of unexpected freedom,
the dizzying space where certainty should be.

"Now," I said, taking the bowl of chips
from her trembling hands,
"you get to create a new league,
one where the rules are yours to write."

She nodded slowly, understanding dawning
like floodlights after darkness—
sometimes the game we're meant to play
only begins when the scheduled match is canceled,
when the scoreboard goes blank
and we're left with nothing but possibility.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I told her that her two teams weren't playing'

responses.text:
# The Scoreboard of Us

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
as we sat beneath stadium lights, dimming.
The disappointment curved her lips downward,
like a missed field goal, wide and unforgiving.

She clutched tickets purchased months before,
when hope was still a currency we traded.
Now schedule changes left us stranded here,
two fans whose anticipation faded.

"Then what's the point?" she asked, not of the game,
but of the hours we'd spent in traffic's crawl,
of rain-soaked shoes and overpriced concessions,
of plans that now meant nothing at all.

I reached for her hand across the armrest,
felt the warmth despite the evening chill.
"We are the teams," I said, "still on the field,
playing a game where both of us can win."

We stayed until the janitors appeared,
talking about everything but sports.
Sometimes the games that matter most of all
aren't measured in innings, quarters, or courts.

I told her that her two teams weren't playing.
She smiled and said, "I know a better game."
And in the empty stadium's echo,
we found a victory we couldn't name.

# Divided Loyalties

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
tonight or any night to come. She laughed,
a hollow sound like distant thunder,
something breaking in the afterglow.

Her two teams: heart and mind,
always in opposition, never meeting
on the same field, under the same moon.
One wearing reason's colors, the other
draped in passion's crimson flags.

She collected loyalties like trading cards,
devotions stacked in careful piles,
teams that could never share a stadium,
fans who would never cheer the same victory.

"If they're not playing," she whispered,
"then what game am I watching?"
The question hung between us
like a ball suspended at its apex,
neither rising nor falling.

I wanted to tell her about the third team,
the one that plays in silence,
the one that knows no opponent but time.
The team that wears her name across its chest
and carries my hope in its pocket.

But instead, I simply held her hand
as we watched the empty field
where her two teams weren't playing,
and something else entirely was winning.

# Spectator Theory

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
and the universe blinked in mild surprise.
She had bet her cosmic inheritance
on a match that existed only in parallel dimensions.

Red versus Blue. Past versus Future.
Memory versus Hope. The eternal derby.

She had painted her face half in each color,
carried conflicting banners to every sunrise,
screamed herself hoarse for opponents
who never knew they were competing.

The scoreboard of her expectations
showed impossible numbers, irrational points,
fractions of victories never quite achieved.

"If they aren't playing," she asked,
"then what have I been watching all these years?"

The question folded space-time into origami birds.
They flew from her lips and nested in my silence.

Perhaps there never were two teams.
Perhaps the field itself was an illusion,
the boundary lines drawn in disappearing ink.

I told her that her two teams weren't playing.
And in that moment of unscheduled freedom,
she removed her team colors, stood naked in truth,
and invented a new game altogether—
one where winning was just another word for living.

# Box Scores

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
on a Tuesday in November, rain
tapping morse code against the window pane.
Her coffee cooled, untouched, as headlines
blurred beneath her fingertips.

She collected disappointments
like baseball cards, statistics
of almost-happenings filed
in shoeboxes beneath our bed.

The Might-Have-Beens versus The Never-Weres,
her favorite rivalry, postponed again.

She wore their colors anyway—
half her sweater blue for childhood dreams,
half red for roads not taken,
a walking scoreboard of private matches.

"It doesn't matter," she said, but folded
the newspaper with too much precision,
creases sharp enough to draw blood.

I watched her add another cancellation
to her collection. Wondered how many games
must be called off before she stops
checking schedules, stops believing
in seasons that never come.

Later, I found her in the backyard,
throwing pitches to shadows,
running bases that existed only in memory,
keeping score in a language only she could read.

I told her that her two teams weren't playing.
She nodded and said, "They always play in me."

# Spectator Sport

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
and watched confusion bloom across her face
like time-lapse flowers on nature documentaries.
"What teams?" she asked, remote in hand,
the television's glow painting her puzzled features.

Oh, how to explain the teams she didn't know she had—
the one that cheers for safety, for the known path,
for shoes that never pinch and trains that run on time;
and its opponent in perpetual derby match,
the wild team with face paint and burning flags,
chanting for revolution before breakfast.

They compete in the stadium of her hesitations,
these unacknowledged rivals, their scores
announced only in the trembling of her fingers
when decisions loom like goalkeepers.

I could see them warming up now
as she contemplated leaving or staying,
as the clock ran down on us.

"There are no teams," she finally said,
"only spectators watching other spectators
watching games that ended years ago."

And in that moment, I understood
I'd been cheering for the wrong sport entirely,
while she had already left the stadium,
had found a new game without winners or losers,
just players, playing for the sake of play.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sharp is the night, but stars with frost alive'

responses.text:
CELESTIAL FROST

Sharp is the night, but stars with frost alive
Pierce through the velvet darkness of my soul.
Each diamond point, a memory that strives
To light the path where shadows take their toll.

The bitter air that fills my lungs with ice
Reminds me I am breathing, I remain.
Though winter's grip demands its sacrifice,
The glittering sky relieves my hidden pain.

How strange that in the coldest hours we find
The clearest view of worlds beyond our own.
Perhaps in emptiness, the searching mind
Sees truth that warmer evenings have not shown.

I stand beneath the cosmos, small yet strong—
In frozen silence, hear the starlight's song.

WINTER VIGIL

Sharp is the night, but stars with frost alive
sparkle like broken glass across black water.
I've waited here where shadows thrive,
my breath—ghost clouds—rising higher, falter.

The moon cuts teeth on mountain ridge.
Wolves sing to emptiness. I answer back
with silence. My fingers, blue beneath this bridge
of light years, constellations, cosmic track.

What keeps me standing in this biting cold?
Some hunger for beauty that burns more fierce
than hearth fires. Some need to behold
the universe unblinking, to be pierced

by ancient light. To feel how small we are.
To taste the frost that coats each distant star.

CRYSTALLINE

Sharp is the night, but stars with frost alive
breathe possibility into frozen lungs.
I've forgotten warmth. These winter months arrive
with promises whispered in forgotten tongues.

My footprints fill with shadow as I walk
across the field where nothing grows but time.
The trees—black skeletons—seem to talk
in creaking voices, speaking in cold rhyme.

I've learned to love this clarity of pain,
the way it strips pretension from my thoughts,
leaves only what is genuine. Again,
I find myself reborn in afterthoughts.

The universe expands in crystal gleam.
I am both less and more than what I seem.

FROST LIGHT

Sharp is the night, but stars with frost alive
illuminate the darkness we all fear.
I've wandered far from home to survive
this hollowness, this absence crystal clear.

The cold has teeth. It gnaws at memory.
It strips the flesh from hope, leaves bones exposed.
Yet in this stark and frozen scenery,
I find a truth that summer has not disclosed.

We are the breathing space between the stars,
the momentary warmth in endless night.
Our lives—brief candles—flicker without scars
against eternity's relentless might.

So let the frost claim everything but this:
The knowing that to exist at all is bliss.

MIDNIGHT CLARITY

Sharp is the night, but stars with frost alive
dance across heaven's obsidian floor.
I stand beneath their gaze, somehow survive
the weight of all I've lost and might lose more.

The cold seeps through my jacket, finds my skin,
transforms my blood to rivers slowed by ice.
Yet something in this freezing has begin
to wake a dormant courage, strange device.

Perhaps we need these moments stripped of warmth
to see beyond our comfortable lies.
In bitter cold, truth shows its naked form—
a beauty harsh enough to harmonize

with all our broken pieces. Frost-rimmed stars
remind us light prevails where shadows are.

WINTER CONSTELLATIONS

CRYSTALLINE COSMOS

MIDNIGHT THAW

Perhaps we're meant to know these bitter nights,
